content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												I gave up WoW (or World of Warcraft) For this game. Why? You only need one character to play every class. The classes build off of eachother to add diversity to your play style as well as to upgade into more role focused jobs. You can craft your own gear, you can make your own food and you can play 90% of the game ALL BY YOURSELF! You don't have to be in a guild or part of a click. The people who play this game are shockingly friendly and supportive. Dungeons are part of a finder in game. The story line is epic and the cinematics are breathtakeing. The opening video almost had me in tears just because I knew what was happening without any words. Square has really outdone themselves with this title and I can't wait to see how they wow me with FFXV!Edit: As per a commented question, The sub options come in 30/90/180 day increments and can be set up as recurring (thanks Pasty858). 180 days is roughly $78.Also, anyone who would like to share in the recruit a friend benefits, message me.SO! Its been a while since I've played. after logging over 200 hours that weren't counted on here, and doing everything short of Savage content, I have to say that I never thought I would play a game that would tug my heart strings so much again. But this game. The most recent MSQ line just keeps the punches coming. It was amazing! If you love FF games, you must give this one at least a one month (or 14day) trial period!

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
9/10 - Would Manderville again.This review was written based on version 3.0Pros:Consistent, large patches about every 3 months.Gorgeous graphics engine. Deep crafting system.Probably the best storytelling in an MMO I've ever seen (but it does take 30+ hour to really get into the meat of it)One of the most friendly gaming communities around.Cross-platform play with the PS3 and PS4, excellent controller support for PC.Possible to play casually and still enjoy/experience the game with hardcore friends.Hildebrand - Game doesn't take itself too seriously and just has fun.Neutral:Game doesn't reinvent the MMO wheel. It is a pretty standard "theme park" MMO. That being said, it is extremely polished and everything in the game is executed very well.Subscription model, I was almost tempted to put this in the Pros column. One of the few games to do this model well in a sea of F2P MMOs.Cons:Tens of hours of monotonous fetch quests sprinkled throughout the game. Usual MMO fare.Long PvP queues, slightly unbalanced. (Not enough people play PvP)Endgame content can be very grindy at times. (Ex: Relic Weapons, and "Run the same 2 dungeons over and over to get currency to buy gear".)Gil sellers - I realize this happens in pretty much every MMO. This didn't make the list because it happens, it is strictly on the list because of advertising chat spam. On an average day you will see a lot of messages (unless you're like me and are so fed up with it you go /away). Expect the spam to be cranked up to 11 whenever a large piece of content is released. I really feel SE could implement better countermeasures with respect to advertising. It does seem worse than in many of it's other AAA MMO competitors. On a side note, I'm told the JP servers are practically gil seller free. I've never tested this myself however. Overall, not a huge con, but an annoyance none the less.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												I've never been an MMO player. Briefly played Tera - liked it but found progression slow - and briefly WoW - disliked the combat, just felt like button mashing. I also played Mabinogi for a short while and really disliked the game's mechanics. One day I felt the urge to play one and I knew a friend was planning to start this so I bought it but neither of us started. 9 days ago a friend of mine was looking for people who wanted to start and I decided that if it was in my steam list I may as well try it out. I am now 95.9 hours in according to steam and I love it. I've just hit level 50 and got my Paladin armour and I'm still looking at all the content coming up. As I speak server is going down to patch even more content into the game. So here's the detailed review:StoryThe story is a good one as far as MMOs go (based on my limited experience). I'd equate it to WoW in some ways as FFXIV builds off of an already established lore but is still extremely easy for new players to get into. I don't want to say much about it but Square Enix really put work into making a good story. It teeters a bit at times, especially around the middle (lv30-40 is a bit slow) but it's very enjoyable if you get into it.ClassesCombat classes are fairly traditional: tank, support, ranged DPS and melee DPS. Still within these wider definitions, each individual class is fairly unique. To add to this you are not restricted to the classes that you pick at the beginning of the game. You will unlock the ability to train any and all classses as you wish which allows for a lot of flexibility. But "Oh, the grind ¬¬" you say. Nope, all classes trained beyond the first receive exp gain bonuses which really speeds up the process. This is alongside the quick levelling options which I'll discuss in a later section. There's more though! All combat classses have a progression called a "Job" which is earned by reaching a certain point in the story, getting a class to lv30 and the corresponding second class to lv15, and then finishing the job quest. It's actually really easy to do and it encourages you to try a different role.All combat classes are unique and don't overlap much at all which is great.As for crafting classes, there's a fair few of them and I have limited experience of them right now but crafting itself isn't just sit there and wait for things to appear. There's an active process and is fairly enjoyable. Just like the combat classes, new skills are unlocked and it becomes a sort of strategic minigame. Quick synthesis for bulk items is available as well so you don't have to do it for each item.Still I can see crafting becoming tedious. repetitive and boring at some point but that's no different from any other mmo. Also, unlike the combat classes, the crafting classes aren't really unique.CombatThe combat system is targetted, which honestly I was sceptical about when first going in as I'm not a big fan of targetted combat but it grows on you. This is mostly to do with how the game feels since you really have to think about movement, positioning, skill orders, skill timing etc. from more or less the beginning of the game. This is a big deal and playing the first 20 or so levels in WoW feels boring and just mashing buttons in a certain order. The 2.5sec global cooldown adds to the strategic element of it too. You have more time to think and decide what move would be appropriate, but you also have a longer window to be punished for choosing the wrong skill. I honestly think this is way more fun and interesting compared to other games with a much smaller global cooldown.Another important point is that this game is very controller friendly. It's on the PS3/PS4 with cross platform support so that would be why. I personally play with a controller and it feels very smooth. I don't feel too overwhelmed with skills and I've unlocked all of them for my job with 3 cross skills in use as well (I have 2 full hotbars but it's very easy to switch between them). It's down to preference in the end but the option is really nice to have.LevellingThere are so many different ways to level it's crazy. Though the main story quest is compulsory, there are loads of side quests available.If you think quests are repetitive you can switch over to doing FATES which are events that spawn that give gil (money) and experience to everyone that completes them based on the level of participation.If that's boring there are many different dungeons to do with solid exp gain on all of them. Duty roullete will give you bonus exp once a day so deffo worth doing that.No? Then you can do levequests which are contracts to do certain things in certain places which you can get by using one of your levequest allowances (which refill regularly). Levequests are available to crafting classes too and are considered the fastest ways to level them.Still not enough? Then Guildhests might be for you. These are very similar to levequests but you're put into a duty (instance) with a party and asked to do it as a group. There's a daily bonus on guildhest roullete as well so that's good.Also, the first time you do a certain dungeon, levequest or guildhest you'll be granted bonus exp which is always a definite plus.Still too slow? Not enough content? Too repetitive? Well if you're that hard to please then I guess I should tell you that there are these things called logs which grant bonus exp for doing certain things. A hunting log will ask you to kill x number of y, while a crafting log will give you the list of everything you can craft. The king of all these is the challenge log which refreshes weekly and gives you a lot of exp for completing tasks like "complete 3 dungeons" or "complete 5 levequests".Honestly there are so many different ways to level that players can pick something that suits them and though some can get repetitive they're fun for the most part.EndgameYou only need to google the game to see the amount of post lv50 content. The game's been out for about a year and there are things constantly being added. The first expansion is coming out soon so keep an eye out for that. Most people will tell you that lv50 is just the beginning, and they're probably right. I'm only just getting into the endgame and I look forward to everything coming up.PriceWell. This is the one major downside I see to the game. It's very expensive. Though nothing new for an mmo, it is a pretty heavy financial commitment compared to most other steam games out there. Especially considering you can get Tera, Mabinogi, and loads of other mmos for free now. You can buy gametime online from other sellers for a bit cheaper but it's still expensive. I suggest playing the trial to give you a better understanding of whether you'll enjoy it. I highly suggest it and will be playing it, but I can appreciate that a few years ago I could never afford to play a game like this.ConclusionI honestly think this is the first mmo to seriously impress me with its ability to keep you interested. It doesn't overwhelm you, nor does it leave you with nothing to do. Bosses are often really cool and have interesting mechanics, even from an early point in the game. I really do feel that besides the price this game is practically perfect. It's a great game - buy it if you can.

Posted: July 6, 2015
												I was a WoW player. I played every expansion, I did HC/Mythic raiding, I spent thousands of hours playing it. If I could go back and get this on launch day instead, I would do it in a heart beat.If you are an MMO players, this  is hands down the best MMO on the market.  I've played every major MMO since Ultima Online back in the 90s. FFXIV has every element you could want in an MMO and executes them extremely well.The class system, all classes being available on a single character, is amazing. No alts, not that you can't have them, you just don't need them.The story is captivating, you actually want to read the quests and see what happens rather than just click through to get the objectives.Speak of quests, there are a ton, even without the myriad of side quests, and only completeing the main story, you can reach level cap on a class. Then roll in dungeons, raids, leves, hunting logs, challenge log, etc etc etc there is never a shortage of things to do, and they have made all of them entertaining.If you like MMOs even a little bit, stop reading and click the buy button. Really, stop.Why are you still reading. Stop it! Go play FFXIV, seriously.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV, the original one, was a mess. The servers were terrible, payments were unfair and confusing, and the game just made it so difficult for you to enjoy. Square Enix realised, "holy hell, this is bad" and revamped the game, leading to the release of A Realm Reborn. And boy did they do good.A Realm Reborn is not only a more polished FF XIV, it is a new game. It offers so much more than the original. Better service, better gameplay, more engrossing quests, everything an MMO can offer is in this game. A Realm Reborn is by far the best Final Fantasy of the last console generation, and it is perhaps the best FF I have ever played. It stays true to it's roots, but still manages to not be a total copy cat of previous FF games. It borrows alot from the orginal series, when Final Fantasy was at it's best, but adds a sense of freshness so that FF new-comers could pick up the game and play it as their first FF and still have a wonderful experience.Detail is where this game excells. The amount of effort into making this as refined as possible is staggering. You could honestly sit at the character creation screen for an hour, picking the tiniest things about your hero. The environments are fantastic, and it's hard to believe that an MMO looks this good. As well as being the best Final Fantasy in years, it is also groundbreaking in the MMO genre. It offers so much to the genre as a whole, it has made a name for it's self as one of the greatest MMOs in recent years. It is addicting. It is enchanting. It is simply bliss.Square Enix have really made me regain my faith in them, and I hope that they let future Final Fantasies learn from A Realm Reborn. I cannot wait until more content is added into the game, and clock in a few more hours. Get yourself this game now, even just for the free trial, it's worth it. Even if you're a hardcore FF fan, or a newcomer looking for a game to start with. This is the one.+ Essentially has it all. Near enough limitless gameplay hours+ Environments look stunning, attention to detail is incredible+ Smooth gameplay, easy to learn mechanics+ Makes great homage to previous Final Fantasy games- A lot of fetch quests- Occasional bug here and there10/10. This is a fantastic game. Get it. Now.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												TL;DR A fantastic, beautiful, well thought out MMO, with amazing polish, a great community and a bright future! - TL;DR Bullet Points -PROS:+ Great and friendly community+ Good looking and well optimised, with extensive graphical options+ No need for multiple characters, one character can play ANY of the in game classes, and switch at will+ Gorgeous world with deep lore+ In depth crafting system with great reward + Huge main story, which feels like a true Final Fantasy storyCONS:- Loading screens in the world, due to PS3 client limitations (worlds are shared)- Sometimes overwhelming UI - Possible overwhelming number of classes on one character, can be difficult to keep track and keep focus- Monthly fee, which may put some people off- Big time investment required to get to enjoy everything in the game (as with any MMO) - The long written part! -Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is the completely reworked and almost entirely remade version of Square Enix's latest MMO. Initially it came out, just as Final Fantasy XIV, on the 22nd of September 2010. Unfortunately, it was absolutely terrible, and is still regarded as one of the worst MMO's in recent years, if not ever. The UI was particularly bad, but the problems were pretty much onmipresent. Graphcis were gorgeous but ridiculously unoptimised, bad gameplay mechanics, etc. However! This is NOT that game! I can't stress this enough!In December 2010, Naoki Yoshida was brought in as the new Director and producer, to try and make the game better. While some of these changes did start to make the game more playable, Square Enix, feeling (rightly so, some would say) very ashamed about this initial release (which I will call 1.0 from now on), and also worried about the damage it would do to the Final Fantasy brand, deciced to close down this game and completely rebuild it from the ground up. The servers for 1.0 closed on November the 11th 2012. The rerelease, called A Realm Reborn (the current game!), launched on August 27th 2013, with a PS3 version coming out on the same day. With the transition to the new game, Square implemented lots of cool in game lore explanations for the upcoming dramatic changes, and it is now a part of the game's story (which I think is really cool).ARR is a fantastic MMO in nearly every aspect. It does, of course, have it's problems, but I have yet to find an MMO which doesn't (not even WoW). I have been playing MMO's since Everquest, and would say ARR is now my favourite of them all, from WoW to EQ to SWTOR to EVE, etc. I feel they have gotten the formula just right.For the purchase on Steam you get the game itself, along with a month of playtime, so I would definitely recommend this if you think it might be for you (there is also a trial on the Square Enix website, but this would mean you don't have to reinstall if youstick with it!). In terms of gameplay, it follows what I think would be fairly described as a rough following of the Western style MMO formula, with some key differences: - Classes are not "one-per-character". On your character you can switch between and unlock every single combat, gathering and crafting class within the game, and even use some of the skills you have unlocked cross-class. It's actively encouraged to do this, and having more than one character is not really of any use, unless you just wish to have characters of different races, or something like that.- Great matchmaking system for instanced content, all instanced content can be tackled using player made groups, or with the ingame matchmaking. It has (for me at least) always been efficient and works well to build groups for all content that needs it.- Levelling feels reasonably varied. There are lots of different ways to level, from simple mob grinding (not recommended!), Main Story Quests, side quests, Levequests (repeatable minor tasks), dungeons, exploring, FATE's (random area specific objectives), etc. If you start to feel tired of levelling your "main" class, you can switch and level some of your crafting classes, or a different combat one, etc.- Storyline makes the game feel like a true Final Fantasy game, the Main Story Quests (of which there are many) contain the games main story (although there are plenty of side stories within the games guilds, etc), which, without giving any spoilers, is very enjoyable and definitely held my interest far more than anything like this in any MMO's I have seen, with the exception of maybe SWTOR. Definitely feels like a more story oriented game, which I love. I feel your character has a much more grounded place in the game world!- Combat, combat is somewhat similar to WoW in the most basic sense, abilities come on a bar, and are used in whichever way you want to fight enemies, heal allies, etc. The global tick rate (global cooldown) is longer than WoW, so if you are used to WoW, you might find it a bit slow to begin with. The abilites in game feel varied and are unlocked at a steady rate, letting you get slowly used to the class you play until you reach endgame. - UI, the UI is reasonably good. It provides all of the information you need, but is probably the one point I feel needs the most work. Once you get used to it, it's completely fine, but can be a bit confusing to begin with. It can sometimes feel like there are a lot of menus to click through, but the improvement from 1.0 is so huge, and it does do the job, that I feel it can be overlooked a bit. - Game World, the world is beautiful and full of diverse environment. The world is very large, and definitely worth exploring. One issue, is that (mainly at least) because the game is currently supported on PS3 (though this may change in the future), a lot of the world is accessed through loading screens. If you are expecting a WoW-esque free world with no loading screens, you may be dissapointed. To me, it's not a massive deal, but I know for some it could be a problem. The loading screens are not long and I don't feel it detracts much from the overall experience. It is also something that has been mentioned by the devs which could change in the future. For me, the quality of the world is enough to let me look past this problem, but for you it may be different.- Crafting/Gathering, for me, ARR has one of the best crafting systems I have seen in an MMO. Crafting is done with individual classes representing the different professions, for example Armorsmithing, Cooking, Leatherworking, etc. Gathering is done in a similar fashion with regard to classes, Miner, Botanist and Fisher. The crafting system is very satisying, useful to the actual game experience (not just a money sink, or waste of time), and very complex at the higher levels, with apporpriate levels of reward! The crafting and gathering classes can all be acquired, just like the combat classes, making for a character which is very diverse and can (technically, if you have enough time!) do everything in the game without the need for alts.- Updates, the game recieves frequent, and large updates. There have been big chunks of content added on a regular schedule, which I would say, puts other MMO's, especially WoW, to shame. The updates come frequently and add lots of content, making it worth the monthly fee, and meaning you never run out of things to do.Overall I would give this game a 9/10. I think that with a few improvements to the UI and world loading, aswell as minor things like balancing, this could easily be the best MMO that currently exists, and I would heartily recommend it to anyone who enjoys the genre. If you ever decide to play and need a friend, just PM me on Steam and I can help you in game!

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is an MMORPG. The rebooted/revamped version of the atrocious Final Fantasy XIV, and the 100th billionth game in the Final Fantasy franchise. FFXIV:ARR is much like what WoW used to be when WoW was good. They took much of what made WoW great back in vanilla/The Burning Crusade and used it to shape FFXIV:ARR, adding a modern touch on top. After the failure of Final Fantasy XIV, Square Enix got rid of most of the development team and learnt from their mistakes. What they've ended up with is an amazing MMO with tons of content and fine details to keep you playing for months. The game offers a unique class system much like FFXI, where you're free to change your class at any time you wish, by simply changing your weapon to that of the class you wish to equip. There's 9 classes to choose from, with each playing a different role: tanks, healers, and DPS's. Each of these classes later turn into jobs, offering more abilities for you to gain and unlock. There's also 8 crafting classes, and 3 gathering classes available. The game is filled with various dungeons, raids, and trials which are essentially boss fights. Many MMOs lack true end game content, however FFXIV:ARR is mostly focused on end game content. Many consider the game to not start until you reach level 50 (which takes anywhere from a few days to a few weeks, depending on how you play and how often you play). The game offers many dungeons for leveling, and even more for late game. Many of which are harder versions of leveling dungeons. On top of this, there's multiple raids ranging from your traditional raids with many players (24 in this case), or smaller 8 player raids. Finally, for those who love boss fights there's plenty of trials to keep you entertained. These are mostly primal fights with varying levels of difficulty. There's tons of gear in the game each offering unique looks, allowing for huge amounts of customisation. In terms of character customisation, there’s quite a few options for you to choose from. There’s 5 different races, with each offering two sub-races of sorts. For example, your traditional “human” race has both midlanders and highlanders. The game does not offer sliders for things such as eye shape, nose shape, etc., but instead has four different types for you to select, with each sub-race having a different selection. As well as this, there’s plenty of hairstyles for you to choose from, with a wide range of colours to select as well as a highlight colour. The game’s OST is absolutely amazing, and possibly one of the best I’ve ever heard in a game. There’s tons of tracks with unique songs for each field location, dungeon, trial, raid, and everything else.  I highly recommend checking it out, even if you do not purchase the game.  The game is updated every couple of months adding more items, dungeons, primal fights, new music, and much more. So there’s always plenty to do. FFXIV:ARR is subscription based. You can pay $12/month for 1 character per world, with a maximum of 8 characters. Or you can pay $15/month for 8 characters per world, with a maximum of 42 characters. Though with the way classes work, you won’t be needing more than a single character usually, so the limit is hardly an issue. Some people are turned off by subscription fees, however $12/month is a small price to pay for such a great game, which constantly gets more content. The lack of F2P or B2P also prevents P2W aspects, and usually means the community is better in general. Overall, Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn has to be the best MMORPG I’ve ever played. The sheer amount of content has kept me hooked for over 400 hours, and will continue to do so as the months go on. If you’re looking for a great MMORPG to play, and have the money to invest, I could not recommend this more.

number of helpful: 111 of 122 people (91%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												I can usually write full reviews for games on Steam, but after playing 2 years worth and nearly 3000 hours of this game it still manages to stump me. I simply cannot explain how much of an incredible feat of the MMO genre this is - honestly. I've played my fair share of MMOs, free-to-play and buy-to-play, but this tops everything.  I have never felt a game be so deserving of a subscription fee in my life. Not even just for the game, but this has by far the friendliest community I've ever seen, and I'm proud to be a part of it. You want to join the game from no knowledge at all? Go and PM almost anyone and they'll willingly help you understand whatever it is you want to know. Don't know the strats in a fight? Shout "First time here" and someone will either explain or dive right in to let you have that experience yourself (which is always incredibly fun). The community is just an extremely light hearted and fun one to be around - with a brilliant hardcore section for raiders too if thats your thing!Ever created a character and thought "Damn, I want to play a tank but I don't want to play it all the time" ? No worries! As soon as you hit level 10 on your first class, run to another class' guild hall and sign on up! You can literally play every single class and all you need to do is change your weapon to switch it!Getting bored of the dungeons and raids? Leveling an extra class taking its toll? This game has you covered, go to the mother♥♥♥♥ing Gold Saucer and spend your life savings worth of Gil on gambling! Only 1,000,000 MGP for that Fenrir mount! (i still don't have it please end this awful rng curse i have)In all seriousness though, there is so much to do I can't even begin to cover any of it, ask yourself these questions;Do you like Final Fantasy? Are you into playing MMOs? Do you like working to bigger goals and upgrading characters over a long period of time? Do you like events, content patches and daily rewards that are worth coming back for? If you answered yes to any of those, then try it. You get a 2 week long trial of the game, and if you decide its a game you like then you can keep the progress you made on the trial and continue with another 30 days free upon purchase of the game.I can't personally say anything bad about this game, other than it stole my heart and won't ever give it back.10/10 - itsa♥♥♥♥♥♥♥mastapiece

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Overview: Incredibly polished and well endowed MMO. Almost every setting is tweakable and supports controllers as well, you get a game that offers you everything you payed for and witholds none of it.It also uphold the name of Final Fantasy in good faith, probably a lot better than the newer FF games. The combat is a bit repetitive however, you've got a wealth of content to discover and quests that reward you well; dungeons from level 15 and up and lots of end-game content (but be prepared for hardcore type groups for the real end-game content, statics with schedules). Pretty soon there's going to be an expansion and new classes so there's much more to look forward to as the game ages. The developer has done a great job at supporting the game thus far and I've seen no signs of them slowing down.+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+                 Here's my breakdown between the positives and negatives of FFXIV:RR.+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-------(Positive things)-------+ Good writing!+ Lots of content! + The Hildibrand questline is the best questline in any MMO hands down. + You've got lots of customization for your character / your HUD / and homes if you're rich enough.+ Generally a nice community for an MMO except for the occasional try-hard who gets unreasonably upset.------(Negative things)-------- This game is fetch quest hell, if you despise fetch quests more than anything then I do not recommend you play this game.- The journey from level 1 to level 50 isnt that exciting. (this pretty much goes for all MMOs)- RNG will occupy the vast majority of your end game time spent. Repeatedly run the same content over and over and over until you get that pretty blouse you wanted to glamour.- If you want to stick to 1 class for running content, the gameplay will get stale fairly fast, which isnt unique to FF, many MMO titles suffer from this. There's no traits or choice options to customize your fighting or spells, just flat stat increases that don't change the gameplay in any way other than just becoming stronger. (And your strength primarily comes from your gears item-level) You will be at level 50 with typically around 3 abilitys you need to use repeatedly for combat, and then 3 special situation skills to use in.. special situations and 2 super abilities you save for oh♥♥♥♥♥♥moments.This varies between the classes but I played as a White Mage, so basically my job was to repeatedly hit the 2 button to cast cure, and then sometimes use a spell called Esuna to remove conditions from myself or others, and then cast an AOE that made HP regen (which you need to keep refreshing for the party once it wears off). This was not very fun to me, so you have to rely on the game to throw variety in the dungeons or enemies to spice things up. Usually it just boils down to memorizing boss mechanics and hoping nobody screws up. So essentially you're a bot following a strictly scripted fight and if you deviate from that you're most likely going to fail; This might be different for other people, but this is just how I felt after a while of doing end-game content.-------But, feel free to give it a go yourself! There's a free 14 day trial for FFXIV, so don't let my opinions get in the way of a potentially good time when you could test drive it for yourself. As far as MMOs come and whats avaliable at the moment, I still recommend you give FF a try since it's one of the best subscription based MMOs out there right now. But this one just isnt for me. (I Still recommend it for MMO lovers!)

number of helpful: 93 of 100 people (93%) found this review helpful15 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
「 Impossible is a word coined by the weak. 」(Alright, time to give this review an overhaul now that I've officially given this game 1000 hours of my life. Just gonna add in some extra tidbits here and there.)FFXIV has easily become my favorite MMO. Easily. And it's weird, because I just sort of downloaded it like, (shrug) yeah, I'll check it out, why not. But then after a while, I realized, 'Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ I'm having SO much fun.' The thing is, I've never viewed Final Fantasy as an MMO sort of game. It was always the main console games for me (FFVII, FFVIII, FFIX, etc.). So FFXIV, and FFXI for that matter, was never something I even looked at or took interest in. But hey, now I'm a full-fledged passenger aboard the FF MMO hype train.I really don't even know where to start with this review. A part of me just wants to go EVERYTHING IS AWESOME THIS IS AWESOME AND THAT IS AWESOME AND IT'S ALL SPECTACTULAR. A+ review. I don't really think I'll be able to cover everything I want to, but I'm gonna take a shot at (some of) it:Stay awhile and listen (!!)Whenever I think MMO, I think, half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥basic story. And that's fine, because it's all about the gameplay and getting the gear and doing the dungeons and getting your rake so you can go farming. And whenever I think Final Fantasy, I think, five-star story that will leave you with great memories for years and years to come.FFXIV actually has a good story to it. And I got pumped for it when I saw that opening cutscene, a scene that I still watch over and over from time to time. Now, the story isn't out of this world, but I did enjoy it a lot. Everything built up to make the end boss much more satisfying. And there were cutscenes. Tons of cutscenes. So many. Which can be good or bad depending on the person obviously. I appreciated it, and it did immerse me into the story more. Edit: And now that I have gotten much farther in the story and, again, have spent 1000 hours of my life with it, I can say now that I absolutely love the story in this game. I mean, the story was good in 2.X (and got real ♥♥♥♥ing crazy around 2.55), but with Heavensward (3.0), I just sort of realized how much I love these characters, I love the story that's going on, and I care. I HAVE CRIED REAL TEARS MULTIPLE TIMES. I have gotten angry, I have been shocked, I have felt many emotions through the course of this game. Other games I'm like cool, cool, cool, let's get on to the fighting. Here, I will shush the ♥♥♥♥ out of anyone who won't let me finish my cutscene. Like a good mini-movie ayyyyy.Eye Candy (!!)In the manner of my kobold friends, this game is gorgeous, stunning, beautiful! I mean really, I'm not even sure how to phrase how much I appreciate the graphics in this game. I think I was killing this buffalo type creature the other day, and the sun was rising (Yes, there is a weather/day/night cycle system. Yeah, it's awesome.), and you know when the sun is shining in someone's eyes and you can see just how pretty their eye color is? Yeah, well I thought this buffalo looked sweet as ♥♥♥♥ in the sunlight. So that, but transfer it to every single zone and x100 because I can view the zones during night/day/dusk/dawn/etc. Also, the newest zones for the 3.0 expac are gorgeous, except now I can just stare at all the beauty while flying and listening to the banging music and ijustlovethisgame. And I still don't think I expressed how much everything pierces my soul. I can't guys, just. Max settings 4 lyf suck ittttt~~~~C-c-c-combo breaker (!!)Combat to me is great. I have never played a tab-target mmo before, so the entire system was new to me. I came from a somewhat action-combat oriented MMO, but I find myself really enjoying the combat here. However, in the beginning levels, it is a little lackluster. You don't have as many abilities open to you though, so obviously you're gonna be restricted to your basic 1-2 combo over and over (sometimes even less depending on the class). Aside from just talking about combat in itself, there are an array of dungeons and trials to do. 4-man, 8-man, 24-man parties all there. There are roughly around 90 (I'm including all the different difficultly levels plus counting floors/turns as their own) dungeons/trials/raids so far. Some trials have a normal, hard, and extreme version, and some dungeons have a hard version as well (although the hard versions are completely different from the normal version, so it's a whole new dungeon in itself. Nice move SE /proudofyouthx). The mechanics for a lot of these are super fun to me, although a bit daunting when you first start out. Some say it's like memorizing a dance with how crazy some fights get. I dig them, though. A lot. I find myself replaying a lot of the dungeons/trials just because the fight is amazing, not to farm gear or whatnot (finalfightof3.0imlookingatyou)The dungeon/trail/raid private instances aren't just it though. There's still plenty going on in the open world, like FATEs and Hunts. Tons of people party up for those, granted you are in a pretty populated server.  We are Sex Bob-omb (!!)Okay. If you haven't heard already, the music in the game is pretty stellar. Go on any FFXIV boss fight youtube video and people will be raving about how sweet the music is. And it's true. The music, especially for the boss fights, gets you SO pumped (finalfightof3.0lookingatyouagain). It's the kind of music where you hear it as the battle starts and you're just like 'Awww man.♥♥♥♥♥♥s gonna be intense'. But it's not just the boss fights (although those are what get the most attention). Just about anywhere you go has some nice music playing. And I actually notice it (!!). I say this because there's some music that blends in with the atmosphere, like in most movies/games/commercials/etc., which is great (and perfect for most scenarios), but then there's the music that jumps out at you. That just compells you to look it up on the internet later. And that's the kind of music that I dig. And FFXIV has plenty of that. The soundtrack for the Heavensward expansion couldn't come out any faster. I crave it.It's just not my style (!!)So aside from the aforementioned lackluster combat in the beginning of the game, I figured I should put the couple of things that aren't so nice about FFXIV.When you first play FFXIV, you may notice the lack of people talking in the chat. It makes the game feel dead, but it's really not (so far from it). Due to gold spammers (or so I hear), everyone just moved over to linkshells, which is basically custom channels. So join a linkshell and FC (guild), and your chat will be lively as normal. But that can be a turn-off to newcomers. Heavily populated cities (depending on your server) may have people talking in the shout/yell/say chat as normal though. Also, the newest 'lobby' area that came with the 3.0 expac is very lively in shout chat. Mostly because the gold spammers haven't reached us there yet hah hhahHAHAH HA.That brings me to gold spammers. Depending on the server you choose, you may not get that many gold spammers, or you may get a hell of a lot. And they do PM you or spam the chat from time to time. But, again, this can be a turn-off for some players, especially since this is a subscription based MMO.Cutscenes that occur during party events, but I won't get into that here (!!)(Chorus)(Outro)(Fade-out)I still left out a lot of the tidbits that I just absolutely love about the game, but alas, this totally short review will have to suffice. I surprisingly ended up loving this game, and you should check it out if it sounds like something you're even remotely interested in. I love it lots. Square Enix and Final Fantasy have (again) taken my soul hostage and I'm ok with that.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV is in a tight spot. Following the poorly-received Final Fantasy XIII and carrying on the legacy of Final Fantasy XI, it has a lot to live up to.And originally, it failed to live up to this. With 1.0, it had a lot of major issues including XP caps, lack of group activities and general bad design. This was a major problem that could've caused the death of the game.However, Square Enix did something different. Instead of following the generic "Make it Free-to-play" model, they set out on rebuilding the game. Almost completely scrapping the original game and rebuilding it from the ground up, they made a game that can serve as the true XIV that people wanted. This is A Realm Reborn.Following the failure of 1.0 and the implementation of ARR, Square Enix decided to keep the universe of 1.0 semi-canon, with ARR following on. Set 5 years after 1.0, there was a catastrophe that served to bridge the gap between the 1.0 world and the ARR world. With many features such as landmass, NPCs and areas staying almost identical to that in 1.0, the whole storyline is completely a new, almost sequel to XIV, with gameplay vastly improved and expanded to meet those of other modern MMOs.The storyline, although generic, does follow the Final Fantasy formula of an evil Empire ruling over the world with an evil agenda, and you and your companions have to fight against them. With this, it is almost a retelling of Final Fantasy VI, with many story elements shared across the two universes, and this is strengthened in the expanded storyline with locations and characters having similar names.The characters within the game are all pretty unique, although it does have it's own versions of "Biggs", "Wedge" and Cid". Each character in the world feels fleshed out, with most having their own questlines and stories separate from the main storyline. This serves to flesh out the universe and make you feel like you're in an actual world rather than a half-baked MMO.Although the storyline is a major aspect of the game, it does serve mainly to unlock additional content, although this is in no way a bad thing. The storyline quests give a good step on leveling up your first character, guiding you through the leveling process whilst not serving to hand-hold the player. Although it is easy to gain levels through quests, it would not be easy for a character to max out by simply completing quests.Instead, the game has a number of different ways to level up, mostly these are through group events.Firstly, one of the most commonly encountered events are FATEs. There can essentially appear anywhere in the field, outside of towns and other sanctuaries. FATEs have a simple objective, often something such as "Kill all of x enemy", "Kill x boss" or "Collect all of x". Usually they involve beating on enemies until the quota is met, which is pretty satisfying. These give the player additional XP and Gil. Mostly these FATEs are level-limited, so many higher-level players would not be inclined to do older FATEs or do them if they are max level, however this has been changed through late-game content that requires players to return to areas and perform in FATEs, meaning that they are available for everyone and serves to keep old content fresh.Secondly, are Leves. Similar to FATEs but for single player, you are assigned them in each town by a special NPC with a unique tasks such as "Kill x and collect their item" or "Plant an item at x". These are pretty fun to pass the time and have a number of benefits, similar to FATEs.Finally, the most common way of leveling up is through Duty Roulettes. Once a day, the player is given a boosted XP and Gil bonus by performing in the Duty Roulette. By choosing to do this, you are randomly assigned a party for a Duty, which can consist of a dungeon, a Trial (Boss fight) or Guildhest (Similar to FATE and Leves). These are unlocked as you progress through the story, and as it is random you can get assigned to any duty that you have previously unlocked. This means that a maxed player can get assigned to a level 20 dungeon. This ensures that the game is kept fresh and that new players can progress through lower level dungeons without the risk of there being no available players, which is also reinforced as an XP bonus is rewarded for all party members who participate with members who are new to that duty. As you progress, more and more duties are unlocked including high and extreme level, with their own rewards. In addition, once the player hits level 50, an additional reward becomes available as a substitute to the XP.I currently have 150 hours registered to Steam for this game, and have just completed the main storyline. There are countless other things that I must complete, as well as the content unlocked in the latest update coming soon. This will add large amounts content which serves to increase the playability for both high and low level players.Square Enix are very good at announcing and presenting new content to the games, with regular livestreams showing off new content to keep up the hype. This builds good relations between both the players and the company. In addition, the moderation team of the game (GMs) I have heard are very helpful, and can resolve most issues. In addition, in the two times I have contacted Square Enix support I have received an adequate response within a few hours.In all honesty, the game is great. Although it is different from other MMOs I have played, it does have a great playerbase who will help newcomers with any issues. I fully recommend this, even if it's only for the 30 day trial.

Posted: December 9, 2014
												Probably this is the best MMORPG you are going to see on Steam at this moment along with EVE Online. If you are fan of Final Fantasy saga keep in mind one thing, this game have more of Final Fantasy than all of supposed games of the series before this since FFX&XI. +GraphicsI'm absolutely delighted with the technical part of this game. I dont understand how all the Final Fantasy's on Steam are so horrible in performance and this one so awesome. A lot of graphic options, full customizable UI, support for multiple screens... Very nice job from Square Enix, It's very rare on pc.+Combat & Boss battlesAt first time maybe the combat looks slow, easy and very simple but you are not going to feel the true difficulty of this game until you face a Primal in Hard Mode. Get your butt ready for die a lot and more if you do it with random people.The battles with the main bosses are super epic, the music it's just wonderful and completely immerses you in the game. I can still hear my screams of the first time I killed Titan in Hard Mode after weeks of tries.+ClassesThe possibility of have all the classes of the game in the same character is just awesome. I cant imagine playing other mmo with a lot of characters for different classes. I am too lazy just thinking about it...The DPS classes are a little bit broken in difficulty and how much dps can do compared to others. This is the only "bad" thing I can say about them.+StoryLike I said this game have more of "Final Fantasy" than some of previous games of the franchise. The lore is very cool and the main history really grabs you into the game. The way they linked the history before A Realm Reborn and the actual history is wondeful. +High End ContentIf you like the pve and the raids you are going to enjoy so much this game. The entire high end content is oriented to this. The difficulty of the bosses at this point is very hard and if is not enough you have a "insane" mode for them and that is almost impossible.+DubbingYou can choose the Japanese voices. YES! (。⌒∇⌒)。-CinematicsA lot of cinematics dont have sound so it's just text and click, click. Except the bosses intros, unfortunately all of them are boring.-MapI didn't played the 1.0 version of the game but I know how the map was and it can be resumed in "corridors everywhere". Now is a lot of better but even with that "remake" of the map it's still too small for a MMORPG. It's not a constant map and it's divided in zones with loading screens between them. This is very common in a lot of mmo's lately and it's a shame.-PVPIf you are looking for a MMORPG with good pvp and funny this is NOT YOUR GAME. This game is completly oriented to pve and the pvp it's just for get some cool armor skins.-Brayflox Longstop (Hard)I hate you Brayflox, I HATE YOU. (Counter of times I've repeated this dungeon for get the Relic: 99853475212258526)

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												After Final fantasy XIV 1.0 was a gigantic flop, Square Enix was brave enough to give the title a reboot.With success!A Realm Reborn is really fun. This already starts with the story which is very long in my opinion. The atmosphere and the music are wonderful. Every detail in the game is lovely designed. There are so many possibilities in the game to kill time. For example, there are FATEs which are events where you must fight in groups against world bosses and other opponents. Even if you've reached max level, you can still enter old dungeons because your level gets capped and you can enjoy them with newer players. If you're bored with your current class, then you don't have to create a new character. Just change your weapon, and you can play as another class. I really like that idea since I don't like to have multiple characters.If you're a Final Fantasy or MMORPG fan, then you should definitely give this title a try. It's one of the greatest MMORPG's in recent years. I've never had so much fun with an MMO like with this one.

content:
Posted: January 30
												My best friend bought me the game back in the day, I wasn't expecting anything after having played Age of conan for years.We started to play and I fell in love with this game! All the pro's:-The best community, so hardly any trolling and very friendly people- Raid and dungeon finder that is cross worlds! (quick queues!)- Regular content updates that include a lot of story and many new dungeons or hardmode versions of dungeons- Party finder to do old content has been updated to be cross worlds now too! (best quality of life update)- Pretty environment/music and character creation is very in depth- Very interesting storyline- Many different jobs and the respective skills all look amazing.- Mounts to collect through many different activities that aren't walled off to anyone, everyone can get them.- Raids and dungeons are amazing, they put a lot of effort into making these and you can tell via environment and story that is related to them! - Glamour!- Quests are fun (especially the Hildibrand quest line) and well made!- To help leveling and learning the game a  new system has been added called the hall of the novice, finishing this will end you up with a good level 15 green starter armor set for your class and a 20% extra EXP bonus ring with added stats, you just need to speak to a Smith in the starting towns!- Seasonal events with nice rewards and story- Only one character needed, you can play all classes and even have bonus EXP when you have a max level character, so leveling up alternative classes will be quicker.- Crafting system is very fun in depth (it's a game of it's own!)- New quest icons to make dungeon related (side dungeons and raids) and class/job quests more visible.- Mog station allows you to buy certain glamour items that you may have missed in previous events for very little money (got to support them somehow!)- UI can be fully customized.- You can marry! same sex couples as well in case anyone was wondering! It's free, but for a fee the couple gets an upgraded plan and they get a two seater chocobo (each) and a ring to TP to each other and your guests will receive a minion!- You get a chocobo! not just as your mount, but through a quest also as your battling companion!- Your chocobo is dyeable, yaaaay! - Apartments are available in game for 500.000 gil and there are many to go around! you get a chocobo stable outside and you can have two planter pots to grow two seeds, so everyone can finally dye their chocobo if they are not in an FC with a company house.- Free company housing (this is also a possible negative, read there for explanation) very handy to have when you have a big and active free company!- If you went away from the game for a while, this game is the one MMO I've found to be very easy to catch up again :)- Beast tribe quests and special beast tribe quests for crafters!- Recent update now made it possible to change your summoners' ifrit/garuda and titan egi into your old trusted and above all cute carbuncles!Possible negatives (if you are bothered by these sort of things)- Everything (dungeons/raids/special quests) is locked by the Main Story Quest line or alternative quest lines, you are forced to do the story to advance.- Servers currently are mostly full, most of the time if you start playing, you may be put into a queue for that server :(- You cannot block someone if they are not online or on a different world (so possibility for them to annoy you again)- Certain mounts are only available on the Mogstation and they can be costly £18.00 for one mount, but it's account wide.- Most cutscenes are without voice acting, so a lot of reading- There are some quite long cutscenes or consecutive cutscenes (very long cutscenes do have a warning before them however)- Monthly subscription, although worth to me, it might not be to others (one character per world discounted sub is available at under £8.00 per months  and personally I see the monthly sub as a way of supporting all the new and regular content we get!)- Your game settings and custom UI are saved locally! just wanted to make people aware of this- Marrying can be costly, despite there being a free option, you can also buy for £5.00 or £10.00 per person and have a gold or platinum wedding, however for gold and platinum weddings only, your guests get a minion and the couple to be wed get, beside amazing cutscenes (check youtube) a two seater chocobo and dyeable clothing and a ring to TP to eachother ! not sure if anyone always finds it worth it.- Free company housing as of today still are not available for newer free companies, since all the wards are full and there's a shortage of availability in these- Mentor system possible negative is that one must have leveled a tank, healer and a dps to level 60 to earn the mentor title and privilege, personally I think it's fair enough.And it seems to affect peoples attitudes a little bit, which is a shame to be honest.There are many more pro's and maybe a few other cons, too much to write down, but I feel I've covered most of the important ones! In short summary I absolutely adore the game and never regretted playing it. There is not a game out there in terms of an MMORPG that I feel is so deserving of a sub. It's the most fun and friendly MMORPG in fantasy setting that I have seen that is high quality and just simply amazing and never ceased to amaze me.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												Final Fantasy XIV. First off skip to the dashes if you don't care about my story. I started this game hating it. I labelled it a generic MMO because classes barely have anything unique about them when you first start. DPS is DPS, Tank keeps things hitting him, healers DPS because mobs can't kill tank at this level. I went into fields after doing too many fetch quests to count and then I did the same combo over and over until things died. Pugilist/Monk. however after quitting and being nagged back into the game I learned at lv.30 the game completely changes. Your class begins to bloom into this spectrum of variety(except DRG they do the same combo til the end of time) and it makes you want to get farther. What's next? How will my class improve more? Every 5 levels you'll find out. lv.50 your classes change so much that noone who hasn't played your class can possibly understand your struggle. The classes become extremely diverse from others (Yes DRG I know your still doing the same combo with a chance of attacking from a different position) and level60 you get to see how hard the game is when your fellow players pick up FLT(Floor Tank) as their main class in every raid. The game heavily suggests you bring sunglasses (For the Holy spam and flashy SMN attacks) and your A-Game and as you progress through this very very long storyline the missions get to the point where you can't even play casually anymore. You got all these moves you have to properly use to get the best out of your class+boss mechanics and fight mechanics you ahve to obey while managing proper synergy with other classes (I'm not going to diss DRG again you know what you do).--------------Ok so I'm mad you skipped my story but it's ok because I'm the annoying one out of my friend circle. I knew you wouldn't notice me senpai. here are the Pros and Cons of FFXIV.The Pros-Amazing Servers with very very very very little lag, and if you experiance alot of lag its your connection/PC/dont play on PS3.-Amazing visuals and well done particle effects. The game looks just flashy enough and fortunately only 2 classes require Sunglasses to play.-Extremely Diverse endgame classes. No class is the same. The Pros and cons are brutally diverse to where if you didn't play the class, you don't know anything about the class.-Relatively positive community. I get raged on and kicked very rarely for trolls. This brings me to my other positive.-SE CARES ABOUT US! Support Desk sends human GMs to talk to you about accidents. Other day I was verbally assualted by a Russian player who assumed I was a female american with sexual fustration because I played a female character. I won't dare repeat the things said to me but after reporting him, I went to get a drink and upon returning the GM PM'd me to ask me what happened. After a calm chat he told me despite me insulting him once I would not get banned because it's only reasonable that things get like this. The other player was banned because I stopped and realized immediately after my first insult that this is a case of harassment and continued the dungeon ignoring his excessive racial and prejudice insults while we let the ninja tank since he refused to.-Little to no bots. You are pretty much going to see RMT rather you want to or not but SE greatly combats this by monitoring trades and allowing reports of bots. You can block bots and ignore them as they will be flagged and banned. I only see 1-2 per day in each town compared to most MMOs where there are armies punishing low-end PC users.-Realistic Story. I won't spoil but this is the most realistic story I have ever seen in a fantasy game genre and honestly tears were shed.-Standard Final Fantasy Story based progression. Play this like you play any other Final Fantasy. Tons of Fetch Quests, minor forced battles and continuously unlocking new things to do while you frantically run around doing 700+ story quests.-Heaven's Ward DLC has almost as much if not MORE content than the original game. How many games release a $20 DLC pack that adds a whole new game to it? Not many.-Unlocked content allows you to easily level up other classes so you can relearn mechanics from another perspective and play endgame how you want to.-No garbage tier classes. Thank god there is no such thing as a class that is useless endgame.-Strong but not toxic player market. undercutting is normal, but not toxic inflations outside relic weapons.The Cons-The story until Realm Reborn is the most Old English ever in existance. It was virtually unreadable for me and many others.--Game mechanic cons---Weekly Loot in all new content. Everytime they release something they new they force a slow grind by making the latest gear be restricted to only once a week. This stops players from "beating" endgame before the next patch on 1-2 classes. This also makes you pick a main class if you don't have alot of motivation to play/access to savages and I don't like it but I deal with it.-Go watch anime, DPS ques are going to take 15-30minutes a piece.--Community Cons---Players will not allow you to do Savages unless you have completed them and have the voice chat of their choosing. Usually TS(Which is problematic for some, but a majority do not have issues with the peogram itself more than a way of accessing it due to lack of PC/Decent Phone). You will need to find a learning party if you want to get the best gear in the game. If your on PS3/4 you will not be allowed by players to do Savages unless your Free Company(Guild) is doing it with you.-Absolutely huge skill gap between some classes. DRG and DRK are very very easy classes to play. PLD is freaking insanely hard at start and doesn't get easier until you pretty much master the class around lv.50. Same for MNK. You'll be doing pretty much garbage damage until you learn Flank isn't behind like most games and learn how to position yourself around enemies in the mist of crazy particle effects and mobile bosses/tanks. Not to mention there are alot of mechanics that only effect certian classes. This is a con only because people get extremely cocky endgame and begin to talk like they are gods because their class is brain dead compared to yours. This applies to what I'm about to say next because this low skill cap on set classes not only draw in beginners who want to learn, but people who feel they don't NEED to learn because healer will cover them and they required much less effort coming up to these points.-When a player is bad... they are fustratingly bad. Hopefully your not as unfortunate as me but 1 person in every random team I get in is absolutely bad to the point where they are literatly halting the team. We are talking ignoring mechanics, ignoring class roles (pull mobs as DPS, only DPSing as a healer, refusing to use tank stances as a tank) This is a community issue and as for my other reviews community issues do not greatly impact my review unless the game is team based.-Heavy pressure on players. I heavily suggest you play this game with no cares because this con is big enough to scare away people who care what others think. This community con is basically when you play any class someone else doesn't like they blame,shame and constantly pick on you for being it. This does not happen often but you will meet people who will purposely get your killed and constantly pick at you for these things. As a healer you will meet players who eat too much damage yet you have to heal them in order to beat the boss. We are talking about people doing optional things to cause you stress and distrupt your ability to play efficiently.These cons may differ on your server/data center.In all if you really love FF games and you enjoy a godlike storyline I heavily suggest this to you. You can see how the game evolves and changes as it both updates and as you progress through the game.

												Pros:+ Play all classes with 1 character+ Many classes: 3 tank jobs, 7 dps jobs, 3 healer jobs , 3 gathering job, 8 crafting jobs+ Original Final Fantasy world, with all spells and summons+ Immersive over 40 hours main-story excluded side-stories and tribe-quests+ PvP 1on1 area, 5 on 5 arena fight, 72 man PvP zone fight - with rankings+ PvE bosses, dungeons and raids for all kind of skills     > over 16 raids now + hard difficulty > over 45 dungeons > 24 man dungeon > over 35 summons/trials to fight+ Freuquently patches every 3 months since 5 years now and huge expansions with new jobs (next Stormblood 2017)+ Huge open world with flying mounts and different states+ No p2w system, no advantage + Deep skill system, specific cross skills, skillpoints, buff-food, materia-melding+ Own your own guild house, your own apartment, have a garden+ Amazing soundtrack most of the time+ Duty Finder, Raid Finder serverwide EU, NA or JAP / your own Party Finder server-specific+ Tons of minigames: card game - chocobo raising, training and race - minions arena - huge casino with games+ Tons of craftable gear, PvP gear+ Selling market of all gatherable and craftable resources+ Random "fate" monsters and monster hunting in all areas+ Daily duty finder task, daily quests task, weekly (patch)raid boss task+ Raise your own AI-party and (future patches>) join dungeons, use AI-gatherers+ Detailed character customisation at start and later in game anytime+ Available in the most common languages+ Cross plattform gaming Mac PC PS3/PS4+ Keyboard mouse or optimized controller support+ Seasonal Events like halloween, valantines day, christmas etc.+ Huge guild system, with houses, airship and guild-intern airship areas+ All skills covert:   > hardcore dps/tank/healer skills with damage to the last second and all buffs up   > casual tanking / damaging and solving certain boss mechanics   > beginner with easy damaging, healing and getting slowly into the gameNeutral:-/+ monthly payment       > keeps away the p2w, 3 monthly updates and expansions      > monthly costs-/+ Lot of grinding      > keeps you at the game      > can be boring, sometimes no people for fatesCons: - sometimes harsh community (like many mmos), though u can find lovley guilds and people- playing with no-english people (japanese, french, russian) > can be frustrating- small pvp community, can be 20 minutes wait time for a 5 on 5- long playtime of main-story required, which will be changed in next expansion- not easy to set up, though there are tutorials    > for steam buy the game > make square enix account > activate your key there > apply paymentNotes* I'm sure i forgot some features of the game, though it's the best mmo i experienced so far. I can see no end to it and it keeps me playing, if i stop for a few months, cause of updates and friends. It gets bigger and brighter every patch

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												See, I don't normally play MMO's. If I try one, it usually captures my attention for a solid week, then I lose interest, uninstall it, and never play it again.This game? Oh man oh man. This game is great. I've only ever played free MMO trash around the web, but this one is by far THE BEST MMO I have ever played.The combat is like you should expect; if you've played any other MMO, it plays similarly to what you would expect out of an MMO. There are a variety of classes that you can choose from as your battlecraft classes and, the best part, you can have every class on one character. This is especially helpful when you're doing end-game raid stuffs. Form one team, and depending on what your team has leveled, you can form different groups with the same team.When I first started playing this game, as a low level I thought the gameplay was spectacular. Everything felt so fresh, and I felt like there was a bunch of things about the game I had yet to discover. Boy, was I right. Once I hit 50 (the max level for every class BEFORE Heavensward, which will increase that cap to 60), I felt like the game suddenly opened up to me. To this day, I still find that I have a LOT to do.If you're looking for a great MMO to play and don't mind a monthly fee, look no further. Final Fantasy XIV will surely fill your MMO needs.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Character creation & terrible inventory organization aside, this is the most solid MMORPG in recent history. Once a practically unplayable mess, it is now staffed by a dedicated team which bring major patches every 3 months. Cons -character creation sometimes requires a 1-time wait to log on in dead hours before being able to play the gamecharacter race/gender features can be quite limited in overall options compared to most other MMOsplayer inventory is a headache, w/ next to no organization optionstab-targeting system sometimes doesn't work as intendedNext to no PVP content (EDIT 1/18/2017: developers have made positive changes to PvP but is still far from an emphasis in the overall game)despite best efforts of new design team a lot of old, clunky features still clot the game in awkward waysNovice-training systems are a step in the right direction but ultimately solve less issues than they set out to addressOnly certain players will like these things -Combat is slower than most MMORPGs, especially w/ the recent ARPG injection to the MMO genresome of the flashier, desirable content at endgame is behind a wall of grindquest & objective-based content often sends players to revisit old contentDungeons oftentimes require extra research from outside of the game in order to not be frustrating for self/othersFree market economy - because of the constant pace of new content the best ways to make money is to learn trade secretsGame is punishing for those wishing to mindlessly kill random mobs out in the world as a means of power-leveling (you must participate in activities working towards pre-definied goals in order to earn xp reliably)Pros -EXCELLENT community - hardcore players are plentiful, yet there are many incentives in place for fair/kind playEngaging story - even if you aren't a huge lore-hound the pacing of the game makes an immersive worldNo add-ons needed (in fact discouraged) - UI provides plenty of features & raid mechanics are an intuitive processPlenty to do - just about everything you can ask for in the world or in an instance, w/ more content always being added"Glamour is the true endgame" - player characters are a breath of fresh air to the genre w/ insane variety of costumesRole-playing - quality tank/dps/healer gameplay, no reinventing the wheel. RPing is also encouraged w/ numerous social features.Every job can be accessed from one character. Discount subscription plan available for players w/ 1 character per serverNo ghost towns - content often brings players of all levels to cities/towns, making every hub populatedUnlocking content is a personal journey that can be achieved at ones own pace - very little of the game feels like it's either rushing nor slowing you down, allowing you to digest what you want or speed through what you want, when you want it.

number of helpful: 52 of 54 people (96%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn takes place in the continent of Eorzea, on the planet Hydaelyn who shares it's name with the Mother Cystal, who will guide you throughout your adventures as the Warrior of Light. The game starts you off as an adventurer with an unknown background and are sent to talk to the Adventurer's Guild in hopes of something to do. You will start off in one of the three main City-states; Ul'dah-the desert city that houses some of the richest and poorest people in Eorzea, Limsa Lominsa-the port city that houses expirates and peopl who love the sea, and Gridania-the forest city filled with people who love the enviornment and the spirits which inhabit our world. Which city you start in will be determine by your class, that you can change later on in the game, meaning that you can level all 13 classes to level 60 (the current max level) all on the same character. These classes are mostly iconic to the Final Fantasy franchise, with new and familiar ways to play them. In terms of an MMORPG (Massively Multiplayer Online Role Playing Game) FFXIV hits it out of the park. I am an very experienced MMORPG player having played games such as SWTOR, TERA, Guildwars 2 and Wildstar to name af ew of the more popular ones and coming from 7 years of World of Warcraft. FFXIV, while not completely unlike World of Warcraft, is vastly different. I will mainly be using World of Warcraft as a comparison as it is the game i have the most experience with playing as well as it being the most popular MMORPG atm. Like stated earlier in FFXIV you can play mulitple classes if not all the classes, if you really want to which is different thatn World of Warcraft. In WoW you progress with one character until it becomes stale and you must do everything all over again. In FFXIV, your progression is made with the character rather than the class you are representing, meaning that if I get tired of playing a Summoner and I switch to a Dragoon, I will have lost no progress in the mainstory, any of my achievments or titles or anything else along those lines. The only thing i have to do is level my Dragoon up to whatever level I so desire. If I realize Dragoon isn't for me, I can simply switch back to my Summoner (same level as it was before I switched) completely free or try out a new class all together and keep my progress for both Summoner and Dragoon so I can return later.While I could spend all day talking about this game and all the features it has, it's time for some Pro's and Con's, since unfortunelty this game isn't for everyone.Pro's-Hands down the best story that I have every seen in an MMORPG, it will not only keep you captivated but it also puts you as the center of attention, which is different than how other games such as World of Warcraft do it.-Class system is amazing for someone who wants to try multiple different classes without wanting to re-roll their characters or make alts, it is actually encouraged you try and play all the classes and see what one works for you.-While not the most graphic amazing game, it will certainly blow a lot of games out of the water. FFXIV just looks stunning if you take a second to enjoy all the great features this game has like dynamic weather, awesome backdrops and  a pretty good character creation page.-Crafting in this game is hands down the best I have ever seen in an MMORPG. Some people level one battle class up to max level and then focus the remainder of their time playing crafting and gathering classes. Whiel some games make these activities a side thing, FFXIV makes them classes all on their own and completely viable to spend all your time and money just working with these classes.-You absolutely cannot talk about a Final Fantasy game without talking about the music that goes with it. The music in this game is fantastic in every regard. If you are a music nut you will die for some of the sound tracks in this game.-Finally, this game gets tons of content periodically in patches. The time between patches is roughly 2-3 months at a time (which sounds like heaven if you come from WoW) and each patch is pack full with fresh new content and things to do (and not selfie cams and twitter...)Con's-Although the story in this game is amazing it is a very story motivated game and as such may not interest some people. There is no way around the Main Story Quests (MSQ) in thsi game, you have to do them to unlock the content. Although you can technically rush through all the dialogue and skip all the cinematics, you will be missing a huge part of what makes this game great.-While the end game raids are all fun, they are not what a raider from WoW would expect. Each major content patch (X.0 X.2, X.4) they will introduce 4 new bosses in the existing raid. At the start of every expansion (well we only have Heavensward and A Realm Reborn to go off of atm) they introduce a new raid with 4 bosses, and like I said every major content patch adds 4 new bosses to that raid, which if you come from wow can be a bit bland. Although I think these fights are great I can also see how some people would not like this.-Lack of class customization. This game does not have class specilization like WoW or SWTOR do. If I am playing a Dragoon and I see a Dragoon right next to me at the same level, we are going to have the exact same abilities. This feature is kind of made up from the fact that you can be all classes but it doesn't really. That beign said its not terrible not picking talents and whatnot, its just a cool feature that isn't there for reasons that make sense (no cookie-cutter builds or best paths)-The grind. While no where near as bad as a Korean MMORPG this game has a really really long leveling grind. I basically split the leveling process into 3 major steps. The 1-50 leveling which is made up of the A Realm Reborn story and learning your class and whatnot. This step was made easier when Heavensward launched as they made MSQ give double xp. Not terrible but kinda lengthy. Next is the 2.1-2.55 leveling experience which is by far the worst part of this game. Once you hit level 50 and complete the main story you then enter something similar to a post story. This post story will set up the stage for the Heavensward expansion but is completely manditory and very very VERY slow. If you haven't bought Heavensward at this point you will get 0 exp and if you have bought Heavensward you will probably get one level, maybe. The 2.X series probably takes around 20 hours all together to complete and during said time you will feel like you aren't getting anything (exp wise) but will get little gear upgrades. The final step is the Heavensward part 50-60, I know this is technically a review for A Realm Reborn, but I will talk about it anyways. This step is probably the most enjoyable as you will be introduced with a new story and a new enviornment along with some new chracters. The Heavensward story is fantastic, but you have to slog through the post story to get there.Those are the major things about this game, obviously there are tons more things I could say but to keep this from being a novel, I will leave the review here. Overall this game is a great buy and any MMORPG player should at least try it out. Some important things to note are that there is a free trial if anyone wants to try it before they buy, you will get 14 days to play the game with a level cap of 20. Also another important note is that if you buy this product on Steam you will be forced to buy every expansion after on Steam, which some people dislike since it regularly goes on sale other places and rarely goes on sale through Steam. On the bright side, you can use your Steam wallet to pay for the monthly fee so it has its ups and downs. Finally, the Square Enix website can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥sometimes but don't let that discourage you, this is a great game and I hope to see you all in Eorzea! <3 Sarris Wolf, Behemoth
