content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
Top notch MMOFreedom to choose Europa, Americas, or Japan serversGraphically brilliant, uses around 80-90% of my 780ti at 2560x1080 (21:9), maximum settings (+custom post processing) and uses it well.Mouse/Keyboard or Console gamepad both available for use, each with their own specialized interface (Very customizable too).Great character creation, 5+1 Races, with two cultural diversities each.8+1 combat classes, 9+4 advanced specializations called jobs. ALL are available to each character.8 crafting classes, 3 gathering. Again ALL available to each character.Heck, be a full time fisherman if you want. Writing which is rich in story, world establishment and humour of all ranges.Gameplay and story start off easy and at a smooth pace, but eventually amounts to huge depth and progression.Seasonal moods are refreshing and explored in full, all year round.No pitiful pay-to-win or limit breaking cash shops. Simply a costume/dye, mount and mini pet store for the most narcissistic among us.AMAZING COMMUNITY (I play with Japanese players, so I can't speak for the rest)The only thing that might let the game down is that voice acting is reserved for critical moments only, but more is being added quite regularly.I recommend all interested in RPGs, Social functions, and MMOs in general to give it a try, even people new to Final Fantasy will feel welcome. Be warned- You may just get sucked in for the long trip, but I certainly enjoyed the ride.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												If you're looking for a new MMO made within the last few years, this is easily one of the best. Unlike most MMO's on the market, FF14 is actually story driven. While the writing isn't always the most amazing, and the voice acting can be hit or miss on some characters, the overall end product is quite well presented. And the story itself is overall quite good, and does a great job at making you feel heroic and important at appropriate times. There are innumerable non-main storyline quests available if you care to do them. Every class has their own unique story to follow. And some side quests that are hidden away for you to find are true gems. There are hundreds upon hundreds, if not thousands of hours, of content to do in quests alone, depending on your pace and weather you're the kind to read everything offered. (Which I suggest, particularly in regards to speaking with nearby characters during main story quests to get an abundance of bonus dialogue that can often be amusing, insightful, and interesting.) Many of the areas within the game are quite beautiful, making exploration quite enjoyable for new players, and older players who have long since seen everything will find many 'favorite spots' dotted about the game that they can always return to if they feel like it. Some scenes are truely a sight to behold when seen at just the right time.As for the gameplay, for anyone who has played Square's previous MMO, FF11, you might find the grind to be somewhat familiar. Or, some might find it to be conciderably easier. Your milage may very based on personal perspective and experience. In terms of leveling, it's far from as mindnumbing as many other games, as Square included several systems to lessen the time sink involved in leveling, in addition to offering items that can increase exp gain. Casual play could see you through to cap with your first class, mostly by following the main quest, within a few weeks provided you read and watch everything. Rushing hard and skipping everything you could cap within a week, maybe two depending on your free time. Combat, contrary to many shallow complaints by people who likely never saw a job past 30, is not extremely slow. A global CD of 2 seconds is not the end of the world, and becomes largely irrelevant rather quickly as classes accumulate off gdc abilities you can use between them. Without even reaching the original~ level cap, you will find most every class has something you should be doing at all times provided you aren't being deliberately lazy and coasting through combat on one or two buttons whie your party does the work. That's a player problem, not a game problem. While there is mountains more that could be said about any number of things, if anything should be mentioned, it's the flaws within the game. It's not perfect. The game's dungeons and raids can range in difficulty from childishly easy, to eye gougingly, aggrevating, difficult. Especially if you have poor party members. Square's idea to lock some content behind a pre-made party wall makes playing all the end game content difficult without a dedicated group to play with. And depending on what server you join, there may not be much, or any, end game playerbase, while others might consist of nothing but end gamers standing around waiting for queues. As amazing as the game looks, many areas are devoid of relavant content past certain levels. As a result, many places will appear entirely dead because there's no reason for anyone to return after a certain point outside of leveling or rare events like hunt mob spawns. Again, this is largely server dependant, but is~ a problem none-the-less. It causes players to concentrate in select few places over time and leaves the world feeling empty, even when a server is completely full. Playing with Free Company members, or joining newbies that you see and taking the opportunity to level something new can do wonders to avoid this problem. Or be a loner that doesn't care about other players being around. That also works, but is kinda boring to me. Perferences. Once you've spent an inordinant amount of time in the game, you might find that the selection of dungeons, while large, grows increasingly repetative after you've leveled multiple classes and have seen the same boss for the 200th time. It's annoying. While not a problem for new players, or even for most players within the first several months or more of playing. For long, long time players. It's aggrevating. The game needs more dungeons, especially of the lower end leveling kind. The biggest flaw in the game, and the quickest to grow tiresome, are the FATES. Randomly spawning overworld combat events. Square overuses FATES for literally everything they can shoehorn them into. Seasonal/special events? Go do FATES. Grinding end game relic gear? Go do FATES. Grinding levels? FATES. FATES get old, and they don't age well. In a few, rare instances they're done well. While it might occationally be lackluster now, with low player turnouts due to the new expansions and higher lvl cap making the fight easier, coupled with fewer people actually needing the rewards. Keep your eyes open for Odin in the black shroud if you do play. That~ is a fate that was done right, and is still exciting to stumble upon even to this day, where I have long since passed any need to participate in it. And if it's on a good day, you might experience something rather impressive to behold, as others in the past have when finding him for the first time. In summery, the game isn't perfect. It's got problems. At least a few more than are listed here. And some common complaints are often blown far out of proportion by people who haven't, or refused, to get invested in the game or give it a fair chance. But it's got an abundance of good points as well. A great story. Great presentation. Solid gameplay. Ongoing support which will someday amount to an even larger game than it already is. Possibly far larger (hopefully). A growing class/job list that provides plenty of variety, all at your fingertips on a single character, and much more. Of all the recent MMOs that I've played, and I've played more than a fair few. FF14 is head and shoulders above the rest, with a potentially strong future to boot. I'd easily give it 9/10. The flaws it has aren't enough to hold it back from being great, and only really~ impacted me after thousands~ of hours of playtime, and I'll keep playing whenever the opportunities arrise in the future.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13
												Let me start off my review by stating that I am in no way an avid MMORPG player. The last real MMO I played was Runescape. That was back when installing Battlefield 2, Halo CE, and Gunz at your local library to have LAN sessions with other kids was common. I did resort in Guild Wars 2 for a time but outside of playing with friends I found myself barely engaged with what was going on. And I guess you could count The Secret World but the interface and design mechanics are a bit overwhelming for someone who doesn't know what they're doing.That's one of the main reasons why I think Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn has currently 6 million active online users. It's not an overwhelming MMORPG. In fact, it's quite the opposite. It's a very laid back and calming experience that will not overwhelm newcomers but at the same time gives hardcore veterans enough of a challenge to really sink their teeth into. It also helps that FFXIV is a labor of love; a project directed at the helm by a gamer for gamers to give us the MMO we should have expected from the first iteration back in 2010. Yoshi P. and his team have done a phenomenal job of rebooting the game and continuing to expand on it. There is a wide variety of things to do. You can play the game following the main story line, or you can just ditch the main story line all together and head down to the casino to spend your days gambling, participating in chocobo racing and breeding stronger chocobos, or capitalize on the player-driven economy by supplying goods and services through leveling up jobs, loot collecting, etc. Hell, you can even do it all on one character if you want to!This game takes a lot of influence from a copious amount of other successful, and even unsuccessful, MMOs and their mechanics and melds it together flawlessly. You have a job system that allows you to switch roles any time you want, and two jobs can be leveled up to create a different job as well. Each job carries a specific responsibility and unique play style so you don't want to worry about trial and error or looking up guides to find out what abilities mesh well together. The only game changer is that you can add additional abilities from other jobs you have leveled up to provide you added benefits for the main class you're working on. FFXIV also provides a fruitful amount of dungeons and trials (bosses) that are all very unique in both design and mechanics. The game's core fighting mechanics are based on a standard triangular job system meaning that any and all dungeons must be tackled by having one person, the Tank, crowd control all mobs and bosses while healers, well, heal, and DPS (damage per second) classes must kill everything. There are also random open-world events called FATEs which are essentially little quests that pop up around the world for all players to see and participate in and rewards are based upon how much you contribute to the objective or objectives.Now, all the good doesn't mean there isn't a bit of bad. The biggest blunder that FFXIV has as a whole is the quest system. As I mentioned before: FFXIV is a calm and laid back MMORPG. All of the main story quests and side quests primarily have you going around and simply talking to people. There's of course your standard fanfare of, "go here, kill x, collect y," type of quests, but it's mostly all talking to people. This is because it is a heavily story driven game much like other Final Fantasy games before it. However, that being said, it's only a speckle on an otherwise perfectly chiseled face on marble and if you're someone who is into reading hours and hours of dialogue and are all in for the story than this is the perfect experience for you. To the game's credit the characters you encounter, despite not having any voiceover work 90% of the time, are unique and interesting both in their stories and personalities and there are a lot characters to meet.The game also has this really bad tendency of being too quiet in general and barebones in its cutscenes. I'm unsure if it's due to the limitations of the engine or because the developers want to keep expanding the game without eating up too much of the hard drive, but the silence of the game is really jarring especially in its cutscenes. There's no ambiance to any of the areas you go to and it's mostly all driven by an absolutely wonderful soundtrack. That being said, it makes the game feel cheap when you're watching a cutscene that's made purely with the in-game engine, no voices, and animations recycled from the emoticons you can use around the game and the only audible sound heard are footsteps when characters move. And when the game decides to have voice acting it's not only bad, but it feels even more awkward since there's still barely any sound going on in the background and the actors sound like they're in a closed recording studio despite characters standing out in the middle of a blizzard. However, the oversights in terms of world building is quickly overshadowed by the beautiful design of game's environments. Every place is absolutely gorgeous to see and it's easy to get lost in. That's really the only negative point the game has. It's mechanics are damn near perfect, the story, characters, and world are all very well done, and the constant expanding universe through free updates the developers roll out quite frequently really make the game feel like it never truly does end. I've sunk over 500 hours into the title, and I've still yet to see everything. I've only just reached the Heavensward expansion, and they've already added in a bunch of new dungeons and story content that's set after all the events that occur in Heavensward. It's a game of love, passion, and dedication and it truly shows its charm despite it's shortcomings. This is the MMO you have to play. Plain and simple.

number of helpful: 101 of 179 people (56%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 8
												I'm going to review two aspects of this game: The game itself, and the community.The game itself is pretty great. Not many MMOs keep me hooked as long as this one has. The graphics are pretty nice, the job balance is done well, the storyline (though not my cup of tea) has more depth than most MMO storylines.My only real complaint (though it's a serious one) about the game is its end game. Once you've leveled everything to 60 (which can take a while), you're basically just going to run daily dungeons for currency to by some of the top tier gear. This currency caps at 450 per week though. Besides that, you can also run a raid and get a drop once per week for another piece of top gear.After you do both of these things, you may be out of reasons to login for the week. Which is obviously not good.There are complaints about the PvP in this game. It's very casual and does have its problems, but it's certainly entertaining in my opinion.Now we get to the second aspect of the game....the community:The community in this game has been a roller coaster of ups and downs in my experience. Unfortunately more downs than ups.Outside of the hardcore raiding scene, it's not uncommon at all in my experience to run into that one person (or sometimes multiple people) in a group that have to be carried. And I'm not talking about someone that hasn't quited learned their abilities yet but is obviously trying, I'm talking about someone who demonstrates a willful, obvious, almost proud ignorance. Many times these people simply ignore advice or actually get offended by it.I've also encountered trolls in dungeons more than once. Everything from someone using cross-class tank skills to intentionally provoke enemies off the tank to annoy them, to people abusing the kick feature in the game to wrongfully remove someone from the group. There are 4 people in a dungeon group, the person who is being voted on cannot vote. The other 3 can, however since the 4th person can't vote, it only takes 2 people to vote Yes (One actually technically since the vote initiator is automatically counted as a Yes) to successfully kick them. This enables all kind of bad behavior from people who queue with a friend. And basically if there's a disagreement, whoever starts the kick first wins.The server I play on (Balmung) has also had some interesting people. I was once kicked from an FC for talking about insects. The leader's girlfriend was triggered by insects, apparently she has a crippling fear of them (despite playing a game with plenty of large insects in it as enemies). I questioned her, the FC leader lost it and kicked me.TL;DR: The game is good, the community is not so good in my experience. I'll probably get a lot of hate for saying so, but it's simply my experience, the truth of it. Everywhere else I've said negative things about the community, I've been made out to be the devil, but seeing as this is where reviews go I want this place to be more than just an echo chamber.Since I can't give this a 5/10, I'll have to vote not recommended since the community of an MMO makes an MMO as much as the game itself does.

content:
Posted: February 6
												It's a little pricey (12.99-14.99 a month), however, this game truly feels like Final Fantasy the MMO, and for that I feel that it's worth both the entry fee, and subscription. If you enjoy other square enix titles/previous final fantasies, DEFINITELY give this a shot, there's a 14 day free trial if you're absolutely unsure about this level of commitment, but from what I've seen so far, it's by far and large worth it in so many ways. This game makes a lot of interesting design decisions unseen in pretty much any other game, for starters, you only need 1 character per server you wish to play on to get the full experience, each character can at any point, while out of combat swap to another job/class. The cutscenes are pretty superb, the story is what you'd expect from a final fantasy game, the combat is fluid and feels good, typical trinity of dps/tank/healer, interestingly enough though you can cross over around 10 skills from any other class and add them to that classes line up, so every class is a dual class in a way, even allowing tank/dps to heal a bit.Soundtrack is amazing, open world exploration is great, game looks beautiful, the minigames are great (triple triad from FFVIII returns with plenty of rulesets!) all in all you definitely get your value for the money you pay. *Free trial just lifted their time based restrictions, the game is now FREE TO PLAY up to level 35 in all classes, after 300 hours of play I only have 3 of the 23 classes past 35, (and only 1 if you count the core classes) there's a lot of game to be had, for no cost if you're looking to try the game.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Final Fantasy 14 is one of those very rare games that embodies wholly what you look for in the MMO genre. I started my experience back in the middle of 2015 and since then enjoyed, almost every step (aside Titan EX). FFXIV caters to the needs of many kinds of players those that heed the call of combat and those that want to craft and relax online. It has open ends on all parts of the scale making sure you have lots to do, without being pressured to do it.The key points for this game include:Playing everysingle class on one character, allows for diversity at times when you need it without taking away your efforts.Great socialisiation, it targets well how people can interract with each other online as their substitute self-Amazing customisation, by god is the customisation good, go a head make your character, you will never find someone that looks like you.Intricate story, though it has had a tendancy to get a little dry at time the primary campaign which takes you through the levels is incredibly enjoyable and the story itself is well written and crafted, though watch yourself if you really hate politics.The combat and leveling,.. the key point of most MMOs, FFXIV has it set to a T. Everything is balanced and created so 'Jobs' can fit in with one another. I my played Archer until I could reach the Bard Job. This primarily made me the support DPS in all dungeons. Whilst each healer and each tank has their own specific uses which each and every ability cater to. This isn't really something I can explain with words so I suggest looking up a few YouTube videos on the classes and Jobs.Lastly the dungeons or Duties as they are called. The main focus of this game as a whole is to prep yourself for Duties which are dungeon crawls, boss battle trials and Raids. All are extremely fun and hold the entirity of the main game within them outside of the storyline. Each dungeon is unique with bosses and units your team have to take down co-operatively, Trials toss you up against one of the big guys which have diverse fighting mechanics you need to learn and master as a team to take down and Raids, well, we all know what raids are...My final scores for FFXIV are as follows Score  Visuals and landscaping  8.5/10  Soundtrack  9/10  Gameplay  9/10  Controls  9.5/10  Dialogue, quests and story  7.5/10  Social aspects and self customisation  10/10  OVERALL  9/10

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												As someone who is burnt out on tab-target combat and hotbars full of skills, I'd always written off FFXIV as more of the same and not worth bothering with. It's always scored highly by critics and players alike though, and is still one of the few MMO's able to command a subscription to play. So after a few steam sales I found myself in possession of the base game and the Heavensward expansion, and I thought I'd give it a try.I can see why people like it so much; whilst the core game is dated, it's polished and well-produced, with reasonable graphics that will age well. Voice acting ranges from good to bearable, and the story (whilst suffering from a lack of interaction on my part beyond nodding and killing things) was enjoyable. I tanked lots of normal-mode and hard-mode dungeons, but not the really high-end stuff, and found that even though I exclusively used group-finder, everybody I met was either relaxed and helpful, or just silent. As someone who is shy of instances with random people because of bad experiences on other games, this was pleasantly surprising to the say the least.Unfortunately as I closed in on the level cap of 60, my fatigue with the combat and hotbars bloated with skills caught up with me. FFXIV is a good game though, and if tab target combat with lots of abilities, dungeoneering and raiding are your thing, then you should check this out.

												Deciding if you should get this game or not? here's a nice, simple read that should help you decide!:)Pros:One of, if not the BEST class system Iv'e seen, very catching and in depth, Job system is perfectBeautiful graphics perfectly optimized for PCA brilliant storyline with cutscenes that suck you in (especially in Japanese)Endless hours of gameplay, never ending things to doONE CHARACTER IS ALL YOU NEED, want to be a tank? do it! press 1 button BOOM you're a summoner.EXCELLENT roleplay game, especially for those Anime lovers out therePerfectly sculpted from other popualr MMORPG's such as WoW, Archeage and many more, (best tipbits)Something for everyone, raids, PvP, PvE and so on, all designed to keep you coming backCons:Combat is rather lackluster early on, but picks up over time Subscription, but hey-hoCan be slightly overwhelming to those who lack MMO experienceCan be a little tricky to level along side friends if you pick very different classesHIGHLY storybased, don't get this game if all you want is action action action!!Last but not least, Highly quest dependent, like I said, roleplay is key here!My score? 9/10. Almost perfect c:

												I have been playing FFXIV since March 2015, of a majority of the MMOs I have played this one has by far had the better story and kept me captivated as well as has made me shed a tear or two. While I would overall recommend this game, it does have it's pros and cons.Pros: Great graphics and wonderful details.Great story.Fun glamour options.Plenty of casual content.Makes you work a bit for your levels (grindy but not overly).Cons:Content doesn't release fast enough (people taking leave from the game for two to three months before the next patch drops).Not enough end game content.Hard to level alone (can't really grind out levels by yourself, but who wants to play an MMO alone?).Depending on your serve the communities can be extremely toxic (choose your company carefully).

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												If you like MMOs play this, if you don't like MMOs then you haven't played this one long enough. ffxiv is getting bigger and better than any other mmo and if you want to invest in a game with a fruitful future ahead of it, then this is the one.I've yet to play an mmorpg with a storyline as good as this, the game is considered to have a storyline that competes amongst even their own well-known non mmo games. Combat is sharp, fluid, and the combos work well; especially when you're decently leveled and don't have peasant abilities. The class/crafting system is also outstanding, and adds tenfolds of gameplay that's worth investing in (if you're worried about leveling said crafting/fighting class, then you'll be relieved to hear that exp bonus' are awarded the greater the level between your current class vs your highest).Some interesting aspects about the world and storyline to consider:-The entire planet begins to recognise your character as you gain levels and further yourself, random NPCs will know who you are and its generally pretty cool to come across games that do that.-Story is of  high standard, there isn't much voice acting in the beginning, but once you start accessing the non-3-year-old content you'll realise SE has been putting even more effort into their story quests.-Not just the main story either, each class and job comes with their own unique storyline which also progresses your abilities, these get real intense, probably better than the main story in the short run.(ill be adding more to this review in time, as well as some minor issues)

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Tried this game at a friend's behest.  First impressions were nice.  The game is true to its Final Fantasy heritage, and provides the atmosphere you would expect from any FF title.  Graphics were great by MMO standards, but not really up to what you would expect from a current single player Square Enix game.  It sets up a nice story, tho the cutscenes all use in-game models and feel poorly acted/animated.  Overall the mood the game creates is a good one, and one I would enjoy playing in.That is, if the gameplay itself were at all enjoyable.As soon as I got into the combat, I immediately groaned.  It's WoW.  The game sticks to the most basic overdone combat system possible.  Target a thing.  Press your skill keys in rotation to damage it.  It starts autoattacking you.  You take damage from that.  You step outside the AoE markers to avoid taking any extra.  Eventually, one of you dies.  Repeat ad infinitum.  Dungeons follow the same formula too.  Tank soaks aggro because autoattacks are unavoidable, healer mitigates that incoming damage, everyone else kills the stuff that's focusing the tank.  Pull a wave, do that.  Pull another, do that.  Reach the boss, do that with a few extra distractions you need to run and deal with in between hitting it.I wanted to love this game, but sticking in the most samey, widely cloned MMO combat system just leaves it lumped right in the same group as 90% of other MMOs out there.  Why?  They're capable of being innovative.  They could have just as easily made it into a XII-style open-world exploration into menu-based RPG encounters smooth transition, with options to allow nearby players to join in on the players' side and assist.  They could have done a lot of things.  They did not.  Instead, they stuck to the most basic formula possible.Oh, and keep in mind it IS subscription based, tho they DO offer a discount if you limit yourself to 1 character (and since you can freely change between all the classes I see no reason for needing alts).So my final score:Atmosphere: 9/10Graphics: 7/10Sound: 7/10Gameplay: WoW/10Substitute in your own number for that based on how much you personally enjoy WoW-style combat.  For me it's a 1/10 on that, and since combat makes up a majority of the gameplay, whether hunting for levels, killing for quests, running a dungeon or raid, if you can't love the combat you can't love the game. I would maybe return to this for the sake of just hanging out with my friends if it were free to play, but I refuse to spend another penny on a game that cannot keep me entertained during the majority of its gameplay.If you enjoy WoW and all of its clones, I do highly recommend this game to you.  If you're like me and are bored to tears of the same system being duplicated over and over for over a decade, stay away.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												I've played about 20 hours of this game before I got the Steam version so most of my criticisms will towards that version. On it's own Final Fantasy XIV A Realm Reborn is a fantastic MMO with fun gameplay and a surprisingly good story. After the disaster that was the original FFXIV Online I'm happy to see it vastly improved with ARR, however with that being said you might wanna be careful if you're getting Steam version so let me explain why. One of the big problems I'm currently having is the amount of crashes when launching the game and I've tried numerous configurations and settings but I still get the same result. At the time I'm writing this review I have the game reinstalling so I'll update it once everything is set up again, sadly I can't stress enough how much this process infuriated me. (After reinstalling the game I figured out that I had to go into my control panel and turn off Link Settings, at the very least this fixed all the crashes)The other complaint I have is the activation process, this can be a bit of a chore if you have an active subscription. Unless your Square Enix Account is new the CD Key won't work and that forces you to make another account. Why Square has to make this harder if you already have an active account is beyond me but this really pisses me off and I urge anyone to just buy directly if you want to avoid all these issues. I'm giving this a cautious recommendation based on how good this game is, just don't buy this version if you're expecting the CD Key to work and instead get it directly.UPDATE: After reinstalling the game I figured out that I had to go into my control panel and turn off Link Settings, at the very least this fixed all the crashes

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												This review is subjected to changes since it's an MMO which goes on a continous implementation of patches. As a veteran player I do not recommend this game. It's super bland grindy at the end game.TL;DR - End Game content (Very important in all MMO): Live letter which boasts and sugar coats about upcoming patch/expansion > patch/expansion gets released > Content worth only 1 week or more of actual fun > Game gets bland and just daily grind heavy even with the new patch > becomes pretty dead for over 2 1/2 month until next patch > cycle repeats..If your new or want to try a new mmo then try this game out. Graphics, story, leveling process and user interface is what will keep you captivated. It becomes only but a grind game at the end game content. Every cycle the director would say a very big update that is coming will improve the game.At the end...it ends up being the same grinding content with the same agenda to kill a monster or do a dungeon (where you kill a monster too), or other similar elements that is sugar coated in different animation/graphics. Example in game - Diadem.Many Veteran players have left this game and many have unsubscribed who resubscribes when a patch gets released which brings their hope up that the game got better but then unsubscribes disappointed. The majority of the players now that are recommending this game are players who have recently just started the game months ago and don't understand the cycle and brags how good this game is with having no experience on the entire game. Also some loyal fans.Pros and Cons of this game:Raid - If you are a hardcore player, you'll be disappointed from the fact that these raids lasts about a week and a half until hardcore players complete it. After completion, the next set of raids do not get released for another 2 1/2 month or even more. In other words their short. This applies to the 24 man raid as well. In heavensward expansion there has been twice where no raid content was released for 6 month each. Making it 12 month total now. They usually release 4 8-man raids every patch and 1 24-man raid every 2 patches. WoW on the otherhand has raids that lasts for months or a year because they release it in Huge contents and content itself is much harder then this game.Dungeons - This is joke. Lasts about a day or two and then it becomes a simple repitiion and grind. The problem with dungeons is that every new dungeon they release, which is about 2 dungeons each patch, makes the old dungeons obsolete which they seem to take out of blizzard text book. However, a good element of the dungeon is that they do bring a new style of fights usually which is displayed on the boss fights. It's another grind just letting you know.Crafting & Gathering - In no way, this element within any MMO is the Bread and Butter. It's useless and a game can be entirely enjoyable without it. This is just another form of grinding to make money within the game or make gears so players stay subscribed longer. The unique part though this game has a different style of system for crafting and gathering which makes it like you are actually fighting a monster with crafting skills. It requires some brain and once you get it down you can just make a macro, and sleep over night and let it do everything. That's all there is but let me say this element isn't the one to draw people to the game and people who say it is...haven't played other MMOs before and haven't tried all other content to it's fullest in any MMO.Character/Leveling - One of the Best in the game because one character can do everything like one character can become Mage, Lancer, Paladin, Warrior, etc. You can switch any time, and level each one individually. Every time you level a different class, you get a 50% more experience if you have another class that is higher then the current class your leveling.User Interface- ANOTHER BEST THING iN THIS GAME by far. You can literally customize it the way you want and save it in 4 different slots. Load up one slot if you changed to a healer example. Controller support - had controller support back in FFXI and it works out pretty well in here too.Netcode - it sucks. Play as a caster to get a visual experience of it when casting and moving. You can get a friend to see movement between both screen also to get the idea.Player Versus Player Classes - Classes in this game are very imbalanced. Warrior and Summoner being the strongest.Player Versus Player Arena - Called Feast(Score Match) and Wolves den(Death Match). First due note that the netcode sucks in this game so get ready to experience some server lag. Also, they haven't resolved to deal with the cheaters that boost points during a season. Every season lasts about 1 patch and some people at the top 100 are involved in cheating to boosting their points higher. The FFXIV team did nothing to deal with them. Instead left them alone which you can see in the forum. The Score match Arena modes are based on Guild Wars 2 style. Needs lots more polishing. There is no pure PVP death match because they made it obsolete with the release of Feast and advertising it. Also, every arena requires one healer, one tank, one range and one melee. So you can imagine how que time can be...It's worse in frontlines. Player Versus player Frontlines - Or Open field fights. They absolutley do not know what they're doing with this. It's legit terrible and they haven't fixed anything in this regards:1) 3 way team and if your in a Team that has a large population in the data center then expect a hour long que to just get in to a frontline match.2) All of the frontline is usually the same with heavy RNG involved except secure mode which was the first frontline to exist. 3) Every patch that contains a new frontline, they make the old one obsolete just like blizzard does. You'll never experience the old Frontline content because they don't care about the players.4) Finally Fourth - They do not listen to community feedback regarding to removing 3 way team both on Japanese and Global forums. Examine the forums, they have widely petition to remove it to improve que time but the FFXIV Team just ignores it. QUE TIME AND GRINDING ARE THE WORST thing in this game.Feedback system - cater to japanese/new player mainly and barely listen to any feedbacks except for those people. That's why we have grind content still.. Director doesn't know what he's doing since heavensward and doesn't learn.Cash Shop - It's becoming ridicolous now. They have a mount for 30 USD bucks. Cosmetics and other stuff as well. They are using it for milking cash from the loyal people.Events - These Events are lined up during the 2 1/2 month drought period to keep people subscribed. Like literally, it's the same grindfest. For example look at the current Yo-Kai Watch event. Heavy grind for 2 month.Marks - All your doing is farming for these at the end to get the latest gear. Before you know it next patch comes and the gear you have becomes useless...seriously happens to everyone.Bags and storage - Item storage is really the worst in this game to a point that you won't have no space and IN CASH SHOP YOU HAVE TO BUY A RETAINER WHICH YOU PAY "3 Dollar per month" to have more space..yeah more subscription money.Community - Excellent for new players. When it comes to discussing the dark side of the game, you'll see those topic silent. Listen to LimitBreakRadio and their community cuz they keep it real about the game.Fanfest event will either break or make it for me. However, be very cautious about the stuff they say and show because it's just another grind content. There are huge content droughts since pre-expansion and Director is only making content for new players.*Update seems like the players who started playing recently during Heavensward are downvoting this. They have no experience of endgame contentGrinding Fantasy XIV Ladies and Gentleman!

Posted: June 9, 2016
												I came from SWTOR, looking for something that would capture my interest since I'm starting to lose interest in SWTOR. I gave this game a shot & have been enjoying it ever since. It has a decent story that picks up later on. Gathering/crafting can be frustrating sometimes but also rewarding. The class system is excellent imo. You just need to equip a different weapon to change class & once you save your equipment, you don't have to go looking for a particular weapon to change class. You just click on it from a list & you're good to go. There's plenty to enjoy about this game. I'm definitely glad I made this purchase. Also helps that I'm a Final Fantasy fan. :P

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												There's not really much new I can say about this game from the other reviews my friends have done (which are spot on by the way), but for about 10 months before even starting to play FFXIV I've had one or two people begging me to give it a go, for those 10 months I never did but ♥♥♥♥ing hell I regret not trying it sooner.People have been calling this game the best MMO to ever exist and I can see why! You never run out of stuff to do and there are countless ways to level up your classes and jobs, the very best part of the game to me is the story, the main story quests aren't filled with fetch this and slay this filler ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and the story itself is genuinely interesting. Each and every dungeon has it's own mechanics which are both fun and mostly easy to get the hang of and the combat itself requires quite a bit of strategy especially in team-based instances. The one real "problem" I had with this game is starting out, trying to learn everything while taking your first steps into the massive world handed out to you can be really intimidating but learning the basics and getting a hold of what you're doing is well worth the hassle.This may not be the most well-written review ever made, but hopefully some people give this game a chance!

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												So I just tested this game for a bit and I have to say it is a very good game. Though I tested a lot of mmo's this is the only one beside World of Warcraft which kept me playing for longer than a month. It has some similarities to other mmo's but also some differences, which in my opinion make this a better mmo than other ones.Pro:- you only need 1 character- nice graphics- awesome community- tactical gameplay for raids (some are very tricky)- multiplatform- much pretty stuffs :3- LalafellCon:- much instancing of areas due to console supportSo i don't really have much negative to say. For people who come to this mmo from other mmo's might be a bit upset about a "slacky and slow" combat due to a long global cooldown. But for me after a while playing this it is not a problem. Due to many mechanics some bosses have it is very good to have a longer gcd to react to the mechanics and it also makes the fights much more tactical than in other mmo's. I think it is for everyone to decide if u like this kind of combat and gameplay. But for pretty reasons this game is awesome and also Lalafell.For people who don't want to instantly buy this, there is a free trial version you can test out. Just give it a try and decide for yourselves. Though it get's even better when you buy the full version and get to max level.I hope this may help some people to decide.I wish everyone a good night and enjoy your games.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Has Triple Triad. 10/10EDIT (3/5/17):I have decided that I have put enough time into the game to give a real review now.This initial part is just my personal story regarding this game, the TL:DR review info is below.To begin, I believe this game is very well put together. Following that, I also find the game incredibly boring. It follows the MMORPG trope of being an incredible end-game grind with no signs of relenting until you've wasted countless days of your life trying to get a single horse (or bird) to complete your irrelevant collection. Beyond the optional grinding, there are weekly locks on a dozen or more progression items, making sure that the player does not progress beyond their peers. This in a way, rewards players for being 'first' to do something. Though personally I find it incredibly frustrating to have to follow theses standards, and return every week, every day, to progress a fraction of a percent.So I find myself asking, "why do I do it?"Why would I torture myself with such miniscule changes, so little reward for hours of work. My answer, it turns out, is incredibly silly.I first came to this world, with prior experience in the Final Fantasy Franchise, and this game was everything I had hoped it would be from a Final Fantasy MMO, post Playstation 2 era, I played every single day of my 30-day free trial, and when it ran out, I immediately bought more. I continued to play it every day. This trend has continued to this day, though I'm a bit busier now and I do occasionally have to skip days. I had so much fun exploring this new world, meeting new friends who I would still call friend to this day, mastering the mechanics of the game, and following the beautifully crafted story of this game, that even now, I yearn to feel that feeling again. I play, in the hope that I will feel that again, I miss being new to Eorzea, I miss meeting the new NPCs, I miss learning new skills. This was my first MMO that I truly have dived into, and I feel as if it will be the last one I will enjoy.For reference, other MMORPG titles I have played :WoW Cataclysm (Private Server)TeraThe DivisionTree of SaviorNeverwinterNow as for an actual review-Overall: 8/10FFXIV: A Realm Reborn successfully captures the feel of what a Final Fantasy world is supposed to be, combining the fantasy world of dragons and magic, with the future technology of the Allagan, but fails to hold through to the end. With lack of ingenuity in an already stagnant genre, the gameplay closes the curtains on an otherwise magical experience.Music: 9/10Nobuo Uematsu does it again ladies and gentlemen. Uematsu once again creates a captivating array of orchestrated pieces for every and any situation. From calm seas, to the strongest of storms he has written a piece for the occasion. This music becomes a driving force behind the story, and the major encounters, setting up these incredible landscapes of sound for the player. Gameplay : 5/10If you have played another MMORPG, you know exactly what you are getting into. With the exception of the armoury chest system, which allows you to play every class on a single character. If you are new to the genre, you may find yourself intrigued by the active battles, need for positional attacks and use of cast timers and group buffs. These are all things that will inevitably tire the average player, they stay the same the whole way through with slight changes to the animation and numbers they produce. The gameplay is basic to put it bluntly. That being said there are quirks to it, there are of course ways to min/max everything you do. So if you take pleasure in that, you might enjoy it more. Story  : 7/10 Final Fantasy games have always tried to create a story driven experience for the player, and A Realm Reborn is no different. This has by far the deepest, most thought out story from any MMORPG that I have played. The characters have unique traits, they laugh, they love, they cry. Throughout the game you will meet new heros, villians, and the occasional idiot. You may hate some, love others, or even completely ignore the story all together. That is why I think this story deserves praise, without getting into the actual content. This game is completely enjoyable with no knowledge of the story, and they even offer to show you the cutscenes at a later time if you wish to view them. This allows players to play at their own pace, if they are tired of watching hours of cutscenes after every quest line, they are free to skip it and come back later. Community  : 9/10I once played World of Warcraft with a few friends of mine, and as you do, I added them to my friends list in game. When I finished playing, at max level at the time they were still the only people on my friends list. I found the community of that game to be incredibly dry. Now this is my personal experience of course, but if anyone had something to say, it was more than likely something rude. Comparing this to FFXIV, I find myself constantly lost in conversation with people in one of the main hubs. People who I have never spoken to before stopping by and talking about local happenings in the real world, and in the game world. You could go to any populated region and ask a question or concern you had, and get a reasonable answer. Well, maybe after one or two ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, but they are usually in jest. The one point deduction on this score is due to the fact that people act different when it comes to dungeons and raids, that is where you will find the elitist crowd. These people are not examples of the whole community, but one small fraction of it, that has a hell of a loud voice.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												I have been playing MMOs since starting on Everquest and moving on to Guild Wars and World of Warcraft and unfortunately for several years there haven't been any games which have really been able to grab my attention in the way the earlier MMOs did.  Modern MMOs seem to have devolved into a quick single player race to maximum level where there is no incentive to even read a quest log, before jumping onto the gear grinding treadmill and ultimately running out of things to do shortly afterwards.FINAL FANTASY XIV: A Realm Reborn has finally changed that, this is the first MMO I have played in recent years which has an interesting, well written story line and actually forces you to complete multi player content in order to progress from time to time.  The crafting system in this game is also incredibly well thought out and rewarding, it is not simply a case of gathering a few materials and pressing a button instead you have to think carefully about strategies to craft each item.  The other thing that also grabbed me about this game was just how beautiful the world is, from the scenery to the chaaracters the game looks stunning and the soundtrack is also top notch.The game isn't without its faults, one of the main issues at low level is the combat system has a very long GCD and until your character gets some extra skills which are off the GCD this can make combat seem very slow at first.  I think the developers should have introduced a few more 'off GCD' skills earler in the levelling process for some of the classes as this was my main gripe at low level.  That said it doesn't take too long before things start to improve and later on in the game once you have all your skills you can often find yourself wishing the GCD was a bit longer!One last point worth mentioning is that the community seems to be great, obviously I can't generalise for everyone playing the game but I have found most people are very friendly and helpful.  This goes as much for people outside of your Free Company (guild) as those in it.  I have bumped into more random strangers who have offered to lend a helping hand and explain things in this game than any other I can remember.  To sum it up this is a great game that you can really immerse yourself in.  It has plenty of depth and everthing before maximum level seems tangible and enjoyable rather than something to grind through.  This means you can enjoy the journey rather than worrying about the destination.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												One of the best MMORPGS since The days of vanilla WoW and Everquest II. One of the things that sets this game apart from current mmo's is the idea that your character is a person just like you. What I mean by that is that your character is not defined as a Mage or warrior, but rather someone who has learned how to be a Mage or warrior; in FFXIV, you can have one character that masters all classes and all professions.Professions (crafting classes) are very unique in that each crafting profession gets skills to help them in the world, for example, the fisherman profession around level 10 gets a sneak skill so they can traverse the world without being attacked. The fighting classes are separated into decouples of war, and decouples of magic; each with gear specified uniquely for it. The fighting classes include gladiator, pugalist, marauder, lancer, archer and rogue. The magic classes include the thaumaturge, the conjurer, and the arcanist. What is so incredibly awesome about FFXIV is how all of these classes can be combined with another to create a more powerful and unique class. For example, you can create a paladin by getting your character to level 30 with a gladiator, and getting to level 15 with the conjurer, to create a slight mix of the two. This game will forever be in my heart as the most immersive MMORPG and the mmo that has truly been worth a monthly payment. If I talked about everything in FFXIV, I'd be here all day typing, but in short, if you are questioning the value of this game, give the trial a try and you will quickly find out if you are a fan. Specs wise, the game runs beautifully, and for a game made quite a while ago, it graphically has withstood the test of time. I would recommend this game to any gamer who is searching for a great community, a great immersive experience, and a great breathe of fresh mmo air.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												UPDATES FOR 3.21*Perspective of a WoW loyalist since vanilla*"Probably the best quality MMO since Wrath of the Lich King WoW."BOTTOM LINE: If youre a PVPer, ignore the reviews prior to 3.2, PVP is slowly gaining popularity and the new modes have a ton to offer. You will be almost overwhelmed with things to do in this game. Theres a lot to offer for everyone.Pros:---Beautiful design for all of the zones, cities, and dungeons.---Awesome sound track I actually enjoy hearing each unique dungeon theme (most of wow was played sound off)---Balanced (for the most part) PVP. This game did what WoW should have done since vanilla. Theres a separate level up     system for pvp that gives you specific skills used solely for that mode. It fixes the whole PVE vs PVP balance conundrum most MMOs face---THE FEAST: This is probably what saved it for me long term. Just release this past week was The Feast which is a competitive PVP mode with rankings. Matches here gave me more of a thrill here than playing in the 2.4k arena bracket in WoW---The ability to play whatever class you want on a single character. This function also allows you to bring in skills from other classes to further customize your playstyle---High quality and difficult end game content (unlike WoW, which has people farming the content within a week of release)---Great communityCons:---People love the story but for me.... meh a lot of it was blah blah chosen one and tons of pointless fetch quests (like really homie i just saved the kingdom now i have to fetch water for 3 privates?)---UPDATED: PVP was originally dead however theres been a resurgence with a competetive pvp arena mode added with seasons (as said above).---Lack of Battleground diversity (However this is slowly and allegedly being addressed by producers)---This game forces you to choke down 15-20 hours worth of dead level 50 content in order to even unlock the expansion pack

												FF14 is a great game and I suggest buying it, I already have 1000s of hours on it (non-Steam version). Although a word of warning if you already own the non-Steam version do not buy the Steam version. Your character is not-interchangable and you can't use the Steam keys on your Square Enix account. You will have to start a new Service Account and you will not retain your old characters. I bought it on Steam during the sale in hopes of getting the expansion for cheaper but it doesn't work that way for previous owners. However, if you are just now deciding to pick the game up this is a great offer and I recommend buying it here and saving the money.Nice class selection, awesome soundtrack, amazing dungeons and raids, brillant story, great social system, able to swap classes freely (no alts needed!). Overall it is one of the best MMORPGs out there, have fun. :)

content:
Posted: March 27
												There is so much I love about this game, and would recommend it to any Final Fantasy fan. Fantastic combat, awesome dungeons, beautiful art style, killer looking battle skills, one of the best crafting systems in any MMO to date... It could have been perfect except for one problem:The ABYSMAL story quests. Go across the world, talk to person nobody cares about, come back, then go there again, maybe fight five trash mobs, go back, repeat five times and hope you finally get to the next dungeon so you can actually fight and use your awesome combat skills. And guess what? If you want any of the cool new classes or expansion content, you HAVE TO DO IT ALL.The weird thing is that many of the side quests and class quests are more fun and interesting than the entire main story quest combined. It's tragic that a Final Fantasy with such great characters and lore chooses to ignore that for 90% of the story quest, instead making you do menial tasks for faceless npcs you won't be able to remember if your life depended on it, while trudging back and forth like some kind of mailman.Despite this tragic waste of potential, I'd still recommend picking it up. The community is great, the gameplay (when it lets you actually get to it) is fantastic. I'll continue dreaming against hope that the Main Story quests get streamlined and sheared to hell, but I suppose it's a testament to the rest of the game's quality that I'm willing to endure it.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												If you're a fan of MMORPGs, Final Fantasy XIV is the perfect game for you. Though it is a subscription based game, as of this review, it has surpassed many Free-to-Play MMORPGs out in the sea of games already with a blend of certain ingredients. Starting off by making your character, you have multiple choices of races you can become. From a regular human, a midget, cat people, elves and even huge peoples. There are many options to personalize your character if you choose to do so, such as eyes(heterochromia), tattoos, and even hair highlights(which was a first to me), You might be wondering if this is when you choose your class now, and you're right. To my amazement, your one character can master ALL the classes within the game. All you need to do is simply reach a certian level and you can accept to join all the class guilds. After that all you do is switch weapons and become that class.(Amazing right?) After you perfect your character, you are immediately thrown into the beautiful world we know as Eorzea.Putting the amazing transition SE has went with the end of FFXI to FFXIV aside, the story of your character begins in a slow pace. Most people will be put off by this slow beginning, but the story does start to get interesting to the point you want to learn more about it. Anymore information and it might end up in spoilers, so you decide whether to pay attention to the story or blitz through quests exclusively for experience towards your character.The last thing I'd like to mention is about the dungeon system. You have finders which will automatically find you dungeons/parties, this can be a good or bad thing. So far from my experience, the community is nice to new players and will help you out and then we have some that are not so......nice. Either way, you can decide to use this or play with your friends within a party up to 8 people. As you progress through the game, you'll unlock more harder and interesting dungeons in which your team of friends can have fun  participating in. You might be wondering if there is anything rewarding from doing these. Besides receiving entertainment, drops such as weapons or armor might be a eye candy for your character. Another big thing would be the music. The music in this game is superb.TL:DR - Buy or at least try the game(free trial is up to 2 weeks). You will most likely enjoy the game and music and join the community, if not....at least you tried it....

												After experiencing all there is to offer, I can't honestly recommend this to someone looking for a faithful paid MMO in its current state. Sure, it's pretty fun for a while, but it gets too demanding and monotonous to enjoy playing in the long run, unless that's what you're into. Heavensward, the $40 expansion, is a well played joke. Multiplying the exp requirement for leveling and making you hike across massive maps* makes up more of this expansion's playtime than actual content. Significant updates are few and far between.*Flying isn't unlocked for the area until you've activated every Aether Current across the map and awarded via quests, and by that time you're moving on to the next area anyway, where the process repeats.TL;DR : A fantastic aesthetic, amazing soundtrack, accessible combat system and engaging story masks a life draining waiting simulator plagued with bad dev choices and Chinese RMT bots.I'd like to hear from those who still stand by this game, as I can't fathom why.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												I won't lie, I was skeptic. Heavily skeptic. Like, I thought this was worse than Dead Island skeptic.Square-Enix's track record has been far from amazing in terms of Final Fantasy titles as of late. Final Fantasy XIII almost cemented my lack of trust in them, and watching the disaster that was XIV 1.0, I just stopped keeping track altogether. They'd lost their magic much harder than I could imagine.This game is lucky I knew someone else who was into A Realm Reborn. At first, I had to laugh at the fact he was still paying for a lousy, broken, boring MMO, but then I started watching. I hadn't realised XIV had ended it's world and restarted again, and I was confused when I found the game to be a lot more interesting than I remember. It shut me the hell up.I decided to dive into this head first, give it a shot, see if it would be something I could get into. After all, I knew people playing it already, it would be a party based activity, something I haven't done in a while.But as you can tell by the amount of hours currently sunk into it, I didn't really need to know anyone prior.This game sunk it's teeth in. Hard.I'm not someone that comes from a massive MMO background. The last one I had played and gotten into was almost 10 years ago. It would be difficult to know if I could recommend this game over other MMOs, or even other games. Although you would probably do this anyway, I recommend looking at gameplay footage and deciding for yourself. I can personally say I've had more fun with this than I was expecting, and keep coming back.Community is pretty good (on Cerberus anyway, and from what I've found from watching other players). Yes, there are a few bad eggs, but considering the MMO and other online games I've come from, this isn't a problem. Every community will have the ragequitters, the griefers and the thieves, but they are so scarce. PvP is probably the main place you'll find these people, if at all.There are a handful of nitpicks, most of them are rather minor, such as the voice acting at points sucking the emotion out of a moment, usually in a single word (this seems to be a SE staple(seriously stop hiring the worst actors to play big roles)) and the HUD does not scale with windowed mode, so it's very easy, if you're running a smaller window, for your screen to get cramped with icons, even if you do shrink them down. But they are nitpicks, nothing that stops the game for me at all.All I can say is, there is a large chunk of time that I have sunk into it and I do not regret it*.*okay I regret it a little. I could've been saving the world or learning to speedrun a game or something else with the time I've spent on this.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												CuteFish Review: Longish review, pro/con list, closing thoughts. Just skip ahead if you don't like reading! :3   FFXIV: A Realm Reborn is a game that aimed to polish and refine the 'WoW-era' MMO instead of hamfisting in a slightly different spin of the genre. A story based leveling system (at first) that leads into a content rich MMO that has appeal to, quite literraly, any form of player who likes the genre. Very challenging group-based endgame PvE, good PvP, and an abundance of 'things to do' that makes for a very gratifying time sink.    Aesthetically, the game has a clean look similar to the other current-gen Final Fantasy games. It runs rather well on my machine and pretty decently on lower end machines, but it's definitely an art style that loses quite a lot of its charm when you start setting graphical settings to 'low'.   The combat system is the standard tab-targetting most of us are likely accustumed to but actually at a slower pace. The game has a 2.5 second global cooldown between abilities. Early on, this feels incredibly slow (because it is) but later on it feels much more meticulous since each ability use is quite a time commitment. I feel much more weight to use the 'right' ability than any other MMO I've ever played, and a big part of using the 'right' ability lies in understanding the fight. This makes the game far less 'go through your rotation based' and just thought-provoking enough to make you forget you're even waiting 2.5 seconds between spells and it's wonderful.   The game has a unique system in which 100% of the content the game contains can be completed on one single character. Every class, job, craft, quest, etc can be completed on one character to the point where there is genuinelly no practical reason to ever make a second. This makes for a unique attachment to that one special character who will likely be with you from beginning to end. All classes (including crafts) can be changed at a whim (outside of dungeons and PvP) by simply changing your weapon. You're given a bonus 25 slots per gear slot to hold every single piece and an easy 'gear set' system to quickly swap between entire sets of gear for your variety of classes.  FFXIV has a pretty decent story with likeable characters and hit-or-miss voice acting. The only major complaint is how you're supposed to be the 'hero of light'... along with all the other thousands of players on your server. Even looking past that, it delivers a classical Final Fantasy adventure that hits all the right notes possible in the MMO setting.   Leveling is rather easy and straightforward; but at the same time allows for an impressive amount of freedom in how you want to go about it at all. Your first class/job will primarily follow the main story line supplemented by FATEs (randomly spawned group content in the world) and dungeon queues to level at a solid pace. The pacing was excellent and was a rather mild curve in the time between levels as you progress. Part of what makes leveling great is that after progressing a little bit into the game you gain access to 'Duty Roulette', which allows you to queue for a random dungeon and upon completetion, receive a tremendous surge in xp on top of the already solid dungeon xp. This allows people on time restraints to level at a very reasonable pace as all you really need is about 35 minutes. After having one max level class, all future classes gain +100% xp to almos everything, partly because they dont get the main story and partly to speed you along.  This is an MMO with a definite PvE focus, as the dungeons are execellently crafted progression of difficulty from the start to the end. A complaint does lie in the first set of dungeons aquired very early on as they were very devoid of mechanics and give a bad impression of future content. Lategame PvE offers a multitude of challenge tiers to accomadate what you as a player are looking to do. Duty Finder raids, unlike other MMO counterparts, don't offer an easy mode, and its nice to see the game respect the playerbase by demanding a minimum skill requirement to start getting your hands on decent gear pieces.   A special mention should go out to this games crafting system. While earlier I mentioned this game has a strong sense of polish to the genre, this area was given a revamp compared to virtually every other MMO with a focus of creating depth, choices, strategy, and a purpose. The crafts are actually classes with their own gear avaiable to them to boast the crafting potentional. Every craft class has their unique spells used during the hard-to-describe act of actually crafting, which plays almost like a classical turn based game balancing many factors such as the progress towards actually finishing the item vs the actual quality of it, among other factors. Craft classes also have certain abilities that benefit other crafts, encouraging you to do them all even if you only really want to use one. Honestly if you've ever wanted to go hard on some crafts, this is DEFINITELY the game to do it.   On a final note, this game has the best soundtrack and the most cinematic, epic bosses in any MMO I've played. I genuinelly don't want to really spoil any of by showing you, but it's pretty freaking great.Pros+ Single-character system builds strong bond with your player character.+ Content that will appeal to any audience that already likes the MMO genre, and many newcomers (are there still any?)+ Combat that requires some actual mental usage regarding what abilities you're using.+ Best MMO on a console (but you're reading this on steam...)+ Great story that blends into the game almost seamlessely.+ Heavily teamwork-based group PvE content.+ The content updates are HUGE. The latest one (3.2) required a hefty time investment just to read through all the patch notes.+ Heavy timesink game based around progressing the overall state of your character rather than locking you behind time/grindgates. Always something to do~+ Most fun I've had crafting in an MMO to date.+ Amazing soundtrack that makes bosses feel larger than life. Many bosses have multiple songs, with one even having 5 whole songs. FIVE SONGS!+ System in place to help new players learn the game, from decent tutorials to a whole network of matching new players with highly experienced ones for guidance.+ Amazing community from my personal experience.Cons- There's a large divide between emptier and fuller servers. Definitely do your research before commiting to a server.- Early game dungeons are pretty awful.- Endgame gear/stat choices for each job is very linear. This is lessened since you can play all 13 classes on 1 character.- The gathering classes are really runescape-y in their grind... but I mean theres not much you can do with collecting rocks.- Some of the voice acting in English sucks. Some of it is pretty great. But mostly mediocre.- When you reach level 50 theres a 100 quest slog to get through before you can start the Heavensward (50->60 content.) It's pretty rough, not gonna lie. At least you only have to do it on one character!Closing thoughts: This game is epitome of taking the fundamentals of a game type and making them perfect. If you're feeling a little burned out by games like WoW or any of its plentiful clones, it may be time to give FFXIV a whirl. If you're just looking for a really comfy game to play and always have stuff to do when you log on, this game is great for that. If you want that classic hardcore PvE content found in the earlier days of WoW, this game delivers on that front too!Overall rating: 9/10

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												Players fresh to Final Fantasy XIV will be thrust into a gorgeous world and told to take part in run of the mill questing. So far, so generic, until you start unravelling the obscenely ridiculous amount of 'extra stuff to do' and take note of just how stupidly well optimized the engine is, and how great the game sounds along your travels.My only complaint as a new player was the levelling process, which usually emphasises a brain-dead 2-3 button combo that you'll spam for practically 20-40 levels... However, this may vary depending on your chosen starter class. Those who stomach the levelling process are in for a treat when they unlock cross-class abilities or even level other classes and professions from scratch (with no character swapping), meaning that the slowness disipates the more you work for all classes/roles. Professions can give your lowbie class an edge, as can said cross abilities, so levelling (again) is nothing like how it was starting from scratch. In short, it's horrible as a level 1 newcomer, but very rewarding for those who can put in the work.Combat leading to end-game is pleasant but basic... And then you enter Hard-Mode dungeons and realize just how much a tab-target MMO can actually feel like an action-combat MMO when your world starts filling up with danger zone galore. In short, if you try the game and find yourself bored by the early game -- don't worry, it does pick up, almost drastically so, usually starting after level 40.What else does it do better than other MMORPGs?Minigames to enjoy at your leisure, professions that actually feel like professions, inherent achievements that reward you for your efforts, hunting logs to encourage some light exploration, content that doesn't just get recycled (eg. a normal dungeon is not even remotely like their 'hard' counterparts - not even close), story and cut-scenes that actually make you feel that your character is part of the damn story (how many MMORPGs have you played where you play as some mute-grunt shambling around? Here in FFXIV, you're the star of the show and they'll remind you of this over and over). Dungeons & Raids (level 50 onward especially) get really fun/frantic and almost no two bosses are the same in any way whatsoever. There's all manner of little touches you'd just need to see for yourself.If you want a game that is TEEMING with things to do, spliced with lovely graphics and sound, on a smooth engine that could probably squeeze 60 FPS out of a brick, later complimented by fun combat and bosses with you as the hero -- give it a try.However, don't wait too long... You have a long road ahead of you.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												*No spoilers*The Good:-Great gameplay with very few flaws (I'll put those in the bad cat.)-Story that is immersive-Visually amazing.-Job/Class system that is perfect for the Altaholic-Long and hard Dungeon crawlsThe Average:-Like in most FF games, the voice acting and chat functions are pretty meh. -Very complicated for a first time player to MMO's (I've been playing MMO's for about 15 years and there were things that even I was confused about)The Bad:-The UI is cluttered all to hell. There are literally 3 locations to see target health bars and you can disable all of them, but the UI is just horrendously big for a game this visually stunning. -Dungeon mechanics normally consist of "Tank N' Spank", or "Don't stand in this shiny circle"-GOLD SPAMMERS, Holy hell When I first logged on and completed the first cutscene I had 12 tells from spammers. You can disable tells but that dramatically impacts gameplay when someone is trying to talk to you in private.-Amount of time to level: I'm 48 hours in to the game and I'm level 37, they do give you a benefit to other classes and jobs, but the original job takes forever.Overall I'd give it an 8/10 with this caveat: If you aren't willing to invest the time or effort in a game that will eat up days of your life while you pay them 15 bucks a month stay away. But if you are an experienced MMO type that revels in the dungeon crawl, raid grind for gear, and alt spamming, it's way worth it. I've played WoW, Elder Scrolls, Eve, and this, and I'm only sticking with this right now. Great game.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												The first MMO I played and really got into was WoW. I quit playing it for good about half a year before Pandaria's release. Since then, I drifted from MMO to MMO, never finding one that really captivated me... until I decided to give the rerelease of FFXIV a spin (after absolutely hating the 1.x version of it): FFXIV A Realm Reborn. And oh boy, it is a huge improvement over FF14 1.0 and an absolute delight to play, even for someone with zero Final Fantasy experience like me. After roughly 1300 (3200 at time of me editing this review) hours of gametime since the rerelease, I can honestly say that this game is absolutely amazing and well worth the money!Edit: Roughly 2000 hours after initially writing this review, I can still say I am completely in love with this game. An absolute must buy! If you're not convinced, there's a trial you can find of FFXIV here on Steam which gives you a little taste of how the game is... sadly enough, it gives you a taste of the early game. The weakest part of FFXIV. The endgame is where it shines, but you'll have to put in more time for that! Again, I can't recommend this game enough!Edit: Another edit, it's now been over 4000 hours and the first expansion (Heavensward) has released, and it is a great addition to an already great game. I really can not urge you enough to at least give the trial a go -despite low level being the weakest part of the game, as I mentioned in my previous edit-.-Ciaran Dango & Sena Tempus, Moogle

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												I have played Final Fantasy for a Very Long Time. Final Fantasy is not so much a videogame as a feel of a videogame, a specific set of familiarities and tones that amass into a notion of strange particularity. It’s hard to separate the act of playing Final Fantasy from our perception of what a game like Final Fantasy is: its look, its feel, the sound of a familiar melody at the title screen that tells you yes, this is Final Fantasy, and everything is going to be okay. Final Fantasy is not a game, but a smell, a memory, a compulsion. I have been playing Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn a lot, to my own surprise. This new rendition of a previous disaster which I have not personally experienced is seamlessly, indulgently playable. It is a game of unrelenting maximalism— every single Final Fantasy mainstay is hurled at you indiscriminately with reckless abandon— while at the same time being totally relaxing. It’s like plummeting into the ocean only to realize that it is the exact same temperature as your body. Unlike something like Call of Duty, which is equally big and playable but requires muscles tensed and brain on edge, FF14 washes over you in a warm crystalline blue glow of fantasy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.I played FF14 while catching up with a friend on Skype. I planned a ♥♥♥♥ing camping trip while playing it. Final Fantasy just occurs, if you let it. Do you know what else does this? Evil.You can play Final Fantasy forever, if you want to.
