content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												This game is not for everyone (even though it probably should be). Short summary opinion is at the end for those that want to skip reading a longer opinion.The quests in this game are much more diverse than in many other MMO games. They range from investigation style quests, to NPC interaction quests, to your cookie cutter fetch and kill quests and more. Some require you to run dungeons and other require you to take part in mini raid style battles on the world map (you dont need a party to participate in these).It needs to be understood that this game is extremely heavy on storyline content to the point that some may feel like they are reading an interactive book rather than playing an MMO. This means quite a bit of single player questing and even single player instanced battles as part of many questlines. For some this may be a source of irritation but for people that are familiar with the Final Fantasy brand, this is an amazing chance to become engrossed in the realm of Eorzea.If you are planning on playing this MMORPG just to skip every dialogue and run to every quest mark, you will probably start feeling either annoyed or confused at what is going on with the quests and frustration may result from that. This is because the main story quests play a large part in character progression in terms of unlocking areas but they are also very detail oriented in terms of conveying a personal story to the player rather than simply grinding out exp to level up.The storylines, both main and side, reflect some of the best writing to come out of a Final Fantasy game in a very long time and you can very easily forget you are even playing an MMO at times. There is a rather large drawback however, depending on your point of view...  This game demands that it's players EARN practically everything. You are NOT given a mount for free when you hit a certain level, you have to meet certain conditions to earn the right to ride a mount or stick with cheap taxi mounts until you do. You are NOT given access to your full ability tree as you level up and instead must take part in quests / storyline unique to your class in order to earn additional abilities and even a job class unique to your base class.You are NOT given access to dungeons in the game until you either follow the main story quests to the point they are unlocked for story reasons or until you find the side quests that unlock them for story reasons.The list goes on but you probably get the idea... things in this game are earned through hardwork, not through mindless grinding or by getting carried on the coattails of a high level friend that can just shower nice items on you (but that second one would still probably help alot if you are that lucky).The game is great, The story is amazing (both powerfully dramatic and enjoyable comical at times) and the gameplay mechanics are enough to challenge even seasoned MMO vets in the level 50+ dungeons and trial fights.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												240 hours.240 hours I have spent of what I think is the best mmo made thus far. This game is amazing for many more reasons than I am allowed to type down in this review. So instead, let me just give you my top 5 reasons as to why I think this game is amazing.5. fluint animation and amazing graphicsMost mmos put all there money into gameplay and story writing. Not that theres anything wrong with that, but this leads to lack of visual presentation. Take wow for example. How long has it been out? Longer than most mmos. Has it updated its visual quality since its release? No. It looks the same as its always been. Now take a look at ff14. What do you see? 60fps gold encrusted in gorgeous platinum grade textures. And the best part is square knew they didn't have to try. ff11's looks are on par with wow. So why did they try? Because they care.4. no limits on how many classes you can haveIn the beginning, you choose your one main class. However, when you complete the level 15 quest from your guild, you are free to take on as many other guilds as you like. There is no need to make a second character unless you REALY want to. Square did this because they knew that it would have been tedious to have many characters under one profile due to class limitations. With just one character, you can suit the needs of all roles. Wether it be tank, healer, or damage dealer.3. NON-elitest communityHow many times have you been kicked from a raid in wow because you had the "wrong" armor on, or you put your attribute points in the "wrong" spot. True there is an optimal way to play ff14, as there always is with video games, but if you dont have a perfectly specced, perfectly outfitted, GOD among charcters... nobody cares. You can shove all of your black mage attribute points into strength, you can equip robes and a wooden sword as a gladiator, you can ignore your skill hotbar as a monk... and nobody cares. No matter your level, attributes, euipment, and mmo skills in general, you will never be dismissed from a game provided that you are respectful and you at least try to do your job. ff14 has the best community of all mmos ive ever seen.2. amount of dlcJust about every mmo gets there largest sum of profit from dlc. The temptation of new classes, races, side quests, main quests, and the increase of your max level is hard to ignore. Now, how much dlc does ff14 have? Take a guess. On second thought don't. I know you would have guessed wrong anyway. The amount of dlc for ff14, as of now, is... 1. That's it. Just heavensward. Other than that, the base game has everything else. Now don't take it the wrong way. this game has plenty of content. In fact, almost all races, classes, side quests, and main quests are added in the main game via PATCHES. I mean, what other mmo does that? Just giving you free stuff because you own the base game? can't think of any? Me neither. It's pretty clear that square cares more about the communitie's satisfaction than their profits in the making. thanks square.1. are you ready fo this... IT'S CROSS-CONSOLE!Yup. You heard me. The pc and ps4 ports of ff14 share the same servers. Servers that are filled with over 5 MILLION happy customers accross the world, and accross different platforms, The ps3 verson of the game is a minor exception, considering that heavensward almost broke the system because it was not built for such content. so its obvious why ps3 needs its own exclusive serverse. But other than that, YAY FOR CROSS-CONSOLE!ff14 is by far the best mmo I have ever played. Even without the 1 dlc that is out right now, you can still enjoy this game for hundreds upon hundreds of hours without getting bored. Infact, you can almost be certain that square will patch in new content to keep you playing.All in all, i recomend this for those who like rpgs, mmos, final fantasy, and any other square related rpgs.Now if you excuse me, i'm going to ride my black and green chocobo into the sunset. along side my titan-egi, of course.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												TL;DR Play it if you like MMOs or come from WoW. Very fun game, and is the second most popular ATM but it should be most.This is the most fun I've ever had in an MMO. It is pretty similar to WoW, but some slight changes like the GCD is 2.5 seconds by default instead of 1.5 or so in WoW.There is so much to do in this game, the End game is MUCH more fun than WoW and much more rewarding. It is a themepark MMO so don't expect to not have to do Story to unlock much of the stuff in the game. It is the best way to level your first class and unlock new things. It's also very interesting so DON'T SKIP IT! Another thing that makes it much better, is you only need one character (I believe there is a very good reason to have 2 characters if you get heavily into crafting, but I haven't so idk), but you can play every single class in the game on that character. This makes the game much more fun to play and not having to do the same quests over and over again to level your class. I would recommend this game to Anyone who comes from WoW, or is just interested in a new MMO in general. So much fun.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
Simply put, it's the best story-focused MMO out there and one of the best Final Fantasy games ever made--even as an MMO. I can't get enough of it. It's refreshing to see a game in this genre put so much heart into the characters, writing, lore, etc.There are still plenty of grindy parts, but there is enough story to enjoy between them that it never feels cumbersome. There is simply so much to do in this game. Lots of variety. One of my top ten games of all time and certainly one worth playing especially if you enjoy the Final Fantasy universe or would like to get into it.The only negative I can think of is that the combat is a bit slow for my taste, but the rest is just so good that it doesn't bother me much, and the fact that you can switch classes by simply changing weapons always keeps things interesting.9.3/10

												Where do I start? I guess I could start back when Final Fantasy XI was released. My first ever MMO. But, nah, that game bored me. I quit that to play Star Wars Galaxies, and boy, was THAT a game! So now that we have the fact that I'm a SWG Vet, and no MMO has ever really caught my attention, or hooked me in, that should tell you how good this game is. DISCLAIMER: Fellow SWG Vet's, this is NOTHING like Galaxies! Except the MMO part. And the fact that you can be any class, whenever you want! Twelve combat classes, that merge into twelve more advanced classes, that you can blend and mix skills to have cross-class abilities, and then you can switch between them on the FLY!. Oh, and the crafting? Eight crafting classes, and three gathering classes! Crafting is very much like Galaxies. Scan for, or buy, mats. Find the best quality mats, and craft the best quality gear!There are dungeons, raids, and an amazing storyline that one would expect from a Final Fantasy game. The characters are very well developed, voice acted, and diverse. Everything falls into place.Before you purchase the game, and as with any other MMO: Do your research! Read up on th game, read reviews (like mine!), find out if there are free trials and friend codes. If you want a friend code, just send me a message, I'll be more than happy to show you around the vast world of Eorzea. It;s a beautiful one

Chocobo....DO YOU WANT TO DO ALL THE THINGS, CRAFT ALL THE THINGS, KILL ALL THE THINGS, GATHER ALL THE THINGS all while being skantily cladded and become a sexualized icon for the FINAL FANTASY WORLDS AND THE IMMIDEIATLY HAVE A SENSE OF SHAME FOR FEELING THIS WAY?!?!Then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												The original version of Final Fantasy XIV was, to say, a disasterous release from Square Enix. Problems from glitches, bad economies between the players and NPCs and being flat-out unfinished.Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn (or version 2.0 onwards) fixes so many of the problems and the game itself has good controls, an easy-to-use interface and HUD and beautiful sceneries and locations (with areas like Coerthas having been altered altogether from the original version). Each class has their own advantages and disadvantages and unique abilities that they learn upon levelling up or completing class-exclusive quests. Upon learning an ability that belongs to a specfic class, for example, Raging Strikes from the Archer, it can be used by other classes providing they're within level range to use it.The game offers many quests and dungeons as the story progresses, with new dungeons and harder variants of the bosses unlockable post-story (as of ver. 2.1 onwards). If you're a completionist-type of player, you will have plenty of things to collect and complete throughout the game.You will have to pay a subscription fee for this game, but for each period of subscription, you will be rewarded exclusive items, better known as Veteran Rewards. If you have a friend who wants to give the game a go, but doesn't want to spend anything yet, the Recruit-a-friend campaign allows them a 14-day free trial to see if it suits their fancy, furthermore, if your friend subscribes, you and your friend will get rewards only obtainable through this campaign.Old and new players will find plenty to do in this game, and if you're looking for a good time in an MMO I would definitely recommend Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Realm Reborn is a sequel to the previously released Final Fantasy XIV, which wasn’t received very well, and this is even conveniently explained in the game’s plot: there’s an apocalypse which ravages the whole realm and begins a new era. Personally I hadn’t played the previous game but this sequel is said to offer significant improvements over the original across the board, it's essentially an entirely redesigned game of its own.The plot is fairly generic save the world kind of stuff: you are an adventurer brought into one of the game’s three big city-states with a special ability to attune to crystals which hold some great ability to hold off evil. You perform tasks for the city-states and eventually rise to become an envoy between them and even serve them. Similar to single-player games, the main plot and many of the other quests are filled with cutscenes, and in the main story’s case, the significant ones are also voiced. It’s all easy to follow and they’ve tried to put a bit of story into everything, for instance all of the game’s class guilds have a storyline of their own that advances as you gain levels and do guild quests.However this kind of plot is well suited for MMO and something as complex as Final Fantasy XIII’s super messy plot obviously wouldn’t work here. Rising in guild ranks and joining armies feels like an accomplishment, and you get treated to far more heroic stuff like taking on massive primals (think summons from previous Final Fantasy titles) rather fast. The game overall plays much like a singleplayer game story wise: the story is focused on your personal character and many plot advancing quests have certain “duty” sections that can only be completed with your own character, such as taking on a boss battle. This can be reversed too in some cases: some boss battles and dungeons instead put you in a party with others. Most of the game can be soloed if you want, but the option to do stuff in a party is totally there too, you’ll only ever be separated for brief periods at a time.This focus on your own character is what sets the game apart from other MMOs in my opinion and makes the game more interesting. The cutscenes are also no worse quality than in singleplayer FF titles and the game’s graphics and particularly animation are fantastic. All characters are lively animated and seeing your character pull off all kinds of stuff like stupid faces in cutscenes is really fun and involving. The game is also really well optimized, running on a large variety of systems and even having its own preset settings for laptops for instance that take your specs into account. The user interface in the game is really good too, super easy to use and slick looking, I was never at a loss to find something.Gameplay is similar to other MMO titles and the difficulty level is really good across the board, you will be challenged at every level and you can always find more dangerous or easier opponents and quests. As a nice twist your character can be literally any class in the game – you can use and level any one class at a time, provided you have joined their guild, and certain class abilities can also be used by other classes. For instance, Gladiators that have leveled Conjurer can cast Cure, which they normally wouldn’t have access to, so cross-classing a bit is encouraged and even required to get Jobs (specialized mid/late-game classes) later on. To swap a class you just swap to a different gear preset, which you can create lists of. At the most basic level you just need to change a weapon to switch to another class.The game is easy to get into as well, there’s a 15 day free trial that offers leveling of a single character up to level 20, but you can cross-class him/her as much as you like, and it’s definitely enough to get a good look at the game. The free trial is best played with a friend that already owns the game though, because you cannot set up your own parties in it, but other subscribed players can invite you to theirs. Marketplace and trading functions are limited but otherwise there’s no significant restrictions. The game is available as a digital download on the website and on Steam, as well as on PS3 and PS4 on the consoles, the multiplayer is cross-platform, and new buyers of the game automatically get 30 free game days. Steam users will also be happy to know that the monthly subscription can be paid with just Steam wallet money, assuming you also bought the game from Steam.TL;DRIt's great. Don't compare it to Square Enix's other new FF games. It's a traditional MMO game with Final Fantasy flavor and one well designed one at that. I enjoy it tons more than the recent main series FF games. And I wrote this review originally for something else in mind, if you're wondering why it's so long and detailed. :P Give it a chance, it deserves more PC Steam players. And, it has a ton of content in a large world. I still feel like I've barely scratched the surface of what it has to offer so far at the moment of writing.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Where do I start? I guess I could start back when Final Fantasy XI was released. My first ever MMO. But, nah, that game bored me. I quit that to play Star Wars Galaxies, and boy, was THAT a game! So now that we have the fact that I'm a SWG Vet, and no MMO has ever really caught my attention, or hooked me in, that should tell you how good this game is. DISCLAIMER: Fellow SWG Vet's, this is NOTHING like Galaxies! Except the MMO part. And the fact that you can be any class, whenever you want! Twelve combat classes, that merge into twelve more advanced classes, that you can blend and mix skills to have cross-class abilities, and then you can switch between them on the FLY!. Oh, and the crafting? Eight crafting classes, and three gathering classes! Crafting is very much like Galaxies. Scan for, or buy, mats. Find the best quality mats, and craft the best quality gear!There are dungeons, raids, and an amazing storyline that one would expect from a Final Fantasy game. The characters are very well developed, voice acted, and diverse. Everything falls into place.Before you purchase the game, and as with any other MMO: Do your research! Read up on th game, read reviews (like mine!), find out if there are free trials and friend codes. If you want a friend code, just send me a message, I'll be more than happy to show you around the vast world of Eorzea. It;s a beautiful one

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												Staying true to the Final Fantasy name, Final Fantasy XIV delivers very great gameplay as Square Enix's 2nd Final Fantasy MMORPG.It's pretty, now supporting a DirectX 11 client, with improved Tesselation and water effects, causes the game to look slightly better than DirectX 9, which the game originally supported.It's very well optimized for PC. I run a i7 4790K and a GTX 970 with 16gb Ram. Not only can I run this game in 1080p maxed out at 60fps, I can also stream it with those same settings at a 3.5 bitrate, and my computer doesn't cripple in performance.It has quite a variety. Final Fantasy XIV boasts multiple classes you can pick from. A wide diversity, that is simplified for dungeon play into 3 categories: Healer, DPS, and Tank. Players will be required to form parties with the minimal 1x Healer, 2x DPS, and 1x Tank. You can't just run in a dungeon and expect to solo the entire thing, you need your party members.The only downside to this game is, you need friends. So you better know people who are already in the game to join, or go alone and make friends on your own. If you don't have anyone to play with, I can't really justify the monthly subscription fee of $13~15.Me? I'm here for the catgirl customization options.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Uhm, this game is very different from other MMos and that is why its so popular. The monthly subscription fee is reasonable given to the possibilities you can have ingame. If you want a game, where you are basically like living in and where you can even relax, sure its a good game.+ Story is literally breath taking and unrivaled+ The crafting here is brought to whole different level (in form of minigames, quality based depending on how good u are with it) and you can literally craft everything (not even joking).+ The level balancing is also really well done ( a high lvl player can always start a new job and go out with his friends who are starting with the game)+ Cross skills in form of a Job ( literally the end game is about having one character maxed lvl on all classes).+ Well thought system+ Freedom of choice what do you want to play the most, if you dont like one specific type, just switch to other and you dont have to reset your progress.+ Most friendly community I ever seen. They embraced me everywhere with a smile, helpful and not raging, even though i just started the game and knew literally nothing.+ huge amount of mini games ( so you can do alot of stuff and relax ingame while waiting for ur dungeon qeueing or so on).+ While are you leveling your low lvl class, there is a vast amount of ingame interaction that you are not bored even though you are nowhere close to endgame content.Cons:- I became a no lifer and shut in, always addicted to just ffxiv.- more like a PvE game, PvP here is very limited to just group vs group (small group or large group). No duels. After some time, you will not really miss it.-sometimes the leveling is rly linear, but which MMO is not? If I should compare it to others, ffxiv still offers alot of different ways and minigames to at least kill the boredom a bit.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												logged 571 hours over a couple of months at the time of writing this. Which doesn't seem like a lot but the way I play games (play for a few hours, stop, play, stop) it's a lot of time to dedicate to one game.I haven't played an FF game I enjoyed since X. That is, until XIV came out. I've played a lot of MMOs including WoW and none of them held my interest for long. In FFXIV there are a lot of things to do and the community is the most enjoyable one I've encountered.One of the things I enjoy the most is that you don't have to stick to one class. On my  main I started off as a Lancer and instead of remaking and loosing all that time you can simply go pick up a new class (which gets upgraded to a job once you complete the level 30 quest). If you get sick of your character appearance you can use a potion that you get as part of the vetran rewards to change everything about them (or you can buy one). If you're just sick of their hair/makeup changing that is as simple as coughing up 2k gil for a makeover. (which is nothing at all later on, especially if you craft)Speaking of crafting, that's a feature that held my interst for hours. It's rewarding, although often expensive. In addition to making weapons/armor/clothing for your character you can also make furniture if you have a house, which you can buy personally or by joining a guild called a Free Company that has one. The only gripe I have is super long DPS queue times but that's less the games fault so much as the fact that I play DPS mainly.It will trash your life and suck up your time. 10/10.

												Final Fantasy XIV is a MMORPG set in it's own realm. Welcome to Eorzea, Pros.Endless gameplay nearlyLarge veriety of activities from Raids to simple crafting and the casino!Free add ons Patches 2.1 - 2.55 all have major content updates that give new gameplay features, story, and modes For free. An MMO with a story! ikr? It's so rare and unique to find an MMO with a good story and out of Guild wars, WoW and Rift FF14 has the best of the best!Cons,Mixed playerbase: Due to multi platform release you have a large mix of Pro players from other MMOs and newbies from the consoles who won't listen to anything you say or even reply causing some issues in low lvl dungeons and gameplay.Learning the game: while somewhat easy learning truly KNOWING what everything does will take some time and can be quite dificult overall.Limited exploration: While the world may feel large compared to 11 or 1.0 It's quite smaller than what it was with each area a limited size due to console version limitations.Server login / character creation limitations: If you wanna join your budy on a High populated server GOOD LUCK either stay up till 3am in the morning and pray Or buy a server transfer for 20$ ontop of your existing 20-30 for the game and first free month.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV is an MMO that takes the common tropes of many others, polishes them up and delivers content on a fairly regular basis with an open producer and a lot of community involvement. With MMOs being largely community driven, the fact that the Final Fantasy XIV team is willing to share as much and as often as they do (going so far as to describe the problems they had in the original launch of the game and how they worked on them) is a breath of fresh air.The failure of Final Fantasy XIV Online was something of a reality check and with the two years spent redeveloping the game we now have a well written story surrounded with an excellent series of challenges to keep people busy with. The game is visually impressive and runs many times better than it's failed predecessor. Combat is at a fair pace with a number of different classes that you can change to on the fly just by changing your primary weapon.While Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is primarily a PvE game, the development team has done an excellent job at bringing in content in a timely manner, providing for quality-of-life adjustments, and has been extremely effective in documenting and implementing a lot of the playerbase's wishes.If you're looking for an MMO, Final Fantasy XIV isn't a bad one to look at. With it's entry price being half that of other new MMOs, and the subscription offerings being more flexible than others, the game is not only well cared for, but hard to beat for it's price of entry.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												There is so much things to say about Final Fantasy XIV that I will try to make it fast!Even though I am upvotting this game (because of my 2078hrs+ and because I have hope that they make this game better in future), I do not recommend this game to every kind of players!It would only depends on how patient can you be!Let's get started!--- GRAPHICS ---+ Pros:- The graphics are decent,you do not need a strongcomputer to run the game!- Some areas can look wonderful- You can run the game with a PS3 as well! (Soon to be removed, though.)- Cons:- Some maps (especially Heavensward's one) can look terrifyingly uggly. ><- Aion (I did not played very much but enough) looks better and it is Free to Play (while this game is money greedy but  I'll talk about that later!)- Your character can't be uggly (if you ever wanted to make a hideous character, it'll be complicated)--- Gameplay ---+ Pros:- You can switch classes any time you want- Past-level 30 you can unlock your class's job- Different gameplays for every classes (Also for crafting / gathering classes!)- Cons:- Gameplay is poor: You have to use a spell to sprint, you don't have access to double jumps or anything original!- There is a lot of invisible walls which is pretty frustrating- Classes gameplay can be repetitive (Many spells are identical. For example, every tank classes has a few %dmg reduced spell for a certain amount of time)- Too long cast-time for caster classes- Dungeons are super slow and most of them are pretty boring to play--- END GAME CONTENT ---Oh boi, I feel like I might put a lot of down sides to it <.< (I don't know what I will type in advance)+ Pros:- Release patches with some content. (About each 3 months I think?)- Cons:- Farming MONTHS to get scripted items. You don't get to make a original <build> to your character since you willbe told what to buy by the system.- Always the same (and continuously) patches: A bit more of MSQ, 1 or 2 dungeons, 1 raid, 1 trial.- Farming but for what? In fact, there is ABSOLUTELY NO POINT to get the highest items.It won't be usefull. If you go in a low level dungeon to help someone, your level and stats are syncced.PvP is a 4V4 team or 8V8. There is also another one with bigger amount.But once again, STATS syncced!There is legit no point to farm. This is my biggest reproach to the game.- If you don't have anything to do, you can level up every other classes max. But it's repetitive. <.<;;Otherwise, you can do their events:It'd be like a small 30 mins story for christmas / or / halloween or other moments.To either get a emote, or -most of time- uggly clothes.Nothing really exciting. Sometimes you'll get 1 event per month, sometime nothing for 3 months!--- Scenario ---(You will discover soon enough in the game that you are not just a normal person and that you have "special" powers making you stronger than most people. You will be siding with < the good people > to protect it from < the bad people >)+ Pros:- Original story, making you look like a badass in cutscenes- Lots of cutscenes!- Cons:- Lots of filling quests, it's pretty annoying!- In Heavensward, they will repeat over and over some stupid things about being in war since 1000 years. But like, VERY oftenly. Ruinning the immersion <.<;;- There is a voiced cutscenes, but then, out of a sudden, no more voiced cutscenes for a while. - You have to clic on voiced cutscenes to continue the dialogue/cutscene making it frustrating when you want to see it kind of like a movie <.>--- Social aspect ---If you are, like me, a League Of Legends player and can't stand the community,you will probably enjoy some of Final Fantasy XIV's servers because the community in game can bepretty open-minded and nice to you! It is one of the reason I like this game and still play it.Plus, the game is good enough to make some cool FFXIV content on YouTube.Growing a community from FFXIV is probably the best since you'll see many nice and open-minded peoplewhile if you play League Of Legends, their players would probably say things like "you suck i'm a better [character's name] than you!"--- THE COMPANY (SquareEnix) ---This is probably the biggest down side of that game.Square Enix is INSANELY money greedy.To play the game, you will have to pay monthly $15.If you want extra-retainers, you have to pay an extra amount monthly (like.. $2 or 3 per retainers per month)They barely offer anything to the players. (As mentionned earlier: Events are rare and you don't obviously get nice things every time.Most of time it's just some clothes. While in games like "Summoners War", they offer a lot of things you could get by paying, even tho the game is 100% free)They will make some cool stuffs, but you have to pay to get those.Emotes (/playdead ? $7!) Zantetsuken? $100!W- what? $100? How come?Riiight. Because you are forced to pay a status coming with the emote.You want some cat ears? You need to pay a $40 meh plushie.How much does that cost to server transfer? O-Oh.. $18 only. TeeheeThey already make so much money, refuse (most of time) to listen to community and will still makelots of things paying exclusive.Errr.. Okay. :X¯\_(ツ)_/¯ It is saddening. Well, I think I am done!While hoping that this game gets better in future with the in coming extension!It is a bit long, but I tried my best to make it fast without getting in details.As I said, there is A LOT of things to talk about, for that game! ^^'Also, don't mind my English. I am French. I'm aware it is not the best! X.XThank you for reading!

												Final Fantasy 14 is "THE" true MMO expereince of the part few years. 												AwesomeWhat took me in was the Job system, no alts no multiple accounts just one character and you can have any class you want anytime you want, want to play tank just equip your tank item set it's as easy as clicking one button (its how the sets work, u equip item create job item set with one click and now you can even put shortcut button on your quickbar for easy access)Entertaining combat system sucked me in, each class/job has its own thing and its own twist on basic gameplay, Ninjas have mudras (like in Naruto, you combine three signs and cast skill that comes from this combination), Monks are position based so you want to move around a lot attack from flank and from the back, and they get faster and stronger the longer fight lasts, Dark Kinghts are aggresive tanks that use loads of mana, overally its great.Now quest design...that is probably the weekest part, quests are mundane and often totally boring, like go to dude "a" and take fish from him, bring that fish to dude "b" who gives you fish stew, now you have to run to dud "a" and give him a stew so he will send you to his 3 soldiers that need the stew.But loads of content, tens of dungeons, tens of trials and boss battles all easilly accesible via  "duty finder" tool make it hard to get bored.If You like MMO's you cang go wrong with this one.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Hello everyone!So after about 150 hours in the game I decided to write my very first Steam review. I want to mention that I have not yet experienced the "engame" of the game. I've been leveling a few classes (as in every MMO i try out lots of different classes before actually leveling one to max-level.  If you are looking for a review of the endgame, this is not it. So far I played White Mage, Paladin and Ninja. What I like about the game  Classes  Nice classes with interesting combos/mechanics.All classes playable by the same character (you can switch to the different classes without creating a new character). Style Beautiful spell effects.Nice monster, weapon and armor design. Mechanics Very good transportation ingame. Once you have visited the different zones and activated the crystal there you can teleport to that crystal for a small fee.Chocobo mounts! These can actually be leveled and fight alongside you, tank for you and can even heal you!Customizable interface. You can move around anything you see and decide how big or small you want it to be. Community Very friendly community. I know that this is not necessarily because of the game but I feel it should be mentioned. I played a number of MMOs before but this has to be by far the nicest community I've seen in an MMO. What I think could be improved  Map  The map takes a bit getting used to. Sometimes it is hard to see where you have to go for a quest that spans across different zones. Abilities  Depending on the class there is a bit of button bloat. Some classes get very niche spells that rarely get used. Leveling  Once you leveled up a few classes you might start to run out of quests. This is because you still have to level the other classes up but can only complete each quest once. So if you did them all while leveling your first few classes you might end up having no quests later on. Luckily you can do FATEs (similar to the events in Guild Wars 2 for example) and repeatable Levequests to level up. Level Sync  The game has a level sync system that lets you do lower level content and still earn experience. This is a nice feature, but I still put it here as I think it could be improved. Let's take my Ninja for example: You get a very nice mechanic at level 30 that lets you combine different hand signs to cast a Ninjutsu. This is when the class starts to get really interesting because different combinations will let you cast very different spells. Now if you would enter a Dungeon that is for level 20 characters the game will de-level you to that level. This means that you will not have access to spells over level 20. In the case of the Ninja this will lead to very boring gameplay. Conclusion So far the game really impressed me. I played a few MMOs before but the style and gameplay of Final Fantasy XIV really drew me in. I recommend you at the very least try out the free trial.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Well what can I say that hasn't been said yet. ALOT is good about this game. Just a few things are bad. FFXIV has got quite a fun endgame after you finish the main story line. I keep returning to it. I'm level 60 for ages now, but there is so much to do. Mainly gear progression for me. Which is grindy but not to much. There are different endgame options for different kind of people too. For example you can get 'relic/anima weapons' which are end tier weapons. These can be gained purely by grinding-like mechanics. But there are gear and weapons you get by doing dungeons and making sure you get your weekly cap of 'X-currency' (tomestones). There is also hardcore raid gear to be gotten, for the peeps who are more serious in doing the hardest raids. I'm not much of a hardcore 'savage difficulty' raider. Not doing them isn't handicapping me in a huge way either.Just a few cons about the game for me:Story quests are dreadfully boring at some times. Storyline quests shouldn't involve 'fetch this or that' or 'talk 10x times to citizens around town' quests.. This get's WAY better after 3.0 though and I truly hope, for new players, they remove/alter some earlier quests. Because otherwise you will get a habit of skipping thru half of the stuff you have to read.I miss an immersive feeling with this world. This is because the whole 'world map' consists of multiple 'instanced' area's. Which do have loading screens in between. It's something that will probably never change. I accept it now but it took me a while. Most area's are very beautiful though!And I really miss oldschool FF prerendered absolutly astonishing cutscenes! There are a few, but I want more! :PAll in all, the game feels very relaxed and has a good balance between difficulty levels. It's a game for everyone, but will take a lot of your time :)

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I'm blown away by this game and everything that comes with it. The visuals, audio, gameplay, writing, events, community,  and merchandise are all top-notch. It even has controller support and is cross-platform; something you nearly never see done well, especially in MMORPGs.Every sidequest has a unique story with meaningful dialogue, and the game is full of cutscenes if you like believable worlds. For those of you who just want to get to the gameplay, everything can be skipped and viewed at another time. If you end up loving the game, there are free desktop/mobile wallpapers and ringtones; as well as tons of high quality merchandise.There is a subscription fee to pay of course, the cheapest being £7.69/€10.99/$12.99 for 30 days. The basic subscription only allows 1 character per server, but this doesn't matter as characters are not limited in what they can learn. It is entirely possible to max out every class on one character if you have the patience.There is nothing negative I can say about this game, it's perfect in my eyes. Download the demo and give it a shot, it might not be for everyone but it certainly does it for me. Oh, and if you still aren't sure; go look at some game art, listen to the soundtrack and watch some gameplay. The passion of the team behind this game speaks for itself.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												*tagged as a Drunk Review*MMOs are incredibly hard to review.They require a very different consumption model than the one which follows any other game constuct.As having almost 4000 hours played would imply, I have a deep invesment into the game if, anything, to prove that I have not wasted over three months of my life playing it.But it is far more enjoyable than any MMO I have played in the last 10 years.Being able to play one character who can level anything? Godsdamned priceless.A crafting system that (before Heaven's Ward) rewarded multiclassing? Superb.Gathering that is wholly necessary to advance crafting returns? Essential to a proper balance of skills and classes.A variety of class roles and requirements, wholly integral to endgame content? Fascinating and complicated.This is the MMO that brought me back after nearly 7 years of exile from WoW.Enjoy it, love it, find solace in the various game design decisions that benefit the solo player and bring so many options to the multi-player.But don't get too invested in PvP. It is an afterthought that, while moderately balanced, is not nearly as fun and intuitive as the rest of the game is,Lula Moon, Faerie server, Lv51+ in every job/class available.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												There is so much things to say about Final Fantasy XIV that I will try to make it fast!Even though I am upvotting this game (because of my 2078hrs+ and because I have hope that they make this game better in future), I do not recommend this game to every kind of players!It would only depends on how patient can you be!Let's get started!--- GRAPHICS ---+ Pros:- The graphics are decent,you do not need a strongcomputer to run the game!- Some areas can look wonderful- You can run the game with a PS3 as well! (Soon to be removed, though.)- Cons:- Some maps (especially Heavensward's one) can look terrifyingly uggly. ><- Aion (I did not played very much but enough) looks better and it is Free to Play (while this game is money greedy but  I'll talk about that later!)- Your character can't be uggly (if you ever wanted to make a hideous character, it'll be complicated)--- Gameplay ---+ Pros:- You can switch classes any time you want- Past-level 30 you can unlock your class's job- Different gameplays for every classes (Also for crafting / gathering classes!)- Cons:- Gameplay is poor: You have to use a spell to sprint, you don't have access to double jumps or anything original!- There is a lot of invisible walls which is pretty frustrating- Classes gameplay can be repetitive (Many spells are identical. For example, every tank classes has a few %dmg reduced spell for a certain amount of time)- Too long cast-time for caster classes- Dungeons are super slow and most of them are pretty boring to play--- END GAME CONTENT ---Oh boi, I feel like I might put a lot of down sides to it <.< (I don't know what I will type in advance)+ Pros:- Release patches with some content. (About each 3 months I think?)- Cons:- Farming MONTHS to get scripted items. You don't get to make a original <build> to your character since you willbe told what to buy by the system.- Always the same (and continuously) patches: A bit more of MSQ, 1 or 2 dungeons, 1 raid, 1 trial.- Farming but for what? In fact, there is ABSOLUTELY NO POINT to get the highest items.It won't be usefull. If you go in a low level dungeon to help someone, your level and stats are syncced.PvP is a 4V4 team or 8V8. There is also another one with bigger amount.But once again, STATS syncced!There is legit no point to farm. This is my biggest reproach to the game.- If you don't have anything to do, you can level up every other classes max. But it's repetitive. <.<;;Otherwise, you can do their events:It'd be like a small 30 mins story for christmas / or / halloween or other moments.To either get a emote, or -most of time- uggly clothes.Nothing really exciting. Sometimes you'll get 1 event per month, sometime nothing for 3 months!--- Scenario ---(You will discover soon enough in the game that you are not just a normal person and that you have "special" powers making you stronger than most people. You will be siding with < the good people > to protect it from < the bad people >)+ Pros:- Original story, making you look like a badass in cutscenes- Lots of cutscenes!- Cons:- Lots of filling quests, it's pretty annoying!- In Heavensward, they will repeat over and over some stupid things about being in war since 1000 years. But like, VERY oftenly. Ruinning the immersion <.<;;- There is a voiced cutscenes, but then, out of a sudden, no more voiced cutscenes for a while. - You have to clic on voiced cutscenes to continue the dialogue/cutscene making it frustrating when you want to see it kind of like a movie <.>--- Social aspect ---If you are, like me, a League Of Legends player and can't stand the community,you will probably enjoy some of Final Fantasy XIV's servers because the community in game can bepretty open-minded and nice to you! It is one of the reason I like this game and still play it.Plus, the game is good enough to make some cool FFXIV content on YouTube.Growing a community from FFXIV is probably the best since you'll see many nice and open-minded peoplewhile if you play League Of Legends, their players would probably say things like "you suck i'm a better [character's name] than you!"--- THE COMPANY (SquareEnix) ---This is probably the biggest down side of that game.Square Enix is INSANELY money greedy.To play the game, you will have to pay monthly $15.If you want extra-retainers, you have to pay an extra amount monthly (like.. $2 or 3 per retainers per month)They barely offer anything to the players. (As mentionned earlier: Events are rare and you don't obviously get nice things every time.Most of time it's just some clothes. While in games like "Summoners War", they offer a lot of things you could get by paying, even tho the game is 100% free)They will make some cool stuffs, but you have to pay to get those.Emotes (/playdead ? $7!) Zantetsuken? $100!W- what? $100? How come?Riiight. Because you are forced to pay a status coming with the emote.You want some cat ears? You need to pay a $40 meh plushie.How much does that cost to server transfer? O-Oh.. $18 only. TeeheeThey already make so much money, refuse (most of time) to listen to community and will still makelots of things paying exclusive.Errr.. Okay. :X¯\_(ツ)_/¯ It is saddening. Well, I think I am done!While hoping that this game gets better in future with the in coming extension!It is a bit long, but I tried my best to make it fast without getting in details.As I said, there is A LOT of things to talk about, for that game! ^^'Also, don't mind my English. I am French. I'm aware it is not the best! X.XThank you for reading!

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												Though I no longer play, I guess this deserves a review with the time I put in.PROS:* The storyline and cutscenes are every bit as good as any other Final Fantasy, even though your main character is generically referred to as the "Warrior of Light." The characters surrounding the story have their own arcs, all of which are interesting, especially in the expansion. Tasteful bits of humor, throwbacks to previous games, and a generally well-put-together campaign make for a game that will have you playing well into the night and early morning. * Beautiful and varied environments, great animations, UI leaves little to be desired, everything visually (and functionally) has that polish you'd expect from Final Fantasy. Also, it might just be my rig--it's decent but not amazing--but I almost always floated around 60fps unless I had my camera on a heavily saturated marketplace.* Plays amazingly well with a controller for an MMO with a decent amount of moves for every class. Granted, I think this was meant for PS3 first anyway, but still, it optimizes perfectly with a PC/XBox controller.* Very few "tank and spank" boss fights, though most of them aren't very hard if you just know where to stand. 99% of charged boss attacks have visual callouts on the ground, the other 1% only have the charging bar. Still, there's almost always something interactive to keep every party member on their toes.* As usual, the venerable Nobuo Uematsu among other composers make some amazing tracks, many of them experimental. There *will* be times where you enter a dungeon group for the first time and thirty seconds in you're like "damn, this song is good." Or you might think "damn, this doesn't seem like it belongs in a Final Fantasy game, but I like it!" OST is awesome, long story short.* Very flexible visual customization for your character.* Class system is a bit restrictive, at first. Mechanically, there is almost no difference between those of the same class, but with all the tools every class has available, there's a lot of ways *to* play them. It's like instead of having to choose what you do all the time, it's about adapting to the situation. For example, most classes have some sort of "toggle" ability that switches up their function, such as tanks being able to turn off/on their aggro generation to deal more damage, healers switching from doing slightly less healing to more damage, or black mages alternating between fire/blizzard to drain/regain mana at will.*** For a more specific and personal example, I played almost exclusively Dark Knight when I FINALLY got it, and prioritized my gear 3 different ways: pure tank, pure DPS, and off-tank (a combination). Since tanks can freely turn off their respective tanky moves, and it's not particularly hard to get a lead on threat (protip: there's a built-in aggro meter), I would usually go with my slightly higher damage setup and gauge how well the healer can keep up versus how much threat I've got. And since turning off Grit (DRK tanky toggle) allows for the use of Blood Weapon (bonus attack speed/cooldown reduction), the damage alone usually still kept my threat up to speed. I would usually save my tanky cooldowns for that switch to compensate and ease the healer into it.NEUTRAL:* The voice acting is good, but completely changed in the expansion for ALL characters, mostly for the better... mostly. There's some spotty acting in both OG and HW, but what really didn't make sense for me was Tataru's voice in Heavensward. We go from a tiny, cartoony female voice befitting a tiny, cartoony character, to what sounds like a British woman in her mid-thirties. Was very jarring to hear the first time and every time throughout.* Some dungeons can be looooong, making grinding for a specific item or simply for experience a massive undertaking. The combat is fun enough to make it not feel grindy though.* Gathering, however, is grindy, but overall profitable since a lot of people who already have money don't wanna do it. It's only really hard to level when multiple people are in the only spot you can reliably skill-up at the level you're at.* Triple Triad is back, and as much as I love it, I hate the way they implemented card restrictions. Until you've collected a certain number of unique cards, you're limited in how you can construct your deck based on the rating of the cards (i.e. at the start you can only have one 3* and four 2*s, rank up for one 4* and four 3*, then a 5* and 4*s). I guess they were encouraging you to have to look up where you can find unique cards or something, because you have no way of knowing what cards can be dropped from NPCs you beat.I thoroughly enjoyed my time playing this game, and recommend it to any MMO fan, Final Fantasy or not. The only negative thing about it is, well, endgame is kind of repetitive. Once I was done with pretty much everything, got all the gear I wanted that I didn't wanna grind the rest of my life for, I just spent my time helping people in my free company with quests and leveling. That in itself is rewarding, so find yourself a good FC and have fun!

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Basically, best mmorpg I've ever seen.The shared cold down time is a pain, however, the endgame content somehow fixed that. I did not find it too uncomfortable when I do my raids and trials, so I would say that system is actually not that bad.The choice on different jobs on one single character is really good system. I've been so tired to lvl again and do the main story again and again to get a new job. Although the lvling for jobs after the first job is really painful, I prefer that than watch the same story again and again.The gathering and crafting for me, is the best design in this game. I am not a hardcore player, so when I feel tired on doing my raids, I usually just go fishing or something else. It left the choice for player not only to fight, but somehow live in this game world. Furthermore, the Gold Saucer is also another way to take a rest. I think ff14 really provide player anothe world to live in, not only a tons of boss to kill.I do not pvp a lot, and I never liked pvp before, so I cannot tell anything about the pvp system.At last, my grading for this game is 95/100, I hope you would give this game a try after read my review. :)

content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												Im only a couple hundred hours in, but I feel that I have enough experience in the game to write a review about it.   Good graphics, at least for an MMO, good mechanics, good story.   Lots and lots of things to do, never a lack of content, and there is a new expansion that has been announced recently.   There is mount collecting, minion collecting, dozens of dungeons, many trials, plenty of raiding, seasonal events, I mean you name it.   One of the very biggest strong points of this game however is that you can play ALL the classes on a single character. (There are 13 different classes, more will arrive with the new expansion.) Not only that, but there are several jobs/ crafting classes that your character can be as well, at least seven that I know of.   As for the world size, there are currently 30 zones throughout the game at this time, there are a couple zones that are a little smaller than others, but for the most part the zones are of very good size and if you enjoy larger worlds than this will scratch at least some of this itch. You will not feel like the world is small. (Even if youve played WoW for years and are trying this for the first time.)   Good, helpful community, some people are jerks, but there are some in every crowd.   There is lots of room for hardcore and casual players, or those that are both, and furthermore, if you like a game where you can solo a lot of content, this game scratches that itch as well.   I hope this review helps.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												Though I no longer play, I guess this deserves a review with the time I put in.PROS:* The storyline and cutscenes are every bit as good as any other Final Fantasy, even though your main character is generically referred to as the "Warrior of Light." The characters surrounding the story have their own arcs, all of which are interesting, especially in the expansion. Tasteful bits of humor, throwbacks to previous games, and a generally well-put-together campaign make for a game that will have you playing well into the night and early morning. * Beautiful and varied environments, great animations, UI leaves little to be desired, everything visually (and functionally) has that polish you'd expect from Final Fantasy. Also, it might just be my rig--it's decent but not amazing--but I almost always floated around 60fps unless I had my camera on a heavily saturated marketplace.* Plays amazingly well with a controller for an MMO with a decent amount of moves for every class. Granted, I think this was meant for PS3 first anyway, but still, it optimizes perfectly with a PC/XBox controller.* Very few "tank and spank" boss fights, though most of them aren't very hard if you just know where to stand. 99% of charged boss attacks have visual callouts on the ground, the other 1% only have the charging bar. Still, there's almost always something interactive to keep every party member on their toes.* As usual, the venerable Nobuo Uematsu among other composers make some amazing tracks, many of them experimental. There *will* be times where you enter a dungeon group for the first time and thirty seconds in you're like "damn, this song is good." Or you might think "damn, this doesn't seem like it belongs in a Final Fantasy game, but I like it!" OST is awesome, long story short.* Very flexible visual customization for your character.* Class system is a bit restrictive, at first. Mechanically, there is almost no difference between those of the same class, but with all the tools every class has available, there's a lot of ways *to* play them. It's like instead of having to choose what you do all the time, it's about adapting to the situation. For example, most classes have some sort of "toggle" ability that switches up their function, such as tanks being able to turn off/on their aggro generation to deal more damage, healers switching from doing slightly less healing to more damage, or black mages alternating between fire/blizzard to drain/regain mana at will.*** For a more specific and personal example, I played almost exclusively Dark Knight when I FINALLY got it, and prioritized my gear 3 different ways: pure tank, pure DPS, and off-tank (a combination). Since tanks can freely turn off their respective tanky moves, and it's not particularly hard to get a lead on threat (protip: there's a built-in aggro meter), I would usually go with my slightly higher damage setup and gauge how well the healer can keep up versus how much threat I've got. And since turning off Grit (DRK tanky toggle) allows for the use of Blood Weapon (bonus attack speed/cooldown reduction), the damage alone usually still kept my threat up to speed. I would usually save my tanky cooldowns for that switch to compensate and ease the healer into it.NEUTRAL:* The voice acting is good, but completely changed in the expansion for ALL characters, mostly for the better... mostly. There's some spotty acting in both OG and HW, but what really didn't make sense for me was Tataru's voice in Heavensward. We go from a tiny, cartoony female voice befitting a tiny, cartoony character, to what sounds like a British woman in her mid-thirties. Was very jarring to hear the first time and every time throughout.* Some dungeons can be looooong, making grinding for a specific item or simply for experience a massive undertaking. The combat is fun enough to make it not feel grindy though.* Gathering, however, is grindy, but overall profitable since a lot of people who already have money don't wanna do it. It's only really hard to level when multiple people are in the only spot you can reliably skill-up at the level you're at.* Triple Triad is back, and as much as I love it, I hate the way they implemented card restrictions. Until you've collected a certain number of unique cards, you're limited in how you can construct your deck based on the rating of the cards (i.e. at the start you can only have one 3* and four 2*s, rank up for one 4* and four 3*, then a 5* and 4*s). I guess they were encouraging you to have to look up where you can find unique cards or something, because you have no way of knowing what cards can be dropped from NPCs you beat.I thoroughly enjoyed my time playing this game, and recommend it to any MMO fan, Final Fantasy or not. The only negative thing about it is, well, endgame is kind of repetitive. Once I was done with pretty much everything, got all the gear I wanted that I didn't wanna grind the rest of my life for, I just spent my time helping people in my free company with quests and leveling. That in itself is rewarding, so find yourself a good FC and have fun!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I've played WoW on and off for years, and I've also played Guild Wars and Guild Wars 2, and dabbled with WildStar and numerous other MMOs. After all my expierenes with MMOs, Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is my favorite, and it's the game that made me stop playing WoW.The first thing you'll notice when you launch the game is just how gorgeous the world of Eorzea is. Gameplay wise, the combat is interactive enough; it may not be as involved as a game like WildStar, but you're constantly using skills and dodging attacks which makes it very entertaining. The main story is interesting, and is full of likeable characters. The voice acting is pretty good for the most part, I haven't encountered anything that really stood out as bad like a Jill sandwhich.As much as I do love this game, I still have some criticism (since after all, nothing is perfect). The most glaring issue is the slow pacing players will encounter at the start. It can easily turn new players off of the game as they will be bombarded with meaningless "go there, talk to person X, go back to quest giver, get reward" type quests, and getting those out of the way before you get to the combat is pretty boring (though you do have the option to skip those and go straight to the combat quests right away).The ability to have access to every class in the game on a single character removes the need for alts, and is neccessary for the job system within the game. Jobs are essentially advancements of a class, and require class A (the class that is being advanced) to be level 30, while having a specific class, class B, be at level 15. This allows you to have new abilities, and access to job specific quests form levels 30-50 (60 with the Heavensward expansion), each with their own story, much like the class quests that you'd encounter from levels 1-30. The only gripe I have with the ability to change classes on your character, is the lack of quests in the game. Since you'll eventually run out of quests to do to get XP, you'll end up doing the same dungeons, FATEs, and levequests repeatedly, which can get dull.Overall this is a great game, and well worth the subscription price in my opinion (there are two subscription models available: Standard $15 a month with no restrictions, and the Entry level for $13 a month which limits you to one character per world). It's a good game for Final Fantasy fans and non fans alike, though fans of the series will probably get a bit more enjoyment out of it due to the bits of (non-intrusive) fanservice sprinkled in.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Alright, I think this game is amazing! I would only recomend it to players who like MMO and don't mind having an incredibly slow start (as well as the 15 dollars per month payment).There is really one major downside to this game that I can think of, and that's the amount of money you pay. 20 Dollars for the base game, 40 Dollars for the expansion, and then another 15 dollars every month. It's definitely gonna drain your pockets at first but let me tell you I think it is worth it.This game is similar to WoW, but improves upon it in many ways, definitely showing WoW's age.- Downscaling levels for earlier dungeons/raids: If you are level 50, and you want to do a level 20 dungeon in a queue like you originally did it, back when you WERE level 20 - 24, you CAN. Not only does it dowscale your gear and character, you can ONLY play with the abilities you had unlocked during that level and previously. It allows you to enjoy every part of the game that you enjoyed previously, again!- Tons of PvE content! If you're a PvE player this game is 100% for you. Tons of dungeons from level 15 to 50 (60 if you buy the expansion). Guildhests from level 15 to 40! (it's ether 15 or 20). 24 man raids at level 50 and level 60. Main scenario dungeons (I think they're still considered raids, they're 8 man dungeons). Trials from level 19 to 60. And more!- PLAYER HOUSING. This is a thing in this game. The downside about this, though, is that a lot of the plots are taken. It's very hard to find a house that you can buy, and even then it takes a couple million gil to actually afford it. But once you do you can decorate it ANYWAY you want!Personally, I don't really find many flaws with this game. The Global Cooldown can be annoying, and the main story quests can be tedious, but the story of the game itself is amazing you KEEP wanting to do the MSQ. I definitely recommend this game for anyone willing to try out a new MMO, check out the free trial and see if you like it.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												So after almost putting 1000 hours into the game, here is the lay down. - First MMO that I've actually put effort into.- Easy to get into and the EXP curve is not harsh. (Doing the main quest alone, with some side quest and you can reach the Level limit no problem) (Leveling up other classes though takes time)- I'm enjoying the story, as do many others, though if you don't want to, it is all skippable.- You only need to make one character because that one character can be any-class as you can switch on the fly. First you must get to level 15 to one of the classes then you can switch to whatever else you want if you don't feel like it suits your role you want to be. Or you can be like me and level up all the classes. (I main Monk)- Want to just be a crafter? There is that too and they make money (gil persay) if you join a good FC willing to support the mats (materials you need).- End-game content is very captivating if you want to raid. There are many raid groups always looking to fill spots if that is what you seek. It is enjoyable and worthwhile. Trust me, it takes a lot of wipes (sometimes one or if your raid team is excellent, only one try), but its feel good.- Great community- Square Enix will not disappoint. They always have something awesome planned for this.- Heavensward Expansion!Would highly recommend trying it out first. It might not be for everyone, but if you like Final Fantasy (and this game as soo many tibbits to its other titles, ex. Void Ark (FF5) , Crystal Tower (FF3), Gilgamesh, and others), you will enjoy this MMO.June, 14th, 2016 Update.So with the Heavensward Expansion out and it being on the current patch of 3.3 at this time, I just want to give an update. My review still stands as is and its still a really good MMO, with Square Enix staying on top of it. Content is plenty, with still more to come and is even more newer player friendly then ever.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn and Heavensward, a great game if you invest the time into it.  I began my Journey into Final Fantasy XIV a while ago, now with over 300+ hours invested, I feel that I can finally leave a decent review.  Final Fantasy has a bit of everything for everyone.  If you prefer to hang out with friends, make new friends, forge relationships, and become a leader....you can do that.  If you prefer to play alone and do your own thing, you can do that as well.  This is a monthly subscription based game and you have 2 membership levels that you can decide upon.  A $12 rank that allows only one character per server or a $15 rank where you can have multiple characters on multiple servers.  I choose the $12 rank as I only play as one character on one server.  The one character that you create is really all that you need.  You can be every class and hold every job as your own character.  If you would like to Tank, DPS, or Heal....you can do all of that by simply switching classes.  Need to apply materia? Need to chop a tree? or Need to make armor? Switch to the correct Job class and fire away.  The only thing that it will cost you is time.  You have to level up each class and job in order to become stronger and sell better items.  Money or Gil as called in game is needed but not necessarily a huge focal point in Final Fantasy XIV,  Gil will allow you to make purchases off of the Market Board (AKA Auction House for you WoW fans), purchase armor, weapons, and you will need some Gil to repair your gear.  Gear will erode after battling for some time and you also have to pay to transport to other areas.  Fighting is pretty straight forward.  Research your rotation for you class, stay out of attack circles, and make sure you attack whatever the tank is attacking while in Dungeon, Raid, or Guildquests.  Leveling up is fairly balanced and there are Levequests that you can obtain in areas to help you level up further and faster.  FC's (Free Companies) are the "Guilds" in Final Fantasy XIV.  It's worth finding a FC that you connect with.  This can save you time in que waiting on people for dungeons/raids/guildquests.  FC's also add a bit of entertainment value and comraderie.  You can make friends and hang out at the Free Company houses located in various safe zones.  All in all I recommend Final Fantasy if you're a fan or a MMORPG enthusiest.  The game is fairly balanced, constantly updated and a refreshing escape from World of Warcraft. Being able to play with a controller is a plus in book as well.  If you find yourself interested, I hope the information I've provided has been helpful and I hope to see you in the game!

												Having played World of Warcraft on and off for the better part of a decade, I can say that this game (even with its similarities) is a refreshing change to the fast paced job that wow seems to have become. Final Fantasy XIV has a very epic and engaging story, not often seen in MMORPGs. Buying Final Fantasy XIV will also come with 30 days free so for $20 its worth giving it a shot, if anything just for the story!

content:
Posted: February 18
												It's kinda hard to write a review on a game with such  a huge amount of content, however, from my experience so far I feel the best way to descibe Final fantasy XIV is it's like one long epic journey through the Final Fantasy history.Some of the best locations, mini games and lore from the franchise all feature in one of best and most thoroughly polished MMO's available. The soundtrack and sound design in FF XIV is just incredible, a particular favorite of mine is the Black Shroud area which has a Secret Of Mana vibe to it but for those who remember Vagrant Story will also drew comparisions.FF XIV is also far more accessable than other MMO's and with the abilities to enjoy every single class within the game on a single character means you don't have to worry about commiting to the unlikable play style when you first begin.The only downside for me is the lack of voice acting and no doubt some would be put off by the subscription fees but when the updates are as big as they are and the quality is as high as it is I find it perfectly reasonable.I'll most likely update my review as I make more progress but for anyone who enjoys MMO's or is fond of the Final Fantasy universe, this is definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												This is easily the best MMO I've played in years. The graphics are beautiful, the character creation is very in-depth, and it actually feels like you're involved in the combat instead of just sitting there tapping buttons until you fall asleep. The crafting system is unique and fun (albeit frustrating sometimes), too. If you get bored of questing, dungeoning, and crafting, you can go play games and race chocobos at the Golden Saucer, if you're so inclined. You'll never run out of things to do in this game.And if you're a roleplayer like me, Balmung has a huge and varied roleplay community--you're more than likely to find what you're looking for, no matter what your RP style is.The only thing I don't like about the game is the character creation restrictions. If a server is overpopulated, you can't make a new character on it, and have to wait until the populated is a bit lower, which is usually really early in the morning (if you're in America). This is a huge problem on Balmumg, which really stinks if you're looking for an RP server. Other than that, though, this game is great and totally worth the $15 a month.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												Bought this months ago for $10.  Of all the MMORPGs I've played, this is the only paid one that I like.  I've only played free-to-play MMORPGS up to this point.  Shares some similarities with WoW, but is much better looking.  Main storyline is enjoyable in parts.  Quests are like you'd expect from an MMORPG, but not as taxing (instead of 'go kill 20 of this enemy', it's 'go kill 5, then talk to two NPCs')  Community is welcoming and helpful.  And if happen to be into role-playing, there's a vibrant community of that in here, as well.Kinda wish the Heavensward DLC wasn't silly expensive, tho.  Its next DLC, Stormblood, is coming next year, I think.FYI, monthly fee required.  If you want just one character per server, it's $12.99 USD ($17-ish CND).  If you want up to 8 characters per server, about $15-$16 USD (well past $20 CND)I'm on the Balmung server under the IGN Krick Etune.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												I've played this game for about 3 days now, and it's absolutely amazing. Please note these are my own personal opinions on the game, and I still have a large majority of the game to uncover.Pros-Breathtaking graphics.-Skill animations.-Roleplaying.-Replayability.-Story.-Inventory-Sountrack-Armor/MountsGraphics - Absolutely wonderful, especially for what is coming up to be a 5 year old game.Skill animations - Nice, fluid, look awesome; very eye appealing.Roleplaying - A large of roleplaying can be had in this game, especially with the requirement of a Forename and a Surname.Replayability - Literally 20+ classes you can all level up on one character and switch between, really awesome idea that works amazingly.Story - Super in-depth, and really worth-while taking your time on your first playthrough to explore the world.Inventory - Literally THE best inventory system I've ever seen in any game. Seperate inventories (literally 20+ slots) for every armor piece, then another 100 for junk/misc, and ANOTHER for quest items.Soundtrack - Beautiful sountrack from Square Enix, as is to be expected.Armor/Mounts - THE best plate armor I've ever seen, weapon designs make sense, along with some armor. Mounts look cool as ♥♥♥♥ as well. Great amount of custimization.Cons-Global Skillcooldown-Confusing at first-Map system-Teleportation is a bit odd-Learning curve-Voiceovers-Tab targetingSkillcooldowns - After every cast, whether instant or a 2-3 sec. cast time, you have a set amount of time before you are able to do another action. Feels a bit awkward at first, and still does right now, but something I disliked.Confusion - Game throws you in, no ♥♥♥♥s given, and it can be a bit overwhelming, take things one at a time and it'll get good.Map system - Feels clunky to use, hard to tell where some locations (i.e. exits, towns, quests) are.Teleportation - Teleporting feels like it should be done at "Aetheryte Crystals" allowing you to go anywhere, but they limit you to zones. Teleportation is done as a skill and costs money, just feels weird and unexplainable.Learning Curve - Big learning curve, but once you get over it, it's very rewarding.Voiceovers - Some of the most random cutscenes have voice overs, and ones that feel detrimental to the storyline have none. Just feels weird at times; inconsistent.Tab targeting - Tab targeting SHOULD (in my opinion) be the closest monster towards you, and it isn't. I don't understand the mechanics and it can cause unnecessary aggro on monsters due to misclicks.TL;DR - Great game with a bit of a hard learning curve. Worthwhile in the end. Fat Chocobo/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												I bought his on steam just to review it. Currently sitting at around 5000 hours, this game still hasn't gotten stale. With a consistent update scedule (major patch every 3 months) it is absolutly worth the monthly fee. The game stays far away from P2W which the community has agree on, the only thing to purchase are cosmetic. (clothes for glamour, mounts ect.) While combat may feel a bit slow at lower levels, there is a huge curve to skill so both casuals and hardcores can enjoy the game thuroughly. Speaking of hardcore, if you are a raider this will challenge you more than most games can, with extremely well balanced savage mode raids.If you are a fan of Final Fantasy or MMOs as a whole do yourself a favour and pick it up. Level a character up to max level and dive into the amazing content. The community is one of the nicest, least toxic communities in MMOs (looking at you WoW).Enjoy! :)Edit: Do yourself a favour and buy this from the SE store, judging by all the negative experiences people have with the steam version. It also makes preordering expansions actually possible.
