number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Of all the MMOs I've  played, and I have played a good number of them, this is one that sticks out as the game that truly has kept me coming back for more after this much time.  On top of that, I've been playing MMOs for so long that I've played a good number of times with subs and non sub games and I sort of got burnt out on subbed games just because none of them seemed to keep my attention long enough to make the payment per month worth it.  In spite of that, FFXIV: ARR is one that I actually returned to even with a sub, because it is well worth the money.  More specifically, FFXIV is for one, a very beautiful game and although graphics alone cannot make a game great, it is a factor at least for me.  Even if a game has great gameplay without decent graphics I probably won't remain interested.  The opposite is true too but in the case of this game, it has good gameplay mechanics along with absolutely stunning graphics.  The stories, let's face it, many times a lot of mmo players skip through the dialog and story to get to more quests and level up fast and while I'll admit there is some of that with FFXIV, for the most part, I find myself interested in reading and enjoying the main story more than most other games of the same genre.  Aside from those things, the class system, the ability to learn multiple classes and the jobs are detailed and interesting enough to really make it stand out for me.  I love that the crafting isn't a simplifed style where it's just click and create like so many other mmos have done.  There is far more I can say about this game that I love but you get the gist of things I hope.  If you're an MMO fan, looking to try something new it is absolutely worth your time to at least give it a try.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Best P2P MMO I've played in recent years. Been a few months since I have played so this might not be completely accurate. Here are my positives (+) negatives (-) and neutrals (o).(+) All classes on one character, each levels individually, Mix and match (some) skills from one class to another. For example, if you plan to play a healer, "Swift Cast" from the offensive caster is absolutely required so you can revive people instantly.(+) This is the ultimate callback game for fans of the more classic Final Fantasy games, though you'll find a little bit from every game here. You probably don't need to be an FF fan to enjoy this, it stands up on its own mechanically. I would basically describe this game as "WoW done better."(+) Level scaling for Dungeons and FATES (Fates are over-world events that people can take part in as a community.) So no matter what level you are, you and your friends can play together. However, you cannot level scale on the overworld unless you're inside a FATE.(+) Party Finder. It works wonders, just queue up and do most anything else while you wait for a party to be automatically formed for a dungeon. You can also join overworld parties. Tanks and Healers will be matched quicker because they are not as commonly played, expect to wait if you are a DPS.(+) Glamour system, make any piece of equipment look like another. You can only unlock the ability to glamour at level 50, but people can do it for you before then. It IS possible to look like a classically colored Black Mage, if you have the currency for it.(+) Mechanically difficult and exhilarating bosses. Knowing how each dungeon and boss fight works before going in is essential to success. This is a double-edged sword, however, you could be stuck on a difficult fight, wiping multiple times with a pub party that doesn't know what they are doing. Sometimes it can get a bit too stressful, you'll always be on the razor's edge, late game. Different classes and roles are easier or harder to play, I wouldn't recommend rolling a tank for your first class. (+) Guilds, Guild Houses and Homes. I highly recommend finding a good guild, there are benefits to reap. Decorate your own Guild House, Personal House or Apartment Room inside your Guild House. You could make your own guild, but I recommend joining an existing one that has some legs and good community.(+) Chocobo Companions. Train a Chocobo to fight alongside you on the overworld, good for soloing. They can be mix-ups of Tank, Healer and DPS. Though the tank isn't all that good, last I heard.(+) Gold Saucer and Minigames! Gamble, collect cards and play tetra master across the world (love it or hate it), race Chocobos FF7 style, earn currency for rewards.(+) Retainers, get one of these as soon as you can, you get up to two for free. They act as your bank and you can send them out on missions to get items for you.(o) Crafting is still kind of a pain like most MMO's, you do not draw from resources directly from your bank like in GW2, so it's an inventory management headache, but there is money to be made and it's far from useless. Each crafting class works mostly the same, but each has some unique skills that can cross-class like combat classes do. Many of which are necessary. It's worth a try.(o) Arena and Mass-Scale PvP is available, though I can't comment on it since it's not my playstyle. EDIT: Recent update added 1v1 dueling.(-) Ability Icon Clutter, a carry-over from WoW. This can be mitigated with good macro building and UI customization management, though.(-) Main storyline isn't interesting until around level 50, which is max level before the expansion. Before that, there are some highlights, but it's mostly a slog through lots of political dialogue. Post vanilla is a vast improvement, though. Also, side story arcs are a lot better, for example, each class has its own story arc.(-) No cross-server play. If you have a max level character on one server, and your friend is on another, one of you will have to make a new character or pay money for a server transfer.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												Closest you're ever gonna get to a truly solid MMO experience.  I came from TERA, i promised myself i'd never play a game with tab-target again.  But here I am, 150+ hours,  While questing you'll spend a lot of time blazing through quests, and for the most part, I didn't feel bored by the story, the combat was engaging, and he quest themselves were decently written and weren't tedious to manage or complete; my only complaint is one must resort to FATES once they hit hit that point of "GOTTA GET TO 50 ASAP"Luckily endgame content in FF14 makes you work for your gear, but makes it easy to accomplish and is not a time sink (for the most part)One can attempt to hunt monsters with a full 8-man raid, along with many other raids to get specific currency to obtain that gear, and it takes a good 5 hours to get all that currency for decent gear to PREPARE for endgame content.  Once you're properly equipped you start facing many challenges that do take skill in your class, and communication with your party to accomplish, such as Hard Mode versions of boss fights in the story mode whilst you were leveling.  The main thing to note about this game is that it is very hard to NOT suck at your class, every class is incredibly unique, espcially when one is allowed to get a job (Specializing in that class role) but the game makes it very easy and simple to do a specific role without much screw ups, levels 1-49 preapre you with very brief 30-40 minute dungeons that give you a proper conditioning to be a healer, tank or get a sense of your DPS rotation, so you won't get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you when you first start out.Free Company's are FF14RR's guild system, and it not only serves as your help hotline, it serves as your home as well... literally, FC's are allowed to acquire houses for all their members for a small payment of... 2 million gil.... >.>  and 10mil if you want a swag pad, FC's in turn give you plenty of leveling bonuses for new players, and the more new players do FATE's, the FC in-turn ranks up in their residing Grand Company of 3 Grand Companies.  Get this game, it's a full package, engaging story, plenty of customization (More hairstyles when you're lvl 20 C:), and traditional but SOLID gameplay.  You won't be dissapointed if you love MMO's.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Of all the MMOs I've  played, and I have played a good number of them, this is one that sticks out as the game that truly has kept me coming back for more after this much time.  On top of that, I've been playing MMOs for so long that I've played a good number of times with subs and non sub games and I sort of got burnt out on subbed games just because none of them seemed to keep my attention long enough to make the payment per month worth it.  In spite of that, FFXIV: ARR is one that I actually returned to even with a sub, because it is well worth the money.  More specifically, FFXIV is for one, a very beautiful game and although graphics alone cannot make a game great, it is a factor at least for me.  Even if a game has great gameplay without decent graphics I probably won't remain interested.  The opposite is true too but in the case of this game, it has good gameplay mechanics along with absolutely stunning graphics.  The stories, let's face it, many times a lot of mmo players skip through the dialog and story to get to more quests and level up fast and while I'll admit there is some of that with FFXIV, for the most part, I find myself interested in reading and enjoying the main story more than most other games of the same genre.  Aside from those things, the class system, the ability to learn multiple classes and the jobs are detailed and interesting enough to really make it stand out for me.  I love that the crafting isn't a simplifed style where it's just click and create like so many other mmos have done.  There is far more I can say about this game that I love but you get the gist of things I hope.  If you're an MMO fan, looking to try something new it is absolutely worth your time to at least give it a try.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Best P2P MMO I've played in recent years. Been a few months since I have played so this might not be completely accurate. Here are my positives (+) negatives (-) and neutrals (o).(+) All classes on one character, each levels individually, Mix and match (some) skills from one class to another. For example, if you plan to play a healer, "Swift Cast" from the offensive caster is absolutely required so you can revive people instantly.(+) This is the ultimate callback game for fans of the more classic Final Fantasy games, though you'll find a little bit from every game here. You probably don't need to be an FF fan to enjoy this, it stands up on its own mechanically. I would basically describe this game as "WoW done better."(+) Level scaling for Dungeons and FATES (Fates are over-world events that people can take part in as a community.) So no matter what level you are, you and your friends can play together. However, you cannot level scale on the overworld unless you're inside a FATE.(+) Party Finder. It works wonders, just queue up and do most anything else while you wait for a party to be automatically formed for a dungeon. You can also join overworld parties. Tanks and Healers will be matched quicker because they are not as commonly played, expect to wait if you are a DPS.(+) Glamour system, make any piece of equipment look like another. You can only unlock the ability to glamour at level 50, but people can do it for you before then. It IS possible to look like a classically colored Black Mage, if you have the currency for it.(+) Mechanically difficult and exhilarating bosses. Knowing how each dungeon and boss fight works before going in is essential to success. This is a double-edged sword, however, you could be stuck on a difficult fight, wiping multiple times with a pub party that doesn't know what they are doing. Sometimes it can get a bit too stressful, you'll always be on the razor's edge, late game. Though the tank isn't all that good, last I heard.(+) Gold Saucer and Minigames! content:
Posted: February 16
												I have always been a fan of MMOs, from my early days of Star Wars Galaxies, City of Heroes/Villans, to Free to Play MMOs like Blade & Soul and Tera. For the longest time of my life i have been a stickler of pay to play MMOs in the current gaming age and I will tell you, as a guy who has played MMOs since he was about 12, THIS GAME IS WORTH THE SUBSCRIPTION! It has an engrossing story, worthy of a single player FF game, beautiful music, grand landscapes and plenty of things to do both solo and with friends and party members. Rarely will you meet anyone who can be considered a jackass until end game (which is currently level 60 with Heavensward) and the next expansion Stormblood is dropping in June. The combat can feel a little slow right now but SE says they are revamping it with Stormblood so we'll have to wait and see what it becomes. But, if you are looking to scratch that classic MMO itch, this game has 200+ hours worth of gameplay IN THE BASE GAME ALONE! NOT COUNTING HEAVENSWARD!!! If you are an MMO fan like I am, do yourself justice and give this game at least a try. There is a reason people hold this game in the same regard as WoW, it is the best MMORPG to release after WoW did, and that's saying something

												So let me start by saying I played this game on the ps3, and on the pc before it's launch on steam. - I'll start this review by saying the original concept was horrible... the game lacked so much and needed a complete overhaul. Well SquareEnix listened to the fans and brought in some familiar faces to help make this new Realm.So you create your character, the game has subscription, but it's definitely gorgeous and fun to play. The readded the summoner class which was my absolute favorite in Final Fantasy 11. You have a vast world to explore, to adventure in and the game is more suited for solo play along with parties. You can go do instances together, have a blast playing with friends or just even hanging around and chatting. Now there is some cons with this game.I don't like the instances as much in this game as i did in Final Fantasy 11. I also liked the auction house more in 11. I noticed there isn't any dlc for this game or if there is i didn't come across any. So im wondering if they are just updating the game like GuildWars2. So i will probably update this game more, but one of the biggest things i must mention is take advantage of the events they have. You get cool items and it's a very memorable experience.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Decided to update my review, just because I love this game so much + my last one didn't do it justice. Going to break the main points down, so it's easier to read.GAMEPLAY: Like most MMOs, you have the holy trinity of dps, healer and tanks. In this game they are divided into classes, which can further specialise into jobs. Cross class skills are used, so lets say I'm a White Mage at level 60, I can use cross class to access some skills from other classes/jobs I've leveled. Classes/Jobs are also handled differently. Your character can switch between any of the classes/jobs as they get unlocked, allowing you to completely change your playstyle should you choose to in the future. There's even classes like Fishing, Blacksmithing or Alchemist if you want to work the markets, or help your Free Company build an airship! Gameplay is like most MMOS, except it can get quite challenging as you get to a higher level. IMO this game has some of the hardest content from any MMO out there. There's the typical "Run around and quest" style gameplay, you can do a main story, there's lots of little "sub stories", trials, dungeons, fates in which many people randomly team up to complete a mini objective etc. Gameplay wise the game definately isn't lacking. The actual combat is quite good, players aren't just taught to stand still and smash buttons. There's lots of movement during fights, as you move away from aoes, deal with specific mechanics to handle bosses and move to specific locations to help team memebers. Apart from the obvious leveling gameplay, there's a lot of other things to go and enjoy. There's sightseeing logs, hunting logs, Gold Saucer events + a lot more. STORY: What surprised me the most about this game is just how good the story is. Not just from an MMO perspective, but from a Final Fanasy one. Generally, it's put together really well. Ofcourse there are a few tedious bits, but for the most part it's extremely enjoyable. The story helps guide you to places you should level, introduces you to more of the world and characters in it. Another thing to note is how well some of the characters are built up throughout the story, you really get to know + like them. Again, content wise you're definately not short, especially with Heavensward just released. There's easily more than 50 hours of story content available at the moment, and the best thing is that it's constantly being added to through content updates. The story is split into mini chapter type things, some with overlaping issues, so certain issues don't overstay their welcome and it doesn't get stale. VISUALS + OST: This is a Final Fantasy game. Even people that haven't played Final Fantasy know that a lot of effort is usually put into these 2 areas, and it applies here. Visually, the game is extremely impressive, especially now with DX11 support. The zones and enemies are extremely diverse, filled with a true sense of imagination and thought put into them. The music complements each area well, with a great range of types used. Lots of different types of musical styles are used for certain situations, from J-POP, smooth jazz and heavy metal. Even if some music tracks don't fit your fancy, theres bound to be plenty more that will.ENDGAME:Decided to give this it's own section aswell, as most people are interested in this. There's a ton todo at end game. There's tons of dungeons, raids and extreme primal encounters you can fight for gear, mounts or glory. Some of these get extremely challenging, to the point that you'd need to form training parties to help train yourself + your team to beat an encounter. There's also a pvp arena, which I confess I haven't used, dailies through beat tribe quests or doing any of the logs I've mentioned above. OVERALL QUALITY: IMO The overall quality is just great. There's so much todo content wise, it's just unreal. With so many possible playstyles and things todo it's hard to not reccomened this to any MMO or Final Fantasy fan. I'd honestly reccommend it just for the story alone. This review really doesn't do it justice, so if you've read this and it's interested you I'd really reccomend watching some videos of it on youtube(Just don't spoil the story for yourself!) and checking out the free trial. Just be warned, this game is an absolute timesink that will steal your life.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												As far as MMORPGs go, FFXIV is not at the same level as it's main competitors. Yet. The world is still lacking in scope, the endgame needs more variation, and lots of features like player housing hasn't been implemented yet.But I still give it my wholehearted recommendation. The graphics are great, the content that IS there is really fun, the production values are as good as any MMORPG I've ever played, and I can't stop playing it. If you're the type of player who rushes through content, you may find yourself hitting a wall at some point, but if you dial it back to somewhere between "hardcore" and "casual", this game is a true gem. Heck, even if you DO breeze through it all, it is a game that grows with every patch, every content update, and every (eventual) expansion pack.The monthly fee might seem discouraging, but not since Final Fantasy XI (also an MMORPG) have I ever got so much playtime and content for my money. If you love Final Fantasy and MMORPGs, you owe it to yourself to at least give it a try.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												The MMO genre has seen several failed attempts in recent years, and only a few have managed to really shine. Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn manages to rise to the ranks of great MMOs like WoW Burning Crusade. Where do I start? Character customization is filled with hundreds of potential combinations. You could easily spend a good hour or so mixing and matching to find a character that suits your taste. You even get to give your character both a first and last name. You have your standard three main roles and classes that fit into them, but the brilliant part is that you can become all of them on a single character. Never more will you have to juggle resources and time between characters just to fill multiple roles, as you can simply switch whenever the need arises. Combat uses the standard auto-attack and skill system, but has plenty of actions that require you to pay attention and move around. Several enemies use AoE attacks and your character can gain damage bonuses depending on his attacking position. The graphics are stunning for MMO standards and add to the beautiful realm of Eorzea. The story is very strong within the game, but it doesn't fall victim to the problem of Tortanic where it was too single player focused. There is plenty to do between main quests, side quests, FATES, dungeons, and primal raids. And the crafting system even manages to be exciting through the unique crafting process. Trust me, I've gotten hyped about being able to make a boiled egg when it almost failed. While the subscription fee can be discouraging, this game provides quality that more than justifies it.

												I picked this up to give it a shot, having heard that the newer version was far improved over the original 1.0 release, and man am I happy I did. The game is gorgeous, entertaining, and does a fantastic job of pulling you into the narrative, and making you care about the npc characters. The ability to level all the classes on one character is a blessing and a curse, but overall I like the way it feels.Biggest downsides for me are the lack of chat bubbles, and the need to grind xp to finish the main story/cap your character once you surpass level 35. There's also a fair bit of gold spamming, and having to type out a ticket to report it every time is very tedious, especially compared to WoW's one button report spam feature.Overall, very happy with my purchase, and the ability to pay for subscription via the steam wallet. It's well worth $30 to give this a try and see if it's right for you!

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												Yes. It is finally here. Final Fantasy 14, the next part in the ever-so-popular series isfinally out for the gamers of the world to enjoy. As for me, i was a bit sceptical about it at first, as i don't really like MMO's. But as a huge fan of FF games, decided to give it a shot. And believe me, i was not wrong. I was hooked right at the moment i entered the main menu: The guys from Square Enix managed to make even the menu look beautiful and soothing, accompanied with all-too-known musical theme. The graphics are amazing, even on the lower settings, and the landscapes are gorgeous and well-planned. The game itself has many clever designs, such as different view on crafting, dynamic battles, party and dungeon finders, daily quests, the all-new multi-class system.... Etc. Etc. And the game always manages to give you something new, more different things to keep you from getting bored. If you still have your doubts about giving your money monthly to play the game, then i will say you that: If you want a solid MMO experience with plenty of traditional FF goodness and recognisible characters - then think no further, just go and pay for it. You won't be dissappointed.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												I am not one usually to leave a review as I find other people have already spoken my opinions but I have been infuriated by the amount of crap I went through to try and play this game. Initial set up was easy - bought through steam, get game code. FFXIV makes you set up an account with Square Enix which is fairly normal for an online game. It takes the usual information like email address, screen name then your name and birthdate. Then your address, and a personal security question. Captcha's on every screen by the way, hard ones too. I do my usual thing of putting in crap because you don't need my damn address or birthdate. Then after that I log in, filling another captcha in as I go.This was around 2 years ago, I play the game and use up the free month before moving on and not playing again. However, recently I decided to start playing again as my friends have picked it up. Forgotten password, so go through that system of password recovery but it doesn't work. I recieve no email with reset details. So I try again, figuring I spelled something wrong. Nope, nothing. More captcha's each time too. Now, they do say it can take some time for the email to come through, and after "considerable" time waiting, to try again. 4 days later the email comes through but has an expiry time on it. If you don't click on the contained link within an hour of recieving it, it no longer works and you have to try again. And so I try again, this time it comes through 6 hours later when I am at work, I was lucky enough to be on a break and click the link. But it won't just reset my password, oh no. It wants my bloody birthdate, security answer and address. Ridiculous hard captchas on EVERY DAMN PAGE. Failing to crack my own answers I make a new account, a new email address to send information to and write everything down this time. Before stopping, putting my pen down and setting fire to the paper. The damn game has a registration key that links with the damn account. So I need to buy the game again. No thank you, enjoy your day.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												A lot has changed since I played so I'll change my review to reflect what I experienced in Heavensward and what I assume hasn't changed about the game. Dungeons: They're incredibly linear and shallow. Boss battles can be mechanically satisfying but the majority of your time is spent grinding mobs with a lot of health. There's really nothing fun or rewarding about them. You'll find yourself spamming queues for them in order to level up after the story stops leveling for you. All of these issues wouldn't matter too much if the combat this game has to offer was fun. There is nothing enjoyable about cooldown dependant combat. Especially if your class has buff micro-management. Raids and trials: Essentially giant sponges that have a long list of mechanics to memorize. You'll find your party wiping tons of times. Drops are rolled on so good luck getting what you wanted. There is nothing fun about completing the same battle over and over again. Why not add longetivity elsewhere? They're another aspect of the game negatively affected by the limitations of the combat system as well. Fates and hunts: Look, I know you want to give people a reason to revisit locations but collecting items and grinding mobs is not a good way to do it. Yet another aspect hindered by the combat system. PVP: It doesn't have much to offer, desperately needs more maps and more of an incentive to do them. You'll have to convert your friends to your grand company as well. Relic weapons: Probably the most boring, time demanding aspect of the game. Trust me, it's not worth the time and effort. Crafting: Literally useless for armor and weapons. Really just a tool for running the economy. Gathering: I'll admit, I like fishing. It's good when you just want to relax and take a break from what should be redundant. But the others, all you do is run around and press one button. Just WTF...Weekly capped gear: This is my biggest complaint about the game. There's gear that gets released with every update and you have to collect tomes by repeating already completed content in order to get them. By the time you have the set the next one is out so you feel like you wasted all of your time doing something boring and repetitive.IL: Item level, it's important as it dictates a lot about what you're able to do in this game. Forget skill, it's all about having the best gear in the game. That's why the game pulls in a lot of people with a superiority complex. Instead of getting better at the game through experience with the combat system, you get better by remembering patterns and getting a just as studied group to do raids all day (Or get the somewhat inferior capped gear)... Queues: Yep, you don't need any friends, play with random people from other servers.... Mostly easy stuff anyways. Story: Probably the only reason to play, ♥♥♥♥ endgame. So, do you want to do the same boring content over and over again for months just get better gear or do you want to play a game where every victory is rewarding and every challenge is engaging and satisfying?

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
Product received for free
												Note that this is for the base game, not the game plus expansion.Pros: Loads of content, loads of stuff to do.  Easy to get into multiplayer content, incentives for veterans to help rookies out, storyline quests progress your levels quite efficiently.  Interesting crafting mechanic, no-fuss travel, lush scenery and classic Final Fantasy aesthetics.  Loads of punny quest titles and memes hidden throughout.  A marriage mechanic that does not restrict (or even ask questions about) gender combinations.  Multi-rider mounts so you can haul your friends around.  Tons of quests and collections, a completionist's dream.Cons: Extremely technical, precise, minmax-y and a lot of poor communication, both between the game and the player and between player and player.  Terribad voice acting, overly flowery and verbose script, a plot that is hamfistedly dramatic and full of predictable and frustrating tropes, ugly "basic" gear practically until max level with few to no alternate options.  Gear-gated content and rng-based gear acquisition (this is a con, to me, take that as you will.).  Story quests force you to solo content, even in a game where no class is built to safely run solo.  Passive-aggressive elitism in the community.I ran out of game time, and I won't be renewing it.  This game is not for gamers who play games to have fun.   This is an MMORPG that is designed for people who feel good about themselves by getting very good at, or completing, extremely difficult or complicated content.   I'm not what one calls a "hardcore gamer" and thus the restrictive, overly specific Holy Trinity of RPGs gameplay left me feeling drained more than refreshed.  After failing a solo story quest duty five times in a row, and finding that I was doing everything right, I just simply should've gotten hit less, I decided I wasn't the kind of player Square-Enix had in mind when developing this game.I'm told Heavensward is much better story and much nicer mechanics, but if you can't even make it to the Heavensward  expansion's content, which begins only after you've completed your entire A Realm Reborn story quest, it's not worth even the cost of the base game.  I'm not going to muddle through a difficult, unsatisfying and frustrating game just in the hopes that I can pay more money to see if the expansion is more to my liking.I game to have fun, not to hate myself.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												This is certainly a decent MMO, one of the better ones currently available, however, I find I can't recommend it.I really wanted to love this game, and the crafting was really great...at least until you got into higher level stuff.  It was with great sorrow that I realized that the higher tiers of crafting had some bizarre, invisible-except-for-certain-times-of-day mechanic putting my happy gathering spree to an immediate, screeching halt.  I understand the need to make things rare in order to maintain the economy, but seriously?  Faced with the choice of standing, waiting for hours for a single node to spawn or buying it from the market, buying it from the market seems a much better choice, at least, until you see the prices, and realise that it would take you just as many hours of harvesting regular things to sell to afford one.  I suppose this is 'balance' but it certainly wasn't fun, and crushed my hopes as a crafter.The game will also 'force' you to participate in queue-for-group dungeon content to advance your main story quest, and I found unless you queued as tank or healer, you'd be waiting sometimes hours for a group (which may or may not even stay together to finish the dungeon!) just to advance your main, storyline quest.  I eventually made it to the end, but after that I was left with just a sense of overall disillusionment.  Add that to the pointlessness of the crafting at higher tiers, and well...As I said, it is one of the better MMOs out there, but I don't feel it has anything for the 'long haul' - unless you fancy queueing for groups and sitting afk at node spawn points for months on end, which ultimately killed it for me.  Perhaps if you have unlimited playtime to do the time-sink routine it'd be worth a play.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
I will update this review probably once I reach 1000+ hours. My hours are 160 at the time of this review.So you probably want a review from someone who doesn't play MMOs, or at least, didn't. I played Runescape back in 2007 with some friends. That was the only MMO I've ever played. FFXIV was still easy to learn, and I just didn't feel a stranger at all. It's impossible to not enjoy this game unless you just hate MMO's, or are impatient.I bought this like a month ago and I just reached level 50 dragoon. It's all so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing. The story is incredible, the music is stunning, the art is amazing, graphics are ridiculously beautiful. The classes (fighting classes, crafting classes, and gathering classes) are all uniquely rewarding. With that said, you can literally play as ANY class in the entire game with a single character. Wanna be a gladiator? Equip a sword. Miner? Equip a pickaxe. Wanna just ♥♥♥♥in cook? Equip a skillet. The community is wonderful. I'm no veteran hence my hours played, but I'm in a great Free Company (like a clan in other games) with great players that make me feel at home.However, this is definitely not a game for everyone. It could be quite intimidating to the average casual gamer who doesn't understand the basic principles of most MMO games. This game requires quite a bit of your time and patience. So, I would absolutely recommend looking up gameplay videos to understand the combat system if you're really questioning this purchase.I guess the only downside is I wasted my entire summer on a single video game. In the real life that sucks, but in Eorzea, it has been so wonderful.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												This game... is addictive.I have not played much endgame, I'm sure it's fantastic, this is a run-of-the-mill MMORPG however. You played Tera, Aion, Rift, WoW, Guld Wars 2, etc, you'll see the familiar elements, the grinds, the farming, etc. So I'll list some pros/cons below:Pros:So much to do (explained below)Graphics"Engaging" cinematics, for real, this game has the most cinematics for a MMORPG I've seen yet (and I played SW:KoTOR)Cons:Semi-clunky (combat, movement, etc)Same old grind, if you want an MMORPG without some type of farm/grind, keep looking and good luck.So much to do:FIrst, the class system is fantastic. Anyone can be any class, crafting, and gathering profession. You wanna be a cook? Go for it, wanna be a warrior and a mage? You can (just not at the same time obviously).This, for me, was one of the things I was most warry about, but ended up loving. Finally, I can play an MMORPG game where I can do whatever I want with no consequences. All it takes is a switch of gear (your main-hand weapon determines you current class/profession). Of course it has a well-done gear swap system as well (can save gear sets, etc), and furthermore there's a "reccomended gear button to auto-equip you for your current class/profession, fantastic.The sheer multitude of classes, professions, and 3 gathering professions is amazing... you will NEVER search for something to do. Along with little quests, dungeons, scenarios, a "game room" type area you will not want.Now... if your goal is to reach endgame and do that content.... you may find the above frustrating and in your way. If you want to immerse yourself in the lore, enjoy the world and characters and various things to do, then you will be satisfied as I was. I've been playing for 71 hours, still haven't reached max level (even for the base game), but I've been levelling 3 classes, 5 professions, all 3 of the gathering professions).On that note, the gathering system and crafting system is the best I have seen, very in-depth. Fishing not only helps other professions, for example, but you also have a fishing log, showing you various areas you've fished at, fish found there, etc. If you like filling out logs and collecting♥♥♥♥♥♥ this game has you covered.The crafting system also has abilities (like combat), to improve and craft you items. You don't simply hit a button and wait for a timer to craft! However, if that's what you want then yes, there is a "quick-craft" button that does that :)About the CLUNKY aspect. The overall feel is clunky not in a bad way, but compared to other games (WoW, Wild Star, etc) it falls more in line with GW2 for movement and combat, but slightly less fluid. There is a weight to movement and actions, the weight is not bad, but it's like the difference between playing Gears of War and Halo or Team Fortress 2 and CoD. Every button in FF14 has a purpose, every movement a reason, and you can feel it.Overall, this is one the most addictive MMORPG's I've played in a while... and I've played a good amount. This is the FIRST one besides WoW that I actually cared about the lore, and the first game where I've actually said "Wow... this crafting system is actually nice." Hell, I even enjoying fishing, fishing! If you've ever played WoW and levelled fishing to 700+ you'll understand what a feat it is for me to actually say I enjoy fishing in a game (that isn't specifically designed solely for fishing).Anyway, review too long and bulky, my work here is done.

												A very solid MMORPG. Sticks to many of the traditional aspects that made the genre popular while putting its own spin on things, as well as keeping the Final Fantasy vibe alive and well.  Final Fantasy fans who are not very familiar with MMORPGs will find this to be a good entry point into the genre. MMO fans should get enjoyment out of it even if they are not big into the Final Fantasy series, although they may not appreciate it as much as somebody who is very familiar with the Final Fantasy series.  Even if you aren't a fan of playing MMOs, you can still get a good experience just by playing through the main storyline.  Since the first month of game time comes free, that gives you more than enough time to play through the story if that's all you desire to do. It's definitely worth picking up and trying. It's a fun game and my MMO of choice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Square Enix goes above and beyond to make this a great title among MMOs. Every aspect of the game is really nice to look at, beautiful scenery to appreciate while running around and a lot of flair to every action made by the characters. The story is deep and engaging with a good level of charm to keep things amusing, as is standard with the final fantasy series as a whole. There is a whole lot more strategy to crafting as well, with a system that makes it much more interactive than clicking a button and waiting for 20 things to be done at once (which you can still choose to do to streamline the process if you're not concerned with a loss in experience or a higher failure rate). With the ability to swap between all the classes in the game at any time on the same character, you'll never even need to create more than one to experience everything, there are even specialised story quests for each class for you to enjoy. Whether you're leveling all your classes to the cap level, crafting up a storm and making money, destroying false gods to deck out your gear or just making your house look nice, you'll never run out of things to do either. All in all, probably the best MMO I've had the pleasure of experiencing, I highly look forward to the next update and I can't see myself stopping any time soon. Give it a go, it's definately worth the price even if you only play it for the first month.If you didn't want to read all that then here's the short version: This game is better than any other MMO I've played, you should buy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												If you love Final Fantasy games and are unsure about picking it up because its a MMO and it'll take away from the experience. Then allow me to reassure you, Even though its an MMO, FFXIV has done it amazingly well with their Story. Taking part with the MMO basics of Dungeons, Raids and Guilds, as well as putting their own twist on it with Aeons/Primals, If you don't get hooked on the fights, The music will get you to come back to them, Each having an amazing soundtrack as it fires you up to fight onward, Coming from someone who enjoys Final Fantasy games in a whole and has put hours upon hours into them, Going to A Realm Reborn was a great refreshing feeling.So far my best experience is the Trial fights with all the different Primals they have in store for you, Not only in A Realm Reborn, but in the Heavensward Expansion as well. Each having a great impact and leaving you wanting to go at them again and again.One other thing to mention is that Final Fantasy 14 allows you to change classes at will, so theres no need to make another character to play a different class, You may begin a new class at anytime by talking to their respected Guilds and taking on their Quests.Long story short, The games great, Ive had countless hours of fun, Trials kept me wanting to come back and VS tough opponents, Dungeons had great mechanics and a great level curve, The music is amazing to listen to, Although it is Pay to Play, You can start a free trial to see if you would like it or not, But Would recommend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												I love this game! All the Final Fantasy characters and monsters! You don't need a new character to play a different class/job! The music is amazing! The story quests are easy to track, and put you at the center as the Hero of Light. Everyone is fighting for the same casue, no good vs bad, so you don't have to worry about being in the wrong place and getting smashed by another player. There is pvp arena's for those who like to. Plenty of things to do, like hunts, treasure maps, the Hildibrand story line, Chocobo racing. Speeking of Chocobo's, you get one early on for a mount, and it doubles as a companion to fight with you. The Duty finder is helpful to get into instances when your friends or Free Company members are not around. It also looks to other servers to find players, as well as being a cross-platform with the PlayStation version. Thats right, controllers and KB/M playing side by sideYour are rewarded for your total subscription time, no need to pay every month if you don't want to, you still get the rewards when you have meet the amount of days payed (exp. your first 30 days payed earns a reward, you can not play for a year, and when you pay again, you get the 60 days reward. After a few, it starts to take more time between rewards).Fighting in this game requires you to move to not be hit by mobs attacks. Even as a caster, you must pay attention to what is coming your way, and sometimes it is just a matter of knowing where to stand to get spells off before you have to move again.Everything in this game looks great, the characters and equipment, mobs and bosses, zones and backdrops, and of course, the cutscenes! Oh and the spells and ability!! There is even a Limit Break system while in instances. A shared guage that builds up to 3 levels, and the different class groups (exp. casters, healer, tank, dps) have a different limit break. A level 3 healer limit break will raise all dead party members, casters cast meteor. Time it right and save the day!Crafting, almost forgot crafting! You don't just click a button and wait for a bar to fill. You have skills to use as a crafter. Skill rotation helps determine output quality. Plus quests for your craft, and the gear just for crafting. Some of the crafting gear is also styled around what you are crafting.Gathering jobs are  miner, botanist, and fisherFree companies have houses that provide a place to grow crops for cooking or feed for your chocobo, training dummys to practice your rotation, and a few vendors for repairing equipment, buying regents, or just selling junk.All of these things (and so much more) tie together wonderfully, and give (me at least) a sense of place in the grand scheme of things.This, compared to one other mmo I played a lot of, is a huge difference. I just didn't feel the other game gave me any drive to "do great things" other than to complete a quest, or run a instance for the fun of it. I never felt like I was part of the Big Picture. Kind of hard to put into words, and maybe I just did not play with the "right" players, and I never made it to end game raids.Over all, FFXIV is Best MMO I have ever played, and still crave to play! I Hope you find this review helpful. :)(If my review has helped you decide, and/or you just like it, maybe you could toss some change to my steam wallet. HAHAHA)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Honestly my favorite modern MMO. I've put countless hours into it and still find it endlessly enjoyable. The classes are all fun and unique, the crafting is active and interesting, and thanks to the job system you can experience everything the game has to offer with a single character.I took a break after finishing end game and getting all best in slot gear for my main class, but when I came back I found out that there was almost double the endgame content as when I left. This game is ever changing and ever expanding, new content is being added quite regularly, and it's not just new raids or dungeons. Whole new story quests, expanding on the lore, are added extremely often.I'm going to sum up my feelings in a list of good and bad from my perspective,******************************************************************************What's the good:The combat: It's slower then most other MMOs but that is a benefit, giving you more time to make a choice on what to do next and how it will be effective. It flows naturally and feels satisfying with just the right amount of power. Later in the game a boss fight stops being just a harder monster you need to work through, but instead becomes a kind of dance, each member of your party having their own role on the stage.The Quests: Yes, they are a lot of fetch quests and breadcrumbs, it's nothing special in the MMO world... But it somehow is. With all the dialog, lore, and the streamlined loot system, the quests in this game somehow transcend the "Go here and do this" standard. The first major thing you might notice? The quest givers know damned well what you're there for, the world has a long history of adventurers and questors, everyone knows you're there to help them with anything and damned if they are not going to take advantage of it. This makes for quite a fun experience as you do the most basic tasks for someone too lazy to pick up vegetables that are literally 5 feet away, and they acknowledge it. If you play and get to level 50, I HIGHLY recommend the "Hildibrand" Quest series started in Ul'dah, it will have you laughing till the end.The Dungeons: The dungeons in this game are basic, but awesome. Each able to be run in about 20-30 minutes and comprising of 3-4 bosses and trash. But they have a ton of atmosphere and charm, each one clearly was carefully crafted to be both visually appealing and challenging. And don't be fooled when you see the labels of "Hard mode" when you get to end game, Hard mode dungeons are not in fact just more difficult versions like in other MMOs, the game designers in fact go back and remake a dungeon from scratch, using the same location but a different path, with different trash and different bosses. Every Hard Mode is a whole new dungeon with a whole new story to it, causally taking place after the events you caused in the normal mode.Community: Other then a few bad eggs and elitists the community is extremely helpful and kind, you should never lack any help if you need it just by asking around. The game actually incentivizes high levels to help low levels with the Syncing system where a high level in specific situations can scale his/her level down to match a dungeon/quest/fate.*****************************************************************************What is Bad:Global Clock: All actions by players and mobs are on a global clock. This gives the game a somewhat turn based feel to it where everything is in time and synced together. Why is this bad? Because for more then a few classes in order to get the most out of your abilities you need to time them PERFECTLY based on this clock, and the fact that you can't see or interact with it means that you'll be guessing based on the countdown on your abilities. Best example of this being a problem is on the summoner Job, where timing your dots right makes the difference of 100% of your damage or 80% of your damage if you get it wrong.Insanely difficult dice roll quests: At end game, there is a series of quests to get your "best" weapon. This is... the most bull♥♥♥♥♥♥you will ever have to face in a game. You have to win 12 random dice rolls, and failing one means having to try again... Did I mention that each dice roll happens AFTER you finish one of the many random events around the world? That you have to wait up to 15 minutes for? Even with higher drop chance it is still Bull. (My best time for completing this quest.. 6 days, friend took more then 2 weeks) Lucky that this is optional.Character creation limitations: What's that? Wanna play with a friend who already plays the game? What's that? They are on the Levi Server? Well FK YOU! Servers every now and then (some more then others, to the point of being closed more often then open) will close their gate to new players, this is done to keep the servers from being over loaded, but this has the nasty side effect of keeping players from playing together on the servers they want, specially the more populated ones where you have more people to interact with and more options for guilds/fcs. Why is this done? Well that brings me to my last problem.Gold Spammers: Yup, the ever present MMO issue is here but 1000x worse. These pesky parasites will spam all chats, all areas, all the time. They even personally PM you with their virus ridden web links, promising massive amounts of gil for your hard earned money. This is done through the in game player search, where they just have to go alphabetically to find every single one of us and spam us one at a time. Of course they get banned, only to instantly make a new random name account and get right back into the game. they come in the thousands and they want all of your money, and in my opinion is the sole reason that servers are rotated the way they are. It's annoying, it's frustrating, and no mater how many of them you block there are always 5 more to take their place. Every now and then Square does a mass Hardware ban and that quiets them for a week or so wile they buy new computers/servers but it's only a temporary fix to a permanent problem.**********************************************************All in all, in my opinion, the good outweighs the bad. This game is an experience, an amazing experience. I've never had more fun with an MMO in my life and I'm not sure I ever will. No one would have thought that after the disaster that was the original FFXIV that this would be what comes out of it. I ask any of you reading, at LEAST give the 2 week free trial a chance. You have nothing to loose but a whole world to gain.

												Theme park mmo, lots to do, terribly grindy but -mostly- in optional places.+most in-depth fishing system I've seen- THE FISH GOT AWAY+most in-depth crafting system I've seen, control outcome of hq rather than lottery procs (eg, Aion)- no "craft from stash"+ Run around as a cute little ball of potato pudding+ Glamour/reskin almost anything+ The story is supposedly okay, if a bit "anime"+ Tons of lorestuff+ Multiple ways to level up- XIV uses unpadded "true" rng streaks of bad luck which should be mathematical improbabilities commonly occur.Like failing a 29% meld 119 times in a row. Thanks, yoshi-p.- Despite flying mounts in HW+ areas, the topography is linear & dull. It still feels like a flat map only now you can go up.- Little permanence to "shiny" items. Current BiS resets every 6mo with the raid tier.- Button / skill bloat (being addressed in the next xpac supposedly)- Relic (sort of a catch-up / alternative to raid) weapon is uninspired tomestone grind designed to funnel players through old content to keep it alive, rather than be inherently fun.- SE does little to discourage win-trading in Gold Saucer tournaments, but occasionally cracks down on PvP tourniesIt's a terrible timesink. Might not be your thing if you prefer fast-paced combat. Global cooldown starts at 2.5s (can be decreased slightly). But as a crafter, it's a great game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												This game... is addictive.I have not played much endgame, I'm sure it's fantastic, this is a run-of-the-mill MMORPG however. You played Tera, Aion, Rift, WoW, Guld Wars 2, etc, you'll see the familiar elements, the grinds, the farming, etc. So I'll list some pros/cons below:Pros:So much to do (explained below)Graphics"Engaging" cinematics, for real, this game has the most cinematics for a MMORPG I've seen yet (and I played SW:KoTOR)Cons:Semi-clunky (combat, movement, etc)Same old grind, if you want an MMORPG without some type of farm/grind, keep looking and good luck.So much to do:FIrst, the class system is fantastic. Anyone can be any class, crafting, and gathering profession. You wanna be a cook? Go for it, wanna be a warrior and a mage? You can (just not at the same time obviously).This, for me, was one of the things I was most warry about, but ended up loving. Finally, I can play an MMORPG game where I can do whatever I want with no consequences. All it takes is a switch of gear (your main-hand weapon determines you current class/profession). Of course it has a well-done gear swap system as well (can save gear sets, etc), and furthermore there's a "reccomended gear button to auto-equip you for your current class/profession, fantastic.The sheer multitude of classes, professions, and 3 gathering professions is amazing... you will NEVER search for something to do. Along with little quests, dungeons, scenarios, a "game room" type area you will not want.Now... if your goal is to reach endgame and do that content.... you may find the above frustrating and in your way. If you want to immerse yourself in the lore, enjoy the world and characters and various things to do, then you will be satisfied as I was. I've been playing for 71 hours, still haven't reached max level (even for the base game), but I've been levelling 3 classes, 5 professions, all 3 of the gathering professions).On that note, the gathering system and crafting system is the best I have seen, very in-depth. Fishing not only helps other professions, for example, but you also have a fishing log, showing you various areas you've fished at, fish found there, etc. If you like filling out logs and collecting♥♥♥♥♥♥ this game has you covered.The crafting system also has abilities (like combat), to improve and craft you items. You don't simply hit a button and wait for a timer to craft! However, if that's what you want then yes, there is a "quick-craft" button that does that :)About the CLUNKY aspect. The overall feel is clunky not in a bad way, but compared to other games (WoW, Wild Star, etc) it falls more in line with GW2 for movement and combat, but slightly less fluid. There is a weight to movement and actions, the weight is not bad, but it's like the difference between playing Gears of War and Halo or Team Fortress 2 and CoD. Every button in FF14 has a purpose, every movement a reason, and you can feel it.Overall, this is one the most addictive MMORPG's I've played in a while... and I've played a good amount. This is the FIRST one besides WoW that I actually cared about the lore, and the first game where I've actually said "Wow... this crafting system is actually nice." Hell, I even enjoying fishing, fishing! If you've ever played WoW and levelled fishing to 700+ you'll understand what a feat it is for me to actually say I enjoy fishing in a game (that isn't specifically designed solely for fishing).Anyway, review too long and bulky, my work here is done.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												I thought I would never really enjoy a MMORPG again, but this game managed to change that.I played a lot of MMOs for a lot of time in the 90s and 2000s. But in the last few years, whenever I tried a new MMO, I usually thought to myself: "there are some really cool ideas here, but meh... I can't invest the time to really feel interested in actually playing it". In other words, I could appreciate MMORPGs, but couldn't really get myself to play them again.But I can play and enjoy FFXIV easily. It's hard to pin-point why: the game isn't very innovative, most of its mechanics have been used in multiple western and/or eastern MMORPGs before it. But it blends them well, and everything feels very polished and sleeky. And the Final Fantasy style gameworld, full of fan-service for fans of the series, lends itself well for a relaxing experience with gorgeous scenary. To help with that, the community seems to be more pleasing and much less toxic than most other MMOs, too.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												I strongly recommend this as an immersive, beautiful, extensively narrative-driven experience, to the point even the crafters and gatherers get their own storylines! While the combat is simplified, it's neither too simple nor too frustrating, and the native controller support is an absolute joy. More depth and complexity can be found in the crafting and gathering systems, although the game is still quite easy to understand.The world, while only consisting of a few maps, is gorgeous, memorable, and full of detail, both in characters and environment.The music is also fantastic, expressing a broad array of emotions, from the tender to the grand. The boss music as well is varied and intense and uses a variety of styles and instrumentation.Achievement hunters might find the game a bit of a grind, as some of the achievements are literally just grindwalls, especially the ones relating to the game's minigame hub, but the fact that most game systems have achievements attached to them, and the sheer array of activities that can be done, mean achievement-hunting is fairly involved and interesting from an intellectual point of view.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												This game is possibly one of the best MMOs i've ever played. dont be fooled by my 1.5 hours on record. i personally bought the disc edition of this game so my main account is outside of the steam client. i can guarantee you i have well over 1500 hours into this game.Although some of the updates of late have been controversial, there is no shortage of fantastic content in this game and it is easy to see that square enix spared no expense. from start to end game, there is rarely a dull moment since every single zone, dungeon, and raid, is completely unique and jammed full of amazing character and design.the music in this game is second to none. honestly, it is the type of music that CREATES nostalgia within you. while the main themes of the game are completely new and inovative, the game incorporates many of the prior games' iconic music tracks such as final fantasy 7 golden saucer, ff7 costa del sol, and many remixes of battle themes from throughout the series. you will find yourself humming along to the theme of a boss fight you have never been in and then realize "Hey! this is from ff4!". but truthfuly, there is nothing like coming back to your starting city and being welcomed by the grand theme of Ul' Dah, or the Liberating bagpipes of Limsa Lominsa. even the perky, yet calm harp and flute of Gridania. i would buy the game just for the music.The graphics in this game are some of the best graphics you will find in an mmo. there are others that boast amazing graphics that surpass this, but the style is quite amazing.the crafting system is the best i have ever experienced and is extremely rewarding. the economy is also, alive and thriving. i can guarantee that you will get many many hours of entertainment out of this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												First I have to say that this is my opinion. If you feel much different from what I think then that's fine and share your thoughts below (I actually want a badge). Secondly I am only talking about the PvE (Player V.S. Environment) elements.I have to say that this is a MMORPG I enjoyed for a while until [Spoilers?] Level 40. Then I quit because of the grinding. Especially if you level up quickly every day. Then you're pretty much done in one month (if you have much free time). I thought for a long time if I recommend this or not. But here anyway.Pros:The Community is nice.The game visually looks really good.The character customization is pretty well made. You can customize your body pretty well compared to other MMO's.The race designs and cities are pretty great!The sidequests are enjoyable.I actually like the HUD.The plots for the main storyline is interesting.Some awesome monsters.The emote system is the best what I have seen.There is really much to do, at Level 50 too (if only I was a bit slow..).There are many dungeons. Great if you are a Tank or Healer.Great voice acting in cutscenes.Cons:Waiting for other people in the Duty Finder takes a really long time if you are a DPS (like others)At the end (around Level 40) you have to grind a lot and is boring like everytime you have to grind in a MMO and you are forced to do this if you want to continue.The mainquests at the end are short and have to grind 2 levels further to go through a short quest. Square Enix is really smart at this because you have to pay every month if you want to complete the mainquests.Leveling is pretty fast until level 40, WHICH IS NOT BAD but it only goes to Level 50. 60 if you have Heavensward. And completing sidequests and end-sidequests is pretty fast for me so I can actually complete this game in 1 month.The combat is terrible. If you only get some meters away from the monsters, then it loses it's interest and regenerates. I even had a time where I stayed in the same place the monster detected me and loses interest and walks away, regenerating.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Having played (and still am playing) World of Warcraft I've been over the MMO market to find one as fun as WoW. Warhammer Online didnt work for me, The Old Republic had nothing in the way of content (also its Star Wars, don't heavily like the series), Maple Story was ok in small doses, and Tera, while pretty, has one♥♥♥♥♥♥community.So while I knew of the original FFXI I never played it and got the basics from hearsay, and the original launch of FFXIV left me glad I had no interest, cut to the present and SE decided to pull it, rework the game, and with Naoki Yoshida's wonderful direction remade and released a truly fantastic MMO that reminded me of the first time I played WoW.Eorzea literally grabbed me like Azeroth first did and I was everywhere, I had my first timer bungles yes, but the game is fair in its guidance and shows you where to go. Dungeons are only 4 people instead of a traditional 5 but that also seems to help on content as with 5 you could have one person carry everything with 4 everyone must pull their own weight. Dungeons offer a fine line of challenge, reward, and ease, you do a hard mode dungeon, wipe on a boss several times but push it more and eventually kill it and get loot and no one is mad but glad? Always wonderful. While young, the games raiding is solid if needs just a bit more tweaking, not I have not done Coil so I cant speak on those as I know they are quite challenging but it all works well and wonderful.Overall I got my monthly payment of enjoyment, and with the developers constantly working on new content for everyone to do it doesnt get stale, also PLAYER HOUSING!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												This game... is addictive.I have not played much endgame, I'm sure it's fantastic, this is a run-of-the-mill MMORPG however. You played Tera, Aion, Rift, WoW, Guld Wars 2, etc, you'll see the familiar elements, the grinds, the farming, etc. So I'll list some pros/cons below:Pros:So much to do (explained below)Graphics"Engaging" cinematics, for real, this game has the most cinematics for a MMORPG I've seen yet (and I played SW:KoTOR)Cons:Semi-clunky (combat, movement, etc)Same old grind, if you want an MMORPG without some type of farm/grind, keep looking and good luck.So much to do:FIrst, the class system is fantastic. Anyone can be any class, crafting, and gathering profession. You wanna be a cook? Go for it, wanna be a warrior and a mage? You can (just not at the same time obviously).This, for me, was one of the things I was most warry about, but ended up loving. Finally, I can play an MMORPG game where I can do whatever I want with no consequences. All it takes is a switch of gear (your main-hand weapon determines you current class/profession). Of course it has a well-done gear swap system as well (can save gear sets, etc), and furthermore there's a "reccomended gear button to auto-equip you for your current class/profession, fantastic.The sheer multitude of classes, professions, and 3 gathering professions is amazing... you will NEVER search for something to do. Along with little quests, dungeons, scenarios, a "game room" type area you will not want.Now... if your goal is to reach endgame and do that content.... you may find the above frustrating and in your way. If you want to immerse yourself in the lore, enjoy the world and characters and various things to do, then you will be satisfied as I was. I've been playing for 71 hours, still haven't reached max level (even for the base game), but I've been levelling 3 classes, 5 professions, all 3 of the gathering professions).On that note, the gathering system and crafting system is the best I have seen, very in-depth. Fishing not only helps other professions, for example, but you also have a fishing log, showing you various areas you've fished at, fish found there, etc. If you like filling out logs and collecting♥♥♥♥♥♥ this game has you covered.The crafting system also has abilities (like combat), to improve and craft you items. You don't simply hit a button and wait for a timer to craft! However, if that's what you want then yes, there is a "quick-craft" button that does that :)About the CLUNKY aspect. The overall feel is clunky not in a bad way, but compared to other games (WoW, Wild Star, etc) it falls more in line with GW2 for movement and combat, but slightly less fluid. There is a weight to movement and actions, the weight is not bad, but it's like the difference between playing Gears of War and Halo or Team Fortress 2 and CoD. Every button in FF14 has a purpose, every movement a reason, and you can feel it.Overall, this is one the most addictive MMORPG's I've played in a while... and I've played a good amount. This is the FIRST one besides WoW that I actually cared about the lore, and the first game where I've actually said "Wow... this crafting system is actually nice." Hell, I even enjoying fishing, fishing! If you've ever played WoW and levelled fishing to 700+ you'll understand what a feat it is for me to actually say I enjoy fishing in a game (that isn't specifically designed solely for fishing).Anyway, review too long and bulky, my work here is done.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												My original review was SO LONG that it became a novel… That soon became a trilogy… That was eventually released on blu-ray DVD.…That’s how much I love this gametl;drThe game comes with a free month, which is more than enough time to give it a try. Despite the lackluster fighting IMO (read below), it doesn't detract from the overall gameplay. FFXIV is an absolutely gorgeous and vast world, and one of the best subscription MMO's I've played. I would recommend this game to any of my friends.---COMMUNITY:FREE-to-play MMOs are like highschool. You’re often surrounded by people who could care less about you or the community, and only a select few people who do care. One of the biggest reasons I play any subscription based MMO is for the community.SUBSCRIPTION based MMOs are like university. You’re at a hub where like-minded people gather, who have paid for their entrance, and in doing so will most likely try their best to thrive; the only way to do so is to become apart of the community.My first day on the server I was invited to a free company (a lesser form of a guild), and I was chatting up my FC mates like no tomorrow. We shared stories, got to know each other a little bit, and some of the max level players came out to help me quest for fun (they even gave me a free pet). We also went to the FC house and chilled in a hot tub, at which point we began to /dance naked without equipment. Needless to say, I felt like the community was incredible.Granted, everyone will have a different experience and some might not be as lucky as I was (although I still vouch for the community since my brother and friend were in thriving FC’s as well). GRAPHICS:I bought the game cause my friend said I could make a hot female character with an even hotter merchant retainer... He didn't lie. But seriously, the graphics are stunning. So often did I catch myself stopping to take in the scenery before I continued on with a quest. And even more often did I catch myself marveling my own character (and others) during cutscenes. From equipment and weapons, to the vast cities and it's inhabitants, I could spend hours just roaming around taking it all in; and that's saying something.ATMOSPHERE:I'll be honest, I'm very biased here, so I'll say it straight; I'm a huge FINAL FANTASY fanboy. From the lore to the cameo's, and all the familiarity that is FINAL FANTASY, I LOVED this game. But I'll try and be objective. IMO, this game isn't afraid to be cute and light, and neither is it afraid to be dark. This is reflective of the writing and plot, to the characters you meet and enemies you fight. Unlike most single player RPGs that become far too cute, or completely dark with no hope for salvation, or "try to hard comedic" with jokes that bash you're head in, this game is a combination of every world, and in nice moderation. I felt after my time spent in the game, I got to see its dark aspects, but never forgot how cute it was. Especially with the immense varying between areas. I adored how one city made me feel fresh and relaxed, while others made me feel rigid and attentive. The same goes for the characters you meet along the way. Even the monsters have great diversity. Although I'll stop there, because the sheer nostalgia of seeing a huge♥♥♥♥♥Malboro or Ifrit will turn this review into a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥GAMEPLAY:Alright this is the bad part, and might be a deal breaker for you. There was nothing wrong with the gameplay. In fact, I actually prefer FFXIV’s approach to the job system where all you need is 1 character to enjoy all the classes (this also removes the bs of having to start another alt if you messed up a skill tree or something). What I felt was this game was very REACTIVE as opposed to PROACTIVE. I was constantly waiting to react during fights, either waiting for my cast bar to finish and react with another skill, or reacting to a boss attack field by moving out of the way. Many MMOs have you proactively moving to avoid damage rather than reacting to a boss attack field. And those same MMOs don’t have a cast time for every single skill, thus creating a rhythmic flow to attack skill rotation (PROACTIVE) rather than waiting on dreary cast bars (REACTIVE). In general this made my gameplay feel lackluster at times. But this never detracted from overall gameplay. Mind you, mastering cast bar skill rotation (and skill rotation in general) is an art form all its own.CONCLUSION:I would highly recommend this game. Even the gameplay which I just bashed isn’t a deal breaker (for me at least). There is nothing wrong with a reactive style of play. Keep in mind this review is just my opinions. FINAL (fantasy) verdict:8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												If you love Final Fantasy games and are unsure about picking it up because its a MMO and it'll take away from the experience. Then allow me to reassure you, Even though its an MMO, FFXIV has done it amazingly well with their Story. Taking part with the MMO basics of Dungeons, Raids and Guilds, as well as putting their own twist on it with Aeons/Primals, If you don't get hooked on the fights, The music will get you to come back to them, Each having an amazing soundtrack as it fires you up to fight onward, Coming from someone who enjoys Final Fantasy games in a whole and has put hours upon hours into them, Going to A Realm Reborn was a great refreshing feeling.So far my best experience is the Trial fights with all the different Primals they have in store for you, Not only in A Realm Reborn, but in the Heavensward Expansion as well. Each having a great impact and leaving you wanting to go at them again and again.One other thing to mention is that Final Fantasy 14 allows you to change classes at will, so theres no need to make another character to play a different class, You may begin a new class at anytime by talking to their respected Guilds and taking on their Quests.Long story short, The games great, Ive had countless hours of fun, Trials kept me wanting to come back and VS tough opponents, Dungeons had great mechanics and a great level curve, The music is amazing to listen to, Although it is Pay to Play, You can start a free trial to see if you would like it or not, But Would recommend.

												I played around 20-30 mmos, ranging from f2p to p2p titles like for example aion, lotro, eso, guild wars 1 and guild wars 2, age of conan, the secret world and ofc the many many f2p titles out there like maestia, shaiya etc. you name it. most of these games i did not play long, maybe for a couple of hours, because i was kinda biased through guild wars 1 which was until now my all time favorite mmorpg. ff14 is challenging this, because it is just ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. i can't even begin to describe this game. im even having fun farming resources and crafting stuff, because it is completly different to other titles out there. im dead serious i hate farming and crafting, i find it really boring, but in this game? nope im having so much fun. and the best part for me is, that i can really learn EVERYTHING with one character. i like this freedom. in gw1 you could essentially use all 1250 skills avaiable and try out so many different combinations, granted that's not the same as in this game, you have much less skills, but still it reminds me of this freedom to go and just try stuff and experiment. i missed that much. this game is giving me exactly that. so if you like freedom in a mmo concerning your character then go ahead and try it out. it's just 10 bucks and you will find out in 1 month if you like it or not ;)
