content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												Once upon a time, a scary person found an ancient radio transmitter, and used it to call an abusive GM.  They 'requested' said GM to slam the moon down, because people weren't RPing seriously enough.  It turns out it wasn't a moon, but a prison for a giant dragon-god-thing, and despite a bunch of players best efforts, it horribly scarred the land, and as in all JRPGs, property values have plummeted.Final Fantasy XIV is an MMORPG for PC and PS4, and is a rare game that I will say right away is one of the best of our generation, period.  It's got great game systems, an awesome story, awesome production value, and recently PvP has been improved to the point of being quite good.  In the spirit of spoiling my own review, I will say the list of What Works, significantly outweights What Doesn't Work.  I'll talk about both, and re-iterate the stuff I've just said in my TL;DR.What WorksGenerally...everything.First, it's a $15/mo subscription that you can pay via Steam, on top of the price of entry.  There's additional options to micropay though Square Enix for cosmetic items, but this is not a pay-to-win BS game like so many others out there.  More specifically, you've got a good, if somewhat clunky Job system that allows anyone to be anything, but not everything at the same time.  If you don't want the responsibility of being a tank or healer, you can be a Dragoon or a Black Mage or something.  Each class has their own unique mechanics; playing a class is mastering a class-specific 'minigame' of maintaining certain buffs on you or doing certain things.PvP has improved to the point, where it's moved into this category.  Some of this is the Garo! crossover event going on until June, because it gives PvP a raison d'etre, but also changes to how The Feast (deathmatch mode) work have really helped.  Prior to this, FFXIV was a raider's game; I think, to the benefit of everyone including said raiders, that has changed.You've also got an awesome story.  There's all sorts of interesting events that a new player can look forward to - fighting your first Primal, raiding an Imperial Castrum with your NPC buddies, scaling a wreck of a crashed airship to face a raid boss in normal dungeon boss' clothing, dueling Eorzean Chuck Norris nee Raubahn in a friendly match...there's so many great moments that trying to just name them all is a challenge.  Even if you don't care about game stories, this one gets good.You crafters and gatherers out there get your own character classes to specifically do those things, too!  I don't recommend maxing a crafter/gatherer out first - combat classes are required to unlock new areas, so you really can't - but your contributions to the economy are a great way to earn Gil, the game's currency, and as new classes get added every now and again, even lower-level stuff never really goes out of style too much.What Doesn't WorkNo game is perfect, not even this one.One thing, is that at endgame, you've got way the heck too many buttons.  I've been experimenting with toolbar-switching macros to try to get around this, but end result is that you wind up feeling like you're trying to play the organ parts to Bach's Toccata in d Minor when playing this game.  The controls could stand for some simplification.Tab-targeting in PvP is flat-out awful, and players hitboxes often overlap such that you can never be sure that you can properly target a...well, target.  This isn't just a PvP problem though - too many players stacking up near a summoning bell, used to call retainers, who act like both banks and a lazy man's way of gathering materials, can lead to significant frustration.PvE is required as part of the main storyline.  This is good, in that it ensures older content is still ran, but if your first class is a DPS class - Lancer, Arcanist, Thaumaturge, Archer - have fun waiting for 15-30m queues for required content.  Luckily, the game also has a 'first timer bonus' system that gives everyone bonus rewards if it's your first time running something; this really helps ensure that you don't get ragequitting endgame players as often.Also, grinding.  The FFXIV team loves grinding for special currencies to be competitive; in Heavensward, one of the last dungeons, "ARF" (Aetherochemical Research Facility) is specifically set up to be ground for marks needed for modest endgame equipment.  If you want one of the Infinity +1 items, the Anima weapons, prepare to cry at the start of every new leg you get to; it's long, arduous, requires significant grinding, and you don't get any weapons that are stronger than things you can easily get from "Palace of the Dead" until you've put in a really, really significant time investment.  I hope you can afford to game for a living.Speaking of grinding, leveling classes beyond your 'main' is tricky once you're done with the MSQ (main story quests.)  Ideally, you're supposed to grind Palace of the Dead - a roguelike dungeon system - for easy XP, as daily quests don't begin to be in your level range until the high 40s.The TL;DRUnquestionably Recommended, all things considered.  There's such quality in this title, that the downsides at their worst turn into annoyances.  I do think things can be improved, but the fact is, at present, this is the best MMORPG on the market.I've played nearly 1000 hours of this title, and while I haven't done everything - I refuse to raid - I will tell you here and now that this game is more or less a must-have.

content:
Posted: April 20
												This game is a great replacement for your current mmo, and is an even greater mmo to learn the basics of roles, dungeons, and raids for other mmos. I previously played Guild Wars 2 and World of Warcraft and this either ties with WOW for most enjoyment, or perhaps even surpasses it. Word of warning though, if you buy the game on Steam you must continue to buy products, like expansions, on Steam. You cannot cross purchases from Steam and Square Enix. If you buy the base game from Steam and the expansion on Square's store, you WILL NOT be able to play the expansion. You defiantly get a bang for buck when it comes to the subscription as events and new content are added all the time. I reached level 50 as a tank in about 3 weeks, and I had a blast doing so. It has informative and optional tutorials if you are new and this is definitely a good MMO to start if you and your friends are looking for something new.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												This is a game that I was unsure whether or not I would be able to get into it at first.  However, once I starting playing and created my character, I was in for a treat.  Many people and news outlets have said how terrible 1.0 was and that a completely new team at Square Enix was formed to create this game.  This game was even created from the ground up since there was no way to fix the original due to outdated code and other factors.  This game was very worthy of my time and still is.  The combat is very fluid, the different zones that you visit are all unique and have some factors that make it stand out  the various dungeons and trials that you do with other players are all very fun, this game is cross platform between PC, PS3, and PS4 players meaning that regardless of platform, you are all playing with each other, the endgame gives you something to do with more harder dungeons, trials, and raids,  and the story in this game is probably one of the most interesting stories that is part of a Final Fantasy game.If you are still unsure whether or not you should invest some time in this game, there is a 15 day free trial that you can try out.+Update - 1The free trail has changed from 15 days to being able to level all classes up to 35.A Realm Reborn Cap - 50Heavensward Cap - 60

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												I don't usually like MMOs; they all have a very familiar sort of pattern. You get your one class, you research it like crazy to metagame the hell out of it, you blaze through as fast as you can to the level cap, and you raid until you get bored and realize how much money you spent and ultimately quit. One look at the hours I've put in for this game, though, shows how exceptional I feel this game is. For anyone who doesn't like MMOs, this is the MMO for you.FFXIV avoids most of what I don't like about MMOs in very clever ways:1) The story is actually really good, and worth paying attention to. It's not fully voiced, and the parts that are have some questionable voice work (especially pre-Heavensward) but it is all well-written and genuinely does feel like a mainline Final Fantasy game, rather than an MMO spinoff. This really is key; despite the gameplay structure, when you're into the plot it really feels like you're playing an RPG, rather than feeling like you're playing World of Warcraft again.2) You're never confused about some new system the game introduces. Any time the game brings something new in, a section for it is added to a very useful help system, which provides information on any given element of the game. Want to know the difference between a duty finder and a party finder? You don't need to go rooting around a wiki or forums; it's right there.3) Your class is determined solely by your equipped weapon. This means each character can be every class at once, eliminating the need for separate toons for different roles. You also get retainers, who act as item boxes, but also as NPC adventurers you can send out on their own quests to get resources for you. This means you never really need mules. You can experience everything in this game (for the most part) as a single character.4) While you can theoretically blaze through the game to the level cap, there's not much point, because in order to reach the level 50+ content in the expansion, you need to finish the main story up to the point where it unlocks, and in order to unlock most if not every dungeon and raid, you need to follow the associated questlines for them. To some, I can see this being a problem, since it will probably take a good few weeks at least to get through it all and Heavensward really is where the best content in the game is right now. However, this again makes it feel more to me like a real RPG. Keeping progression story-based prevents you from losing track of the story in favor of the metagame and powerleveling, and for me that meant I remained interested in what was happening throughout the entirety of its progress. Granted, it also meant I spent more time with the game and thus it cost me more subscription money, but I think I would not have liked the game nearly as much if I could just buy my way to level 50 and skip all the excellent story and characterization in favor of jumping straight into Heavensward.5) Hildibrand Manderville.I would say, at least give the free trial a shot if you're on the fence. You might be surprised.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25
												I'm level 20 and about done with this game. I played WoW a long time ago and loved it, I also love Final Fantasy games but this one just doesn't do it for me. My connection was smooth the entire time and Square Enix has done a great job with streamlining a lot of traditionally tedious MMO annoyanes, especially transportation and combat damage calculations. The controller mapping works fantastically too, making it a true cross platform game. But the world, quests and characters are so bland. The quests are either a glorified tutorial or run and kill x number of monsters and get x vials of blood from them. The character specialization is non existent, you can be every class and gathering profession as one character and there is a very clear "best" gear for everything. The gear only covers a few generic roles (DPS, Healer, Tank). You don't have tech trees or talents to pick from, the only specialization you get is from choosing a few spells from another class to use. Which is mostly useless except for passive buffs, as your own skills class's skills work better. I like the gathering system but what kills it entirely is you have to switch to the gathering class to even sense nearby ore veins or plants...the locations I've travelled to so far have been pretty uninteresting too which I thought was surprising for a Final Fantasy games. The monsters are great, but unfortunately that's all that's really worth exploring. As nice and smooth as a lot of the systems in this game are, you don't get to make any choices. You can choose which class to play or which Free Company (guild) to join, but in terms of how you play there character there is a very concrete playstyle and gear set, and the in game HUD queues will walk you through everything. My entire time in combat is starting off with my bleed (3) then alternating between basic attacks 1 and 2, 2 only doing slightly buffed dmg... (I'm a rogue) and so with the quests being as monotonous as they are there isn't much left keeping my playing. What is perfected is the grindfest, if you like to grind and max out everything, this is the game for you. There are hunting logs and gathering logs to fill out. For me having all professions on one character is awful, but it's clear why some would adore this feature.I'll give it a thumbs up because this won't even get read if it's a thumbs down... but even though I spent $30 on the Heavensward bundle and I'm already done with an entire MMO, in terms of game time I do think I got my moneys worth. And somehow some people do enjoy the in game cities and story... so there has to be some type of people that does enjoy the setting that I find boring, and the actual gameplay itself. I'll say the community is also really friendly, if a bit quiet. I can totally see a shy person finding a FC they loved and then enjoying the game a lot more with other people. I really wished I liked it more, the other reviews have been great and I was really hoping for something that would blow the other MMOs out of the water. But for me now I'm downloading WoW and I'm gonna see if nostalgia has distorted my views

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is, without a doubt, the best MMO I have had the joy of playing. Of course, I grew up on Free to Plays that bombarded you with microtransactions everywhere you turned, and perhaps it's simply the feel of a clean  'I know exactly what I'm paying for' MMO that makes me love it so much.The dungeon runs are smooth, and every single party I've been in has worked extremely well together. The only quip here I might have is how long some queues take, but if you're in a Free Company, chances are you'll have at least one person there to wait with you- which speeds things up considerably, might I add. Even when I was in a dungeon queue for over an hour, all I had to do was switch gear sets and work on my Blacksmithing. So really, I view the wait times as forcing me to get off my lazy♥♥♥♥♥and work on some more 'mundane' classes.The idea of being able to play literally every class with /one/ character was, I'll admit, a little overwhelming at first. I didn't understand it all that well, but one of my companymates helped me out and showed me the ropes of juggling more than one class at a time. It's not that difficult once you're used to it.I can't say much for the soundtrack, as I listen to music of my own while playing, but I can say something about the graphics. They're absolutely stunning. Some of the best I've seen for an MMO, honestly. Even little things, down to how clothes and hair blow when the wind picks up, and how your clothes will actually change texture if it's raining to actually make them look wet.The community is actually surprisingly low-key, friendly, and helpful. I've only been playing for a few days and I've already made over 20 friends who've helped me understand quite a bit about the game. The only downside is I get a lot of whispers from spammers. They're easy enough to blacklist, which is another very well-implemented system, so it's not a big problem either.Overall, I just really enjoy XIV. Maybe I haven't been playing long enough to say my piece, but it's a stellar MMO and if you're a fan of either FF or MMOs you should definitely check it out. Make sure you have enough for the monthly fees, because it'll have you wasting all your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												For some reason Steam doesn't show me playing when I launch the game, but I do have many hours into the game. Wanted to add that before my review.It's just really good. I don't really know what to say. Whether this be your first MMO or not, it's a completely solid experience. I was out of the MMO scene for a while, pretty much stopped playing them towards the end of WoW's Wrath of the Lich King expansion. Played plenty of others, was originally really hyped for Guild Wars 2 but felt it was entirely disappointing and the genre fell out of favor with me for a while. Never was the biggest Final Fantasy fan either, of those that I've played IX is my favorite, but I had some friends get into XIV when A Realm Reborn launched and decided to try it out. I absolutely adore this game. The content is good, the progression is well done, and all the jobs feel interesting and fun and what's better is that you can do every job on one character. It has the right amount of difficulty and accesibility. You don't have to do long attunement chores to get content unlocked. Instead, you unlock content through short quests, whether it be part of the main story or side quests, and it gives you a reason to be there by giving you lore behind the dungeons.There's also plenty of end game content, and the story continues even after you hit max level. You have hard modes of dungeons you've done previously, but it's not just new mechanics as they feel like whole new dungeons. Halatali Hard has you going a different route with whole new bosses as an example. You have two 24 man raids, Crystal Tower and Syrcus Tower, and the hardest content in the game is 8 man (Coil of Bahamut). You have the post-50 primals such as Ramuh or Shiva and hard modes of the pre-50 primals like Titan HM or Titan EX. It's a game with plenty of fun and interesting encounters, and with a new expansion coming out sometime in the spring you'll have even more to look forward to including new jobs, a new race, and more story. Not to mention other post-50 content like Hildibrand which is an awesome quest-line.If you're wanting to try it out but not sure, there is a trial and I recommend sticking with it until you get to Ifrit at around level 20. The story that leads you to Ifrit and as well as the fight itself is what made me really want to see more of the game. That isn't to say there's not some low points in the story, especially pre-50, but there's some great moments and it only gets better once you hit max level on your first job.XIV provides plenty for both the hardcore raider with hitting the Coil of Bahamut, or the more causual minded MMO player who just wants to chill with friends. Was game of the year last year for me, and will probably be again this year. At least a 9/10 in the MMO genre, and currently the best subscription based MMO on the market.

												Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is, without a doubt, the best MMO I have had the joy of playing. Of course, I grew up on Free to Plays that bombarded you with microtransactions everywhere you turned, and perhaps it's simply the feel of a clean  'I know exactly what I'm paying for' MMO that makes me love it so much.The dungeon runs are smooth, and every single party I've been in has worked extremely well together. The only quip here I might have is how long some queues take, but if you're in a Free Company, chances are you'll have at least one person there to wait with you- which speeds things up considerably, might I add. Even when I was in a dungeon queue for over an hour, all I had to do was switch gear sets and work on my Blacksmithing. So really, I view the wait times as forcing me to get off my lazy♥♥♥♥♥and work on some more 'mundane' classes.The idea of being able to play literally every class with /one/ character was, I'll admit, a little overwhelming at first. I didn't understand it all that well, but one of my companymates helped me out and showed me the ropes of juggling more than one class at a time. It's not that difficult once you're used to it.I can't say much for the soundtrack, as I listen to music of my own while playing, but I can say something about the graphics. They're absolutely stunning. Some of the best I've seen for an MMO, honestly. Even little things, down to how clothes and hair blow when the wind picks up, and how your clothes will actually change texture if it's raining to actually make them look wet.The community is actually surprisingly low-key, friendly, and helpful. I've only been playing for a few days and I've already made over 20 friends who've helped me understand quite a bit about the game. The only downside is I get a lot of whispers from spammers. They're easy enough to blacklist, which is another very well-implemented system, so it's not a big problem either.Overall, I just really enjoy XIV. Maybe I haven't been playing long enough to say my piece, but it's a stellar MMO and if you're a fan of either FF or MMOs you should definitely check it out. Make sure you have enough for the monthly fees, because it'll have you wasting all your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												For some reason Steam doesn't show me playing when I launch the game, but I do have many hours into the game. Wanted to add that before my review.It's just really good. I don't really know what to say. Whether this be your first MMO or not, it's a completely solid experience. I was out of the MMO scene for a while, pretty much stopped playing them towards the end of WoW's Wrath of the Lich King expansion. Played plenty of others, was originally really hyped for Guild Wars 2 but felt it was entirely disappointing and the genre fell out of favor with me for a while. Never was the biggest Final Fantasy fan either, of those that I've played IX is my favorite, but I had some friends get into XIV when A Realm Reborn launched and decided to try it out. I absolutely adore this game. The content is good, the progression is well done, and all the jobs feel interesting and fun and what's better is that you can do every job on one character. It has the right amount of difficulty and accesibility. You don't have to do long attunement chores to get content unlocked. Instead, you unlock content through short quests, whether it be part of the main story or side quests, and it gives you a reason to be there by giving you lore behind the dungeons.There's also plenty of end game content, and the story continues even after you hit max level. You have hard modes of dungeons you've done previously, but it's not just new mechanics as they feel like whole new dungeons. Halatali Hard has you going a different route with whole new bosses as an example. You have two 24 man raids, Crystal Tower and Syrcus Tower, and the hardest content in the game is 8 man (Coil of Bahamut). You have the post-50 primals such as Ramuh or Shiva and hard modes of the pre-50 primals like Titan HM or Titan EX. It's a game with plenty of fun and interesting encounters, and with a new expansion coming out sometime in the spring you'll have even more to look forward to including new jobs, a new race, and more story. Not to mention other post-50 content like Hildibrand which is an awesome quest-line.If you're wanting to try it out but not sure, there is a trial and I recommend sticking with it until you get to Ifrit at around level 20. The story that leads you to Ifrit and as well as the fight itself is what made me really want to see more of the game. That isn't to say there's not some low points in the story, especially pre-50, but there's some great moments and it only gets better once you hit max level on your first job.XIV provides plenty for both the hardcore raider with hitting the Coil of Bahamut, or the more causual minded MMO player who just wants to chill with friends. Was game of the year last year for me, and will probably be again this year. At least a 9/10 in the MMO genre, and currently the best subscription based MMO on the market.

												Pros: - Intersting story that isn't hard to follow and has decently played out cutscenes.- Collision/Impact style based tab target, Not the usual tab target where you can clip through people/npc/enemies, It actually makes you dodge attacks and not just stand there bored pressing 1 , 2 , 3 repeatedly untill the mob dies like generic tab target games.- Brings back the old type of class systems where you can do everything on the one character, An aspect I personally love because it means you dont have to play through the same story over... and over... and over... to play the different types of classes available or master different professions - you only need the one character.- Game lets me be a Ninja Catgirl.Cons: - Pay to play.- Its still tab target.- No open world pvp/Very little pvp content.- Servers are pretty limited, Europe/Japan/NA.All in all its a good game, Probably not worth the full price unless you plan to dedicate your life to it, On special i'd definitely reccomend it, The amount of content you can do on your one character is staggering and i'd imagine it would take multiple months to get to that level so you wont be bored quickly.Take a week off work, Ignore your friends and social obligations and dive into the world of Eorzea, At the very least you'll leave with a miqo'te fetish.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Don't let my small game time dissuade you taking my review seriously, I have been playing since 1.0 and most of my logged hours are with the beta client which was patched to the retail client.Anyway not really a review, but this is hands-down the best subscription MMORPG currently on the market. It may feel strange to those who aren't familiar with the Final Fantasy franchise, but to those who are (or are familiar with the original version of FFXIV) this game is now a huge success, and it's not hard to see why.By adopting common traits found in modern MMORPGs, yet dousing it in Final Fantasy flavour, A Realm Reborn feels like an MMORPG while still feeling like a Final Fantasy game. Square Enix are committed to continually updating the game as well, with loaded content patches being released every three months since launch. I hope they continue this trend.Just be wary, you may not enjoy or appreciate the first 30 or so levels, but when you upgrade your class to a fully fledged job and can change jobs whenever you want (providing you are out of combat) and more importantly, when you experience the incredible amount of content that the endgame provides, you will realise that FFXIV is finally reaching the potential we all had hoped for.I can't wait for the first expansion this Spring.Goodbye real life.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												I played WoW for 6ish years on and off, and when I was gifted a subscription by my sister, who gave high praise of it, I I thought it couldn't play that differently. WoW set a very rigid image of how an MMO was set up to milk time whenever possible from the user to give the illusion of accomplishment. However, I began to notice very quickly that where WoW wasted your time, FFXIV ditched those gameplay mechanics and replaced it with something more sensable.First, I'll give you a brief look at classes, money, and travel. Travel first because its simple. Remember all those long flight times, and even with flying mounts it didn't compensate for having to traverse the continuous, no-loading-screen continents. In FFXIV you teleport to the zone and that's it, no fuss, maybe a little walking if your destination is in the back of zone.This ties directly into money, so that's next. In FFXIV quests actually give you some substantial amounts of money for getting everything you need from gear to materials for professions. However, repair costs ramp rather quickly, as do teleportation expenses, so part of managing your character becomes maintaining enough income to sustain everything you need. Daily quests and dungeon queues are actually important if you don't maintain any crafting/gathering skills, unlike WoW where they're a chore simply to improve a reputation with a side faction.Classes are completely different as well. Unlike WoW where you get locked into focusing on a class unless you want to start up a whole new character, and restricted to 2 professions, FFXIV puts no barriers in your way. One character can level to 50 on every tank, dps, healer, crafting and gathering profession, and there are economic and gameplay insentives for expanding your knowledge of the game with this. Every class/profession has 2-3 cross-class skills that can enchance the abilities of another, not just combat but also in professions. The more professions you level, the easier it becomes to be independant of their version of the Auction House, as well as make boatloads of money.Last, I guess I can put some facts down about differences in guilds and endgame. In WoW, you had to find a dedicated guild and organize parties yourself to complete 10 or 25 raids, which essentially the home to all the best-in-slot gear. They eventually added in a token system where hard 5 mans and the 10 mans would grant accumulative currency for buying equivalent or near-BiS items. However, you'd find yourself tediously working through a raid clear all week, and very rarely a boss would drop something useful to you (and you actually win the roll), making it akin to the lottery everytime you actually got something you needed. In FFXIV, they bipassed this by making the token gear the BiS in most or all cases. If your gear dropped in 4man dungeons you were always the only class that would be able to need on it, and even in the 8 or 24mans there would rarely be another class-mate (HEH).  Also, there's nothing particularly unique a dps brings to the table than another, same with tanks and healers. Some do things better than others, but the developers saw class balance as an important thing to accomplish, UNLIKE WOW. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ just remembering how useless they would make certain classes from patch to patch is infuriating as I'm writing this. That doesn't happen in FFXIV, in fact, you can randomly queue for the endgame raids everyday, multiple times a day if you want. Farming those tokens is easy, and queues are generally short. The only weekly restriction is on the current endgame dungeon's loot, which is 1 drop a week.TL;DR: FFXIV doesn't waste your time, and seems more interested in enjoyable gameplay than epenis upgrades to flaunt over your fellow players that are more busy IRL.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I can't believe I haven't reviewed this yet, but my play time should speak for itself. Do not confuse this game with the atrocity that was XIV 1.0. Square Enix literally dropped a Bahamut meteor on that game to crash the servers and reimagine it as the beautiful experience it is today. Graphics are top-notch, at least if you have a decent enough rig to play it on high quality. The community overall is incredible, though your experience will vary by server, play times, and free company allegiance (FFXIV's version of guilds). Inter-played cooperation is mandatory for endgame content, and the game sets you up very nicely to learn your chosen role well by level 50. And then if you decide you don't like that role... all you have to do is switch weapons to a different class and try again.Hallelujah, no more multiple characters to play multiple classes; I'm looking at you, WoW. Final Fantasy's job system makes it totally feasible to level every class to cap without having to jam up a server with 10 different characters, and you might be surprised by the number of people that do exactly that. Even the crafting system is much more interactive than others I've tried, and it's the crafters and gatherers that drive the game's economy. The sense of community is all-inclusive with plenty of experienced players willing to lend a hand to upstarts, though of course don't expect everyone to be this way. Like any game, this one has its elitists but the funny part is that some of those still haven't beaten the last raid.The best pieces of advice I can give you are these:1) If you buy the game, give it until around level 30 to start getting truly fun. That's where you unlock your job (as opposed to your class), earning you extra abilities, and it's where the dungeons start to get really fun.2) Once you hit level 50, there is a HUGE learning curve jump when you get to extreme mode primals and the Coils of Bahamut. That's not to say these things are impassable, but you will have to buckle down and learn the mechanics rather than expecting a clear on your first try.3) If you get lost, use the /sh shout function in chat. Talk to someone! I can almost guarantee there will be someone around to lend a helping hand.4) Listen when people give you advice. 90% of the time, they say it because they want to help improve their server's experience, not because they think you're a n00b that sux.5) If you're new to the game and chose the Brynhildr server, hit up Taliel Sicilian. ;)

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												This game is an overall amazing and stunning MMO to play and my favorite yet. It is very rare to find an MMO that just completely nails so many amazing features at once. This game has a very nice social aspect to it with a wide variety of emotes, housing, mini games, guilds and more that just allow the very large player base to interact like few other MMOs. This game creates a wonderful atmosphere with it's visually stunning graphic style and quality. It also features one of the hardest sets of raid content I have ever experienced. The game has a large variety of raids and dungeons at varying difficulties that allow for both casual and hard core raiders to enjoy themselves. The easier raids are just slightly more mechanically driven than WoW's Raid Finder while the highest tier of raids take more skill than almost any MMO I have played. This game almost has it all for an amazing target based MMO with amazing developers that literally took a dying game and turned it into my favorite MMO to date. I highly recommend this game to any MMO fan.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												They really improved this game- and I love that I can choose to play the same character on PC or PS4 depending on which I'd rather be on at the moment (unrelated to the PC version, but the controls work very well on PS4).It has a bit of a slow pace, and of course it's an MMO so there's grinding involved- but the game looks good, is easy to use and unlike FFXI you can solo your way through anything even if you're not a great player, while also making it easy and rewarding to group up both for dungeons and world events.It has pretty much every feature you'd expect for a modern MMO, an involving story, variety to do, and it has likely the best online community of the AAA group.You won't feel any adrenaline playing this game, but if you're looking for something relaxing it's perfect. Need a break from enemies? There's entire classes devoted to gathering and crafting you can switch to on the fly (one character can have every single class, almost like specs in another game with no respec cost). There's many mini games, even an entire zone dedicated solely to mini games (the Gold Saucer behaves much like the one in FFVII).Gathering professions are considerably more involving than other games; and even fishing's enjoyable (though, a bit limited- take in small doses).The game looks and sounds nice, but some of the voice acting is... questionable. Also, there's still a sub fee.That said- for a mainstream MMO it's one of the best, and I'm hard pressed to think of one that has the same general appeal for the f2p. Sides, a month of gameplay for an hour's work at minimum wage, or two starbucks coffees, has never seemed unreasonable to me.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												Don't let the fact that it's an MMO fool you. There's a proper Final Fantasy plotline sandwiched in between all the MMO trappings, and the main story quests can be played mostly solo if you're antisocial. From a technical standpoint the game runs really well. It's not as demanding on resources as you might think for a game as pretty as this game can be (If you're not sure it'll run well hunt down the latest benchmark utility they put out with the Heavensward expansion,) and even on the lowest settings it still looks really nice. The game's core new gameplay conceit is that you can switch classes and jobs just by swapping equipment. This works well, and some skills are even transferrable between classes which can give you a leg up. Crafting and gathering are their own classes as well, and the process of crafting high-level items can be exhilirating or heartbreaking. If you're a fan of MMO's, then there's a lot to like here. If you're a Final Fantasy fan, then there's a lot to like here. There's just a lot to like all around.

My ping to the server is around ~36, not sure what's going on there.If you're an MMORPG veteran, you'll probably enjoy it. If you've never played a MMORPG before, I'd recommend starting your journey on FFXIV, or WoW.I would recommend it to a friend.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												NEW VERSIONI got in after about a day of trying to get into the server. Once you're settled in, it takes at most 30 seconds to queue into the server on prime time.I play a tank and I get a lot of love because of that. It appears tanks are extremely rare in this game. I always get the award for playing the most needed class. This is an actual reward in the game.TUTORIALThe tutorial is huge and extremely good. It's not the type of tutorial that holds your hand, treats you like a baby and gives you little bites. It's a big tutorial that lasts throughout the entire first half of the leveling process. More features of the game open up over time, similar to Guild Wars 2's new player experience but not silly like in GW2. There are obvious tutorial instances that teach the basics of the trinity and let you actually train and figure out how the mechanics work before you get thrown into a dungeon.DUNGEONS + DUNGEON ROULETTEThere's lots of them. Main quest dungeons, sidequest dungeons, instances that only have a boss in them, etc.How does it prevent dungeons from being empty? The duty roulette system gives you a massive boost in rewards once per day. You don't pick a specific dungeon. The roulette picks it for you, meaning you never know what you'll get. Meanwhile, players who need to do a dungeon for their quests/items/gear will get their parties filled.I'll compare this with GW2 that has a party finding/LFG tool. In there, you need to actually search for party members, which works ok witht he LFG tool. In Guild Wars 1 there was no such tool and you could end up waiting for hours to get a party.WAITING FOR PARTYAs I said before, the roulette fills up parties for massive rewards. It's not unheard of to get nearly an entire level worth of exp using the daily roulette. But how fast does it fill up? For me, as soon as I click the button to start up the search.Why? Because I'm a tank and the guy who dragged me into this game is a healer. We only need to find 2 more DPS guys, of which there are bazillions. As a tank, I get friend requests all over. People are overly friendly to me. In chats and forums there is talk of not enough tanks in this game. Since I am one, I don't have a problem. But if you prefer playing DPS, you may end up waiting for a while. I've seen players complain about waiting 30 minutes or more. COMBATOkay, I'm not a fan of the combat. All I do is press 2 buttons, maybe 3 and just rotate through them. Dungeons may have a few more rotations. Just fighting in the overworld is pretty lame.Dungeon encounters are quite interesting though. You have the regular trash mobs leading up to the boss. Early bosses are pushovers. They gradually get betterCRAFTINGThere's a huge expansive crafting system. In fact, the gathering classes and crafting classes are quite fleshed out, similar to the combat classes.In the beginning it is the old basic ingredient gathering and putting them together. Later on, you need to start making choices, mixed in with a bit of RNG. Using CP, Crafting Points, which are similar to mana points, you can activate skills that can improve the quality of an item, do nothing for a step (this has a use), make you more focused, etc. Again, comparing with GW2... In GW2 you put 2-4 items together and press craft. That's it. Here, you put 2-5 (or 6?) items together, but they can be of different qualities, which affects the outcome. You activate skills which further change the outcome. Crafting one item takes several steps. These are not ingredient steps but "attacks" you do. It's not braindead coma crafting.USEFULNESS OF CRAFTING IN EARLY LEVELSCrafting is actually useful here, even in early levels. I did outlevel my crafting level. I mean, my main tank character got to level 38 but my blacksmith and armorsmith are still around 10. I didn't even need to craft items for my char to use because I got all ym gear from main-quest quest rewards. But that's just one class. There are many other classes and your character can take them all. You onlyneed one character. To swap jobs you swap out your gearset.When I start building my disciples of magic classes, I'll want to craft a bit for those.Also, all the quest rewards are normal quality, which is fine. Crafted can get high quality, which has better stats.Crafting makes more money than it costs, even at low levels. Some items cost 20gil (gold) in ingredients but sell for 500 or more, especially more if it's High Quality.HOUSINGDon't bother. It costs 20 million for a house on my server (the oldest one). 100 hours into the game and I've made 140 000 gil and I'm not even max level yet. I haven't focused on making money but I have been preparing for it. I can make some good coin selling whatever I find but I'm a hoarder and so far my hoarding paid off.There's this thing called retainers. These are NPCs you hire. They are needed to sell stuff on the market (trading post). They are also your bank/storage. You get 2 for free.These retainers can be sent on ventures. That means they will go and gather items for you. Either monster drops, mining, woodcutting or fishing. You can sell 20 items(for example 20 stacks of items totalling for example 1500 items, so not individual items.) per retainer. Ventures, unlike what you may read in outdated posts on the internet, are super cheap to buy.Here's what they don't tell you: You can buy additional retainers, for real money, at about 1-2 bucks per month. This is on top of the subscription fee.Some don't like that. I don't really care. It may be a reason not to get the game. It essentially is monthly microtransactions in a sub game.Speaking of microtransactions... there's a lot of cosmetic things that can go up to and over 25 bucks. Like mounts. I HAVE NOT REACHED ENDGAME YETI'll update this if I remember to do so.----------------------------OLD VERSIONFriend told me to get this game. Spent the 10 bucks... Been maybe 7 hours since I installed and am still on char creation screen waiting for the server to open.This may be a common issue in this type of MMO, having full servers and then having to wait and refresh and wait for a spot to open up, waiting for hours or days... it still means you're not actually playing...While the server selection screen has nice sparklers and new age music harp music, it's not really all that fun.

It really captures that sense of being in a traditional Final Fantasy game, and if you play with friends, it enrichens it that much more. Definitely would recommend.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												This game is a breath of fresh air.I've been playing since December 2013 (I played 1.0 back in September 2010 and stopped because my computer at the time could barely run it) and even when the game got grindy at times I've never not had fun. The design of the game is polished and vibrant. Almost feels like a second home sometimes. I don't have many complaints other than wishing the environments felt larger, but in Heavensward the new areas will be huge since they're adding flying mounts. The environments that do exist are GORGEOUS and even after playing this game for a year I still find ways to appreciate their design even more.Although the game is an MMORPG, the overall feel and style plays like a JRPG. Yoshi P even stated that the upcoming expansion will have 50+ hours worth of main content and will feel like a standalone game. I would feel comfortable putting FFXIV alongside the other mainstream FF titles.The story isn't very complicated, but it's entertaining enough to sit through. In typical Final Fantasy fashion you are the "Warrior of Light" and you have to save Eorzea from various threats including primals and Garleans among other things. The voice acting has improved since the first few installments of the story but it could be better. Still nice to hear a voice in an MMO story though.This game caters to both extremities of the gaming spectrum. It can be kind to casuals and newbies, and challenging and and rewarding to hardcore/veteran types. There are a wide range of activities from Chocobo Racing/Triple Triad to clearing the Coils of Bahamut (the current highest difficult raids within the game). The mechanics of boss fights range from simple dodge mechanics to complicated maneuves that require the whole group's attention to execute correctly. FFXIV is an extremely rewarding experience and I highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for an MMORPG to play solo or with friends, or to anyone who is a fan of the Final Fantasy series. This game in its current state has only been out for 1 year and a half and I am always amazed by the consistent and strong updates they make to the game. Every addition so far has only made the game better and I can't wait to witness the future of this game unfold.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												This is a beautiful, immersive and meticulously detailed game, the amazing gameplay of which will reel in franchise fans and newcomers alike. While Final Fantasy XIV is unlike its single player predecessors, the lore recognizeable by the long time FF fans creates a story with depth and character interactions generally forgotton by MMO creators. As such, the attention to detail regarding idiosyncracies of certain characters is conveyed through their speech, and this attention to detail extends to the environment as well. Small things that one would barely notice can be found in the game, such as the pattern of shadow created by light shining through a grate, as well as that shadow adjusting alongside the in game time of day; the stitching on armors and clothing, right down to the shadows created by them on the player; and many more details that add to the game's wonderful environment.Within this environment is gameplay that is executed uniquely, and superbly. Skills operate in a style familiar to MMO players, with a relatively short global cooldown, and individual skill cooldowns which vary depending on the strength and usefulness of the skill. Combat utilizes a TP, similar to a stamina system, while magic utilizes the classic MP. Some magic skills of which rely on a casting time, which occurs at the same time as the global cooldown, making casting fluent yet balanced. Skills can be clicked, hotkeyed, setup through user macros, and so forth. The combat truly appeals to every style of play, as well as every player through its broad range of classic Final Fantasy jobs that players can quest as.The questing is reminiscent of other MMOs, and yet the game approaches these concepts in ways that makes them less of a grind than they could be. Rather than the traditional, "Kill 50 of this monster," or ,"Gather 30 of this material," the quests bring these numbers down to 5s and 3s, which allows the player to take the time to actually understand WHY they are doing what they are doing.Furthermore, many players will actually be ABLE to do what they want to be doing, for the game has been optimized wonderfully. Areas are divided by loading zones, but the transition between these is so fluent and quick that it took me this long to even remember they were there. With easy to use presets such as "High end PC" or "Low end laptop," adjusting settings is user friendly. If you would like to adjust things yourself, there is of course an option for custom settings.Yet what truly sold me on the game, what I believe to be the greatest of its qualities, is the job change system. Many MMOs have you make one character, choose one class or destiny for them, and that's that. You're either forced to pay for some sort of reset, make a new character, completely start over or combinations of the above. NOT in Final Fantasy XIV. By simply equipping a new weapon, your stats, gear, abilities, everything switches to the role that weapon relates to, and you can head back to lower level areas to train yourself anew. This is done WITHOUT losing any of your previous progress. In fact certain jobs can use abilities learned from other classes, and often need to in order to reach their full potential. The best part is that no mistakes can be made with this system. There is no "woops, you didn't train your warrior class so your strength is too low," there is some minor ability point allocation, but this is done easily and can easily be reversed. A single character can serve you for every adventure, and as such, the character creation allows you to bring that perfect character to life.One truly could spend a few hours just in the character creator, detailing everything from the muscularity of your character, to their eye color, to the color of the tips of their hair vs the rest of their hair, etcetera, etcetera. There are four basic races each with two deviations in appeance to begin with, and the next perk that comes along is that you don't have to worry about "which race has the best looking armor." Armor is purely based on class, scales based on size, and doesn't vary from race to race, only between genders. There exists a range of emotions to emulate via these characters in game, if roleplay at all interests you, and the community has considerably less..."game challenged" players than other MMOs.Worth every cent of the subscription fee, Final Fantasy XIV is a game whose developers LISTEN to their community (see the 2.1 Patch) and who truly care about their game. The friendly community, and the freedom and beauty offered by the environment will leave you wondering why you didn't play this game all along.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15
												TL;DR - I am confident this is the best MMO out there, especially for a Final Fantasy fan.By far my favourite MMO of all the many ones I've played in the past. What put me off in MMOs has been worked on in this game, such as an engaging, worthwhile story, a decent sense of progression, and the greatest thing of all, being able to be all classes on one character. It has content for both casual and hardcore players, plenty of mini games and collectables, such as mounts and pets (minions, which have their own RTS mini-game now). Crafting/gathering classes are actually extremely fun for the first time in an MMO for me, so give those a shot for sure. The game can be grindy at times, but it isn't ball-achingly dull like most games. I've been subsribed for almost a year, I've taken a year break, but now I am back into it and I plan on staying for years to come. For the first time in any MMO, I've truly felt the urge to keep coming back.If you plan on playing this game, I highly suggest trying to get yourself on Gilgamesh (at certain times in the day, off-peak hours when the server isn't full and people delete characters), under the Aether data center (NA). From what I've heard, it's the place to be, and the server to get stuff done later on in the game. I moved here from an EU server and have had no lag issues whatsoever, only ones to blame on my internet.PS: Expect super over the top boss fights that the FF series is known for. A lot of them are visually stunning, it's almost distracting how amazing some of the visuals are in this game.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												There is a sharp divide in the player base. And it's the same divide you see over most of the internet and its associated communities: Half the players are awful bigots, white nationalists, and just generally gross people who sexually harass you, scream awful things in the shoutbox, or otherwise hound and harass you - these ones tend to be ex-WoW players, who joined once the game received high review praise.The rest, however, are lovely, kind people, who are pleasant to be around and always helpful.You will be pestered fairly frequently by goldfarmers trying to sell you in-game currency.The game is really good. The crafting system is a great. Battle system is solid. Party mechanics work well.You can literally try any class out with your character, just by equipping the necessary stuff.What stands out to me are little things, though - a rather robust character creation system, and the ability to dye most of the armour/equipment as you see fit.I just love things like that.Superfluous outfits are available too. And at lv.50, you obtain the ability to "glamour" your gear, to wear whatever you like without sacrificing stats.They have a system of marriage, with no restrictions on gender.Is this the first game with marriage equality? Because I can't think of any others.And that is just an awesome touch.So much love, Square-Enix.<3

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
Delightful?The game is exceptionally good for MMORPGs, and as well as having good story and mechanics it has a mature and generally friendly community who partake in serious role-play that some servers are dedicated to. Offers a huge amount of things players can do (Such as crafting, fishing and similar tasks) and encourages players to engage in Jolly co-operation with dungeons and things of the sort. Worth the money, but it requires about £8.99 / 12.99 € in subscription fees every month so while you will only get players willing to pay a decent amount of cash to play this, a lot of players are unable to play because of this. The game works very well in cohesion with steam, despite most in-game purchases and subscription payment going on at their own website they still accept steam wallet as payment. It looks beautiful and is a somewhat relaxing game to play imo, I would highly suggest giving it a try since they do offer a Free Trial[www.ffxiv-freetrial.com]. Allows you to download the demo on steam.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												This game lacks quite a lot to make it the most deep mmorpg around.It has low variety of endgame armor models, low varity of impressive graphic skills (unless you're a monk class).The grind is there, but it's not as painful as it could have been.The amount of classes is good, but lacks some core ones (2handed dmg dealer most noticable, or dual wield damage dealer outside rogue/ninja which will  be introduced shortly after I make this review)The story is quite lacking -some- times, but is quite epic at others. Lack of addon support.While these may seem as deal breakers to some the game has insane features on other departments, offering deep customization on things I didn't even know it's possible to customize. And I say that, having played all the popular (and not only) mmorpgs out there.The overall design is just FLAWLESS, and for that the game designers have my utmost respect.I don't just mean that about the graphics. The music of the primal encounters, and other major fights are just epic, well made, inspiring pieces.The boss encounters do have very interesting mechanics at time, but - as everything - once you conquer them they turn easier.The game offers a LOT to do, and it's fun as long as you interract with others.Getting into a good Guild (Free Company) is a great tip for newcommers. Many players are helpful and offer tips, and you can forge relationships which is up to you if they last.The social experience is there, and that's a part of MMOs players neglet a lot as they blindly rush towards endgame.I know I did that, and I've got ~450 hours played in about a month that I started this game.That said, this game is addicting, much like any mmorpg you enjoy (won't name other popular ones)- mmorpg players will understand. The monthly subscription is not even worth mentioning as everybody who has played mmorpgs before knows there's a vast difference in game quality, support, and other features when a game has subscription. What you pay for, you get.Should be mentioned that the game itself is relatively cheap and comes with a 30 days sub-free to try out.There's also a trial version available in which you can play for 2 weeks with max level 20 (and other restrictions).I'm quite sure a game for a console costs more(about 3 times as much) and it's a 1 week experience tops.In a market where going Free to Play seems like the only option to maintain a game, this game grows.Credit for that goes to it's nice comunity, it's regular updates, it's low downtimes, it's nice optical and accoustical experience, and most importantly to the fact that this very game in it's 1.0 version failed horribly, shut down, and was Reborn, as the title suggests, into what is currently one of the greatest of it's kind.Additional awesomeness points go to writers/translators or whoever named the Quests and FATEs in the game (FATE = Events that happen randomly in the world) - The naming is just great, at times I found myself just laughing at the screen with the things I was reading.The game is so well written I cannot even begin to explain.Overall, I feel the game was one of the most worthy purchases I've made in quite a while.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Owned it for just over 2 weeks, and got up to level 20 with my main character.The style really does make it feel like a Final Fantasy game. From the music the moment the game loads, to the style of clothing, to classic creatures such as chocobos and moogles.What also helps make the game different compared to some other MMORPGs is that your class changes simply from switching out your main weapon. This is for combat and non-combat classes. All gear has a level limit which is determined by the class, but some may also be stricted to specific classes, preventing your level 1 Marauder running around in level 50 Lancer gear, or even the other way around.I still need to decide if I will be continuing this after my initial subscription expires, but currently it is optimistic :)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game, like other MMOs, is deeply addictive. While I don't like games that involve too much grinding, Final Fantasy XIV has some fun mobs and dungeon-like events called FATEs that make leveling up your character fun rather than a chore.The graphics are beautiful, and exploring the game is a joy, especially once you play long enough to get a chocobo!With emotes, it's possible to role-play within the game if you want, but it's not necessary. There's a little less player interaction in chat that I'd like, but FFXIV forces you to play with other people via it's four- and eight-person story-based dungeons. It's a crapshoot as to whether you'll get paired up with good folks, but it definitely keeps you on your toes.All and all, I dig it. I'm about halfway through the story right now, and I like it an awful lot.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV is a beautiful game. The world design is wonderful, bringing life to new areas with each update. Dungeons are fun, interesting, and easy to get into. While there is a primary storyline, which you need to follow to unlock different aspects of the game, a lot of the side quest are unique and very filling. When I say filling, I simply mean that there is a lot of "stuff" to do. From slaughtering cacturns, to exploring new areas; each quest comes along with an interesting narrative.When I first started to play, I joined up with two pals from beta. They were significantly higher level than me, but were able to help me by lowering level to match my own. It really made the game more fun, and we got a few good laughs out of the dungeons. They had me join up in their Free Company, and now I've got lots of people to just hang out with and dungeon run with.Sure the cost isn't exactly cheap, but it is easily worth the monthly fee. Besides that, the only real issue is that even on the lowest graphics, it can still slow down a computer to a crawl.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												Don't purchase this game from Steam as they will give you a "key" that will not allow you to login to the game or register the game successfully. Even after logging into the account management section for Square Enix, I still could not use the key that STEAM provided. I attempted to use it at the login screen that prompts use of the key, as well as the actual account management site AND Mogstation. So just when you sit down and have some free time to play, you actually have to contact Square Enix, sending and email, since their chat support is offline on Weekends, only to find that you have to wait for a response for more than a day or two. So at this point, when you do get a reply, its likely that you go back to work, bummed that you did not get a chance to play the game that you purchased, because STEAM and SQUARE ENIX can't get their crap together and communicate effectively and the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥gets passed along, down the hill to the customer, even after they are both multi-million dollar companies. That is laziness and stupidity in its finest. Rant over. P.S. Yes I have played FFIX on both PC and PS4, but took a break and decided to come back. What a waste of time, lol. Now for the review. It's a fun MMORPG, polished and continually improving. The map system still sucks, hopefully that will one day improve. Auto-Travel to quests would be nice, who knows, maybe they have that now. I don't know, I have not gotten back in the game yet. It still has cat-girls, so it is not all that bad, lol. The raids can be confusing, because of the crazy stuff going on in your team hot bars, so you just hope the DPS does not pull to much Aggro from the Tanks and the Healers do their part and everyone avoids dying horribly, you know the usual. That being said, don't expect more from this game than any other MMORPG, they are all clones, with different character models, animations and so on. There are some neat aspects that I believe they are learning from MMORPGS where you have to dodge, like Wildstar and Tera, but with a better story and player base. Get it. It's another pretty way to waste your time and meet others who are also wasting their time. Enjoy.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												I've played my fair share of MMOs, and I have to say, this one tops them all quite easily.The graphics are pretty damn good, and it runs really well on almost any system.I'm used to grinding in MMOs, and so far I've yet to really do anything 'grindy'.For an MMO, it has a story that is actually good. And believe me, they did it well. Each story mission immediately leads into the next, with no need to grind levels between.The class or 'job' system is a really neat structure that works very well. you can change class when you want, and level everything on one character. No need to make alts to try other classes.Only complaint I have is that you can't go swimming (invisble walls stop you from going into deep water).And remember there is a 14 day trial if you want to try it out! Highly reccomended.

												I've been playing Videogames for over 25 years now  and MMORPG for like 10 my first one was FFXI->Everquest->Aion->TERA and now FFXIVI didn't want to play it before ARR it was until FFXI took over I gave it a chance:Good:Graphics Look Amazing some voice acting through CS is always welcome.Story isn't the best ever but quite good.Jobs with different utilities and such.Hours/Days/Months of content and enjoyment even better with friends.Bad:It gets dull overtime you overcome the content (Like Story/Extremes/Raids).You will end doing dailies if you ran out of things to do with your endgame char or lvl up jobs you don't even like to use later on (mostly through FATES) just to make your sub worthy.Endgame community is quite toxic/elitist and forget that this is a game people are suppose to have fun with.This game is great,I recommend you to switch between other games or unsub for a few months until new content comes and so on don't feel forced to pay every month if you barely play it.I recommend this game to anyone who is looking to play an awesome mmorpg but not for a lifetime, it is up to you anyways :D

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												There is a sharp divide in the player base. And it's the same divide you see over most of the internet and its associated communities: Half the players are awful bigots, white nationalists, and just generally gross people who sexually harass you, scream awful things in the shoutbox, or otherwise hound and harass you - these ones tend to be ex-WoW players, who joined once the game received high review praise.The rest, however, are lovely, kind people, who are pleasant to be around and always helpful.You will be pestered fairly frequently by goldfarmers trying to sell you in-game currency.The game is really good. The crafting system is a great. Battle system is solid. Party mechanics work well.You can literally try any class out with your character, just by equipping the necessary stuff.What stands out to me are little things, though - a rather robust character creation system, and the ability to dye most of the armour/equipment as you see fit.I just love things like that.Superfluous outfits are available too. And at lv.50, you obtain the ability to "glamour" your gear, to wear whatever you like without sacrificing stats.They have a system of marriage, with no restrictions on gender.Is this the first game with marriage equality? Because I can't think of any others.And that is just an awesome touch.So much love, Square-Enix.<3

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												They really improved this game- and I love that I can choose to play the same character on PC or PS4 depending on which I'd rather be on at the moment (unrelated to the PC version, but the controls work very well on PS4).It has a bit of a slow pace, and of course it's an MMO so there's grinding involved- but the game looks good, is easy to use and unlike FFXI you can solo your way through anything even if you're not a great player, while also making it easy and rewarding to group up both for dungeons and world events.It has pretty much every feature you'd expect for a modern MMO, an involving story, variety to do, and it has likely the best online community of the AAA group.You won't feel any adrenaline playing this game, but if you're looking for something relaxing it's perfect. Need a break from enemies? There's entire classes devoted to gathering and crafting you can switch to on the fly (one character can have every single class, almost like specs in another game with no respec cost). There's many mini games, even an entire zone dedicated solely to mini games (the Gold Saucer behaves much like the one in FFVII).Gathering professions are considerably more involving than other games; and even fishing's enjoyable (though, a bit limited- take in small doses).The game looks and sounds nice, but some of the voice acting is... questionable. Also, there's still a sub fee.That said- for a mainstream MMO it's one of the best, and I'm hard pressed to think of one that has the same general appeal for the f2p. Sides, a month of gameplay for an hour's work at minimum wage, or two starbucks coffees, has never seemed unreasonable to me.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14
												People complaining about how this game has a subscription service.People call this game pay to win, its pay to play. There's a difference.Pay to win is the ability to pay for items or in-game currency to gain an advantage over players.Pay to play is a subscription service to keep the game running and keep updates rolling out. If the company didn't make any profit off of this, they would most likely abandon it. As you can see, hundreds of thousands of people don't play this, but it still has an active community.If you complain about this game not being free, complain about World of Warcraft as well, one of the most popular, if not THE most popular mmo out there.I would recommend the game to people who do like WoW, but dislike the 2002 graphics.Play with friends, or find a free company. Community is great.Gameplay : The game has a similar if not identical gameplay system to World of Warcraft. There is a high variety in classes you can choose from, that fits your playstyle.The game has good tutorials that you can use that can be accessed at anytime for reference.If you can't find out how to do something, join a guild, or ask a friend and ask.Or google it.Google exists.Grinding mobs isn't really a thing. Just do leveling roulette and do a dungeon for your level.Classes: Make a character, pick a class, switch whenever.You can change from a gladiator to a conjurer to a pugilist at anytime. Of course you can't do it in combat or in a dungeon, but you can still try out everything.Gear : Main quest should supply you with the gear you need. If not, buy it off the market. If you're poor, run dungeons and get gear from there.Staff and Support : You can enter a support ticket for any bugs or questions that are not found in the FAQ. The FAQ also acts as a tutorial when you can't find out something. Otherwise google it.Google exists.They usually respond within a couple hours or a day, from my experience.Story : So much story. So much. This game is not enjoyable if you don't pay attention to the story. You will end up not knowing what you are even doing. Basically saying, don't rush the game.Bad♥♥♥♥♥♥: Boring without friends.Story can get boring.Everything can get boring.The game thrives on community and pretty features.You can expect to find me in the Primal data center in Malboro under the name Naomi Sato.Oh you get a 30 day trial which you can basically level up to the max level in a good amount of time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15
												TL;DR - I am confident this is the best MMO out there, especially for a Final Fantasy fan.By far my favourite MMO of all the many ones I've played in the past. What put me off in MMOs has been worked on in this game, such as an engaging, worthwhile story, a decent sense of progression, and the greatest thing of all, being able to be all classes on one character. It has content for both casual and hardcore players, plenty of mini games and collectables, such as mounts and pets (minions, which have their own RTS mini-game now). Crafting/gathering classes are actually extremely fun for the first time in an MMO for me, so give those a shot for sure. The game can be grindy at times, but it isn't ball-achingly dull like most games. I've been subsribed for almost a year, I've taken a year break, but now I am back into it and I plan on staying for years to come. For the first time in any MMO, I've truly felt the urge to keep coming back.If you plan on playing this game, I highly suggest trying to get yourself on Gilgamesh (at certain times in the day, off-peak hours when the server isn't full and people delete characters), under the Aether data center (NA). From what I've heard, it's the place to be, and the server to get stuff done later on in the game. I moved here from an EU server and have had no lag issues whatsoever, only ones to blame on my internet.PS: Expect super over the top boss fights that the FF series is known for. A lot of them are visually stunning, it's almost distracting how amazing some of the visuals are in this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Ignoring my playtime (I actually rebought the game on Steam, I'm sure I'd have upwards of a few hundred hours otherwise) this is one of the only MMOs I've been able to get into. It reminds me of the WoW glory days but it seems to have learnt from WoW's mistakes. HOWEVER, keep in mind it's practically a WoW clone in some regards. This is a very 'traditional' mmo. An excellent one, but it still isn't exactly gamebreaking innovative anywhere. You still have the old school action hotbar combat with tab targetting, you still work off an ability rotation, the holy trinity class system is here, etc.If you don't LIKE those systems, then this game probably isn't for you. If you're looking for an alternative to the giant that is WoW then this is an excellent choice. Personally as someone who LOVED Guild Wars 2 but was immensely bored by the lack of end game (And ♥♥♥♥ Anet's expansion and how they handled pricing) FFXIV was an extremely welcome sight. This game has some of my favorite raids and a seriously massive amount of end game content with lots more being added every few months. Even if you aren't a super hardcore MMO player I find the game excellent to revisit every few months just to check out the new content.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Fantastic game, HORRIBLE customer support.Technically, we own the game on PS4 and PC so it's not even remotely close to the time actually played, but that doesn't matter, what matters is my impressions.I'll also preface by saying I just started playing this, so I don't have as much experience or knowladge as my brother, but I've been playing FF games and MMORPGs for many many years so it's not too hard to grasp.I am a massive FF fan. Have been my entire life, and always will be. It's a tried and true series that I always come back to (whether it's Kingdom Hearts, the OG FF games or new ones) and I gotta say, this one holds up at the top. If you've been missing the high-fantasy style that the series has maybe "lacked" in the past few years, look no further. This is true Final Fantasy spirit. To break it down simply:-The combat it tab-target, but just feels so much more exciting. Every hit packs a punch that isn't there with most games except TERA. -I don't pay much attention to story in MMO's since 99% of the time it's pointless fetch quest filler with some over-arching theme that really doesn't go anywhere till endgame, so I mean don't expect to be paying $15/month (or whatever I'm paying) for a crazy story. -The graphics (which I got on max) are incredible, let alone for an MMO, but it's to be expected for an FF game. The character model detail is amazing and the world looks so clear at all times of day.Here's where things get realllllllyyyyyyy rough.Square Enix has the worst support/instructions/literally everything that isn't the game itself is the worst I've ever experienced.Let me tell you a story.I long while ago in a far off land, my brother bought FF14 on PS4 on my PSN account. Simple. Started playing till I kicked him off, so he buys it on my Steam. Simple. Well. No. Not that simple. One day I decided to start playing myself but because the PSN account is now linked to his SE account, I was unable to even change the USERNAME box on the FF14 menu when trying to log in. Okay, so I tried Steam, still, when I enter my details it asks me for a registration key (as if I didn't already own the game?) So we scoured the internet for days, finding literally no information as to how it was possible for me to play. So, being the guy my brother is, he bought it a 2nd time on PS4 (so we could get another key, ya know?) NOPE. $25 down the drain, he doesn't even get a confirmation email, no code, nothing. Nothing at all. So I created a new SE account, then what? It asks me to log in with a "one time password." Okay? So I get the app that gives me a one time password, then what you ask? IT ASKS ME TO PUT IN MY ONE TIME PASSWORD TO GET A ONE TIME PASSWORD. WHAT?????? Meanwhile, my brother finds out the they can apparently unlink your SE account from PSN once, so he asks to get that, and they don't reply back with anything, and nothing has changed. So I created a new EMAIL to create ANOTHER SE account, and I had to purchase the game off of THEIR site, in which they didn't send me anything after paying until I contacted their support telling them I never got my game, in which they didn't even reply. I just simply FINALLY got an email with the code. We now own FIVE copies of this F$0^ing game. Worst time I've ever had trying to just play a game. But man, is it good. Yes. Yes it is. I also say this as someone who hates P2P with a burning raging passion so maybe that says something?
