number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Pro's: The game is beautiful. Even on medium settings the game looks great and runs smoothly. The story is actually enthralling and is keeping me interested and I don't find myself speeding through text and skipping cinematics. Atleast, not for the main stories lol. The monsters are really well done and there are a wide variety from cute and cuddly (i.e the Cactus monster thing...) to the scary *** demons. The dungeons are fun and it seems that most of them tie in with the main story so you in a sense have to unlock them. Same goes with getting your first chocoboCons: There are some things that really do bug me in this game which may be just superficial on my part. The first is how the map is. When zoomed out to look at a regional view all you see are name blocks with lines directing which zones are connected. It's not like a google map view that you find in most mmo's. Along with that is trying to find where to go with quests. Some mmos if you have quest lets say 3 zones over, will usually point you to the nearest exit from the current zone into the next. This game doesnt seem to do that. If you have a quest in one zone over, sure it will show you. But if it is 2 zones over then you need to go and track it down. The zones themselvs I wish were not instanced. Even parts of the main cities are instanced. I personally like complete open world games. Or at the very least, the main cities should not be broken into instances. Getting a mount is kind of a pain. You need to progress to roughly lvl 20 before you get the quest to get a mount. Then you need to go farm some tokens in order to get a certificate. That part isnt necessarily hard just annoying. Even if you have the collectors edition and have the two mounts already, you need to get the normal chocobo first before you can use them. My biggest gripe however, is the use/lack there of of voice over for the games. Some main story cinematics will have voice overs, some dont. Some times you will have voices then all of a sudden you dont. It's not my sound card, or computer, or whatever, it's the developers that didnt put in voice acting for the whole game. I hope they do add in more sometime down the line. Overall though this is a very well done game and I am impressed. Even with the nuances I am enjoying the game immensly and definitely recommend playing it even if it's just the trial.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												As one of the MMO players, This game is not bad at all, and I will not compare it to any other game whether it's a bad or good thing. all I have to say is that this game didn't lower my expectations. I can tell you that this game seems more directed towards its story however. Even with a week of experience of playing this game, a friend of mine and I haven't even went passed lvl 10 on our second try. either because of story delay, or just how slow we are. so it isn't really favoring the "just lvl up and do battlegrounds and raids" but other than that this game kept me really busy. even knowing that i would hit the lvl cap, I would probably make another character.   This is a great opportunity to take a monthly break from WoW and other FTP or PTP MMO games. what also got me interested playing this game is the change on its audio, subtitles, ETC. Regarding that it's developed by SE. I really can't stand english voice acting. Upon knowing this as soon I started listening to Japanese voice actors, I felt comfortable playing the game. I don't know about you guys, but After playing a few games that originated in Japan, the difference between voice acting is sychronizing with the mood. That's how I see it. When it comes to english voice acting, I always expect few if not most, messed up on certain occasions, and I'm always afraid it's always on the best parts.That's all I can offer on my review on this. I'm sure there are more helpful ones than mine.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												This game is beyong anything I could have ever imagined.Gameplay wise, the game is smooth, easy going, and rather slow paced. The start of the game may seem a bit grindy, but the more you progress, the more features you unlock. Every quest you complete seems rewarding.The environment one of the most beautiful I have seen in any MMO, being easily comparable to games like Tera Rising. The graphics are absolutely phenominal and the attention to detail makes the game really immersive.The community as far as what I have experienced contains some of the nicest people I have ever met in an online game. People are inclusive and ready to help new players out.The only issues I have had with this game are a global cooldown of 2.5 seconds, although you  get used to it quite fast, and the lack of voiceacting in cutscenes. Voiceacting could have deserved a little more focus, especially seeing as when you actually get to experience it, it is absolutely great, funny and immersive. That's literally the only issues I have had though, and if you are able to ignore these minor things, you are going to have a one-of-a-kind experience.I will update my experience with this game the more I progress through it.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Ok. First of all I am not an MMORPG fan. I Have played 2 before and not for very long. I swore I would NEVER pay for a subscription fee. Now I have paid for one and do not regret it at all. This game is awesome. The amount of stuff you can do in game is impressive as are the graphics and framerate if your PC can handle it.  I have so far played as 2 different classes and to me they feel different. I play them different, which is a good thing. People are generally pretty helpful to noobs and not total d1ckfaces, Although you do get some of those too to be fair.The community seems to be pretty tightly knit and friendly. Within a few minutes on each of 2 servers I have played on, I have been invited to join Free Companys. Or Guilds if you prefer.There does seem to be a fairly steep learning curve with menus and such, and the game doesn't really explain them very well if at all. Stick with it, ask questions and experiment and after a while you will get the hang of it. The map can be daunting at times. I find I'm getting better at it all of the time, but initially it can really mess you up. Especially when there can be different height levels in some areas such as towns. The map does not shift up or down to accomodate your vantage point. When playing with a party, it seems you will share/split experience. That can be pretty cool. Audio is good and has some classic FF music, which is nice.Graphics are incredibly vibrant and colorful, like you'd expect from a FF game.Character interactions are a little tedious. You read alsmot EVERYTHING. Even most cutscenes are not voiced. Although there are a few. Account creation is a  little weird. Especially when you have to use the game client+the website+subscribe and link your account. This could have been a little less confusing. When a friend wants to join you and they just got  the game it is entirely possible that they may not be able to join you. The  world you are on might be full. They can't wait for someone just to logoff. That doesn't seem to work. They have to hope that someone deletes a character at some point I have a lvl 12 character in one world and my friend cannot join me. I had to create a new character on a new world to play with them. One last thing: I believe, (and I might be wrong about this), that you get 8 character slots per world. To give you an idea, there are roughly 8 worlds per server area and about 7 server areas. That is pretty impressive. Would I recommend this game to people? Sure if you are a Final Fantasy fan or an MMO fan. Not for everybody...but I'm loving it so far.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Wow, this game man, this game. After of awful the original FF14 was, i was quite sceptical to buy and play this game, and after a few review searches and decided upon buying it and wow am i glad i did.If you love a entertaining story, even though it has a slow start, this will be the game for you. Everything about the game screems to you with a beatiful final fantasy charm. With music and grapichs that sound and look quite stunning, am entertained by running around on a chocobo at times and looking at the scenary that is around me.The gameplay is a drastic improvement over the previous game and borrows several mechanins from other mmo's and adds its own new ones, and everyone mash quite good together.Since this is an mmo game and a final fantasy game, expect grinding near the end, but at least with pretty scenary. Of course, atm moment of this review i will not recomend the game for those that look to mmo games for PvP. They do have a PvP arena, but because of some server lagg it will not be that fun at all. There is also no open world PvP like there is in Star Wars The Old Republic or World of Warcraft.The game in itself consentraits on the PvE content and has given us some really hard dungeons and trials to rage quit over. And if these are the things you are looking for, prepare to be sucked in and suddenly find that its 10 hours later.EDIT: By patch 2.3 they have added a 24v24v24 pvp battle arena which should be fun enough, but of course even that has its issues.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												It's funny how I read forums from 3 years ago about how people will be surprised if this game becomes big and successful... And then I go play this game. 20+ year gaming vets agree this game does more right than its beaten-to-death-then-beat-some-more-horse of a cousin. Also, CHOCOBOS AND MOOGLES!Rode a chocobo to a chocobo farm to talk to a chocobo trainer to get a quest to summon my chocobo to assist me in battles and quests to get different chocobo gear and hope to one day fly my chocobo in the skies of Ishgard amongst other chocobos.Chocobo/10.In all honesty though, it's very polished. Also, certain features really appeal to me that don't appear in many other games. The job system for example. I always end up making a bunch of characters and never getting as far as I'd like on any of them in MMO's because I want to try every class. In this game, I can do every class on one character! Perfect! With the recent switch to Direct X 11, the game is better lit and more reflective than ever! Janitors of of Eorzea all are standing proud at the gleam of their polished floors! Well done and a helmet tip to those fine gentlemen and gentlelalas on your travels mustn't be overlooked!AND I HAVEN'T EVEN GOTTEN TO THE FLYING MOUNTS YET!

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												my recommendation is a 51/49 yesthe game is fun up until you get to end-game (at least from when this review is written, we'll see future updates)but they are abusing player's timeif you wanna do end-game things, you better not have a IRL job and no friends to play with, because you're never going to get maxed jobs/classes (jobs as in gathering + crafting) with all fully equippedthere's not enough time to do all that, mainly because of how limited you are, /450 gathering/crafting points a week for example...also for the anima weapon (the very end-game weapon you can get) there are, at the moment, 3 steps to level it... one is doing some fates... that... ok... takes maybe 2-3 hours for each things in that step (like on 5-6 maps)then it's doing dungeons, also easythen you need to farm different things, but if you wanna play more casually, like me and my friend, you need to farm EVERY DAY NON STOP FOR 3 MONTHS!! no joking, it's about 87 days... the tribe quests (not the last, vanu one, which would be even worst) but the 4 other tribesthose tribe quests takes like 30 mins to do a day... IF you're lucky and not get into fate quests because some of them can take 30 mins or even 1h to 1h30 to pop (that one in sylph tribe...)ok i'll be nice and inform about the reason of it being so slow : i sometimes do them at night and there's no one playing, so no one doing the fates and so it takes longer to pop those ones you needso farm it for 3 months is the best casual-wayand in that same step afterwards you need to craft 4 times each 4 different items (each one of a different crafting job) in high quality...so you already need to get your crafting and gathering jobs up to that point... and you can only have 3 job crystals at a time, with that 450 point limit a week it will take forever even with the best items equipped -_-so basically end game = work-at-farm festand this is in "game" categoryworking isn't playing

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												This game has some interesting mechanics that help it stand out. First off, the multiclassing system is pretty neat. At around level 10 your character gains the ability to level up in other classes simply by equipping the weapon associated with that class. All of your stats and gear can also be independently associated with those other classes, which basically means that other than race, gender, or name, you can experience all the content of the game with just one character.The graphics are quite nice, although not spectacular. The textures are a bit soft and the game has a fairly stylistic, cartoony feel. However, aesthetically the game is beautiful. There's not a single ugly character to be found anywhere, except perhaps the giant or tiny races, and that just depends on your taste.Combat doesn't stray far from standard "Diku-MUD" style tab-targeting / hotbar combat like you'd find in almost any other MMO since EQ. They do manage to mix it up a bit, however, with attack chains and synergies, encouraging you to mix up your rotation depending on the situation. Many enemies also telegraph their attacks, which is a trend that is becoming more and more common in the genre.Questing is fairly standard, with only a few very special quests featuring cutscenes or voiceovers. Quest objectives usually consist of escorts, defending against waves of enemies, run and fetch, click on various sparkly objectives scattered around, or kill X number of mobs. Again, this is pretty much what you'd expect from almost any MMO.There are a few interesting twists on the standard questing model, however. Scattered around the gameworld are various public quests called "Duties" which usually automatically activate once you get in range. Sometimes they're triggered by speaking to an NPC. These work almost exactly like the public quests of Guild Wars 2 or the rifts and invasions in Rifts. Aside from that, each class has a monster journal which tracks various enemy kills. The enemies you need to kill in order to fulfill the various objectives in your journal are marked with a special icon, and when you complete a set, you get a fairly decent amount of XP. This makes it fun to just run around hunting for these mobs and doing the public quests.Speaking of mobs, the enemy designs are fantastic. The various types of creatures you're likely to encounter often have surprising and very creative designs. This is fairly typical for Asian MMO's, but fairly rare here in the West. This, combined with the beautiful character designs, is where FFXIV shows its chops by blending Eastern and Western sensibilities to create a compelling overall experience.There's also a player housing system, and although I haven't tried them myself, I hear the dungeon encounters are really well done.All that said, I find that this game hasn't really managed to get me hooked for some reason. Maybe it's the stale controls and format, which is almost too reminiscent of almost every other mainstream MMO of the past 15 years. Another problem is the quest tracker. While it's pretty good about showing you where quest objectives are on your map, if you have quests located in another zone, it's not always easy to figure out where to go. I also found myself frequently having to do a lot of backtracking. I'd be questing around in a certain zone until I'm too low for the content. Then  I'd have to run all the way back to a central area and then head off in a different direction to find quests I missed which by then would be several levels below me. This might not be as much of an issue if you're not a completionist and you decide to do more leveling with the duty and achievement system, or you've already leveled up a couple times and you're more familiar with where the quest hubs are. I guess I've gotten too spoiled by "breadcrumb" style questing, which was first popularized by WoW.I decided not to pick up a subscription and continue past the trial. This is a great game, don't get me wrong, but it's just not for me. There are too many great games out there to justify another subscription. I'm already subscribing to 3 or 4 other MMO's that I rarely ever play.  Personally, I think a better model would be for MMO's to let pre-pay, maybe at a rate of 5 or 10 cents per hour for full VIP access. Then you can spend those hours however and whenever you like, without the pressure to keep playing to justify your subscription.Do I recommend this game? Yes, if you're looking for an MMO with tons of content and features that you can sink hundreds of hours into, absolutely. If you're a "one-game" type of person and you're looking for a great fantasy MMO, you can't go wrong with this one. However, if you have a huge steam library and/or you're already subscribed to one or two other MMO's, this one doesn't really offer anything new and interesting enough to justify another subscription. Even though I'm uninstalling, I'm still going to give this game a thumbs up. Square Enix really did an excellent job and they deserve kudos.

Atm I'm still an active WoW player so I decided not to continue my sub to XIV but over the month I tried it I was convinced that the price is reasonable and worthwhile if you plan on making this your MMO of choice to focus on. As a fan of Final Fantasy this game definitely scratched the itch to see the worlds again and enjoy the familiar settings and creatures and enemies usual to the series. Combat is solid, and crafting as well, quests are relatively normal as far as MMO quests go, not a massively innovative experience but if you're not looking for something amazingly new and different and just want this because you enjoy Final Fantasy you will not be disappointed.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												A top contender for one of the best-worst MMO's ever.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -FFXIV had a bit of a rough start when it first launched which prompted Square to create an end-of-the-world Event that ended Version 1.0 ( 1.23 or higher ). This event is always shown as the intro to the game in form of a fantastic CGI video with a rather sad sounding song. However, if you ask me, I dare to say that they planned it from the start as it would give them a great amount of publicity.Here are some of my top complaints of the game.* There is no freedom. It's another Hallway-game.* The storyline is absolutely atrocious, but it does have a few gems.* It feels like work, without pay. You work, and you gain nothing.What I mean when I say there's no freedom, is that just like FFXI it isn't an open world game. You walk from zone to zone. This was fine when it was in FFXI because of it's role as one of the first MMO's. This is NOT okay in an MMO of 2010+. For example, every single town is split up into two separate zones, usually as one top and one lower section. In Limsa Lominsa, this can become utter ridiculous where the lower Limsa crystal can have 20 people standing around, yet because of it's divide you'll never see any people if you are on the upper half because the lower part when watching from upper is a separate instance.This was done I recon in order to make things run smoothly or whatever, but it's just stupid in all honesty.This leads us into the other part. Jumping is a lie. You don't actually jump in the game - You just display a Jump animation. Let me explain: There's no true Z-axis in FFXIV that measures if you are moving vertical. If you can walk it, you can jump it. But if you can't walk it, you can never jump it. Combine this with the fact that everything is divided into zones and we find out the true nightmare of a player of the explorer type - A gilded Cage.Which leads us into the expansion, Heavensward where they introduced flying mounts. They work differently in that they do count the Z-axis, but your jumping still don't. And the most damning fact of it all that everyone I know hate - Aether Currents. A completely, arbitrary thing that Square Enix pulled out of their asses just to spite players. If you want to fly, you better hunt each and everyone down in ONE ZONE in order to fly in just THAT zone. And the hilarious part of this is that usually when you've found all Currents, you're done with that zone so why would you ever go back to it? This makes it so that the only zone worth spending time finding them in is the Churning Mists because at least there, you can fate grind from like 52 to 60Make no mistakes. FFXIV is work. It's not a journey to gain strength, it's just good ol' labor for everything except by the end of the day, you'll have gained nothing of true worth. You're not stronger, you're not more skillful - You're just screwed over.Finally, and here's the golden anaconda of it all.The storyline, is rancid. You really need to try hard to make a story that sucks this much. Just about every single NPC has a special kind of stupidity to them that's out of this world. I have heard D&D players who made joke characters still be better than these numbnuts! And just like how Square usually makes games these days,You are not the Hero.People have joked around about MMO's always telling how everyone is special and they are the chosen ones and all that. FFXIV does this the opposite way. It makes you do all the work, but you are never the hero of this tale. Even after you complete a full storyline and have your fame reach the far wides of Eorzea, you're still going to be everyone's errand boy and if some special NPC shows up, they'll push you aside and go " No! This is something I must do! I who haven't lifted a single finger since you saw me must deal with this enemy!  " or " No -Name-! This enemy is too strunk for us! We must flee! " even though you just eliminated an entire army just to get to that point.It's like Square looked at Mystic Quest and went " Oh man! This is amazing! Let's take ideas from this game! "= = =In conclusion, I cannot recommend FFXIV to anyone.I have spent over 800 hours with the game.I've had some good moments, and I have screamed from the top of my lungs about the story.I have met friends, I got a random guy and his girlfriend to get into the game and they love it, but my hate only grew.If you think you can stand all these things, then I implore you to try the trial out.But otherwise, I cannot recommend this game to anyone with two braincells.PS. I am slightly wrong about Jumping, but in grand gist of it I am right. Jumping in FFXIV is largely a pointless ordeal.

												This game is super fun. it does a good job of teaching you how to do your jobs, via what is called guildheists. although some people ignore this, it is quite essential for tanks and healers, not so much for DPS.it keeps you in the game with a good story (alot of dialogue though) and even if you dont carea bout the story the combat is fun. Everybody plays a role too DPS has to kill adds/mobs and sometimes interact with the environment, the healer has to make sure that the whole party stays well and sometimes also interact, and the tank better know those boss mechanics and tell the party while also making it easy for the other members.but im babblibg, all in all i give this game a 9/10 really deserves it PvP and PvE are fun, the community is nice (as long as you dont mess up too bad) and healers, stop rage quitting.good luck and have fun in Eorzea!

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												A fantastically well made MMO that uses some unique gameplay systems and really makes the game shine. It takes a lot of the core elements from other successful mmo's and solidifies and cleans them up to make them 100% better. You can really feel the high quality of the game as you play it and experience the world, it feels like a true adventure compared to a lot of mmo's that I've played due to the variety in leveling and the choices for how you want to play that exist in the game. You can play every class on a single character which is one mechanic that I greatly enjoy and prefer over having to create alternate characters to experience different gameplay styles.The gameplay is relatively fast paced compared to Final Fantasy XI or any other Final Fantasy title, as it plays like World of Warcraft but with a global cooldown for most of the abilities. This isn't a bad thing at all, and the global cooldown was never a problem for me since it isn't all that noticeable with everything else going on around you. Dungeons are fun to play and easy to hop into due to the duty finder that is in the game, but it is even more fun to create a group outside of the duty finder and then hop into a dungeon with a pre-made party. Making friends in-game is also relatively easy compared to Final Fantasy XI or any older mmo really due to the large and friendly playerbase. In my experience, everyone except for maybe a few players were all exceptionally friendly and sociable, and within hours of playing I was able to joing a small FC (Free-Company, the guild system in the game) and they turned out to be great friends. The game is well backed by the dev team and I forsee the game continuing for a long time to come with great amounts of content updates and expansions, maybe even excedding the support that Final Fantasy XI got over the years. Seasonal events are plentiful and always fun to participate in, and the game is overall a great experience. I'd highly reccomend playing it if you are a fan of MMOs or of the Final Fantasy series looking for something a bit different.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												A Year in review of Final Fantasy XIV-Content-You get more than your moneys worth you get many jobs to level you have crafting which I can say my brother he’s no lifed for weeks on end, There is the now full Binding of Coils of Bahamut Raids to participate in if you want a challenge, There is also the three part 24 man Crystal Tower Raids, Summoned Beasts known as Primals each taken from the summons from previous Final Fantasy games are here to challenge your resolve from Ifrit to Odin!, and HOURS worth of story to enjoy and speculate on. Want to prove dedication to you chosen job? Work on a relic its at least 3-4 weeks of content to do to get a beautiful looking top tier weapon.-Graphics-For an MMO the game is beautiful lush green landscapes of Gridania, the mountainous plains of Limsa Lominsa, and the scorching deserts of Thanalan. Each of these environments are flushed out with amazing textures for a game in this genre.-Gameplay-You get two options to fit how you choose to play keyboard and mouse or controller both are equally viable options I personally use a controller its literally the most amazing thing to play an mmo effectively with a controller square nael'd it (puns!)-Community- It’s the same thing everywhere in any online game you get those people who are way to competitive for their own good and take this game way to seriously. You have your fun people who just want to do stuff and mess around. There is free companies which is the "Guild" system in this game start one with your friends and build a community or find one you fit into. Who knows you might find someone special I know I did :3-Overall-I have spent way too much time I care to admit to in this game I just cant fuly get bored of it because I keep coming up with new goals to work on there really is alot to do and there will be even more to do when we get to Ishgard in Heavensward!10/10

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												FFXIV:ARR is my first full experience with an MMO.  I tried XI, but found the learning curve and controls to be more that I had the patience to deal with.  XIV is casual and controller friendly, but most importantly to me, it's a Great Final Fantasy game.The game does the standard Tank | Healer | DPS trinity and knowing your role is important.  If you Don't Rush through the story to lvl 50, there's enough opportunity to become familiar with your role(s) of choice, and plenty to do after your first 50.A single character can be (level) every class in the game and is based on (gains experience with) Weapon/Tool in hand.  As you level each class, you gain skills that can be shared in select other classes.  In addition to classes, there are jobs which provide unique skills.  Jobs can be acquired when a Primary class reaches 30 and a secondary class reaches 15.  This is all explained in-game.In addition to the fighting classes, there are crafting and gathering classes.  I initially had NO Interest in this, but at one point decided I'd try my hand at one of them.  IF you enjoy it, it's ridiculously addictive.  If you find it tedious, leave it to those who don't.Story, Graphics, Gameply... I'm loving them all.  I've been playing since Aug 26th 2013 and to date immensely enjoy this game.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												This is like an MMO turducken for me, seriously.  It has things I like from a few different MMOs, but never had in one.  In addition to the standard MMO quests, it has a storyline going through it that you'd expect out of a Final Fantasy game (Mind you, I never played any past X).  You can switch classes (once unlocked) by switching your weapon.  There's a "Duty Finder" which is similar to WoW's LFG/LFR tool, but a single tool for all of the game's group content.  Dyeable armor, and a system similar to WoW's "Transmog" system... Ugh.  I could go on and on about it's features.The music is beautiful, and so are the graphics (I have a higher-end PC, though, so results can easily vary).  Bottom line: If you like the Final Fantasy franchise, and you like MMOs, you should set your sights on this.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31
												I usually don't play games where you have a skill bar of 1-9 and pressing that button and this button. I am more of the black desert online/vindictus "HOLY ♥♥♥♥ DID I JUST STAB THAT GUY 10 TIMES AND SHOVE A SWORD INTO HIS SPINE IN HALF A SECOND" fast pace action MMO guy. BTW Black Desert Online sucks♥♥♥♥♥♥only play it for the PVE. Anyway. When I played this game it was a different experience the combat is a 1-9 bar but the mechanics are interesting dodging attacks by moving out of the way or sometimes getting behind cover to avoid a blast keeps me enticed to the gameplay and it's not just a button mashing fest. The skill animations and effects are gorgeous as well but at the end of my session my eyes have gone blind mainly because I play at full brightness right up my face. The combat is not just the same buttons again and again you have to add some buffs and skill timings for maximum effect nothing is old when it comes to combat. Especially the raids.The class system is great and encourages you to delve into new professions/classes with an extra EXP bonus to help you level up faster. Being a tank is not just standing there and getting your♥♥♥♥♥♥slapped out of you, you are sometimes responsible for landing stuns or inflicting status effects to help out your party and sometimes the dungeon throws minions in boss fights and it's up to you to make sure those extra mobs don't kill your buddies. I only play as a tank for now since I love what I do. The crafting is frustrating however but it's very rewarding if you craft a high quality item, it's a little minigame of chance and strategy to achieve the ultimate goal of completing the craft. It's not entirely RNG as you can guarantee a successful craft but the quality will not be High. High QUality is not mandatory but if you want some extra stats or to turn it in for extra EXP it's highly recommended to HQ. The story is amazing although the voice acting is nothing special (sometimes cringy). It starts off with voice acting but unfortunately it just drops in the last half but some of the bosses you fight actually speak which is quite strange. After that in the new Heavensward expansion it will include much more constant voice acting and a lot of british accents.The story is one of betrayal, triumph, and friendship and some lighthearted moments. The moogle sections are the most  entertaining in my opinion. There are some moments where you want to strangle an NPC for being an idiot and sometimes for acting like a♥♥♥♥♥♥and that shows alot about how the game immerses you into the story. The other small mechanics like the screenshot system or the group pose system are amazing and makes the game alot more personal so you can take some amazing photos of your travels or with friends. The raid/dungeon finder is a great system as you can pair up with other people across servers. JP/ENG/Etc. However if you play as anything but a healer or tank prepare for long queue times because tanks are the least played class which is a shame. However if you do play as a tank queue times won't be a problem for you. The duty finder comes with a function called roulette where it finds a raid/dungeon/boss fight at random. So if a max lvl vet applies for the roulette they can be queued into the lowest level dungeon in the game but still get decent exp for it and the completion award is also scaled so it's still rewarding for vets. This roulette systems allows beginner content to still be populated so that beginners are not left alone while everyone else is queued into high level dungeons. Housing in this game can cost a bit for the furniture but the inital cost of buying the host can cost millions so it's suggested that you work hard for gil or join a guild that owns a guildhouse. The armors and weapons in this game look absolutely amazing and a new expansion is coming around summer time that adds even more items and sometimes the community can design the items so if you love designing and sharing your creations this is a great game to share your ideas with. Right now there is a DPS Gear design contest 1/31/17. The world looks beautiful however the textures are not next gen and some parts can look ugly but this game has been out for a long time so yeah. Overall I love this game and the gameplay is something that caught me by storm, I look foward to the new content that is being pushed and more adventures with moogles. kupo. Feel free to ask any questions or for my opinion on certain things in the comments.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												FInal Fantasy XIV ARR is by far one of the best MMORPGs I have ever played!I'm not going to list all the MMORPG games I have played as I will be here for ages, but I will say I have been playing MMORPGs for over a decade! (wow I just realised that).From a Final Fantasy Fan perspective: I am a huge Final Fantasy series fan and this does the series justice! I was worried about how it turned out originally before they did the remake, and now that the devs have their heads on straight it is absolutely amazing! From an MMORPG player perspective: One of the many key features I love about this game as an MMORPG in general is; You can have as many classes/jobs and crafts as you want on ONE character! There are so many games out there that just dont adpot this simple yet extremely appealing feature! So many times I have wanted to just be ONE character - build up a story for that ONE character - and not have to make loads of other characters just to experience different classes/jobs and crafts. If you prefer to have different characters for different classes/jobs and crafts then you can still do that! So it really does appeal and accomodate to both sides.There are so many amazing features about this game that really makes this MMORPG stand up above the rest but the best way to understand it is to experience it for yourself. Otherwise I would be here typing this post until my fingers bleed. One final thing I will say is that if you are a fan of the Final Fantasy series then I would recommend this game 100%! If you have never played any of the Final Fantasy series then I would still recommend this game 100%!Happy hunting everyone!

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												I enjoyed a good portion of my time with Final Fantasy XIV. I got in at the start of the game with several friends and we had a blast. MMORPGs, however, change over the course of their runs, as does a player's experience and expectations. While I will say that much of what I love about Final Fantasy games (e.g., the characters, music, aesthetics, and general familiarity) is represented within XIV, I cannot speak highly of nearly all its other aspects. Many of my initial complaints with the game at launch are still relevant to this day.  • Dungeons are too formulaic and linear. • Character and gear customization (statwise, not in the visual sense) are extremely lacking and might as well be non-existent.  • Combat is too similar to WoW and, outside of boss battles, just feels underutilized and boring.My other issues are a bit broader and can apply to many other modern MMOs. As a game grows with more people looking for more to do, many developers tend to stack and recycle content in order to meet demands. Over a period of time this vertical style of game design left me exhausted, as I found myself progressing over the same ground and partaking in the same acts of gear obtainment. Sure you get faster updates, but most are simply shallow attempts at extending your time within the game. My second larger issue lies in the social aspect of the game. Hanging with your friends is fun, even in a virtual world, but part of what used to make MMORPGs so enjoyable and unlike anything else around was the ubiquitous nature of social interaction with other players. Coming across a couple of adventurers in a dugeon who were looking for a specific item drop and struggling against some tougher enemies, and then coming to their aid, completing their quest, chatting it up, and agreeing to meet again for a hunt or leveling party was a very rewarding experience in older MMOs. Seeing and interacting with players on your server was extremely commonplace and even required to get anything done within the game. In XIV that level of communication and dependency has gone the way of the dodo, and has instead been replaced by instanced areas and queues with multi-server pools. This lends itself well to solo play, but at the cost of unique social networks and deeper player on player engagements.I came into XIV hoping that many of these issues would be resolved, only to be slowly let down over years of an increasingly unsatisfying experience. As it stands I think the game has a lot of potential, but is in need of many improvements and changes. I once recommended Final Fantasy XIV, but am sad to say that I can no longer do so anymore.

Using triggers to swap through targets "Allies only for healer so you arnt swapping through nearby mobs or vice versa for DPS"I'm running a GTX970 but running that game in 1440P Resolution with everything maxed on DX11 and no stutter whatsoever. Absolutely gorgeous and running smoothe at 60 fps. So by my standards this game is well optimized.-ConsI haven't liked the maps so much, the layouts of where mobs are and what level they are seem a little out of whach. Lots of low lvl areas can have sections where hostile mobs are twice the area level. Or adjoinig areas will leave from a starting area straigjht into level 40 mobs. Also the design of some of the cities seem like wasted space. These of course are just things I noticed and dislike. If you care about the story and the mechanics then these things shouldn't hinder you.

												So I tried this game for a year. It's time for a honest review.I must say, the game is fun, but after a while it becomes very repetitive. It's your average everyday MMO, and it's very typical for the Asian Culture to adapt to grinding. This game does involve alot of grinding. The story is okay. Not yay jump out of your chairs. It is way better than ESO, however, despite lack of voice acting. If not so much of a reader, I won't recommend this game.PVP is♥♥♥♥♥♥on here. Not to mention, dead. You'll have a better chance forming up a party and run a dungeon or two, but that eventually gets boring. Speaking of forming a party, you also have to know how to tank, dps, or heal, depending on your role, unless you want to get bagged on and bullied. The community here is somewhat friendly, but there's alot of elitists that somehow feel they're entitled to pick on other players, even though they were all noobs one time.The game lacks mini games or should I say distractions. Yes, there's Levi's, Fates, Golden Saucer, and Chocobo racing, but it lacks executiuon. The very least, Levi's is all about escorting and battling monsters. Almost the same as doing the quests and hunting. Fates is all about battling and battling mini bosses. Battle, battle, battle another words... Then Golden Saucer is the run down version of the actual Saucer that should've existed from FF7. Only appealing thing behind it is Triple Triad, which is meh, and the Chocobo Racing is a JOKE. Hardly delivers a challenge and lot of the times I feel like I'm racing against NPC's more so than players. This game will drag the user down pretty quick when it comes to progressing. Unless one really loves to grind, and loves to focus on one class and literally put in the 10-12 hours into the game, one is going to either jump through class to class to be flexible and prevent boredom or one will simply quit because as I will state, the game becomes extremely repetitive. The race choosing is extremely bias. Not to mention, the gender choice. I've found more male players create their fantasy waifu girl than those who're legit females as one example. It's a very sexist game. There's also more lalafells and mon's in the game than there is the other three races. PRetty much what it boils down to is you're either a sexy cat lady or a jailbait child. Last but not least, the membership. This is a luxury game, you have to remember this. It's graphics and battle mechanics are WAY worth purchasing than WOW's; however, depending on how much of a character lover you are, this game will hurt your wallet per month. It doesn't have benefits behind what one chooses, unless one is willing to pay 14.99 or more depending on the contract one signs. Then one will receive small bonuses throughout the veteran program this game makes, getting costumes, mounts, etc. But nothing good or valid that is worth pursuing. So here's a brief review of what I experienced in the game. I come back every now and then, sure, but this game doesn't attach to me. I come from Runescape. I don't wish to play traditional turn base MMO's anymore. They get repeitive and boring. This game has also turned into a fashion rolemodel, and not an actual FF game. Which is why I left out of the other con's I've mentioned.Hope this helps.

number of helpful: 24 of 47 people (51%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Why make an mmorpg if you're going to remove any reason for players to communicate and cooperate with eachother, and then go even further beyond by making the campaign singleplayer. How does a development team so thuroughly miss the point of their chosen genre? The only reason I have so much time in this game is from shooting the♥♥♥♥♥♥with other people who had given up on actually playing it as I waited for my subscription to run out. The setting is great, the lore is great, the score is great, the character design and aesthetics are descent and yet they forgot the one thing that every game needs; fun! It simply isn't fun because it doesn't require you to do anything at all. The entire game can be played on a sort of auto pilot and even when the more difficult challenges come it's more of a matter of whether or not you've perpared beforehand than whether or not you're actually good at the game. There is literally nothing rewarding or worthwhile about this game, and while the same could be said of all video games with a certain mindset, this game actively tries to prevent you from playing it. There's really no reason to do so because all of your agency even down to the choices you make in combat are removed. There is an objectively correct choice to make in every encounter. Once you know them all there is no more game. Just going through the motions out of habit.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												Ohh...Ohhh...Where do I begin?..Being a fan of the original FFXIV (not for the gameplay, mind; I'm not that dumb), I finally came back home to Eorzea to find out what exactly happened at the end of the storyline of the original game. And I'll admit, it took some doing to get past the trivial "ey ur knew here, lemme give u sum tips b0ss" ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that every game passes off as a tutorial, because, ♥♥♥♥ experimentation. Yet, as I managed to toss myself over the hurdle, I noticed something huge. Something that the original XIV lacked.It was good.No, I'm serious, it's ♥♥♥♥ing good!Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is sapping away at my life, and most other games only hold my attention for maybe 10-20 hours at max. Given that this is an MMO, of course it's going to take a nice chunk of time out of my life, but here's the thing: that $20 price tag comes with a free trial. At any point, I could have said "bump this, I'm going back to <insert game of your choosing here>", but I haven't, even with over 80 hours of gameplay under my belt.Of course, it runs on a monthly subscription service, so it's only as fun as your wallet will let you run with it, however, for what it's worth, I prefer this model a lot more than any Free-2-Play, Play-2-Win model that any MMO has come out with, rivaling the likes of Warcraft, Guild Wars, etc. You're not going to be able to simply buy that gargantuan sword with your real-life money, you're gonna have to either buy it with in-game money, earn it via quests, or make it your own ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed self.We can sit here all day and talk about the original and how crap it was (and believe me, it was crap), but trust me when I say that when Square messed up, they knew exactly where they messed up. They took the game down, continued to tweak it, gave us a hell of a send-off (look that stuff up, it's ♥♥♥♥in' hella), and fixed it all.Does it reek of MMO-isms? As in, do random people pester you to join their clan? Yeah. Do people continue to barter even though the shops are literally right there next to them? Oh, hell yeah. Are there toxic players who will scold you for not healing or tanking the--The ♥♥♥♥ kinda question is that? You already know.Point is, for all of its flaws, if you're into fantasy JRPGs and MMOs, this one is a must. Highly recommended, though your milage may vary.Also, Psy is still an evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Don't trust anyone 3-feet tall and wearing a mask, I always say.9/10

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												An absolute love letter to the FF franchise! This, IMO, is the best Final Fantasy since 9. I have never cared much for MMO games but this game is fantastic.You can be as social as you want or you can play the majority of it solo. Increadibly fun, one of the best soundtracks in any FF games (we all have that special FF game, so not as good as that one of course) and a good story that makes you feel invested in the game's characters and world. I initially tried the game because as a FF fan, I just felt an oblligation to give it a try but never thought I would get too far...that was over 900 days ago, I've been comming back to this game over and over since it launched, I have sunk countles hours into the ps3 version then the ps4 version and now on the pc, and just look how many hours I've put in (btw, I dont leave the game running in the background, that number is fairly accurate).P.S. you could beat this game's story within the first 30 days which are included with the purchase of this game but there is an endless amount of things you can do.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												FF XIV is one of the best MMOs since WoW and these days id go as far as to say its now better than any other MMO it is extremly well polished has a lot of active players still.I imagine that this game would be even more fun in a party but as a weeb that spends on adverage 20/24 hours of the day in his room i wouldnt know anything about friends :P but in all seriousness i have had plenty of fun playing solo the first 10 levels or so are standaard MMO stuff you can power though this quick (i did it in about 7 hours) then the real fun begins.You do have to pay a monthly sub fee to play however you can find game time cards online for fairly cheap or you can just do direct debit. its an overall 10/10 from me so far (im wrting this review at 26 hours in) and i paid full price for the game here on steam as well as a 60day game time card from amazon to add to the 30 days you get from buying the game

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												FFXIV is a game made by people who love their game. They don't patronize their player-base, they respect the feedback and the game itself is a joy to both see, read, install, tweak, connect to and play. Every element is looked at twice, from a Tonberries's knife to a Lalafell's squeal. They are very straightforward with their game and policies, no shortcuts, no easy passages, no level boosts. The community is very surprisingly helpful and loving. You will rarely meet a single elitist despite them being in top-tier omg-I-can't-have-it gear.The content will provide equal satisfaction to hardcore players (next to impossible encounters) and casual players (challenging and rewarding encounters). I have only around 500~ hour in the game, not a single one was spent in boredom. Also, the game is japanese, think of every great RPG in history, who made it ? The japanese know their stuff and so it shall continue to be one of the greatest MMOs. Compared to other MMOs, this is like having sushi, you can always go to McDonalds for a (fast), cheap, calorie-filled heart-clogging hamburger that you eat in the car just to quieten your hunger of which half of it gets flushed in the toilet after (World of Warcraft), or you can have a culturally-rich, expensive, hand-made and carefully crafted piece of Sushi that is both healthy and full of nutrients, and yet tastes and looks good (FFXIV).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Final Fantasy XIV is a fantastic MMORPG for both the new and old players of Final Fantasy. Players of previous Final Fantasy games will see some familiar faces and be immersed into a beautiful new world with amazing views, in depth story, character models to die for, and a user friendly UI. I could not help but feel the nostalgia while playing. There are many things I enjoyed about the game and a few things I was aggrivated with. I will go into detail below.PROS:Fast leveling systemThe game is BEAUTIFULDifficulty seems to be just rightCharacter creation is very in depthFANTASTIC story.. A++ Friendly User Interface with complete customizationUpdated contentCONS:Navigating the map can be wonkyFinding appropriate level quests can be difficult IF you D/C from the game it takes many minutes before you are allowed to log back inGil Spammers are very annoyingIn conclusion, this game is absolutely worth the money to play and with a new expansion on the horizon, now is a great time to dive head first into the story line. You will not be disappointed!

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Was sceptical at first due to playing WoW for more than 7 years, I had always thought WoW would be my go to MMORPG for life but I've recently grown incredibly bored with it and needed something new. I was hearing othing but great things about this game, and how can you not love Final Fantasy? So I decided to try the free trial and what do you know? I was immediately hooked. Stunning visuals, easy to follow yet original plot that stays true to the Final Fantasy style of story telling, fantastic community of players and overall just an incredible game. If you're a fan of Final Fantasy like myself, but are hesitant towards this one then try the free trial and see for yourself. Can't go wrong with 14 days of free play! Can't wait to sink time and immerse myself into this one.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Would I reccomend this game?Yes (provided you enjoyed the demo)I have 137 hrs on record so I feel I've experienced enough of the game to review it.The game is very story focused but relies too heavily on cinimatics. The majority of these are without voice acting so it can become irritating to do one quest, watch a cinimatic fully voice acted, then watch another that has no voice acting. It would be perfectly understandable if the side quests had no voice acting and the main story did but that isn't the case.The combat system within this game is very very very well done. I literally cannot praise it high enough.The game however is very much not for everyone. A lot of people talk about moving from WoW to this game and one thing they must understand is this game is very different from WoW. The world is not a 'world' but a series of zones linked together by 'doorways' and loading screens. This game is very different from any other mmo on the market. This is both a postive and a negative.There is a demo for this game. Use it.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Great game. The style is visually appealing, combat is fun, and the class system is fantastic. I was interested enough in the main storyline to pay attention in cutscenes too. I love how well varied and exciting the boss fight mechanics can be while clearing dungeons. It can get pretty chaotic, and you have to be quick to act. The only thing I don't care for much, is how you can only get gear drops from boss fights. I guess I'm just too accustomed to random drops from enemy mobs like in Diablo 2. Still, the lack of drops only makes getting that piece of armor, or new weapon even more exciting when it finally does happen. This is the most fun I've ever had in any MMO, and I'll continue to enjoy it in the future.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												Ohh...Ohhh...Where do I begin?..Being a fan of the original FFXIV (not for the gameplay, mind; I'm not that dumb), I finally came back home to Eorzea to find out what exactly happened at the end of the storyline of the original game. And I'll admit, it took some doing to get past the trivial "ey ur knew here, lemme give u sum tips b0ss" ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that every game passes off as a tutorial, because, ♥♥♥♥ experimentation. Yet, as I managed to toss myself over the hurdle, I noticed something huge. Something that the original XIV lacked.It was good.No, I'm serious, it's ♥♥♥♥ing good!Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is sapping away at my life, and most other games only hold my attention for maybe 10-20 hours at max. Given that this is an MMO, of course it's going to take a nice chunk of time out of my life, but here's the thing: that $20 price tag comes with a free trial. At any point, I could have said "bump this, I'm going back to <insert game of your choosing here>", but I haven't, even with over 80 hours of gameplay under my belt.Of course, it runs on a monthly subscription service, so it's only as fun as your wallet will let you run with it, however, for what it's worth, I prefer this model a lot more than any Free-2-Play, Play-2-Win model that any MMO has come out with, rivaling the likes of Warcraft, Guild Wars, etc. You're not going to be able to simply buy that gargantuan sword with your real-life money, you're gonna have to either buy it with in-game money, earn it via quests, or make it your own ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed self.We can sit here all day and talk about the original and how crap it was (and believe me, it was crap), but trust me when I say that when Square messed up, they knew exactly where they messed up. They took the game down, continued to tweak it, gave us a hell of a send-off (look that stuff up, it's ♥♥♥♥in' hella), and fixed it all.Does it reek of MMO-isms? As in, do random people pester you to join their clan? Yeah. Do people continue to barter even though the shops are literally right there next to them? Oh, hell yeah. Are there toxic players who will scold you for not healing or tanking the--The ♥♥♥♥ kinda question is that? You already know.Point is, for all of its flaws, if you're into fantasy JRPGs and MMOs, this one is a must. Highly recommended, though your milage may vary.Also, Psy is still an evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Don't trust anyone 3-feet tall and wearing a mask, I always say.9/10

												Final Fantasy 14 is the best MMO I've played. content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Honestly this game feels... dated.  Like an old wow clone. The combat is simplistic and boring, and the game feels clunky and poorly responsive.  In an era of combat action like in Tera, Guild Wars, etc, it just feels sluggish, and the combat itself is slow.The questing is slow and there is far too much unskippable NPC dialogue and cutscenes that don't actually add anything to the game.  The intro is like 10 minutes long and painfully boring. You have to do it EVERY time.The game overemphasizes main quest unlocks, so that even if you know what you're doing you still have to go through a very tedious rigamarole to do anything.  There's also not enough quests to support leveling multiple classes on one character.  Eventually you realize that you're better off just grinding monsters and joining the pop up events (called Fates, think of rifts in Rift if you've played that).  Except that the combat is so boring and slow you'll be asking yourself why you're doing this, and when does the FUN actually start.End game is simplistic as well, and there's no real reward for doing challenging content over the easier ones.Pretty much hte only thing the game actually has is its character graphics, which look out of place against the environment graphics (the thanalan desert region looks particularly bad, especially the scrub brush).Considering how expensive it is (the main item, plus expansion, PLUS sub), this game woefully underdelivers.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												I'm a bit mixed now that I've sunk two weeks into this game. Some of the good initial impressions of the game have given away to stark realities, instead, so this review should be fairly even keeled.* Is it better than most of the other MMOs out there? An unreserved yes.* Did Square-Enix learn from the mistakes they made from their past four MMOs? Yes.* Is the story any good? Yes.* ...are you sure? Look, it took a lot of balls to scrap the entire game and rewrite the entire story using the existing assets and build it all on top of a new engine, but by Cid's scruffy beard, they actually did it, AND they justified all the retconning into the story itself. If there's any company with the capability to keep this game afloat while they were fixing everything, it's Square-Enix, because of their sheer amount of resources. Credit given where credit is due, they did a good job.* Is the voice acting good? My experience is that it seems to be a bit better in Japanese than in English.* Can you set the VA to JP and subtitles to EN? Yes. Or any other permutation you like between EN, JP, FR, and/or DE.* Is being able to level every class and every crafting/gathering profession on a single character all its cracked up to be? Not if you don't like the side job that you have to level in order to be effective at your main. I dislike GLA, for example.* How hard is it to change classes? As easy as changing your weapon. Changing your weapon changes your bars, skills, stats, and everything.* For crafting and gathering classes too? Yes. Crafting is interactive, not just queueing up 20 of X and letting a bar fill up. Gathering nodes are all per-player, and equally interactive. (YMMV with the interactive crafting bit.)* Are you going to single-character everything anyways? Shyeah, man. I hate rolling alts. Also, I got the Lightning hair, and I ain't giving that up.* Lightning hair? Yeah, there was a cross-marketing promo with FFXIII-3. You could get Lightning's hair, armor, Snow's hair, armor, and various weapons for all classes. There's allegedly going to be a DQX cross-marketing event soon, but that may be restricted to JP-only.* Are they any good? The weapons cap out at level 13. (Get it?) An armor/weapon skin system is on the horizon, though.* Is the default UI good? Yes. I can do most of what I had before in WoW with the stock UI, but I had a very minimalistic setup because I was my guild's OT. I miss having more granular threat indicators, but I can manage. There are rumors that custom UI mods are on the horizon. I miss ThreatPlates.* Is now a good time to get into the game? Best time to get into the game would have been a month to two weeks ago, considering the 50% off sale, and age of the content leading up to 2.2 patch landing late this month or early next month. Because of it, now is a rapidly-narrowing window.* How much FF fan-♥♥♥♥♥♥y is in this game? If you can't stand seeing Chocobos, Moogles, Cid, airships, Bahamut, Warriors of Light, Dragoons, and so forth, this isn't the game for you.* How far have you gotten in the game? I'm level 41 now. My time played is a little misleading, I have occasionally accidentally left the launcher open, thus artificially inflating the time played.* What's the best thing you've seen in the game overall? Because development is being headed by a Japanese studio, maintenance is scheduled during THEIR day, which means OUR (USA) night. Usually when I should be going to sleep anyways. Data centers are domestic to JP, NA, and EU regions, though, don't be alarmed.* What's the- Hang on, I gotta squeeze in another thing: Second best thing is that this is an MMO you can play entirely with a controller, BUT does not compromise the UI for Mouse and Keyboard in any way. Both are well-refined and equally suitable to play this game.* Okay, I was going to ask, what's the worst thing you've seen in the game overall? WAR (T2 Tank specialist) needs to level to MAR (T1 Tank generalist) 30 and GLA (another T1 Tank generalist) 15. I find GLA to not be my cup of tea, but since WAR/MAR doesn't get a taunt ever, you have to level to level 22 GLA and cross-class Provoke to get a proper taunt.* Final Recommendation? FFXIV has a benchmark tool that doubles as a character creation toy, located at http://na.finalfantasyxiv.com/benchmark/. You should download it, spend a lot of time playing with character creation to see if you like the aesthetics, and then benchmark to see if your computer can handle it.EDIT 06-25-14: I am at four months playing this game, now. I won't inline edit things any further to reflect this, but:* I have discovered there is an executable in the install directory to allow you to play the game without having to launch it through Steam. This has affected my time-played count. Maybe triple that, now.* I am now at level 50 Warrior, and have several other combat jobs at 30 or so. All other jobs are at least level 15 to eliminate the time needed to go grind out the subclass for evolving to job.* I am an omnicrafter now. I have maxed all the crafting jobs, and it is *very nice*, either to make gear for myself (in the form of levelling my incomplete jobs), my retainers, or for FC mates. I'm still working on the gathering professions.* I'm letting my sub lapse for a bit. I'm going to TI4 in Seattle next month, but you can bet I'll be back afterwards.* Patch 2.3 is slated to arrive July 8th and bring Rogues, Ninjas, Ramuh, Shiva, personal guild housing, and more.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												The grind to the endgame may seem annoying at first, but once ya get there it's worth it. Can pretty much play as any class all on one character, and the community varies but mostly it's all good. Plus, would recommend finding a good group of people or join an FC with some experienced players if you're really struggling; they'll help you get to the end content and it makes the game more exciting to play knowing you don't have to face the dungeons, trials and raids alone. I haven't played any other MMOs that are out there but this is a really excellent one to get into. And bonus: the DLC that is coming will only add more amazing content. And avid FF fan or not, the game just sucks you in. There's a lot of positives from this game, maybe with a few downsides here and there. You always have the trial version to test out the game - whether you can run it smoothly on your computer, or to test out and see if you'll like it. If you don't, then it's no risk. Just keep in mind that if you do want the full version, you're going to have to pay that monthly subscription (cheapest being $15 a month). Is this game worth it? In my opinion, hell yeah it is.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
   FF + Sleep  NO GRADES NO LIFE    FF + School  NO LIFE NO SLEEP     School + Sleep   ♥♥♥♥ THIS NO FF NO LIFE  I think this table pretty much sums up about life after the introduction of Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn. This game is about grinding, those of you who have played FF X should know the pain of grinding. But in FF14, grinding is much better than before, because of all the things you can do. Look, FF14 is so diverse that I've met all kinds of people. A normal MMORPG divides into PvE or PvP group, yet, in FF14, there are way more groups than you thought. One of my friends only level crafting and has little levels when it comes to combat classes. One of my friend only focus on PvP in wolf den, and doesnt care much about raiding because it's really hard to find a good pug if you are not in a major free company that focus on pushing through turns and dungeons. Overall, this game wins at diversity. The things you can do in this game is just unlimited, but be aware my friend, once you introduce FF14 into your life. Say Byebye.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												Something I'm not seeing anybody state, is that it's cross platform in means of you are playing with both PC and console users. Even if you're on PC, you're not limited to just playing with keyboard/mouse. It states partial gamepad support, but there isn't a single thing in the game that you're not able to use the gamepad for, save typing/chatting. Even that is partially covered with their translation system where you input something in your own language and the game is able to translate those phrases(a large amount of game-related phrases) to their native language.Enjoying it. I've got a black mage and white mage at 50(current max, pre-heavensward) and am still leveling other classes as well as professions.If you enjoy gaming with others, this is your game. If you enjoy playing a game alone, this is your game(excluding mandatory dungeons with others for story quests). You are able to learn all classes, all professions, and have the ability to swap between them outside of combat, at any time, save in a dungeon.Comparably to world of warcraft, this has more content to it and it isn't just one dungeon that has one story, but the hard mode dungeons have their own story(and look/content) behind them, instead of WoW's concept of just doing the same content but with harder mechanics. Yes, there are trials that have the same content and harder mechanics, but that equates to maybe 20% of the accessible dungeons/raids at end game. The reason they are harder and have more complex mechanics is story driven as well, and not just a mode to be toggled and gotten into.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												I took a chance on this game and bought both the game and the expansion at once. Currently I have two level 30+ classes and am only about halfway through the story of ARR.Also as my first review, I figured why not do FFXIV. Final Fantasy has always been a part of my life ever since i could remember. I honestly expected a lot from the game and wasn't disappointed; that being said, I do have a couple of issues about it. - From my experience, if you are planning to play this alone don't expect it to be fantastic. Many of the servers are constantly full making it difficult to create a character in and the majority of the community is at end game, making newer players like myself roaming around alone. I was hoping to just jump into a Free Company (a.k.a. guild) and joke around, have a laugh, and level with people. Its difficult to find a FC like that and i have yet to find one.- Leveling alone is boring, soloing FATE's can be difficult, and as of right now nothing seems fun about leveling.- Instance based mapping and invisible walls everywhere.- Haven't seen a lot of friendly people running around, seems like everyone who is running around is just there to level and not to enjoy the game or community.The customizability is amazing, you can go from being a healer to a dps to a tank in one mouse click.Game is extremely addicting and i still have yet to discover exactly what makes it be, I could be bored to death of doing the story quest and dungeoning but the second i log off, i just want to play again.Overall, i really enjoy this game and i can see myself playing it for a while. My major flaw in it is finding the lowerlevel community and having fun with people, everyone seems to be at end game just wanting to do thier dailies. It might just be the server that i play on, (Diabolos) or a new player thing.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Would I reccomend this game?Yes (provided you enjoyed the demo)I have 137 hrs on record so I feel I've experienced enough of the game to review it.The game is very story focused but relies too heavily on cinimatics. The majority of these are without voice acting so it can become irritating to do one quest, watch a cinimatic fully voice acted, then watch another that has no voice acting. It would be perfectly understandable if the side quests had no voice acting and the main story did but that isn't the case.The combat system within this game is very very very well done. I literally cannot praise it high enough.The game however is very much not for everyone. A lot of people talk about moving from WoW to this game and one thing they must understand is this game is very different from WoW. The world is not a 'world' but a series of zones linked together by 'doorways' and loading screens. This game is very different from any other mmo on the market. This is both a postive and a negative.There is a demo for this game. Use it.

content:
Posted: January 19
												This game changed my opinion about MMORPG:s. I think it's is the ultimate choice for someone who's new to them.I have never been able to play an MMO for more than an hour or three, as they didn't feel linear - I couldn't figure out what I was supposed to do, at all, and the quests and storyline (or lack thereof) seemed so dull that i gave up on them.Then came A Realm Reborn. ARR did to MMO's what FFXIII did to JRPG:s - if you've never played one, you won't get overwhelmed by it all, since there is SO MUCH to learn. This game will give you enough time to thoroughly comprehend what it is you are doing, especially during battle, as well as why you are doing it. Not to worry though, there are hardcore, elite gamers here, as this is not a simple or easy game in any way. The battle system is also made in such a way that there's no need to compete for points - this makes for a friendly atmosphere where people enjoy helping each other out.PROS:- This is a visually stunning game - the scenery often takes my breath away.- The community is extremely friendly and helpful towards everyone. The median age seems to be higher than in other MMO:s, and I hardly ever witness any bratty behaviour.- One character is able to play and level up on all classes/jobs. If you want to change from black mage into gladiator you can do that without creating a new character.- Fairness and equality: you can not pay for an advantage over others. Your level will also be syncronised to match the difficulty of certain battles. Such things mean an enjoyable yet challenging experience for everyone.- You can have a minion tag along with you wherever you go. Beware though: the cuteness may be too much to handle.- You get to ride and battle with a chocobo. Kweh kweh.CONS:- This game is highly addictive and will probably ruin your social life. I wish I were joking, but I'm not.- There may bit of an input lag (depending on your connection and hardware) because of the way the servers receive information. Sometimes when I've clearly evaded an attack, i still get damage dealt to me.- The chocobo is the only possible battle companion (apart from pets, I won't go into that now). I wish that my adorable dust bunny could strike a hit!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												Something I'm not seeing anybody state, is that it's cross platform in means of you are playing with both PC and console users. Even if you're on PC, you're not limited to just playing with keyboard/mouse. It states partial gamepad support, but there isn't a single thing in the game that you're not able to use the gamepad for, save typing/chatting. Even that is partially covered with their translation system where you input something in your own language and the game is able to translate those phrases(a large amount of game-related phrases) to their native language.Enjoying it. I've got a black mage and white mage at 50(current max, pre-heavensward) and am still leveling other classes as well as professions.If you enjoy gaming with others, this is your game. If you enjoy playing a game alone, this is your game(excluding mandatory dungeons with others for story quests). You are able to learn all classes, all professions, and have the ability to swap between them outside of combat, at any time, save in a dungeon.Comparably to world of warcraft, this has more content to it and it isn't just one dungeon that has one story, but the hard mode dungeons have their own story(and look/content) behind them, instead of WoW's concept of just doing the same content but with harder mechanics. Yes, there are trials that have the same content and harder mechanics, but that equates to maybe 20% of the accessible dungeons/raids at end game. The reason they are harder and have more complex mechanics is story driven as well, and not just a mode to be toggled and gotten into.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												The grind to the endgame may seem annoying at first, but once ya get there it's worth it. Can pretty much play as any class all on one character, and the community varies but mostly it's all good. Plus, would recommend finding a good group of people or join an FC with some experienced players if you're really struggling; they'll help you get to the end content and it makes the game more exciting to play knowing you don't have to face the dungeons, trials and raids alone. I haven't played any other MMOs that are out there but this is a really excellent one to get into. And bonus: the DLC that is coming will only add more amazing content. And avid FF fan or not, the game just sucks you in. There's a lot of positives from this game, maybe with a few downsides here and there. You always have the trial version to test out the game - whether you can run it smoothly on your computer, or to test out and see if you'll like it. If you don't, then it's no risk. Just keep in mind that if you do want the full version, you're going to have to pay that monthly subscription (cheapest being $15 a month). Is this game worth it? In my opinion, hell yeah it is.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												Ohh...Ohhh...Where do I begin?..Being a fan of the original FFXIV (not for the gameplay, mind; I'm not that dumb), I finally came back home to Eorzea to find out what exactly happened at the end of the storyline of the original game. And I'll admit, it took some doing to get past the trivial "ey ur knew here, lemme give u sum tips b0ss" ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that every game passes off as a tutorial, because, ♥♥♥♥ experimentation. Yet, as I managed to toss myself over the hurdle, I noticed something huge. Something that the original XIV lacked.It was good.No, I'm serious, it's ♥♥♥♥ing good!Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is sapping away at my life, and most other games only hold my attention for maybe 10-20 hours at max. Given that this is an MMO, of course it's going to take a nice chunk of time out of my life, but here's the thing: that $20 price tag comes with a free trial. At any point, I could have said "bump this, I'm going back to <insert game of your choosing here>", but I haven't, even with over 80 hours of gameplay under my belt.Of course, it runs on a monthly subscription service, so it's only as fun as your wallet will let you run with it, however, for what it's worth, I prefer this model a lot more than any Free-2-Play, Play-2-Win model that any MMO has come out with, rivaling the likes of Warcraft, Guild Wars, etc. You're not going to be able to simply buy that gargantuan sword with your real-life money, you're gonna have to either buy it with in-game money, earn it via quests, or make it your own ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed self.We can sit here all day and talk about the original and how crap it was (and believe me, it was crap), but trust me when I say that when Square messed up, they knew exactly where they messed up. They took the game down, continued to tweak it, gave us a hell of a send-off (look that stuff up, it's ♥♥♥♥in' hella), and fixed it all.Does it reek of MMO-isms? As in, do random people pester you to join their clan? Yeah. Do people continue to barter even though the shops are literally right there next to them? Oh, hell yeah. Are there toxic players who will scold you for not healing or tanking the--The ♥♥♥♥ kinda question is that? You already know.Point is, for all of its flaws, if you're into fantasy JRPGs and MMOs, this one is a must. Highly recommended, though your milage may vary.Also, Psy is still an evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Don't trust anyone 3-feet tall and wearing a mask, I always say.9/10
