content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												I quit playin this not long ago, and now that the irritation has subsided, here's my experience.tl;dr - Really good mmorpg(8/10), prolly the worst FF(2/10) I've ever played.The easy stuff first: The visuals are beautiful, it's FF after all. The sound is worth the price of admission alone. Seriously, I've played mmorpgs for a long time, and it doesn't take much longer than a few days for the game music to get muted and my own tunes turned on...for this game it took over a month, the soundtrack is just that good.The storylines aren't bad. Nothing special, but the way FF uses its cutscenes it gets ya engrossed, so you find yourself actually listening to the voice acting and even paying attention to what they're saying...from time to time.The crafting system is so damn close to perfect and totally unique, if it weren't for the RNG aspect it would be perfection.You make 1 character, and they can level all the things. Changing jobs is easy as switching your main weapon, it's great.Ok, that's about it for the good stuff. Now the bad:The job system is trash. Nevermind the combat itself feels like a very slow WoW rotation, there's basically no customization in the jobs at all. You cross class skills, once unlocked through leveling, and you have materia sockets in your gear, and that's all the customization ya get. The amount of skills able to be CC'd is laughably small, and if you've every played any other mmorpg with sockets you already know how many options that isn't.The crafting system actually feels like it was the main job system, cause there's actually options there, but one thing brings it down, and this one thing actually hurts many other aspects of the game: The RNG.The RNG is just...rage-inducing.Everything about this game feels too balanced, to the point where the devs chose balance over fun.Also, loldrg is alive and well.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Awezome mmo! One of the best i played! World of Warcraft used to be my favorite untill they started with daily ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and garrisons, making their game feel like a chore. Another thing that made me switch was the use of alts, spending countless of hours atempting to level each character up because their classes were separated to new characters, in Final Fantasy your free to switch to any job just by equipping a weapon or tool.+ So for Final Fantasy, expect to spend alot of time on a enjoyable story line for all jobs and quests you come across, something thats been missing in many mmo's. The depth of the story makes this game truly unique, even your job weapons and tools have their own stories!+ The world is gigantic, so theres alot to explore, though don't forget to attune to every crystal you come across as they will all serve as a teleportation method troughout the zones.+ The bosses you come across on your travels feel challanging and tactics will be needed ranging from basic to the most  advanced nerve wrecking ones. + The economy is well made within the game, allowing players to forge the economy. As you come across certain materias within your main quest you will be able to sell them for over 100.000 gil which will be enough for any gear or items your going for.+ The graphics look amazing, though a better anti-alising method is needed, edges do look jagged even in 1080p with high desktop settings.+ The soundtracks are great! though i preffered certain tracks in v1.0 compared to the new ones. + Rapid patches are thrown out with ever month or so, giving you even more to enjoy!+ The pricings are quite on the cheap side, monthly subscription is not all that expencive compared to other mmo's as you can choose between multiple or a single character for each server.+ PC gamers and Console players can play togheter! The community is friendly and supportive, something rarely seen in most free to play games.- Farming bots are present in the game, though they are harmless to players, they are capable of damaging the economy. But such bots are present in most mmo's, so Final Fantasy are not alone on this.And as for the conclusion of my review, if your looking for a deep and well thought out mmo, this one is most certainly recommended!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												What I've been doing this whole October:"Wasting" My Time With Final Fantasy XIV.How was it?- Well from a FF Fanatic, IT IS SO GOOD THAT I USED $80 (+$30 for some additional stuff and +$12.99 for the Subscription this November, $122.99 if you hate math and that's without tax) JUST SO I COULD MAX 1 CLASS TO LV60. I still need to max out 22 more classes.Can low-end PC play it?- Graphics was very crisp even my crappy PC could handle it. It's been out since 2010 and it's looking good af.Was it grindy?- Eh, not really. It's pretty much your fault if you hit a level gap making you unable continue the Main Story Quest.Speaking of Quests, I heard FFXIV's Content was Quest Locked, was it hard to go through the Quests?- Most of the game's content is locked through the Main Story Quests. They prolly did it just so people wouldn't skip MSQ and just grind fest through all the mobs in the Overworld. It wasn't hard doing all the Qs because it's a basic RPG Element that PEOPLE SHOULDN'T THINK OF AS A NEGATIVE THING.That sounds really annoying, is it really worth to do all of that just to unlock content?- Worth, trust me. I've been there.Was the Story engaging?- Story wise, it was very very engaging I tell you. You're basically an adventurer who got there that got mixed up in all sorts of problems and was told to realize you were the "chosen one". It sounds very cookie-cutter yes, but the way it was presented had that *umph* power of a Final Fantasy game. Although, I recommend reading/watching some stuff about the lore/backstory before FFXIV:ARR came to be.ARR? What's that?- ARR stands for A Realm Reborn. It's the base game which you will cap till Level 50 (enough to feel the FF yum-yums).Level 50 is the level cap? Isn't it a bit too low?- That's not the "actual" level cap. To hit the actual cap, you must buy the FFXIV: Heavensward expansion, which gives you a whopping 10 more levels and a ton more of content to unlock!!! (wooo!). And oh boy if the road from 1 to 50 was tiring for you, 51~ 60 is something.Just tell us already what that "something" is- HAH HAH! You thought it was all just mere character levels? HAH! It's not even the final "level". You also need iLvL to progress on "everything" that is Heavensward related.Wait what? iLvLs? You're making no sense at all...- iLvLs, Item Levels. The the even some the Veterans of FFXIV hate. It's basically your gear's Average Level. Like I said before, you need it to progress and hitting iLvL gap is worse than simple MSQ level gap.Can we just end this already? I feel like I learned nothing at all...- lol, okay then.1) Very good game for MMORPG people especially for the ones who play and love FF.2) Graphics can be compared to current MMORPGs.3) The balance between Grinding and Questing is 50|50.4) Content wise, it's worth every penny. From Massive Dungeons to Epic Boss Fights to Intense Raids.5) Cost wise, go buy the FFXIV: A Realm Reborn base game. If not, just go download the demo for 14 days.6) Final Score: 9.4/10 --- Would get thrown off the stage again. (Yes I'm looking at you Titan Extreme)

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												I've been playing this game for a little while, took a lot of breaks back in the day when it first came out on the PS3. I can honestly recommend it to anyone who's looking for an incredibly high quality MMORPG. With a fantastic job system, and a story that's actually worth the time that it takes to get through it all for once which for an MMO is really good. I honestly can't remember the last time I enjoyed the story to an MMO like I do this one. The game relies on the classic holy trinity of Roles (tank/DPS/Healer), and the way it's done is fairly cut and dry, every job fills one role and cannot fill any other role in the duty finder, although this would normally end up being pretty boring, they mitigate that issue by allowing you to change your class pretty well whenever you want, and all you have to do is just take the new job's quests and change your weapon, which I love.All in all I can recommend this game to MMO fans who both want a challenge and a really well done story. Also save me please I've spend too many hours of my life already in this game.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												As I just hit the 3,000 hour mark, I figured i'd give a review about the product which has broken my social life and my sleeping habits. Pros:Play any class on a single character -With 13 fighting/healing classes, 8 crafting classes, and 3 gathering classes, this is an amazing feature -Get bored tanking? Try a healer, or if you get bored of that, try a dps. Don't like fighting? Try a crafter or a gatherer. Simple as accepting a single quest.Amazing storyline -Even though you don't have to, you can always start a new character to go through the story in a new starting city, new class, or a new gender just to see all the little things you might have missed or just never got to see the first time.Music -The music is just... great. Listen to the soundtrack somewhere especially for the boss fights.Customizability -Want your chat in the top right of the screen for some reason? You can do it. Want Bosses to have green names and friends to have red names? Do it. -Wanna look like a literal pig? Buy the suit at the casino and glamour it onto your midget or your giant. -Don't like being a lizardgirl? Become a catgirl! (For a small real-world fee)NeutralCash Shop -Some might see this as a negitive, but as all the things in the cash shop are only cosmetic (dyes, mounts, ability to change character look, seasonal clothing, ext) I see no reason to dislike it. Not gonna buy anything from it personally, but don't see a need to diss it.Unskippable storyline -If you want to get to endgame content fast, this is the wrong game for you. You have to go through the whole storyline to get to the endgame, as well as expansion content.Monthly payment -About $15 per month to play. Granted, every few months you get "free" stuff, but still. -Personally don't have problems with it, as it eats up so much time that I can't play other games, so I just buy 60 days of gametime every other month.ConsAll my friends have left me -But at least I still have a catgirl strong demonic man with horns.

												A fantastic MMO with a fantastic world.The FATEs and instanced group duties get you cooperating with other players, something which I really enjoy doing in MMOs.If you're unhappy with the class you chose, you don't have to create a brand new character, you can just change classes (a nod to the Job System sometimes seen in the Final Fantasy series, as introduced in Final Fantasy V). You do have to level up again to get to the level you were at before, but that means that you get to have a feel of the new class you chose.

content:
Posted: January 25
												I adore the game, love it, runs great, mostly amazing community, met great people, adored the story, and above all:It lets me get every class on the same character. No grinding through the story time and time again like every other MMORPG I experienced.Though this review is more as a warning: Do /not/ get this game via Steam. It doesn't say so on this page, but if you fall in love with this game, but want to buy a physical copy in the future of an expansion, for instance? The codes will not work. They won't let you trade the codes for Steam codes, and if you want to get value out of the codes from physical copies of the game, you would have to restart from scratch..Codes for digital goodies from items like plushies or the lore book from the SE store do work, however. Do I recommend the game? Yes. Gods yes. Do I recommend it via Steam? Sorry to Steam, but no, I cannot.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												There's a two week trial to play the game. There is a free trial on Steam...just gotta type in "Final Fantasy XIV" and then it'll finally show up as a "Free Demo." Also when looking at reviews to get to know the game, ignore anything under 100 hours. They don't know what they'e talking about.As it says for me, I've logged 440 hours at the time of this review (Thats bound to change very soon though). I'm downright addicted to FFXIV. Yes, there are points in which the game is tedious. Yes, there are certain things that make me sigh. And yes, the few cutscenes that are voice acted are terrible as the VA's suck. First things first. Some of the negative reviews says the game is SUPER grind heavy. That's both FALSE and TRUE. It doesn't take long to get a single character class to 50 (Present max level though the DLC/Expansion that comes out this spring will raise it to 60 while adding an entire new area, new dungeons, raids, bosses, and 3 new classes). What takes long is getting your max Item Level Gear which is...130? I'm not too sure on that myself. I haven't hit ilevel100 yet on my main.More on the Grinding. You can hit max level in under 2 weeks of moderate gameplay for one of your classes. That's not long compared to some other MMO's. Of course most other MMO's don't allow you to level EVERY CLASS in the game on ONE CHARACTER without the need for alts. What makes the game 'Grind heavy' is the fact that there's 9 Combat Classes and 11 Crafting/Gathering Classes. That's a total of 20 (Well 22 technically but those two share the same exp pool as its base class) different classes to get to level 50. On one character. And yes, there is a benefit from leveling all the classes. You can 'Cross Class' certain skills to other classes. Giving them benefits of different skills.Some of the early dungeons are pretty boring but they're not really meant to be like really great. They're basically tutorial dungeons. Letting you learn the mechanics that you'll see extremely often in later, harder, and significantly more fun, dungeons (and raids.)The crafting/gathering system is a love-hate thing. Though that's true of most every MMO. One of my Free Company minions focused almost exlucsively on the Crafting and Gathering Classes and almost hit 50 on all of them within only a few weeks time. If you're dedicated and manage your exp sources right (Levequests and crafting/gathering level appropriate stuff) your crafting/gatherers will level fairly quickly.There's two different subscriptions too. So all those peope ♥♥♥♥♥ing about "Its 15 bucks a month" are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tting you. 15 bucks a month is for the premium subscription that simply allows you 8 characters per server for a max of 40 throughout your Data Center. The Base Subscription, which is like...12-13 bucks? Restricts you to 1 character per server and a max of 8 in your data center. I'm not sure on the price as I have the premium subscription myself. The base subscription is cheaper then, say, WoW's subscription. And its worth it since you don't really need Alts. (I just really like the game. >.>)As people will say, the game looks very nice. The music is fantastic (But what did you expect? Its a FINAL FANTASY game!). The story is interesting. Gameplay? I like it. It's solid. There's not really much to say about it. It's an MMO...Oh! I saw one negative review talking about monsters "Auto attacks" and there being to avoid getting hit by them unless it uses a move that creates a 'zone' that you want to get out of...that's not true. You can avoid getting hit by a monsters auto attacks if you STAY OUT OF THEIR RANGE. Which is understandably hard for a Melee Class or a Caster Class. But the Archer has no problem literally kiting a monster without ranged attacks around in circles. Ya just gotta becareful not to leash them...as they'll become invincible while they retreat back to their spawn area.What else to say...what else to say...Hm...JUST TRY THE FREE TRIAL! ITS FREE.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Whether you're a fan of the series, looking for a new MMO to invest yourself in, or both, FFXIV is definitely a good choice. Some will get tripped up over the subscription fee and not give it a chance as a result, and I would tell those people they are making a sore mistake. Once you get into the game, you'll immediately experience some of the best visuals that you've ever seen in an MMO, which in itself is reasoning to stay. Plus, you get the first month free.The plot actually plays a significant role in FFXIV, again unusual for an MMO, and is actually quite interesting IMO. As stated, the game is absolutely beautiful and I've found myself on many occasions stopping, going into first person, and just absorbing the beauty. The player community is very friendly, and you'll find yourself joining a Free Company in no time. In fact, I'd recommend it, but I digress. But the most interesting thing about FFXIV is its Job system. One of the most unique character specialization systems I've seen in an MMO, where you need to thread together 2-3 different classes to create a job unique to that class combination. although there are only around 8 or 9 jobs as of now, the possibilites are vast, and I am optimistic that it will gain many more with future expansions. The game is still in its vanilla stage and is already working MUCH better than its predecessor MMO. I have high hopes for the future in this game, and enjoying it thoroughly as of now. I recommend to any fans of MMO's or Final Fantasy.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												Hey there everyone. I've had many years of experience in all genres of games & gaming in general. So I figured I'll try to write the best, most accurate review I can without using the 'useless' details. I hope you guys enjoy. :)So to start things off. A Realm Reborn is NOT a "different" Final Fantasy from the original XIV, but at the same time it is. Final Fantasy XIV was a very unsuccesful game. So it was redesigned by a new team from the ground up and A Realm Reborn was released. ALSO THERE IS AN ACTUAL STORY TO THE GAME FOR ALL YOU STORY BASED PEOPLE! :D-------Graphics-------The game is stunningly beautiful for graphics. Modern laptops / PC's should not have massive framerate issues at all unless you're in 2 of the 3 main cities & it's heavily crowded in them. Depending on your settings, you will notice downgrades (of course) within the water, and the shadows. They even went as far as to lessen the amount of animation in character movements. What stinks is that the PS3 cannot control these options so the game is a bit choppier on that system. I'm not entirely sure about the PS4 as I don't have one. I would imagine it's more of a modern - high end PC power. The dungeons look stunning as do the creatures & bosses. I did the first dungeon called Sastasha, and my whole group stopped just before the last boss because we were too "wow'd" by the fact there was a sunset over the horizon of the cave. It looked absolutely gorgeous.-------Audio-------As far as sound goes, the game will sometimes glitch with what sound(s) it produces. Randomly at times in combat you'll just stop hearing your characters skills / spells. However, with that said, the music is very nice to listen to. I'm not saying it doesn't get repetitive after mannnnnnnnnny game hours and eventually you'll use your own. But remember, this is a Final Fantasy game. They want their music to at least be somewhat tasteful. I'm not entirely sure why they did this either, but when you're on a mount, if you aren't moving the music for the mount softens. Upon moving again it kicks back up. This is a bummer because I'd like to just sit there and listen to the chocobo theme for hours. :DAll in all though you can tell they took their time and didn't just throw slop together knowing MMO'ers use their own music anyways eventually.-------Characters & Character Customizing------- The characters look amazing to say the least. You have 5 races to choose from, both male & female unlike Final Fantasy XI which Miqo'te (female) and Rogeadyn (male) were gender restricted. Boring Humans (Hyur), Freakishly Tall Elves (Elezen), Little Cute People(Lalafell), No-Claw-Having Cat People (Miqo'te), and Chris Redfield's / She-Hulk's (Roegadyn). Within those races you first choose the gender, then you choose 1 of 2 options for a clan / tribe. These can have some differences, to many. Mostly being stat wise. One clan/tribe has melee/ranged based stats while the other has caster based. Then you go on to customize the look of your character. This ranges anywhere from the height and voice & changing the color of your hair / eyes, to the breast size on females & muscle tone on males. While there is A LOT to offer when it comes to customizing, there are some downsides. There are only 4-6 different base faces which may seem like enough but when you see the options you'll soon find yourself leaning toward the same one every time. While there are quite a few hairstyles / facial hair options, you'll soon take notice that they could have added in a lot more. Such as adding length for facial hair for guys, and more actual styles of hair for girls with a sub option of hair band colors and not 3-4 of the same hairstyles all just with a different color hair band. Some can have earrings which is actually a downer because it interferes & overlaps with earring based gear (yes earrings do show up when you equip them). -------Gear & Loot-------Since gear was mentioned in the previous paragraph I figured it was fitting to put it next. Now don't get me wrong, I like the look of the gear in ARR. But if you've played games like World of Warcraft you'll be disappointed in the way this game is done. Most loot is earned simply by completeing quests & dungeons. You will NOT find an upgradable piece of gear on a creature. Remember, this is Final Fantasy. You find them via dungeon treasure boxes & raids. Also there is not a buttload of gear. They do have a wide selection of things because of how many classes / jobs there are but you'll not see outfits that you go, "Hmm, I wonder where they got that." The weapons don't look all that flashy until higher levels / endgame. But they still graphically look very well done. EVERYTHING EXCEPT YOUR BELT shows up on your character. They just introduced the new Glamour system which lets you change the physical look of your gear without altering the stats (Transmogging for you WoW readers). The loot table goes as follow;White (Common) - Pretty useless stuff, but if it's better, wear it.Pink (Aetherial) - Better or worse than greens as the actual stats on them can differ. So in short, they aren't fixed stats and are not tradable.Green (Uncommon) - These are pretty much your dungeon leveling pieces of gear.Blue (Rare) & Purple (Epic) - Towards your end game you'll get these. Of course these have better / best stats.-------Classes & Jobs-------Very basic description. Will list the classes / jobs beneath. You start out as a class, and at 15 once you've completed the required quests you'll be able to change into a different class at any point in time by visiting that class specific guild and joining them. Or choose to go further within the first class of choice to learn a job. A Job is an advancement in the class you already are. For example, Conjurer (healer) into White Mage (advanced healer). You need 30 in Conjurer, and 15 in Arcanist to advance to a White Mage. The game is typical in terms of tanks, heals, and dps'ers. It shows you that as well. You can be any & all classes / jobs in the game as long as you meet the requirements and you can change at any time. All you have to do is equip the proper weapon to change to that class or job. One thing I probably should mention as well. There IS crafting in the game. They're also classes. They're known as Disciples of the Hand. Here are the Classes & Jobs that go hand in hand with each other;Disciple of War (Melee & Ranged):Class: Gladiator (Melee Tank) - Job: Paladin Class: Marauder (Melee Tank) - Job: Warrior Class: Pugilist (Melee DPS) - Job: MonkClass: Lancer (Melee DPS) - Job: Dragoon Class: Archer (Ranged DPS) - Job: Bard Disciple of Magic (Caster):Class: Thaumaturge (Caster DPS) - Job: Black MageClass: Conjurer (Healer) - Job: White MageClass: Arcanist (Caster DPS W/Pet) - Job(s): Summoner (DPS) & Scholar (Healer) Disciple of the Hand (Crafting): ~NOTICE~ You ALSO level these up as a regular class. Unique. :)Class: AlchemistClass: ArmorerClass: BlacksmithClass: CarpenterClass: CulinarianClass: GoldsmithClass: LeatherworkerClass: WeaverSo that about sums up my most important / basic review. Sorry for thy length. This game does have A LOT to offer. I encourage anyone who's a fan of MMORPG's to give this a try. If you'd like to know anything else about the game, feel free to just ask me or look up what other reviewers have said. Take it from someone that's played a ton of World of Warcraft. This game is unique in a fun way and actually shows you so. I have a blast playing it and hopefully see more of you guys on it. ^-^

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												FFXIV definitely takes its time to get started, but once it gets going it's ridiculously easy to get swept away by the setting. The world is beautiful and the soundtrack even more so - this is one of the few MMOs I've actually turned UP the music to listen to, rather than turn off and play my own. It all comes together to give it that "Final Fantasy" feel, which is either your cup of tea or isn't. If you long to rush into battle between White Mages and Black Mages, and face off against classic Final Fantasy bosses such as Ifrit, then FFXIV is the game for you.However, it's far from perfect. With the exception of the absolutely stellar opening cinematic, cutscenes are generally quite atrocious, and the voice acting even more so. Not only are they overly long and painful to watch, but the writing is also sloppy, which just makes every cutscene a bore and every time I reached one I just wanted it to end. I also found I had to turn the graphics down a fair bit just to reach 60fps, which is not something I usually have to do, but even when I did hit 60fps certain parts of the game were still choppy.On the gameplay side of things, there's nothing FFXIV does that isn't standard for the MMO genre. The hotbar-based combat is as generic as you can get, but still fun, and you'll find no shortage of baseline MMO kill this, fetch that quests. Where the game really shines is in its story quests, which while not the most elegant considering their reliance on cutscenes, are far more interesting than the grind.If you're a fan of MMOs or a Final Fantasy fanboy, you'll find a lot to like about FFXIV. Is it the best MMO out on the market? Not in my opinion. but damn it if I wasn't having a lot of fun anyway. I always had that "just one more quest" or "one more dungeon" feeling in order to progress the storyline, which is nice to have in the current paradigm of "gogogo loot slot machine" MMOs.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Whether you're a fan of the series, looking for a new MMO to invest yourself in, or both, FFXIV is definitely a good choice. Some will get tripped up over the subscription fee and not give it a chance as a result, and I would tell those people they are making a sore mistake. Once you get into the game, you'll immediately experience some of the best visuals that you've ever seen in an MMO, which in itself is reasoning to stay. Plus, you get the first month free.The plot actually plays a significant role in FFXIV, again unusual for an MMO, and is actually quite interesting IMO. As stated, the game is absolutely beautiful and I've found myself on many occasions stopping, going into first person, and just absorbing the beauty. The player community is very friendly, and you'll find yourself joining a Free Company in no time. In fact, I'd recommend it, but I digress. But the most interesting thing about FFXIV is its Job system. One of the most unique character specialization systems I've seen in an MMO, where you need to thread together 2-3 different classes to create a job unique to that class combination. although there are only around 8 or 9 jobs as of now, the possibilites are vast, and I am optimistic that it will gain many more with future expansions. The game is still in its vanilla stage and is already working MUCH better than its predecessor MMO. I have high hopes for the future in this game, and enjoying it thoroughly as of now. I recommend to any fans of MMO's or Final Fantasy.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												Hey there everyone. I've had many years of experience in all genres of games & gaming in general. So I figured I'll try to write the best, most accurate review I can without using the 'useless' details. I hope you guys enjoy. :)So to start things off. A Realm Reborn is NOT a "different" Final Fantasy from the original XIV, but at the same time it is. Final Fantasy XIV was a very unsuccesful game. So it was redesigned by a new team from the ground up and A Realm Reborn was released. ALSO THERE IS AN ACTUAL STORY TO THE GAME FOR ALL YOU STORY BASED PEOPLE! :D-------Graphics-------The game is stunningly beautiful for graphics. Modern laptops / PC's should not have massive framerate issues at all unless you're in 2 of the 3 main cities & it's heavily crowded in them. Depending on your settings, you will notice downgrades (of course) within the water, and the shadows. They even went as far as to lessen the amount of animation in character movements. What stinks is that the PS3 cannot control these options so the game is a bit choppier on that system. I'm not entirely sure about the PS4 as I don't have one. I would imagine it's more of a modern - high end PC power. The dungeons look stunning as do the creatures & bosses. I did the first dungeon called Sastasha, and my whole group stopped just before the last boss because we were too "wow'd" by the fact there was a sunset over the horizon of the cave. It looked absolutely gorgeous.-------Audio-------As far as sound goes, the game will sometimes glitch with what sound(s) it produces. Randomly at times in combat you'll just stop hearing your characters skills / spells. However, with that said, the music is very nice to listen to. I'm not saying it doesn't get repetitive after mannnnnnnnnny game hours and eventually you'll use your own. But remember, this is a Final Fantasy game. They want their music to at least be somewhat tasteful. I'm not entirely sure why they did this either, but when you're on a mount, if you aren't moving the music for the mount softens. Upon moving again it kicks back up. This is a bummer because I'd like to just sit there and listen to the chocobo theme for hours. :DAll in all though you can tell they took their time and didn't just throw slop together knowing MMO'ers use their own music anyways eventually.-------Characters & Character Customizing------- The characters look amazing to say the least. You have 5 races to choose from, both male & female unlike Final Fantasy XI which Miqo'te (female) and Rogeadyn (male) were gender restricted. Boring Humans (Hyur), Freakishly Tall Elves (Elezen), Little Cute People(Lalafell), No-Claw-Having Cat People (Miqo'te), and Chris Redfield's / She-Hulk's (Roegadyn). Within those races you first choose the gender, then you choose 1 of 2 options for a clan / tribe. These can have some differences, to many. Mostly being stat wise. One clan/tribe has melee/ranged based stats while the other has caster based. Then you go on to customize the look of your character. This ranges anywhere from the height and voice & changing the color of your hair / eyes, to the breast size on females & muscle tone on males. While there is A LOT to offer when it comes to customizing, there are some downsides. There are only 4-6 different base faces which may seem like enough but when you see the options you'll soon find yourself leaning toward the same one every time. While there are quite a few hairstyles / facial hair options, you'll soon take notice that they could have added in a lot more. Such as adding length for facial hair for guys, and more actual styles of hair for girls with a sub option of hair band colors and not 3-4 of the same hairstyles all just with a different color hair band. Some can have earrings which is actually a downer because it interferes & overlaps with earring based gear (yes earrings do show up when you equip them). -------Gear & Loot-------Since gear was mentioned in the previous paragraph I figured it was fitting to put it next. Now don't get me wrong, I like the look of the gear in ARR. But if you've played games like World of Warcraft you'll be disappointed in the way this game is done. Most loot is earned simply by completeing quests & dungeons. You will NOT find an upgradable piece of gear on a creature. Remember, this is Final Fantasy. You find them via dungeon treasure boxes & raids. Also there is not a buttload of gear. They do have a wide selection of things because of how many classes / jobs there are but you'll not see outfits that you go, "Hmm, I wonder where they got that." The weapons don't look all that flashy until higher levels / endgame. But they still graphically look very well done. EVERYTHING EXCEPT YOUR BELT shows up on your character. They just introduced the new Glamour system which lets you change the physical look of your gear without altering the stats (Transmogging for you WoW readers). The loot table goes as follow;White (Common) - Pretty useless stuff, but if it's better, wear it.Pink (Aetherial) - Better or worse than greens as the actual stats on them can differ. So in short, they aren't fixed stats and are not tradable.Green (Uncommon) - These are pretty much your dungeon leveling pieces of gear.Blue (Rare) & Purple (Epic) - Towards your end game you'll get these. Of course these have better / best stats.-------Classes & Jobs-------Very basic description. Will list the classes / jobs beneath. You start out as a class, and at 15 once you've completed the required quests you'll be able to change into a different class at any point in time by visiting that class specific guild and joining them. Or choose to go further within the first class of choice to learn a job. A Job is an advancement in the class you already are. For example, Conjurer (healer) into White Mage (advanced healer). You need 30 in Conjurer, and 15 in Arcanist to advance to a White Mage. The game is typical in terms of tanks, heals, and dps'ers. It shows you that as well. You can be any & all classes / jobs in the game as long as you meet the requirements and you can change at any time. All you have to do is equip the proper weapon to change to that class or job. One thing I probably should mention as well. There IS crafting in the game. They're also classes. They're known as Disciples of the Hand. Here are the Classes & Jobs that go hand in hand with each other;Disciple of War (Melee & Ranged):Class: Gladiator (Melee Tank) - Job: Paladin Class: Marauder (Melee Tank) - Job: Warrior Class: Pugilist (Melee DPS) - Job: MonkClass: Lancer (Melee DPS) - Job: Dragoon Class: Archer (Ranged DPS) - Job: Bard Disciple of Magic (Caster):Class: Thaumaturge (Caster DPS) - Job: Black MageClass: Conjurer (Healer) - Job: White MageClass: Arcanist (Caster DPS W/Pet) - Job(s): Summoner (DPS) & Scholar (Healer) Disciple of the Hand (Crafting): ~NOTICE~ You ALSO level these up as a regular class. Unique. :)Class: AlchemistClass: ArmorerClass: BlacksmithClass: CarpenterClass: CulinarianClass: GoldsmithClass: LeatherworkerClass: WeaverSo that about sums up my most important / basic review. Sorry for thy length. This game does have A LOT to offer. I encourage anyone who's a fan of MMORPG's to give this a try. If you'd like to know anything else about the game, feel free to just ask me or look up what other reviewers have said. Take it from someone that's played a ton of World of Warcraft. This game is unique in a fun way and actually shows you so. I have a blast playing it and hopefully see more of you guys on it. ^-^

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I get why people might be turned off by this game. Monthly subscriptions have long fallen from grace, not everybody enjoys the Japanese aesthetic, it doesn't really bring anything new to the table, etc. Final Fantasy XIV is very traditional MMO with clearly defined character roles, familiar combat and loot systems, dungeons and everything else you expect from a title like that. However, it does all of those things exceptionally well. GameplayThere is a lot of content to enjoy with substantial updates that have so far been free. The focus is clearly on group content and righteously so as the dungeons an large scale boss fights are easily the highlights of the game. In recent years, many MMOs have walked away from the holy trinity of Tank - Healer - Damage Dealer but Final Fantasy XIV embraces it which I for one greatly appreciate. You always get the feeling that you were relevant for the success of a dungeon run as all roles are equally important. This feeling is something that I missed sorely in other recent MMO titles that are either built so that "everyone can do everything" or hide away the group content that actually requires you to work together until the end-game. Final Fantasy XIV on the other hand eases you into all of its group content so even if you've never played an MMO before you'll quickly find your way around. The game allows you to level all classes on one character. The class you are currently playing as is determined by the weapon you have equipped. So you can experiment around until you find what suits your playstyle best. Combat plays out as you'd expect with global cooldowns, hotbars for skills and items, etc. Later int he game enemies and especially bosses require a fair bit of movement and positioning so there is a very dynamic feel to every fight.PresentationPresentation-wise both sound and graphics are good but not great. There are better looking MMOs out there but spell effects still look cool and character models are well done for the most part. There are some low-res textures here and there but certainly not bad enough to hurt the experience. Plus graphics are not all that important in a game like this anyway. A few awkward voice actors really stand out among the other which are decent enough. Sadly just about everything except main story cut-scenes isn't voice which is a shame but let's be honest, nobody reads what quest NPCs have to say anyway. ;)Final VerdictFinal Fantasy XIV is a great game that has a lot to offer for fans of traditional MMOs and can also serve as a great introduction for the uninitiated. Those looking for a more action-oriented take on online RPGs might not get what they are look for but if you like strategic battles and want a fresh take on tried and tested gameplay mechanics definitely give this one a try.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												This has been the only MMO to hold my attention for more than a month ever since the closing of City of Heroes. I never played the original FF14, but I heard the horrible reviews, and even remember seeing gameplay and feeling disgust towards it. To be honest? The only reason I even touched it was because of the free beta on PS4, and at that time I didn't know the game had undergone an overhaul. Since then I'm moving in on my 3rd month of subscription, and I regret nothing.The game is quite a grind at times. This is what I warn everyone. Professions are a grind, quests can be a grind, and the game has a lot of areas to explore which can seem like a grind... but despite all these boring aspects, something keeps drawing me back and makes me want more. I even find the monotony of crafting really fun for some reason!The combat is an interesting blend of auto-attack mixed with button clicking. Each class is different, and sometimes they even have a specific trick to them. This makes the game really interesting to me, because you're not always just playing a clone of another class... pressing the same buttons and using the same attacks. Each class has a designated role and are unique (And in addition, more classes are being added).The character creation is my favorite thing about the game. Despite not having any sliders (With the exception of height and muscle tone and stuff like that), or whatever you'd call ESO's system... FF14 uses, for the most part, a selection system, where you select different facial features and stuff. Despite sounding primitive and boring, there's great potential in it, and you can generally make what you're aiming for. This, in addition to the beautiful full color palette for hair and stuff as well as the cool features like hair hightlights and "odd-eyes", really made me feel like I was creating a character -I- wanted to make, and not a character the Devs wanted me to make *COUGH*ESO*COUGH*.The story is really interesting, and actually doesn't feel like it singles you out as the only person in the entire world (Like most MMOs have begun to do these days). While you -are- labeled as an important figure, they acknowledge you're not the only one. This makes Roleplaying a lot easier if you're into that kind of thing. You don't run into a TOR mindset of "I -AM- THE TROOPER" and stuff like that. You're just an adventurer, and they even give you a blank slate to start off with so you can really think of your character as whatever you want. Your character doesn't feel written for you.Also, the game is just beautiful to look at. Everything about it is really pretty, and I found that my favorite place is the desert as ironic as it is. Usually deserts are really ugly and plain, but the developers take great care and consideration into every zone to make it look unique and interesting. It's not just a plain desert, but more like prairie land and canyons. The forest isn't just a big forest, but also includes things like dark, mystical woods hidden away. Things like this make the game really appealing to play. And best of all? The game is completely open. Traveling becomes easier later, but from level 1 it's possible to travel to any location you really want to (given the time and luck to pass by so many enemies!). I was able to meet up with my friend in a whole different area, even though I didn't have the airships unlocked yet (This was Ul'Dah to Gridania though, not sure if you're able to get off Limsa without unlocking the airships or the boat to Thanalan).The community is pretty great, and really active. I play on Balmung, and I constantly see people everywhere. I see recruitment for raids, dungeons, Free Companies (guilds), and all that. There are actually sites to help you figure out the population of a server, but you'd have to google it.The most interesting thing to me is actually the cross-platform play. People who are playing on the PS3 version, the PS4 version, and the PC version all play together. There's no console barriers, because Square uses their own servers. I myself play FF14 with my sisters, one on our PS3, one on our PS4, and me on the PC. The only downside is that if you want to switch you have to buy a whole new copy. *CAUTION* MAKE SURE YOU KNOW YOUR PC CAN HANDLE THE GAME BEFORE PURCHASING. My sister's computer couldn't so she ended up re-buying the game for PS3 and then upgrading (For free) to PS4.Overall, great game. I love it.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												One thing I'd like to really touch on that very few people seem to mention, probably because they're used to MMOs and dived right into the classes they know and love: The game does a legit phenomenal job of teaching people the skills they need in their class.  MInd you, people can be dumb, and I'm not saying they're any less dumb in XIV.  You'll run into people who can't count (and therefore, at best, only hit the target with a 1 on it), and the like.  But my wife, as basically an MMO newbie (She played GW2 before this, which has very nearly nothing in terms of group dynamics, although it is very fun), learned almost all of the skills she needs as a tank by, get this, actually reading what the NPCs said in the Gladiator quests.  Reading the quest text, I kid you not, gave her legit valuable lessons in how to play well.  The only stuff she had to pick up from us were 'use marks' and 'tank swap mechanics exist'.   Now, it's been a while since I've played another EQ Clone.  Maybe this is standard now, I really don't know.  But this by itself means I can easily recommend it.  Probably the other big thing I can say is that, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥I love crafting in this.  Ya gave me a system and it's an actual thing.  Fantastic, although it is boring as all get out to start with and they don't really start showing you the systems for a bit.  And at least before the latest update, it was actually a thing you can level without the exercise being a giant moneypit (No idea about now, crystal prices have taken a hike lately I guess and that muddles things).  I'm enjoying it.  Will you?  I hope so!  If not, this is Fine, Too.  But it's worth a whirl.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Not really seeing where it being worth a sub comes in, if it's just for the FF nostalgic feeling then it's not enough for me (huge FF7,8,9,10 fan). Instance based MMO, with gameplay feeling similar to that of Tera, but really I would play Tera's combat system over this one.  Got pretty far, and the max level guildmates kept telling me it's going to get better. Smh. They said that when I was lvl 10, lvl 20, lvl 30, lvl 40 (if you're starting out, get ready for the long♥♥♥♥♥lvl 10-20 QUE time for guildhiest a.k.a. instance mini-dungeons). Like to say I was fortunate though, to have ran into a helpful higher level player who let me join his 180 member large Free Company a.k.a. guild. Without them, I would have left even sooner as it was getting boring AF waiting in que, one boring errand quest to the next (the "say" or public chat is dead, no matter what time of day; I was in Faerie server, which I looked up to be a pretty active server). However, overall the game is just not cutting it for me, I'm not saying it's a "bad" game, I'm saying I'm not seeing how this is worth a sub. If it was F2P, I would proba continue to play a little longer but the sub requirement is too much. It's a subscription game, and only the few main, and I mean MAIN-MAIN (mainly when you're changing arc) story quest are voice acted in the cutscenes. Most of the time, the game has these awkward bad lip syncing cutscenes with no voices. The story itself, I have to say is, well, passable but definitely the worse (by a decent margin) out of the four FF games I've played (gave it some slack cause it's an MMO, most mmo story sucks and this one was meh- okay). So again, NOT A BAD MMORPG, just Mediocre run-of-the-mill action mmorpg with FF nostalgic value. If that's enough for you, then go for it. But for me, when I see a subscription requirement I expect quality content and not just at end game (yes it is one of those mmorpg where it's super boring and everyone says to grit your teeth and bare through to get towards the later game and end game).P.S. Great OST, just amazing ear pleasure and pretty visuals. Oh and also web shop to buy in-game items are insanely priced for a subscription game, of course they are optional but jeezus, FFS $7.99 for a single EMOTE. content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												Background: Huge Final Fantasy Fan, Bought a PS4 just for FF7 Remake. Anyways!Replayability: Now this is a weird one. You can swap out the class of your character by merely going into the menus, and putting the correct equipment on. You then get to experience that class story. It is actually 100% recommended and I would go as far as to say it is required as you need at least 2 classes to obtain the Advanced Classes. But this is true for most Final Fantasy Games.Combat Options: Final Fantasy XIV is the 2nd attempt at a FF Themed MMORPG. For those of you with vast FF backgrounds the Combat type is FFXII with more control of your character placement and equipment slots. For those not familiar with FFXII it is an Active Time battle played out in the general vicinity of enemy spawn points, meaning you can run by just physically running away but you can also attract more enemies as well. Social Options: The game has been around enough to have many guilds on every instance Server. Experience is shared between those who participate, not just the initial aggressor which means you can't 100% kill steal something, which is a problem in other games. Final Thoughts: I have since retired from this game after 628 hours due to Burnout...I have great respect for those who continue the good fight, but I just can't continue.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												As an MMO, this game sometimes feels more like a Single-player game entirely. The learning curve is simple but there is plenty to keep adding to the list as you progress. The classes all have their own difficulties, and playstyles. Such as Paladin being your basic sword and shield tank that runs in and bashes people over the head with their shield, hunkers down behind said shield and holds aggro. While Warrior is very run-in with a middle finger to every enemy in the dungeon, get as buffed up as possible with HP levels rising well above 9000 and relying heavily on that high hp when your buffs run out.AoE's are proper AoE's. You do not want to stand in them for even a second as most that are in places your level could potentially kill you out right or make the fight "flee or die". I would say that this game is worth buying, even a Collector's Edition is worth buying if you're into that sort of thing. And it will be an enjoyable experience for quite a long time.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												I'd love to write a review of the actual game. But since Steam gave me a key for the PAL version, despite the fact I'm an American and my account both here and at Square Enix is for the US, I can't use my Steam key to activate the game. And of course my repeated attempts to contact Steam Support have gone unanswered, so I'm just out the $45 I paid for the product. Thanks so much Steam! You're my hero! D:Update 6/26/2014: After nearly two weeks, Steam finally made good and refunded my purchase so that I could buy the right version of this game for my region. I criticized them when they were bad, so it's only fair I commend them when they do right. May have taken a little while, but they finally did right by me.Now that I've been in the game, I can actually share some feedback. Character models and movements are some of the prettiest I've seen in any MMO, and the Emote system is phenomenal. It seems Square put a *lot* of effort into making the game very RP-friendly, between emotes and custom groups for chat channels.Beginning quests are fairly easy, but there is a *lot* of running between distant points. The little crystals you can use tot eleport around are helpful, if a bit hard to get used to their naming scheme. But ti still seems I spend a lot more time running from point A to point B than actually playing the game, which is a bit frustrating.As pretty as the character models are, the outfits and armor are just plain silly. It does a good job keeping in the style of previous Final Fantasy games, but it really doesn't fit here. With the more realistic-looking characters and backdrops, the clothing looks overly cartoonish and out of place. To be armored is to look ridiculous, in sharp contrast to the starter outfits you begin the game with.As a player new to FFXIV, its pros and cons are pretty much a dead tie for me. I'll give it a nod towards Recommended only becasue the game does seem to have a good sesne of humor about itself, and that alsways helps. But it's barely a win so far.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												After putting over 400 hours into this game, I finally feel like I have enough experience with it that I can leave some insightful feedback.FFXIV is a great game which does a lot of things right, so don't read the negative parts of my review and think I am suggesting that the game isn't worth your time. The graphics are amazing, the story is great, the gameplay is solid, and there is plenty to do even after you reach the level cap; but for all of this the game still has several flaws which can really take away from the enjoyment.The first major problem I noticed early on is just how long it can take to queue for a dungeon sometimes. Tanks and Healers have it much better than other classes because they are rare and high demand classes, but DPS classes can sometimes wait for hours just to get in a dungeon.The community of an MMO can really make or break the experience, and the community in FFXIV can be pretty bad at times. If you are new to a dungeon or raid, there is a high chance people will abandon you in the middle of the run after a single fail or insult you. It's a good idea to know what you're doing, but because so much of this game is about knowing what's coming next, the only way to learn is by reading guides and practicing. You are bound to make some mistakes before you get the content memorized, and one mistake in this game can cause your entire party to be wiped.It can take days or weeks of practice to learn the ins and outs of a single raid. This alone is not such a big problem, but trying to get seven or more other people who also know every single attack and gimmick is extremely difficult. Even though I knew the fight, it took me more than two weeks to get a party together that was capable of clearing Titan (Extreme), and I've been trying for weeks to get a party together that is capable of clearing Turn 5.In the end, I would still recommend this game to anyone who likes Final Fantasy and MMORPGs, but just beware that this game has a steep learning curve and everyone wants instant gratification. You will have to put up with a lot of dumb things such as people expecting you to do speed runs when all you are trying to do is clear a dungeon for the first time for your quests, and on the flipside, people joining your Turn 5 runs who have no clue what they are doing and cause your raid team to fail again, and again, and again.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6
												I had previously left a review that personally left me embarrassed by my childishness at what was a monster of my own making. I figure this is my way to attone for it.Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is a reboot of the original Final Fantasy XIV after gameplay issues caused the MMO to stagnate and become near unplayable. However with its reboot, with the death of the 1.0 version being a canon happening, players start out as an adventerer in the fictional world of Eorzea a diverse land governed by several city states that are under threat not just by the Garlean Empire threatening to invaid, but by beast tribes summoning their respective gods as Primals beasts that absorb the aether from the land and threaten to do far worse than push back the people. However blessed with the power of the Echo the players strive to fight back these threats and bring Eorzea to a whole.Starting off you have a few races to choose from and they are purely cosmetic as stat differences mean very little the more you play. Make your character and choose your starting class from one of the many combat classes which not only determines your roles in dungeons but might also be your main class when progressing through the story quests.The starting classes are:Marauder a Tank class that goes up to the job of WarriorGladiator another Tank that goes up to PaladinPugilist a Melee damage dealer that turns into a MonkLancer a melee damage dealer that becomes a DragoonArcher a ranged physical damage dealer that becomes a BardRogue a melee damage dealer that becomes a Ninja (Only available once you reach Level 10 in any other class)Conjurer a healer that becomes a White MageThaumaturge a Ranged Magical damage dealer that becomes a Black Mageand Arcanist a Ranged Magical damage dealer that becomes either Summoner or Scholar.The fun thing about classes and jobs is that you can be either the class or job at any time once you obtain it. You can also play any class at almost any time you want on one character which is needed to get the jobs because for example to be a White Mage you have to be a level 30 Conjurer with 15 levels in Thaumaturge. This adds a push to getting characters to play the other classes, and believe me I ended up enjoying Thaumaturge so much I nearly leveled it up to a Black Mage before I forced myself to get back on track.The game is easy to play but challenging to master. Each class has its own strengths and weaknesses. For example DPS classes deal damage with ease but need to avoid taking damage just as much. Tank classes can take hard hits on the chin, but have low damage dealing and might struggle to keep their health up. Healers can outlast the best of them being able to keep their health up, but lack the damage output or defence of the other classes. These differences are vital to the party based gameplay that Final Fantasy is known for especially in dungeons.The dungeons in Final Fantasy XIV can range from easy, to frustrating, but never boring. After the first dungeon every following one features at least three bosses with interesting mechanics to them. From avoiding attacks to area wide effects that can leave each class with a list of tasks to do each time. I advise playing with a friend who has challenged these dungeons before or at least looking up visual guides to them as certain mechanics can be difficult to learn first time. However these dungeons can get rather complex when you add in more people.The standard light party in this game is four people typically one tank, one healer, and two DPS. However the max full party is eight people doubling the number of classes needed. This means a lot of co-operation is needed and knowledge of terms such as Main Tank and Off Tank, Rez, and so on will be needed as these are standards in communicating strategy to other players. You may get the odd bad Tank/DPS/Healer, but all in all the party members generally have the same understanding of the game that you have at that point.In addition to fighting things there are also two non-combat class types: Disciples of the Land, and Disciples of the Hand, or Gatherers and Crafters. As you defeat enemies you'll obtain things like skins, meats, and other such things in addition to gathering through Mining, Botany, and Fishing that you can use as a Carpenter, Blacksmith, Armorer, Goldsmith, Leatherworker, Weaver, Alchemist, and Culinarian. These generally are used for making money or making items you can use in game such as food, potions, or even some equipment.Social interaction is an inevitability in this game. With MMOs there's bound to be other people playing and as such you'll run into people who may want you to join their party for a bit, or their free company. Free Companies are the guilds in this game. Player owned and operated guilds can be set up for nearly anything such as raids, helping new players, or even roleplaying. Various perks are earned as players in the free company earn points including buffs that affect the whole company such as increased EXP from battles. In addition Free Companies can more easily get the money needed to purchase an estate in one of the many residential areas. For a fee you can buy a plot of land, or an apartment that you can decorate and make your own. The cash needed can be quite a lot but chances are the benefits will really apeal to you if you enjoy a lot of customization and really making spaces your own. You can add guardens, combat dummies, chocobo stables, and much more however it's purely optional. However it's nice to have a place to let your character rest when you're ready to log off.There are issues with this game of course, it's not perfect as much as I wish it was. The biggest complaint is the subscriptions which requires that you pay money to keep playing the game every month. This is an issue until you realize that they give you the first month free, feature free play events, and give you access to everything you want. Understandable that you don't want to pay for an MMO you might not play more than once a week, however I don't see it as an issue.Another issue is in the inherent saturation of DPS classes. Queueing for a dungeon could take half an hour if you're lucky where as with Healer and Tanks they arrive and join in the DPS queues that were waiting for so long. Hardly surprising however but as more classes are added with expansions there's a larger number of Tanks and Healing classes available as well.Overall this game had won me over at the first level up, and once you get in the groove of your class you never fully get out of it.

Do I recommend the game? Yes. Gods yes. Do I recommend it via Steam? Sorry to Steam, but no, I cannot.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												What I've been doing this whole October:"Wasting" My Time With Final Fantasy XIV.How was it?- Well from a FF Fanatic, IT IS SO GOOD THAT I USED $80 (+$30 for some additional stuff and +$12.99 for the Subscription this November, $122.99 if you hate math and that's without tax) JUST SO I COULD MAX 1 CLASS TO LV60. I still need to max out 22 more classes.Can low-end PC play it?- Graphics was very crisp even my crappy PC could handle it. It's been out since 2010 and it's looking good af.Was it grindy?- Eh, not really. It's pretty much your fault if you hit a level gap making you unable continue the Main Story Quest.Speaking of Quests, I heard FFXIV's Content was Quest Locked, was it hard to go through the Quests?- Most of the game's content is locked through the Main Story Quests. They prolly did it just so people wouldn't skip MSQ and just grind fest through all the mobs in the Overworld. It wasn't hard doing all the Qs because it's a basic RPG Element that PEOPLE SHOULDN'T THINK OF AS A NEGATIVE THING.That sounds really annoying, is it really worth to do all of that just to unlock content?- Worth, trust me. I've been there.Was the Story engaging?- Story wise, it was very very engaging I tell you. You're basically an adventurer who got there that got mixed up in all sorts of problems and was told to realize you were the "chosen one". It sounds very cookie-cutter yes, but the way it was presented had that *umph* power of a Final Fantasy game. Although, I recommend reading/watching some stuff about the lore/backstory before FFXIV:ARR came to be.ARR? What's that?- ARR stands for A Realm Reborn. It's the base game which you will cap till Level 50 (enough to feel the FF yum-yums).Level 50 is the level cap? Isn't it a bit too low?- That's not the "actual" level cap. To hit the actual cap, you must buy the FFXIV: Heavensward expansion, which gives you a whopping 10 more levels and a ton more of content to unlock!!! (wooo!). And oh boy if the road from 1 to 50 was tiring for you, 51~ 60 is something.Just tell us already what that "something" is- HAH HAH! You thought it was all just mere character levels? HAH! It's not even the final "level". You also need iLvL to progress on "everything" that is Heavensward related.Wait what? iLvLs? You're making no sense at all...- iLvLs, Item Levels. The the even some the Veterans of FFXIV hate. It's basically your gear's Average Level. Like I said before, you need it to progress and hitting iLvL gap is worse than simple MSQ level gap.Can we just end this already? I feel like I learned nothing at all...- lol, okay then.1) Very good game for MMORPG people especially for the ones who play and love FF.2) Graphics can be compared to current MMORPGs.3) The balance between Grinding and Questing is 50|50.4) Content wise, it's worth every penny. From Massive Dungeons to Epic Boss Fights to Intense Raids.5) Cost wise, go buy the FFXIV: A Realm Reborn base game. If not, just go download the demo for 14 days.6) Final Score: 9.4/10 --- Would get thrown off the stage again. (Yes I'm looking at you Titan Extreme)

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
 What is it? Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn (From here on out called FF14 Online) is an MMORPG Fantasy game set with the Final Fantasy Universe.  What is it NOT? FF14 Online is not your typical Final Fantasy Game. Its an Online MMO, which means you MUST have an internet connection to play. There is also a monthly fee ($14.99USD) to play, so please consider this before diving into this game, as it could become very expensive and a waste of money for those of you that do not play at least once a day. Graphics:  FF14 Online has some of the best graphics for an MMO I have seen in a long time. Everything is crisp, framerates are smooth, and the cutscenes are not like previous entries (Extremely higher detailed than in-game. Yeah, Im looking at you, Final Fantasy 12!) There are multiple options in system settings you can mess with to achieve the highest Framrate you can. Even lower end systems can play this fairly well without too much of a hit to visual quality. Gameplay:  The game plays as you would expect any major MMO to: You begin by creating your character. Changing their appearence, race, class/job, etc. Do not fret too much about picking a starter class. Unlike most MMO games, FF14 Online allows you to eventually learn any and all classes/jobs. Most of which have crossover abilities! (A Gladiator using curative spells? An Archer with black magic? Yes! You CAN do it!) Does it have Single-Player Mode? FF14, as stated before, is an MMORPG, meaning there is no true single-player mode available. While this is a fact, most of the main storyline can be completed solo, with the exception of certain dungeons. There is also a lot of solo content for you to play, if that is your thing. But you get the true enjoyment out of this game with the group system, Free Companies, and many other vsrious social forms. Do I recommend this game? I give this game a definite "Yes"! If you are into games that give you the most bang for your buck, give it a try. You can play a 14 day trial of the game if you go through the official website http://www.finalfantasyxiv.comIt is a game worth giving a try! If you enjoy this game, please leave a comment below with your opinions and adventures!

content:
Posted: February 6
												I had previously left a review that personally left me embarrassed by my childishness at what was a monster of my own making. I figure this is my way to attone for it.Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is a reboot of the original Final Fantasy XIV after gameplay issues caused the MMO to stagnate and become near unplayable. However with its reboot, with the death of the 1.0 version being a canon happening, players start out as an adventerer in the fictional world of Eorzea a diverse land governed by several city states that are under threat not just by the Garlean Empire threatening to invaid, but by beast tribes summoning their respective gods as Primals beasts that absorb the aether from the land and threaten to do far worse than push back the people. However blessed with the power of the Echo the players strive to fight back these threats and bring Eorzea to a whole.Starting off you have a few races to choose from and they are purely cosmetic as stat differences mean very little the more you play. Make your character and choose your starting class from one of the many combat classes which not only determines your roles in dungeons but might also be your main class when progressing through the story quests.The starting classes are:Marauder a Tank class that goes up to the job of WarriorGladiator another Tank that goes up to PaladinPugilist a Melee damage dealer that turns into a MonkLancer a melee damage dealer that becomes a DragoonArcher a ranged physical damage dealer that becomes a BardRogue a melee damage dealer that becomes a Ninja (Only available once you reach Level 10 in any other class)Conjurer a healer that becomes a White MageThaumaturge a Ranged Magical damage dealer that becomes a Black Mageand Arcanist a Ranged Magical damage dealer that becomes either Summoner or Scholar.The fun thing about classes and jobs is that you can be either the class or job at any time once you obtain it. You can also play any class at almost any time you want on one character which is needed to get the jobs because for example to be a White Mage you have to be a level 30 Conjurer with 15 levels in Thaumaturge. This adds a push to getting characters to play the other classes, and believe me I ended up enjoying Thaumaturge so much I nearly leveled it up to a Black Mage before I forced myself to get back on track.The game is easy to play but challenging to master. Each class has its own strengths and weaknesses. For example DPS classes deal damage with ease but need to avoid taking damage just as much. Tank classes can take hard hits on the chin, but have low damage dealing and might struggle to keep their health up. Healers can outlast the best of them being able to keep their health up, but lack the damage output or defence of the other classes. These differences are vital to the party based gameplay that Final Fantasy is known for especially in dungeons.The dungeons in Final Fantasy XIV can range from easy, to frustrating, but never boring. After the first dungeon every following one features at least three bosses with interesting mechanics to them. From avoiding attacks to area wide effects that can leave each class with a list of tasks to do each time. I advise playing with a friend who has challenged these dungeons before or at least looking up visual guides to them as certain mechanics can be difficult to learn first time. However these dungeons can get rather complex when you add in more people.The standard light party in this game is four people typically one tank, one healer, and two DPS. However the max full party is eight people doubling the number of classes needed. This means a lot of co-operation is needed and knowledge of terms such as Main Tank and Off Tank, Rez, and so on will be needed as these are standards in communicating strategy to other players. You may get the odd bad Tank/DPS/Healer, but all in all the party members generally have the same understanding of the game that you have at that point.In addition to fighting things there are also two non-combat class types: Disciples of the Land, and Disciples of the Hand, or Gatherers and Crafters. As you defeat enemies you'll obtain things like skins, meats, and other such things in addition to gathering through Mining, Botany, and Fishing that you can use as a Carpenter, Blacksmith, Armorer, Goldsmith, Leatherworker, Weaver, Alchemist, and Culinarian. These generally are used for making money or making items you can use in game such as food, potions, or even some equipment.Social interaction is an inevitability in this game. With MMOs there's bound to be other people playing and as such you'll run into people who may want you to join their party for a bit, or their free company. Free Companies are the guilds in this game. Player owned and operated guilds can be set up for nearly anything such as raids, helping new players, or even roleplaying. Various perks are earned as players in the free company earn points including buffs that affect the whole company such as increased EXP from battles. In addition Free Companies can more easily get the money needed to purchase an estate in one of the many residential areas. For a fee you can buy a plot of land, or an apartment that you can decorate and make your own. The cash needed can be quite a lot but chances are the benefits will really apeal to you if you enjoy a lot of customization and really making spaces your own. You can add guardens, combat dummies, chocobo stables, and much more however it's purely optional. However it's nice to have a place to let your character rest when you're ready to log off.There are issues with this game of course, it's not perfect as much as I wish it was. The biggest complaint is the subscriptions which requires that you pay money to keep playing the game every month. This is an issue until you realize that they give you the first month free, feature free play events, and give you access to everything you want. Understandable that you don't want to pay for an MMO you might not play more than once a week, however I don't see it as an issue.Another issue is in the inherent saturation of DPS classes. Queueing for a dungeon could take half an hour if you're lucky where as with Healer and Tanks they arrive and join in the DPS queues that were waiting for so long. Hardly surprising however but as more classes are added with expansions there's a larger number of Tanks and Healing classes available as well.Overall this game had won me over at the first level up, and once you get in the groove of your class you never fully get out of it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												This is probably the most poorly designed MMO I've played in years from a gameplay perspective. Lag is literally built into the combat system. Invisible walls are absolutely everywhere, there is an entire city of pirates, surrounded by ships and water, yet there is no swimming. You won't be on too many boats either.That being said, the game is quite fun and addictive, the atmosphere is great, and the story isn't too bad. Do be prepared to do an inane amount of fetch and deliver quests, however (and the bulk of these will come from your "primary" quest line that advances the main story of the game). You will cross continents to fix jewelry, or gather ingredients for soup or perfume. There is teleportation, however, so it's not as bad as it could be. Be aware that this never ends. You'll still be doing trivial chores well beyond the level cap.Aside from the continuation of quests at cap, the game does become a bit of a dungeon simulator, but this isn't all bad. The best thing about this game is a very strong sense of progression. There is always something to do, always something you can level, and the community isn't too bad. I haven't touched the PVP, but I've heard nothing good about it. There are PVP exclusive abilities as well. Really, just the combat lag is enough to make me stay away from it.Overall, I'd recommend the game. It's fun for what it is if you can ignore the glaring flaws. However, unless you've tried everything else MMOs have to offer, or you just really like Final Fantasy as a franchise, you could probably do better.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												There's a two week trial to play the game. There is a free trial on Steam...just gotta type in "Final Fantasy XIV" and then it'll finally show up as a "Free Demo." Also when looking at reviews to get to know the game, ignore anything under 100 hours. They don't know what they'e talking about.As it says for me, I've logged 440 hours at the time of this review (Thats bound to change very soon though). I'm downright addicted to FFXIV. Yes, there are points in which the game is tedious. Yes, there are certain things that make me sigh. And yes, the few cutscenes that are voice acted are terrible as the VA's suck. First things first. Some of the negative reviews says the game is SUPER grind heavy. That's both FALSE and TRUE. It doesn't take long to get a single character class to 50 (Present max level though the DLC/Expansion that comes out this spring will raise it to 60 while adding an entire new area, new dungeons, raids, bosses, and 3 new classes). What takes long is getting your max Item Level Gear which is...130? I'm not too sure on that myself. I haven't hit ilevel100 yet on my main.More on the Grinding. You can hit max level in under 2 weeks of moderate gameplay for one of your classes. That's not long compared to some other MMO's. Of course most other MMO's don't allow you to level EVERY CLASS in the game on ONE CHARACTER without the need for alts. What makes the game 'Grind heavy' is the fact that there's 9 Combat Classes and 11 Crafting/Gathering Classes. That's a total of 20 (Well 22 technically but those two share the same exp pool as its base class) different classes to get to level 50. On one character. And yes, there is a benefit from leveling all the classes. You can 'Cross Class' certain skills to other classes. Giving them benefits of different skills.Some of the early dungeons are pretty boring but they're not really meant to be like really great. They're basically tutorial dungeons. Letting you learn the mechanics that you'll see extremely often in later, harder, and significantly more fun, dungeons (and raids.)The crafting/gathering system is a love-hate thing. Though that's true of most every MMO. One of my Free Company minions focused almost exlucsively on the Crafting and Gathering Classes and almost hit 50 on all of them within only a few weeks time. If you're dedicated and manage your exp sources right (Levequests and crafting/gathering level appropriate stuff) your crafting/gatherers will level fairly quickly.There's two different subscriptions too. So all those peope ♥♥♥♥♥ing about "Its 15 bucks a month" are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tting you. 15 bucks a month is for the premium subscription that simply allows you 8 characters per server for a max of 40 throughout your Data Center. The Base Subscription, which is like...12-13 bucks? Restricts you to 1 character per server and a max of 8 in your data center. I'm not sure on the price as I have the premium subscription myself. The base subscription is cheaper then, say, WoW's subscription. And its worth it since you don't really need Alts. (I just really like the game. >.>)As people will say, the game looks very nice. The music is fantastic (But what did you expect? Its a FINAL FANTASY game!). The story is interesting. Gameplay? I like it. It's solid. There's not really much to say about it. It's an MMO...Oh! I saw one negative review talking about monsters "Auto attacks" and there being to avoid getting hit by them unless it uses a move that creates a 'zone' that you want to get out of...that's not true. You can avoid getting hit by a monsters auto attacks if you STAY OUT OF THEIR RANGE. Which is understandably hard for a Melee Class or a Caster Class. But the Archer has no problem literally kiting a monster without ranged attacks around in circles. Ya just gotta becareful not to leash them...as they'll become invincible while they retreat back to their spawn area.What else to say...what else to say...Hm...JUST TRY THE FREE TRIAL! ITS FREE.
