number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												This is probably the most poorly designed MMO I've played in years from a gameplay perspective. Lag is literally built into the combat system. Invisible walls are absolutely everywhere, there is an entire city of pirates, surrounded by ships and water, yet there is no swimming. You won't be on too many boats either.That being said, the game is quite fun and addictive, the atmosphere is great, and the story isn't too bad. Do be prepared to do an inane amount of fetch and deliver quests, however (and the bulk of these will come from your "primary" quest line that advances the main story of the game). You will cross continents to fix jewelry, or gather ingredients for soup or perfume. There is teleportation, however, so it's not as bad as it could be. Be aware that this never ends. You'll still be doing trivial chores well beyond the level cap.Aside from the continuation of quests at cap, the game does become a bit of a dungeon simulator, but this isn't all bad. The best thing about this game is a very strong sense of progression. There is always something to do, always something you can level, and the community isn't too bad. I haven't touched the PVP, but I've heard nothing good about it. There are PVP exclusive abilities as well. Really, just the combat lag is enough to make me stay away from it.Overall, I'd recommend the game. It's fun for what it is if you can ignore the glaring flaws. However, unless you've tried everything else MMOs have to offer, or you just really like Final Fantasy as a franchise, you could probably do better.

number of helpful: 18 of 36 people (50%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												This is probably the worst MMO I have ever played in my entire life. There's no open world pvp, no group questing or group story, you can't run instances with friends without a full group otherwise you get no rewards, the instanced pvp is unbalanced beyond belief.Other things that annoyed me is how repetitive the sound effects are. I played as an arcanist and it was the same *PIIIING* *PIIIING* on every single spell I used. I didn't even feel satisfied killing a single monster. The ingame economy is also broke beyond belief. I've seen common ingredients being sold for thousands of gil, and super rare items going for next to nothing. Oh and the game seems to have around 8% of the voice acting completed. At first I thought the game might be glitching because cutscenes will randomly have or not have voice acting.Basically the only thing you can do in this game is grind. You can't escape it. In a good MMO you could take a break by pvping or group up with friends to do something. But not here... It really is the most boring experience I've ever had playing a game. I suppose if you grind long enough to start doing raids, you might enjoy those... But honestly since this game is just another WoW clone, you'd be better of just playing WoW if you want a game with good raids.If you're a Final Fantasy fan even then I wouldn't recommend spending money on this. The story is depressingly dull. I'm supposed to feel like an epic hero, but I just feel like someones errand boy. Just stick to the main series.I wish I had the words to convey just how bored I felt. But if you take anything from this review, anything at all. That is that you should take a second thought before you buy this game.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Over the years I have played Ultima Onine, Dark Age of Camelot, WoW, Warhammer Online, WoW, Neverwinter, LOTRO, Guild Wars, and Star Wars the Old Republic. So far Star Wars has held my interest the longest. FFXIV is looking good so far, and seems to be on par with Star Wars in keeping my interest. The graphics are pretty, but the storyline so far isn't anything great, but I have heard from people the storyline takes a bit to get into. Also I do like the ability to change classes at any time, that's very different from other MMORPGs I haved played. The classes, not jobs, have a hunting log where you get a bunch of experience for fighting certain enemies. So far there is no PVP, which is good for me since I do not like PVP. So there is no chooseing sides like Republic vs Empire or Horde vs Alliance. They are supposed to come out with a better PVP system, but i do not know when it is coming out. Also you can play online with PS3/Ps4/PC people, and you can crossplay it on those systems too. I grabbed this game along with Secret World while they both were on sale. I'll probably buy at least another two months, but I may not continue it due to school. You should pick it up while its on sale to give it a try and see if you like it or not.Recentlt got back into the game now that I have a full time job, and it is still great. I don't have Heavensward, but you don't need it till you finish A Realm Reborn.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												I really liked this game, but leveling is a chore and a half, simply because you run out of things to do quick when you end up having to level an alt. A large chunk of your experience comes from the story mission and you can only do that once, so afterwards you find yourself struggling to get things done. The final blow for me came when I realized I only had a limited amount of Leve missions and I had wasted them on early levels for my alternative class (to unlock my first job), which meant I would have to wait several days for my Chocobo. The idea that I would have to run around for three days was just mindnumbingly traumatic for me, so I logged off and said goodbye, with only minimal sadness. I would suggest trying out the two week trial before paying for this game. Some people might like it, but most don't seem to.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												I do not recommend this game. For the following reasons I cannot recommend anyone spend their time on this game without significant improvements made to account set up and initial updating.In life there are certain necessities: obtaining resources, developing skills, overcoming obstacles and entertainment to name a few. What motivates one must satisfy a need with a reasonable investment of time and effort. My sole purpose in this game is to play as an imaginary character in an imaginary world filled with imaginary things. As a purchaser I cannot make money, or update my resume with anything related to this effort which is now becoming something of an unjustifiable obstacle relative to the outcome.I will now chronicle the genesis of this obstacle in order to play as an imaginary character in an imaginary world filled with imaginary things (a meager need that has yet to be satisfied): 1.) I purchased the game on steam and installed it - no problem. 2.) Upon starting the game I needed to set up a Square Enix account which I attempted to do through the launcher (naturally, as the option is provided right there). In my experience, this was a convoluted, glitchy process that resulted in several attempts and approximately two hours of my time wasted. As setting up an account is usually a straightforward process I did not make a log like a dutiful beta tester. Essentially, my email was at once recognized to the extent I could not repeat the registration process to clarify what might have gone wrong, yet not recognized to the extent I could not recover a password. Eventually I simply made an account directly through the Square Enix website. A painless, wonderful and perfectly pedestrian result that by comparison had me shouting joyfully "It's alive! It's alive" with Handel's "Messiah" ringing in my head.3.)  After the account was set up I could then update the game. Whereas the registration was likely to have different results for different people depending on wind currents caused by butterfly wings and their relationship to which particle collider test had run on a that day with reference to the alignment of various celestial bodies, the size of the update is massive - and is taking a long time.With reference to needs and motivation I have run a gauntlet with no satisfaction in sight for another 1386 minutes, and at this point am making two major recommendations: 1.) If the option to create an account via the launcher is intended, it needs to be as simple as creating an account on the website. My experience has shown a discrepancy in ease of use between the two.2.) The initial update is as massive as the investment of time required for the game to be ready to play; a possible way to mitigate this is to sell a more recent version. If this has no effect on overall download time, find ways to make it more effiecient.At this point I will complete the updating process, but cannot recommend this game unless these two recommendations are given serious consideration. Butterfly wings and all.Update: Day1 of gameplay.Still can't recommend this game due to problems out of the gate, but the game itself seems pretty solid.Aesthetics are very pleasing while keeping the kibble to a minimum; map so far looks good.No comment on quests yet as I have not progressed much past the tutorial.Overall get the feeling the learning curve for the game is worth the patience it will take to master.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												A game that requires you to teleport from one area to another to talk to an NPC and deliver an item. 100 hours later, still only halfway through the story. If you are interested in playing with friends who have this game, you must finish out 346 main scenario quests, and 112 Heavensward quests. They are relatively simple quests with some decent dialogue, but at 458 quests, the tediousness of running from one area to another sets in. This does not include class quests, which range from another 50 to 100, and sub jobs, crafting jobs, gathering jobs, which delve out even more quests required to complete. Your level of fun-factor will be on whether you think a story-line of 500 quests is actually worth doing in order to experience that coveted "end-game content" of hunting for relics.  Thankfully there is a pretty decent matchmaking system which helps with knocking out the dungeon/leveling content. They got the mechanics down for partying really well; it's a shame a lot of the game is designed to waste your time teleporting back and forth to areas already discovered. This wouldn't be so bad if these quests were not required, but it just drags the game down when you're playing a massively open world with a highly linear storyline.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I got this game a month ago.... My life has been taken over.But in all seriousness, this game is fantastic. I've played a lot of mmo's during my years of computer gaming and I have never once had the real patience to grind through them to reach the end game. This game however has held my attention from start to finish, the cutscenes and dialog are all very well done for the story and this game is just very engaging to me.Clearly since this game is an MMORPG it does take a bit of grinding here and there to get the the end game stuff, but let me tell you once you get to endgame it all starts there. There is so much to do at the end game its rediculous. I still havent gotten anywhere close to finishing it. I've only just scratched the surface of my Relic weapon not to mention only just beating the First Coil of Bahamut....damn T9. And the primal fights are just a fun way to pass time when you feel like making a farm party for them. Tbh just about everything in the endgame is incredibly fun, to me anyway, and will keep you busy for quite a long time. Not too mention this game is very friendly to Casual players as well as Hardcore ones. The combat itself in the game pretty much easy straight through the whole game till the end game. Casual players can find themselves just hanging around talking with people in the community or just maybe running some dungeons for loot or fun, While Hardcore players can find themselves getting engrosed in the endgame constantly trying to get that Primal or Turn clear, as well as farming several endgame raids and bosses all to get that one piece of gear they want.Additionally you don't even need to level a combat class specifically. I know quite a few people who were so engrossed in crafting and gathering that they maxed a few of those classes before even hitting level 50 with a combat class.Speaking of combat, in this game personally I feel that they did the combat right. Everything feels very easy about the combat and the moves and combos flow together very nicely, it doesnt feel clunky.This is all I have to say for now, and I very highly reccommend this game to anyone who loves MMORPG's and is a fan of Final Fantasy.Also, F**K you Titan Ex, I have cleared you once and never again shall I attempt your annoyingness.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIV: A Real Reborn doesn't innovate too much. But that's okay. What it does do, is give you a well made, streamlined, and more importantly, FUN MMORPG with a lot of good Quality of Life features.Been playing as a Gladiator (tank class), but interested in learning some healing magic? Just equip a cane. Poof, you're a conjurer now! Want to try out being a Lancer? Pick up a spear. Every class has its own level and stats, and you can switch at any time.Crafting works the same way, and is quite possibly the only crafting I've been interested in. Dungeons are well designed, have interesting mechanics, and scale your level down so that they remain a challenge even after you've far outlevelled them.And of course, if you like Final Fantasy games at all, this game is practically a love letter to them, between meeting people named Biggs and Wedge, having moogles deliver mail, a certain battle where a jazzy remix of the FF2 battle theme plays, and if you level up your Black Mage enough, you get the big hat and the glowing eyes.Find yourself a friendly Free Company (like a guild), help each other with crafting and dungeons, and take your time exploring Eorzea. I love this game, and can't say enough about it, and I hope you will too.TL;DR- If you like MMORPGs and want to play one that doesn't try a whole lot new, but does what it does REALLY well, play this game. If you like MMORPGs and Final Fantasy, buy this game right now. Immediately.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												After putting some time into the game, I feel like I can make a solid review.Pros - - Has class change system (many roles on a single character) - Contains a mostly single-player story for those who like to play solo - Is an MMO and has co-operative so you can play with others - Has some PVP for those who enjoy it - Graphics are really goodCons - - Crafting and scavenging is extremely repetitive - Leveling your character can get repetitive (at certain levels, you grind specific tasks) - Inventory system has two separate inventories, which felt clunky. - Overall, an unrewarding experience  I got this game because a buddy of mine was playing it and I also played Final Fantasy 11 and enjoyed that.  So, I purchased the orignal game and put time into the free 30 days that I received.  After playing most of that, I feel like I spent most of my time doing menial tasks over and over again.  In the end, I feel like my time was wasted and I didn't have much fun along the way.  So, I won't be buying any expansion or re-subscribing to this game, and I don't recommend any one else doing this as well.Also, square-enix has 400 different websites you need to scour through to get what you need.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I've not played many subscription based MMORPGs before, I used to play World of Warcraft before the cataclysm expansion, but I've played more than my fair share of free to play ones, and I can say without a doubt, that this game is amazing.  While the graphics aren't as nice as some of the more modern MMOs out there, it's by no means ugly to look at.  Between the scenery, the effects of differen't spells and weapon skills, you'll be enthralled the first time you play it.I'd say if anyone is wanting to give this game a try, that they do so knowing it's not like other Final Fantasy titels, with the exception of Final Fantasy 11, so please don't think it'll be a singleplayer games you can just buy and play.  The upside of going through Steam is you can use your steam wallet to pay for your subscription, and you can use other methods as well if you like, so it can be pretty convenient if you happen to get a lot of steam gift cards or just find using steam to purchase stuff easier.If you do give the game a chance, please put it a bit more time than you would with other games, the first 5-10 hours is pretty much just introductory stuff, teaching you the basics of the game.  Also for those of you who prefer to play solo, pretty much all the content, apart from dungeons and end game raids, can be done by yourself.I'd give this game an 8/10, while the graphics are a bit dated, and the fact that you can solo most of the content and not all the cinamatics are voice acted, it's a very good MMORPG, and should keep your attention for a while.  I know I can see myself playing this game for a long time.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												This game has great visuals, great soundtrack and excellent gameplay. You create a character and you go through the main story which is classic final fantasy but thats just the surface, theres a whole world to explore and you can play with others effortlessly to progress through the ranks and collect gear, mounts, pets or even amass great wealth and buy yourself a mansion for your company of heroes. You can also swap classes on the fly and even combine them to form jobs or even focus purely on gathering and crafting. Its all there, its all final fantasy so give it a try. If your a new to mmos then this game eases you in perfectly or if you have played mmos in the past then after adjusting to the differences you will find a vast list of improvements to what you are already familiar with.The only negatives are short semi frequent loading screens but the way they are done does not really impact the scale of the world at all and more frequent voiced dialogue might be an improvement but at the same time not having as much could be a positive as it allows you to pay as little attention to the story and still understand whats happening. It also has a great community so its worth picking up the FREE trial if you are not yet convinced.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												I was expecting this to be another MMORPG to try but I honestly fell in love with the entire game from soundtrack to storyline- and most especially the class system (Armoury System). I've always been conflicted with being stuck with one char per class as with other MMOs but FFXIV brought something entirely different and now I play all of them on a single character with relatively few restrictions 500+ hours in. Strictly speaking with MMOs, I usually just play the damage dealing classes but this game made me fall in love with the tank and healer roles as well- which was entirely surprising. Crafting? I've always found it to be dreary but playing as a Disciple of Hand (crafters) makes you really want to level them all to 50 too. All in all, I've enjoyed so many aspects of FFXIV: ARR and I would recommend it to any MMORPG gamer and even more so for Final Fantasy fans.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												The game is pretty much excellent. If you haven't played it, you should definitely try. Especially at the current price. I tried many mmorpg's over the years, starting with Lineage 2 and WoW, Guild Wars, EVE, and countless others. Most recently I played TESO, SWTOR, GWII and the newest WoW expansions. And this is the game I'm playing the most. This is the game I return to.It has absolutely beautiful graphics and excellent music. The style is very FF-like, so if you don't like the JRPG vibe, you might not enjoy it. But if you do, or at least don't care, it might just be the game for you. And it might actually improve now since they are dropping PS3 support with Stormblood...To be fair, I fail to find even one MMO game that is so well done. Game mechanics are great, classes are well balanced, new dungeons and raids come out a few times a year. And they are all consistently good.You can argue that you don't like this dungeon or the other, this raid or the other, just like in any other game. But in here, you will never just stop and say - hey, this is really bad design, this is poorly executed. Content is just that well thought out.And the story, the lore, don't get me started on those. It's one of the first games that has me actually waiting for the next chapter. Everything is put in context of a bigger story, everything has its cause and effect. Many characters are simply really cool, they make you want to help them, they have their own ideas and motivations. I find this aspect of the game particularly compelling.Just like any other game, FFXIV has its downsides though. To me they are not very important, but I'm listing them here so as to not feel like I'm cheating anyone:1. The game is slow to start. The story is a bit mundane at the beginning. The global cooldown feels long at this early stage because you don't have that many actions to fill it with. Everything seems to be happening in slow motion. It picks up speed around level 30 or so.2. The endgame is grindy. I think this is the case with every MMO. If you find a cool community to be a part of (a free company, i.e. a guild) this is a non-issue though. You will always find something interesting to do. AND - you can level all classes on a single character so you can jump in and out of endgame whenever you want.3. The pricing of the Steam version is a mess and you cannot buy addons outside Steam if you got your game here. Buy outside of Steam if you can.4. The voice acting sounds a bit weird sometimes, especially pre-Heavensward.5. The story is linear, you basically have no influence on the narrative.6.
